Discussion on wind poison symptoms: Reviewing various classic texts, there are often discussions about weakness in the feet, yet this ailment was rare in ancient times. Since the Yongjia period when many scholars migrated south, numerous cases have appeared. In Jiangdong, there are practitioners who focus on classic methods and excel in these treatments, achieving great success due to the teachings of these two figures. Furthermore, between the Song and Qi dynasties, there were deep masters of Buddhist teachings who recorded their methods in old texts, compiling nearly a hundred treatments for foot weakness. In the Zhou and Wei dynasties, this disease seemingly did not exist; thus, Master Yao's compilations did not receive much attention, and Xu Wang's records were not taken seriously. Hence, even when there were three methods practiced, the teachings were not uniform, and not caring for frost and dew, as well as temperature variations, led to a lack of understanding of the disease in regions such as Shanxi and Hebei.[53p]
Since the glorious Tang dynasty was established, the world has been unified, with the southernmost regions being heavily fortified. Those who do not adapt to the local environment have invariably faced troubles. Recently, even among Chinese scholars and officials who do not traverse the rivers and seas, there are those who suffer from this issue. This is largely due to the current state of affairs, where the prevailing attitudes are confused, and all things seem to be equalized. However, this affliction begins at the feet: it manifests as swelling in the legs, and is commonly referred to as “gout” by contemporaries. According to historical masters, the weak-footed are meant in this context. These masters have described various remedies for weak feet, including over eighty potent formulas, such as those using lotus leaves and yellow essence from Mount Yongping, which are all quite essential. Yet, for those studying these remedies, they often seem cumbersome, as it is essentially a compilation of prescriptions. In times of urgent need, one cannot rely on detailed guidance. Therefore, I will now select the most effective remedies that I have come across for urgent use, without elaborating further on the others.[54p]
On How It Affects the Feet

The question is asked: When people are affected by wind toxins, they can fall ill anywhere; why is it particularly focused on the feet? The answer is: Humans have five organs, with the heart and lungs connected to the hands and fingers, while the liver, kidneys, and spleen are associated with the feet and toes. The energy of wind toxins arises from the ground, and the cold, heat, wind, and humidity of the earth create vapor. Since the feet are always in contact with the ground, those afflicted by wind toxins will first be affected at their feet. If the illness does not heal over time, it may then spread to the limbs, abdomen, back, head, and neck. At first, one may not be aware of it, but over time, the chronic nature of the illness becomes evident. The classics say this is a transmission of symptoms.

On Recognizing Its Manifestation

All cases of foot ailments are caused by exposure to wind toxins. Most people do not recognize this illness immediately; it may only manifest after the onset of another sickness, or one may suddenly feel lethargic, remaining inactive for two to three days before noticing it. Many lesser-skilled doctors do not understand this condition and mistakenly treat the symptoms as other diseases, often leading to fatal outcomes. Therefore, this illness frequently goes unrecognized. It begins very subtly, and one may feel normal in terms of food intake, hydration, and play, but suddenly experiences weakness in the feet, unable to move. This is the distinct sign. The Yellow Emperor states: It is a lingering issue of wind and dampness causing obstruction.[55p]
On the Manifestations of Wind Toxins

In cases of foot ailments, one may not feel any unusual symptoms in the feet, yet discomfort can be present in the head, neck, and arms. Additionally, there may be difficulties in various parts, yet the heart and internal organs suffer from distress. There are those afflicted by wind toxins who might experience symptoms such as vomiting upon seeing food, aversion to food odors, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation. Some may feel a palpitating sensation in the chest and desire to avoid bright light, or experience a foggy mind and forgetfulness, with speech becoming disordered. Others may have fevers and headaches, or feel extreme cold and pain throughout the body, or experience muscle cramps, swelling of the legs, or stubbornness in limb movements. Sometimes, they may face spasms in the joints or numbness in the lower abdomen. All these are manifestations of foot ailments and are also referred to as symptoms of wind toxins.

The signs can be difficult to discern, requiring careful observation; otherwise, one may miss crucial indicators. Once the illness develops, treatment can be challenging, particularly for women. Furthermore, there are women who, after childbirth, often suffer due to exposure to cool conditions in spring and summer, which can lead to these toxins, so caution is advised. Symptoms include heat, discomfort, palpitations, irritability, and nausea—all indicators of this condition. Additionally, if one feels a cold sensation in the lower abdomen and experiences discomfort with urination that is different from their usual state, this is also a sign of foot ailments. Pain and weakness are associated with dampness and obstruction.[56p]
On the Causes of Disease

In all four seasons, one should not sit or stand for long in damp and cold places. Also, one must not, when drunk and sweating, remove clothing, shoes, or socks to cool off in the wind, as this can lead to foot ailments. If, during the hot months, one sits or stands for too long in damp places, the heat and humidity can penetrate the meridians, causing pain and discomfort in the limbs. Conversely, if one sits or stands in damp and cold places during the cold months, the cold and dampness may enter the meridians, leading to intense coldness and cramps throughout the body. If one cools off in the wind after being overheated, the resulting illness can lead to stubborn pain and twitching in the flesh, gradually moving towards the head.

On ordinary days, when there is suddenly extreme heat that is unbearable, one must not immediately seek relief in the cold. If a severe cold follows, one cannot endure it, and such conditions will lead to illness. There are diligent scholars focused on their studies, who sit or stand for long periods in damp places, unable to move, and when a cold wind strikes, it invades the meridians, unbeknownst to them, resulting in sickness. Thus, people afflicted by wind toxins may first experience symptoms in their fingers and toes, as excessive sweating opens the pores and allows the wind to enter swiftly. Symptoms may also first appear in the soles of the feet, or in the arches, or in the lower legs, inside and out.

To prevent illness, at the first signs of discomfort, one should apply moxibustion to the affected area with three to twenty strong treatments, and thus recover, preventing recurrence. The Yellow Emperor states: cooling off in the wind, or drunkenness followed by retreat indoors can lead to such diseases.[57p]
On the Differences of Cold and Heat

It is asked: Why do those who are afflicted experience both cold and heat? The answer is: The body has three yin and three yang. Among the cold are three yang, where the problem must be cold; among the heat are three yin, where the problem must be heat. Therefore, the manifestations of cold and heat differ internally and externally. Heat is treated with cold remedies, and cold is treated with heat remedies, according to one’s intentions. When the spleen suffers from yang poison, it manifests as stubborn heat; when the kidneys suffer from yin dampness, it manifests as cold stagnation.

On Diseases Following Beriberi

Though suffering from beriberi, one may still have issues with stones, which must be treated with pressing stone remedies. When diseases arise due to beriberi, various remedies can be applied. If there are difficulties with urination, then herbs like polyporus and poria, along with other diuretics, should be used for treatment; if bowel movements are extremely hard, then the Five Soft Hemp Seed Pills and similar remedies should be used; if the body is swollen and water retention occurs, then one should use remedies from the water treatment prescriptions. The same approach applies to other ailments, and there should be no restriction.

On the Urgency of Treatment

Whenever there is a slight abnormality in symptoms, one must be greatly alarmed and decisively treat it as a priority, without delay. If qi rises into the abdomen, whether it is swollen or not, the chest and sides may feel full, and qi rises to the shoulders; if it is urgent, death can occur in an instant, while a more moderate case may lead to death within several days. One cannot afford to delay. Signs of urgency include a rapid pulse, constant shortness of breath, instances of sweating, alternating chills and fever, persistent vomiting—all of which indicate a likely fatal outcome.[58p]
On the Efficacy of Medication: Real and Imagined

All cases of beriberi result from an excess of vital energy, leading to death; there has never been someone who died from taking medicine that caused deficiency. Therefore, those with beriberi should not receive excessive tonics, nor should they undergo drastic purging; ultimately, they need not fear deficiency, hence they should avoid preemptive herbal concoctions. Those who do otherwise tend to perish unheeded.

On the Examination of Patients and Inquiry into Illness

In the world, there are many patients whose friends and acquaintances come to inquire about their ailments, yet such individuals often lack practical experience and have never consulted a remedy. They claim to possess knowledge, misleadingly presenting themselves as experts and spouting erroneous theories; some say it is deficiency, others claim it is excess, some declare it is wind, while others assert it is sorcery; some attribute it to water or stone phlegm, presenting a myriad of fallacies and contradictions. This confuses the patient, leaving them uncertain, and as time is fleeting, disaster can strike suddenly, causing everyone to disperse. Therefore, it is crucial to have reputable individuals or esteemed doctors who understand the nuances of illness, explore remedies deeply, and possess a comprehensive understanding of historical and contemporary practices. Only those with clarity on these matters should examine patients; otherwise, it can lead to grave mistakes. I lament the many who fail in this regard, thus I seek to elucidate these matters clearly, providing detailed descriptions of ailments, enabling future patients to protect themselves. However, if any symptoms match, one must adhere to an appropriate remedy and not rely on the theories of outsiders, thereby inviting unnecessary distress and regret. By understanding the prescribed remedies, healing is not difficult; one must not trust misleading words that lead to self-deception. I have once prepared a decoction of winter cherry, which has proven effective for treating beriberi; patients must use it urgently.[59p]
On the Examination of Pulses

In cases of "flat-foot disease" (脚气), although many examinations and observations are made, it is vital that the three positions of the pulse do not contradict the four seasons in order to be auspicious; if they oppose the four seasons, do not treat. As mentioned in the "Pulse Classic," I shall not elaborate here. Those who are originally slender and dark are easier to treat, while those who are large, with thick flesh that is red or white, are difficult to cure. People with darker skin endure wind and dampness better, while those with red or white skin do not. Thin individuals have firm flesh, while fat individuals have soft flesh; soft flesh is more susceptible to deep-seated diseases which are harder to cure.

On Swelling and Non-Swelling

When a person suffers from "flat-foot disease" for a long time without recognizing it, and later develops another illness which resolves, they may then suffer from vomiting and weakened feet again. Upon diagnosis, I inform them they have flat-foot disease. The patient replies, "I have never suffered from swollen feet; why do you call it flat-foot?" They refuse to take the medicine. I regard it as a stone manifestation. In the midst of uncertainty, they die within a short period. Hence, flat-foot disease should not only be considered through swelling; there are cases with swelling and without swelling. Those who experience stubborn lower abdomen numbness often do not have swollen feet. Stubborn lower abdomen issues for merely three to five days can lead to vomiting, a condition termed "flat-foot invading the heart." Such cases are perilous and may result in death imminently. In general, when flat-foot disease reaches the heart, it is difficult to treat, as kidney water overcomes heart fire.[60p]
On the Need for Caution

In the case of beriberi, one must be particularly cautious regarding sexual activity, mutton, beef, fish, garlic, shepherd’s purse, mustard greens, wild greens, bottle gourds, alcohol, flour, ghee, unpasteurized milk, pork, chicken, goose, and duck. It is advisable to use carp heads in prescribed treatments. All these should be strictly avoided, and one must also refrain from intense anger. Only acceptable foods are polished rice, corn, fermented soybeans, scallions, leeks, garlic chives, peppers, ginger, and orange peels. Additionally, sour fruits and foods must also be avoided; those who consume them cannot recover. Fresh cow's milk and raw chestnuts are highly recommended.

On the Duration of Recovery for Those Who Can Be Treated

Many people suffer fatal outcomes from beriberi, which can be categorized into three types: injury from sleeping late, arrogance and excessive pride, and doubt and indecision. These three conditions lead to certain death. Thus, it appears that there are genuinely no good doctors; even when good doctors exist, patients without the right disposition to accept treatment are quite rare. Just as a fine steed may go unrecognized by a wise trainer, and a talented mentor may find no one to teach, the same holds true for such illnesses.

Currently, for those who are ill and possess an appropriate disposition for acceptance, if I treat them, they can be cured in no more than ten days. However, for those without such a disposition, treatment is unnecessary. Even if it can be treated, recovery may never come. This principle applies not only to beriberi but to all diseases. Good medicine and wise words must be visibly appropriate; they cannot be forced upon anyone. Treatment should be given to those who have faith in it and not to the doubtful.[61p]
On the Prescription of Decoctions for Illnesses

The wind toxin enters the body, and there are three categories of pulse patterns. Internally and externally, the symptoms may appear similar, but the pulse will reveal the severity. If the pulse is floating, large, and slow, it is advisable to take two doses of the Sustaining Life Decoction, which should facilitate recovery. If the wind is strong, one should prepare the Decoction of Overcoming the Servant and add four liang of white atractylodes. If the pulse is floating, large, tight, and starts to quicken, the Bamboo Juice Decoction should be made. If the patient has a pulse that is weak and thin, the Wind Guiding Decoction is appropriate. This type of pulse is often due to deficiency. If there is severe deficiency with shortness of breath and lack of strength, one may prescribe a nourishing decoction in accordance with the temperature of the illness. If not yet recovered, the Bamboo Juice Decoction should still be administered. If the patient has a floating, large, and rapid pulse, this is the most severe among the three pulse categories. Alternatively, if the pulse is deep, thin, and rapid, it is equally a dreadful pulse. A floating, large pulse indicates an external illness, while a deep, thin one indicates an internal ailment; treatment methods do not differ, and one must be attentive to the pulse's indications. The appearance may still be acceptable, yet if the hands and feet remain weak, the life force may diminish rapidly, and within a few days, there could be a fatal outcome.[62p]
In such a condition, there are often those who may experience it, yet none survive. It is imperative to urgently take Zhuli Decoction, consuming one dose daily, ensuring that the decoction is constantly available without a gap of half a day without it. This decoction has a high content of bamboo leaf juice; if taken when less than very hot, it will remain in the heart and cause further harm. Each time, it must be taken extremely hot. If the Zhuli Decoction induces a downward effect, it is certainly beneficial. If after taking three doses of Zhuli Decoction the pulse remains unchanged and there is severe bloating, one can use a large turtle shell decoction to induce a downward action. If the decoction is exhausted and does not induce movement, one can use pill medicine to assist the decoction in this regard. Subsequently, continue taking Zhuli Decoction to ensure the pulse is weakened and to stabilize the breath before stopping. One may then take the Thirty-Two Description of Eight Winds powder. Furthermore, at the onset of the illness, one should apply wild kudzu paste twice daily; this will alleviate stubborn numbness and weakness in the legs. If having consumed Zhulii Decoction, the pulse weakens as if in health, and strength gradually increases yet the legs are still unable to move, one should eventually begin to take small steps. In severe cases, after recovery, it may take half a year before one can walk with assistance.[63p]
Once the pulse and body feel healed, one should diligently take the Eight Winds Powder. Do not treat lightly just because the feet cannot walk; such light treatments may not bring full benefits and can lead to worse conditions, thus losing the effectiveness of the treatments. Do not hastily apply wild kudzu paste on the edges either. If someone hears about Bamboo Sap Decoction and fears it may harm the waist or feet, do not administer it. It is important to understand this method; it is not suitable for everyone, and thus should not be given indiscriminately. This caution is to clarify misunderstandings.

Bamboo Sap Decoction has three variations: for mild cases, take the initial method; for severe cases, follow with the later method progressively. This wind toxin can easily infiltrate, so patients should take the Small Golden Tooth Powder in empty doses and apply a little in the nostrils and ears. Those who are weak, recently deceased, overly sensitive, or strong should also take it and apply it to the ears and nostrils. Those near the deceased or observing the sick should carry a small dagger in a red pouch; males on the left arm and females on the right, to counteract toxins. It is advised to start with a small dose.[64p]
Patients should drink adzuki bean tea and, in winter, take Cezi Golden Tooth Wine and Xuming Decoction. This is for treating wind toxin illnesses, which initially appear similar to seasonal epidemic diseases; however, the pulse remains floating and weak without change. Those who feel better should not be treated, as some may die within a few days or in ten days. Symptoms may include confusion, jaundice, rash, red eyes, or severe necrosis in the lower body. This is urgent; upon diagnosis, administer Xuming Decoction immediately, followed by Ge Gen Decoction and Ma Huang Decoction. If this does not yield results, continue with two or three more doses of Xuming Decoction, which will certainly lead to recovery. This illness is extremely critical, and one must ensure the medicinal broth continues without interruption for even half a day; otherwise, it could be fatal. The disease known as "foot qi" originated in Lingnan and can also be found in Jiangdong. Symptoms may include slight feelings of pain or numbness, swelling of the legs, weakness when walking, numbness radiating to the abdomen, alternating sensations of heat and cold, difficulty urinating resulting in urgency or congestion, shortness of breath, a feeling of suffocation in the throat, and an inability to eat due to nausea. If these symptoms are present, first administer Xijiao Xuanshu Hua Decoction.[65p]
Human Health Manual
[Song Dynasty] Zhu Gong

Athlete's Foot

Cold-induced illnesses primarily affect the feet rather than the hands. The cold, heat, dampness, and wind of the earth create steaming vapors; frequent exposure to these elements leads to athlete's foot, causing its symptoms to resemble those of a cold. The pulse tends to be floating and string-like due to wind, moist and weak from dampness, surging and rapid from heat, and slow and thin from cold. For wind-related issues, sweating is the remedy; for dampness, warmth is needed; for heat, purging is beneficial; and for cold, applying heat helps.

The onset of athlete's foot can be subtle and is often recognized only due to other illnesses. Toxic energy entering the heart leads to numbness in the lower abdomen, causing vomiting, which can be lethal rapidly. However, it remains distinct from colds; as Master Sun noted: a sudden weakness in the feet that prevents movement signifies this difference.

In summary, individuals with athlete's foot typically experience symptoms starting from the feet, which may first present as mild weakness or pain, with pain resulting from excessive cold, leading to a painful sensation. Sometimes, individuals may suddenly collapse while walking, experience swelling and pain in the legs, or suffer from thin and weak legs, palpitations, or numbness in the lower abdomen. The prolonged nature of the illness leads to deep internal complications, hindering the smooth circulation of vital energy and resulting in skin that lacks nourishment, leading to numbness. Numbness signifies that the skin is desensitized, unable to perceive what is present or absent.[66p]
Some may experience body twitching, while others may see food and vomit, detesting the smell of food. They may feel fullness in the chest and urgency of breath, or have soreness all over, all indicative of "foot qi." The Yellow Emperor refers to this as "wind-damp obstruction." Chronic weakness is termed "wind," while pain is called "damp obstruction." Obstruction means a closure; being closed off and insensitive is thus termed obstruction. In the presence of cold among the three yangs, the issue must be cold; for this, use “Yuebi Decoction” or “Small Renewing Life Decoction.” When “Small Renewing Life Decoction” is prepared, add fresh ginger juice for the quickest effect. In the presence of heat among the three yins, the issue must be heat; modify “Small Renewing Life Decoction” by removing aconite and reducing cinnamon by half. For severe agitation, “Purple Snow” is best. For constipation, use “Spleen Contraction Pill,” “Divine Function Pill,” “Five Soft Pills,” “Big Three Abdominal Powder,” or “Papaya Powder.” The ailments of foot qi are all due to excess qi, and none have died from weakness caused by medication. Headaches with body heat, limb joint pain, and weak flexed feet indicate that the person has chronic foot qi, which is now being triggered. For swollen feet, “Betel Nut Powder” is indicated. For discussing foot qi, “Thousand Gold” and “External Treasury” offer the most detailed accounts, and thus will not be repeated here. Generally, “Yuebi Decoction,” “Small Renewing Life Decoction,” “Job's Tears Wine Method,” “Spleen Contraction Pill,” and “Divine Function Pill” are essential medicines. Acupuncture is also excellent. Taking tonics and using decoctions for washing are major prohibitions for doctors.[67p]
Jisheng Fang 【Song - Yan Yonghe】

Foot Disease

The "Thousand Gold" says that foot disease is caused by the invasion of cold and toxic winds. It further states: the cold, heat, wind, and dampness of the earth all produce steam, and when the feet are often exposed to this, foot disease results. However, in ancient times, there was no concept of foot disease; in the time of the Yellow Emperor, it was called "Jue." Between the Han dynasties, it was referred to as "Huanfeng," and after the Song and Qi dynasties, it became known as foot disease. Although the names differ, the essence remains the same.

From this, we can observe that cold, heat, wind, and dampness can all lead to this condition, not only cold and toxic winds. The disease usually goes unnoticed at first and may arise due to another illness, sometimes suddenly causing great discomfort, only to be felt several days later. It often begins in the feet, presenting as mild pain or weakness, sudden collapses during movement, swollen legs, thin and withered feet and knees, heart palpitations, numbness in the lower abdomen, cramps throughout the body, nausea or vomiting when seeing food, aversion to food smells, chest tightness and shortness of breath, or generalized aches. These variations in symptoms reflect the different manifestations of the illness. Generally, with cold conditions affecting the three Yang channels, there will be cold symptoms; with heat conditions affecting the three Yin channels, there will be heat symptoms. Indeed, these words are true.[68p]
In discussing the pulse, the floating and string-like pulse arises from wind, the soft and weak pulse arises from dampness, the full and rapid pulse arises from heat, and the slow and rough pulse arises from cold. Wind is treated by sweating, dampness is treated by warmth, heat is treated by purging, and cold is treated by warming. For those suffering from foot conditions, acupuncture should be employed quickly. Using decoctions for washing is a major prohibition in treatment.

Foot ailments arise from kidney deficiency; however, women also suffer from foot conditions due to the deficiency of blood and the stasis of phlegm, as well as emotional disturbances such as anger and sorrow, leading to the development of this illness. Given that many women suffer from this, it can be understood that these ailments due to blood deficiency resemble those from kidney deficiency in men.

The treatment for women is fundamentally the same as for men, but must also include medications for emotional disturbances, which will always yield results. Furthermore, the methods of tonifying and purging should align with the four seasons: in spring and autumn, one should urgently tonify and purge; during summer, when conditions are severe, one must focus on promoting sweating; and after the onset of winter, one should adjust treatment according to whether the condition is improving or worsening, with slight nourishing added.

Otherwise, qi and blood will continuously weaken, leading to recurring issues every year with rising heat—a natural consequence. The general principles of treatment do not exceed this. In addition, throughout the seasons, one must be careful to regulate and manage, avoiding prolonged sitting or standing in cold, damp places, and during hot months, one should not expose oneself to damp areas. By being careful in these respects and treating according to the symptoms, recovery will certainly occur.[69p]
Instructions for Treating Carbuncles

Carbuncles arise when the lung meridian is overheated, manifesting on the fingertips and requiring urgent attention; if not alleviated within seven to eight days, they can be fatal. Treatment can begin within four days by puncturing. If a black sore is not too severe, treatment can still be effective; however, a severely black sore post-festival indicates death. Those that can still be treated after the festival require medicinal intervention.

The appearance is characterized by small, dark lesions as large as millet grains, while larger ones can be the size of plums, ranging in color from red to black, occasionally showing blue and white, often surrounded by a solid core, which is the root. They are not swollen, but may be excruciatingly painful, affecting the heart and reaching the bones, and may also cause the body to feel warm. If treatment is delayed, the poison ascends, causing the face to swell with purple-black blisters that can corrupt the organs, leading to death.

In the south, this condition is known as "toxic invasion," as there’s a fear that cutting off the fingers will allow the poison to spread upwards, leading to a high chance of fatality. Sudden, sharp pains in the fingertips that seem unbearable may appear red or yellow, or dark blue or black. If there is foul-smelling blood or pus between the teeth, death is likely within seven days.

For those with thickened flesh, one should excise the affected area and cauterize it with iron until charred like coal. It is also advisable to apply moxibustion over the carbuncle vigorously, and to take juice from sunflower roots, woad flowers, bamboo sap, rhinoceros horn juice, bitter orange soup, and detoxifying drinks. If one vomits pus and blood and does not seek treatment, one should cover the pus and blood with ash. If not, the toxic gas can infect others. Carbuncles can cause immediate harm, as evil winds penetrate the muscle and veins, initially going unnoticed.

Once the poison has become congested and manifests fiercely, tiny and deep lesions may appear darkly or murkily. The ailment targets the heart; if the condition slightly eases, it can lead to organ invasion.[70p]
Foot Back Disease

The foot back disease arises from symptoms of wasting thirst. If it occurs at the toes, it is called "liu-jia" (decomposition). Those with a purple-black color are fatal; if not purple-black, it can be treated. It is appropriate to take bitter herb pills.

Arm Toxicity

Arm toxicity is related to the heart and kidney channels, connected to the five fingers. The toxic gas flows and leads to leakage; this is malignancy. It should be treated with internal medication for gas flow and pain relief. This back elbow toxicity involves the flow of qi and blood, accumulating and forming toxins, which are abscess toxins. Use the pain-relieving internal gas flow drink.

Tendon Abscess

Tendon abscess occurs between arteries, above the tendons, causing inability to bend or extend the arms. If not treated swiftly, it may lead to necrosis of tendons, resulting in chronic disease. If it develops on the arm, it is called "chi-yin," characterized by redness, swelling, and pain. Initially, it should be treated with moxibustion; if it ulcerates, it may endanger life and must not be taken lightly. Internally, take internal expelling powders with added agarwood and bark of five-flavored plants, and also take yellow alum pills and shi-qi powder, frequently using protective heart powder; externally, use iron ring powder mixed with ginger juice for application.[71p]

Heavenly Snake Poison

Heavenly snake poison arises when the heart is afflicted by wind injury at the fingers, elbows, and arms. This signifies a severe toxic condition, and one should treat it with a pain-relieving and qi-flowing drink. If this condition has not yet matured, it is inappropriate to immediately use knives or needles to pierce the corrupted flesh, as it may aggravate the situation. If it becomes deeply rooted, it will be difficult to treat, and even after breaking down, it may take years to regenerate flesh; one should apply Erhuang San to the area.

Arm and Face Poison

Arm and face poison manifests on the surface of the arm, resulting from blockage in the liver and lung meridians, leading to stagnation of qi and blood which gathers into toxins; this is a severe condition. One should use a detoxifying and qi-flowing drink, followed by a pain-relieving internal tonic. Surrounding the affected area, one should apply Jinku San as a poultice.

Palm Poison

Palm poison affects the right hand due to yin fire. The qi and blood of the Taiyin and Yangming flow into the left Jueyin meridian, while the poison of the left hand arises from heart fire, with the Taiyang flowing into the right foot Taiyin Yangming. The earth regenerates flowing through the five phases—mother and child generating and nurturing each other. This condition may stem from emotions like joy, anger, worry, and thoughts, or from cold congealing qi and blood, leading to blockage and toxin accumulation. One should use a pain-relieving and detoxifying medicine, followed by an internal tonic to promote qi flow, and externally apply Jinku San as a poultice.

Wrist Poison

Wrist poison occurs on the back of the hand, resulting from wind, cold, joy, anger, fright, and phlegm affecting the heart, with blood failing to circulate, resulting in toxin formation. One should use a pain-relieving and poison-expelling powder, along with an internal tonic for clearing qi. It may be applied through the palm or the outer wrist, and further treated with Sanyang Neituo San.[72p]
On feverish conditions
The conditions of the lesser yang channel often exhibit more qi and less blood, as the lesser yang possesses a corresponding fire, even more so than the extreme yin. This is due to excessive worry and mental labor, influenced by external forces and internal emotions. It is advisable to anticipate difficulties in muscle growth and to avoid reckless use of harsh medicines. However, if the symptoms manifest as red swelling, similar to millet, do not underestimate them merely due to their small size.

On cold sores
Cold sores arise from the alterations in nutritional intake, lingering toxins from wind and dampness, and prolonged exposure to cold weather. These conditions attack the area below the knee and affect the spleen channel. Initially appearing like grains of rice, they gradually become ulcerated, resembling coal in color, as putrid blood invades and damages bone and flesh, leading to significant issues. Over years, the joints cause pain and do not regenerate muscle. Begin treatment with an infusion of mugwort, snake bed seed, perilla, and agrimony for washing, and internally take medicines like astragalus, white atractylodes, black atractylodes, angelica, white peony, forsythia, and raw rehmannia. For external treatment, apply a medicinal paste wrapped in paper. Also, focus on internal reflection to alleviate labor or strain.

On ulcerations
Generally, the symptoms in the lower body primarily involve black atractylodes, complemented by the pungency of coptis, and combined with green tangerine peel, along with licorice. Use targeted medications according to the symptoms, and you shall obtain results. This poison affects the liver and kidney channels, causing unbearable pain, treat it with internal methods to remove stagnant qi. For external application, utilize leg wind remedies, and the same treatment as for women's ulcerations can be used.

On the poison in the Weizhong point
This poison affects the kidney channel, resulting from cold air obstruction. Modify the treatment with perilla qi-moving drink. Start with the detoxifying qi-moving drink, followed by the perilla qi-moving drink, adding astragalus when expelling pus.[73p]
Leg Wind

This boil is located in the small intestine and kidney meridians, caused by cold and heat, with evil energy and toxins flowing through both legs; this is known as wandering toxicity. One should use a perilla (zisu) decoction to treat it, followed by a decoction to dispel toxicity. For external treatment, first apply golden silk paste for four to five days to draw out the toxic fluid, and then use ointments for treatment.

Crane Knee Wind

Crane knee wind is akin to dysentery wind and drumstick wind. The circulation of qi and blood harmonizes throughout the body; if affected by cold, the flow slows down and is insufficient, whereas heat stimulates it too rapidly. Internal injury from emotional distress or external injury from environmental factors leads to irregular circulation of qi and blood, resulting in illness. It often stems from prolonged heat accumulation followed by invasion of damp heat, obstructing the flow of blood and causing pain, particularly at night. Treatment requires warming and dispersing the cold dampness and expelling the accumulated heat. When blood flows freely in harmony with qi, the illness ceases. Alternatively, if one hastily resorts to potent medicines, suffers from overexertion, indulges in rich foods, or is affected by wind and rain, leg swelling and severe pain may arise from stagnant blood in the meridians. If left untreated for an extended period, it may lead to atrophy, resulting in knee swelling, muscle tightening, and severe pain, with weakness and gradual thinning of the legs, and dry, frail thighs and calves that cannot flex or extend. The appropriate treatment is to dispel wind, regulate qi, nourish blood, strengthen tendons, and remove dampness, allowing the smooth flow of qi and blood, leading to a natural recovery.[74p]
Knee Eye Poison

This poison affects the kidney channel and bladder, causing stagnation of qi and blood, while damp heat attacks the knee eye, forming poison. For treatment, apply crane's knee wind medicine externally, and use fragrant liquor decoction internally.

Abscess

Commonly said to be hard and without pus, little do people know that the swelling and hardness is due to internal pus that cannot surface at once. It needs to be guided out from within before one can pierce it with a needle.

Bone Groove Abscess

Bone groove abscess occurs above the knee and at the ankle wrist. Its pain feels like a knife-cut, while its itching is akin to insect-biting. Urgently use moxa on the abscess three to five times, then apply frankincense universal plaster, and take alum pills.

Foot and Hand Manifestation

This condition arises from heat in the heart channel, resulting in uneven walking that harms the foot, causing blood to accumulate and form an abscess. The treatment is the same as for cold, leakage, damp poison.

Bone Fistula Abscess

This condition appears between the hand's yangming channels, initially as a grain and gradually enlarging like a red bean. The pain is unbearable, and it can grow to the size of a bayberry, with no blood or pus emerging, while poison flows through the channels and spreads throughout the body. Those with this ailment should be cautious; it cannot be viewed lightly. It's advisable to use methods for treating sores, adjusted accordingly.[75p]

Foot and Leg Conditions

Foot Malady

This condition affects the kidneys and connects to the Yangming meridian, causing pain in the heart. To treat it, use remedies for knee pain, heel sores, and "crane knee wind."

Heel Sores (also known as "cow pupa worm," "earth chestnut")

These sores develop on the heel, typically due to injury from movement. They appear glassy with no pus, only a purple color, which means they should not be punctured. Initially, apply "golden hoop powder" or "iron hoop powder." Avoid wind and cold; movement is not advised. First, take a purging medication to clear toxins, followed by a dampness-reducing papaya soup. Once ready to drain, use a needle to puncture and release the pus, applying golden silk and purple gold plasters.

Shoe Lace Ulcers

Shoe lace ulcers occur beside the ankle, resulting from cold and damp exposure, leading to toxicity in the foot Yangming channel due to an accumulation of Qi and blood. Utilize "pain-relieving flowing Qi drink" for treatment.

Sole Malady

The sole malady affects the kidney and heart channels in the foot, resulting in damp toxicity, termed "sole carbuncle." One should take the "pain-relieving flowing Qi drink" alongside areca nut pills for treatment.

Blood Wind Ulcers

These ulcers arise from disturbances in women’s menstrual cycles, potentially occurring twice a month or being absent for a month. As a result, blood and Qi seep into the foot Yangming channel, leading to these sores. It is advisable to use "wood fragrance flowing Qi drink" and "five accumulations powder," applying paper plaster externally.[76p]

Kidney Qi and Wind Poison

This poison arises in the calves, affecting the bladder meridian; cold air harms the kidneys and lurks in the bladder, which is known as wind poison. One should use perilla flow qi drink and apply iron hoop powder externally.

Internal and External Ulcers

Internal and external ulcers arise alongside the three li and at the sides of the yin intersection. They occur due to cold air attacking the lower abdomen through the kidney meridian, with internal invasion of wind evil and external assault by cold air, possibly resulting from a collision injury. These ulcers gradually become necrotic, with pus that does not dry up, caused by the interplay of damp heat and wind poison.

Three Chains of Mole Crickets

This condition appears on both hands in three varieties: upper, middle, and lower. They are all caused by damp poison damaging the skin, the qi and blood injuring the kidneys, and anger injuring the heart, leading to stagnant blood and qi conflicts, resulting in this series of poison chains. Treatment involves flow qi drink, three fragrant internal expulsion powder, and pain-relieving descent qi drink.

Interstitial Abscess

This condition appears on the arms and is caused by the blockage of qi and blood in the liver meridian, resulting in toxic accumulation. One should use expulsion flow qi drink and toxic elimination flow qi drink for treatment.

Wind Poison Abscess

This condition occurs between the toes, due to blocked qi and blood causing stagnation in the spleen and stomach, potential damage to the meridians, overconsumption of fried foods, or accumulation of toxins forming sores. It may also occur if the wind enters through a deficiency. A warming internal qi-regulating drink is recommended. Pregnant women should adjust the dosage accordingly.

Definitive Theory 【Jin Chengwujia】

Sweating of Hands and Feet[77p]

In cases of typhoid with sweating in the hands and feet, how can this be clarified? The limbs are the source of all yang energies, and the stomach governs the limbs. Sweating in the hands and feet is a sign of yangming. When the pathogenic heat of the yang meridians spreads and affects yangming, it causes sweating in the hands and feet. Yangming is the master of bodily fluids, and when ill, there will be spontaneous sweating. One may experience sweating all over the body, only on the head, or specifically in the hands and feet, all of which belong to yangming. Why does this happen? If there is sweating all over the body, it is termed “heat exceeding,” indicating that the heat is expressed outward. If there is only sweating on the head, it shows the heat cannot extend outward but rather ascends. Sweat in the hands and feet indicates that heat is concentrated in the stomach, manifesting as fluid discharge. The texts state: when the hands and feet sweat profusely, there is a likelihood of constipation. If there is dripping sweat from the hands and feet, and if the stool is hard with difficulty in speaking, purging will lead to recovery. From this, it is evident that sweating in the hands and feet is caused by heat accumulating in the stomach. Some may ask if sweating in the hands and feet can occur due to cold accumulating in the stomach. The text says: when there is cold in the middle, one cannot eat, there is difficulty in urination, and there is profuse sweating in the hands and feet; this is indicative of wanting to form a stubborn mass, and indicates cold in the middle. Furthermore, heat accumulating in the stomach is a sign that one can purge, while cold accumulating in the stomach is a sign that one cannot purge. How can this be clarified? To distinguish between these two conditions, it can be said that when constipation is followed by diarrhea, this is due to cold in the stomach, where food and fluids are not differentiated, hence it cannot be purged. However, if this is accompanied by difficulty in stool and the signs of yangming are present, it indicates that it is a purgable condition, and one should be careful in diagnosing the illness.[78p]
The Confucian Way of Serving Parents

Numbness of the Fingers

When an ordinary person first feels numbness or lack of sensation in the thumb and index finger, or if they are unable to use them, it is an indication that within three years there may be a stroke. It is advisable to first take a dose of Yu Feng Decoction and Tian Ma Pills, as this is a way to treat what is unwell before it becomes ill. Thus, the sages treat what is unwell before it becomes ill, rather than treating what is already ill.[79p]
The Theory of Foot Edema in the Northern Regions

The "Inner Canon" states: When the sun prevails, fire energy becomes trapped within, dispersing outward, leading to swelling of the lower legs. Fluid accumulates internally, resulting in swelling externally. It also states: The spleen pulse is firm and long, and its color is yellow; this indicates illness characterized by a deficiency of qi. If it is soft and dispersed, lacking luster in color, this indicates foot swelling resembling water.

Those with spleen disorders experience heaviness in the body, muscle atrophy, inability to retract the feet, painful walking, and pain in the feet. This happens when excessive food intake generates insufficient qi and dampness accumulates below, thus dampness is received from the lower part. As mentioned, it is said that damp qi from the spleen and stomach flows downward, affecting the liver and kidneys, leading to pain in the legs and swelling of the feet.

The five grains enter the stomach, and the waste, fluids, and ancestral qi are divided into two channels. Thus, ancestral qi accumulates in the chest, exiting through the throat, traversing the heart and lungs to facilitate breathing. The nutritive qi secretes fluids, injecting them into the pulses, transforming them into blood to nourish the extremities and internally support the five organs and six bowels, responding to timely needs.

The defensive qi expels excessive energy and circulates in the gaps between the flesh of the extremities, constantly flowing without pause. Furthermore, the pathways of ancestral qi consider internal grains as a treasure; when the grains enter the stomach, they are transmitted through the pulses, overflowing within, spreading outward. The pure and specialized flow travels through the channels, continuously circulating, beginning and ending perpetually, which is known as the rhythm of heaven and earth.[80p]
Sometimes, improper diet leads to a failure of the stomach’s energy to invigorate and the spleen’s energy to transform. The energy flows through the hundred channels, descending and affecting the liver and kidneys. The interaction of earth, wood, and water converges and descends to the feet, resulting in swelling and pain in the lower limbs, which is what is referred to as "gout" in Jin, as called by Su Jing.

For treating this ailment, one should eat heartily for breakfast, eat less for lunch, and it is best not to eat dinner at all, for fear of injuring the spleen and stomach's operational energies and losing their natural balance. Moreover, eating at night causes stagnation of blood and qi, leading to increased swelling and pain. In ancient times, this ailment was rare, but since the Southern migration during the Yongjia era, many scholars have suffered from it. Following the establishment of the Tang Dynasty, those who were tasked with governance in the southern regions, where the land is low and wet, often suffer from it due to the accumulation of mist and dew, as they are not accustomed to the water and soil conditions.[81p]
People from the northern part of Guanshi do not recognize this ailment. The texts "Wai Tai Mi Yao" and "Zong Lu" also indicate that this condition is common in Jiangdong and Lingnan. This is likely due to the attack of dampness on a weakened constitution, which is why the classics state that it harms the skin, flesh, tendons, and bones. Hence, the creation of treatment plans is based on the specific conditions of the land at that time.

Now, observing the northern regions which are crisp and free of low-lying damp areas, and considering that the pores are tight and external pathogens are hard to invade, one wonders why there are individuals suffering from this ailment. It is likely due to excessive consumption of milk, rich wines, and damp foods, compounded by overindulgence in nurturing one's body that fosters dampness. As moisture accumulates and cannot be expelled, it settles in the feet and ankles, leading to prolonged swelling and pain. This issue arises from the consumption of these damp substances, which is distinctly different from how ailments are treated in the southern regions.

Thus, it is essential to consider the topography and dietary habits of the area, creating two treatment strategies: one to address the dampness of the land and the other to handle the impact of food and drink. Medications and treatments should be adjusted according to the prevailing conditions to align with the principles of Xuanqi.[82p]
East Garden Ten Treatises
Yuan Dynasty - Li Gao

Distinction Between Internal and External Injuries to the Limbs

Internal injuries, such as illnesses, occur when the vital energy of the heart and lungs is severed from the outside, leading to laziness and a propensity to lie down, with heavy and unresponsive limbs. This is due to heat damaging the original qi. The spleen governs the limbs, and when affected by heat, there is insufficient energy to move. The classics say that heat damages qi, and when heat is present, bones can decay and tendons can loosen; this is what is referred to.

In contrast, external injuries from wind and cold indicate that the vital energy of the kidneys and liver has been severed internally. The kidneys govern the bones and are associated with cold; the liver governs the tendons and is associated with wind. Since ancient times, diseases of the kidneys and liver have been treated similarly because they support one another. Thus, the classics say that the gallbladder governs the tendons, and the bladder governs the bones.

Whether it is a stroke or an injury from cold, on the day the illness occurs, one feels the need to lie down; it is not that one cannot be supported, but that the tendons and bones are painful and unable to move, thus indicating a physical injury. The classics state: "Cold harms the form; cold causes the tendons to cramp and the bones to ache." This is what is referred to.

For internal injuries and labor, along with irregularities in diet, if one experiences heat in the palms and coolness in the backs of the hands, it indicates internal issues; whereas, if external injuries from wind and cold are present, the backs of the hands feel hot while the palms do not. This distinction is remarkably clear.

Inability to Control the Limbs

When the spleen and stomach are deficient, one feels lazy and prefers to lie down, with involuntary limbs; during the autumn dryness, when damp heat diminishes, the body feels heavy and achy, with dry mouth and tongue, lack of taste in food, irregular bowel movements, frequent urination, loss of appetite, inability to digest food, and concurrent signs of lung disease, such as chills and a sad disposition, along with an unhappy, pale complexion—this is due to the yang qi not rising. It is advisable to promote the yang and augment the qi, and the formula for this is to enhance yang and strengthen the stomach.[83p]
Athlete's Foot

The disease known as athlete's foot is indeed caused by dampness. Dampness harms the skin, flesh, muscles, and tendons and relates to the lower parts of the body; however, it can arise in two ways. One is from external influences, and the other is from internal causes, hence the treatment methods should differ accordingly. Thus, it is necessary to discuss this in detail.

As for the disease, it presents symptoms without a name; the term athlete's foot originated with Su Jing during the Jin Dynasty, and it was not known in regions such as Guanzhong or Heshuo. Only in the South does the cold underground water and the clear, damp air penetrate the people, leading to the condition from the feet. The classics say: "When clear dampness invades the empty, the illness arises from the lower parts."

Some might argue: "Now in the North, the land is high and cold, and the people have close pores; why are there still many cases of this disease? Could it not be caused by the dampness of the land?" The answer is: the disease in the South arises from external causes, while the disease in the North is due to internal factors. How can this be explained? Northerners often consume too much milk and drink alcohol excessively, impairing their health without restraint. Milk, in its essence, has the nature of milk, while its form and quality resemble water; the same applies to wine and sweet drinks. As food enters the stomach, the stomach's energy rises and mingles its essence with taste, spreading through the meridians and transforming into qi and blood. This nourishment supports the extremities and feeds the five organs and six bowels, creating a cycle of response that corresponds with the rhythms of nature. This is known as the equilibrium of heaven and earth, which relies on the abundance of vital energy when the spleen and stomach are uninjured.[84p]
If the vital energy is insufficient, then the foundational energy of the stomach is inherently weak. When intake of food is excessive, the energy of the spleen and stomach gets injured, unable to properly transform and digest what is consumed; the essence and flavors cannot circulate smoothly, causing the nature of dampness to flow downward. Those conditions originating externally stop at the lower limbs, causing swelling and pain; while those arising from within might even reach the joints of the hands. The classics state that swelling of the feet and lower limbs is caused by water, with heavy swelling being due to the arrival of the Taiyin; this describes only the external causes. The methods of treatment have been elaborated by previous scholars. However, for internal conditions, there has yet to be a established treatment approach. Yang Dashou states that leg qi is a type of obstruction disease, treated with disseminating and unblocking medications to prevent Qi from becoming stagnant. If obstruction has already formed strongly, then cupping and removing the stasis in the blood is necessary. The classics say: if accumulation occurs, swelling and heat result. After cupping, treat with medication.

The "Inner Canon" discusses the southern regions where the ground is weak and the water and soil are poor, influenced by mist and dew. The Jiangdong and Lingnan regions are generally like this. When transitioning from spring to summer, the mountains and forests are steamy and dense, and the air is filled with wind, dampness, and toxins; the feet may be affected, resulting in endemic leg qi. The symptoms include weakening and bending of the feet, gradually leading to pain and numbness, slight swelling of the shins, numbness of the lower abdomen, headaches, irritability, phlegm obstruction and regurgitation, intermittent chills and fevers, and difficulties in urination; in severe cases, it may attack the heart and become urgent, thus treatment cannot be delayed. Therefore, it is essential to pay attention to classical formulas; those skilled in this art, could they not be more prevalent among the Jiangyou region?

Regarding different methods, the northern regions are characterized by high elevations, exposed to cold and frigid winds.[85p]
Their custom is to drink thick yogurt and eat meat. Among those who drink thick yogurt, those who consume quickly and in large amounts are considered capable. The classics say that excessive drinking leads to reversed energy, and it is stated that food enters the yin and nourishes the yang; now they are going against the yang way, which is considered a reversal. Thick yogurt and strong wine are damp and hot substances associated with drinking. Furthermore, overindulgence in nourishment increases dampness as the water quality descends, causing energy to stagnate—hence it settles in the legs and calves, leading to swelling and pain over time, which is a result of improper diet.

The "General Discussion on Ventilation and Solidification" states: When grains are abundant but energy is lacking, dampness resides below. Moreover, the dampness and heat of thick yogurt and strong wine are even worse than that of grains. The "Essential Discussions of the Ultimate Truth" asserts that when the yin is strong, fire energy becomes trapped internally, spreading outward, leading to swelling in the legs and lower limbs. This is what they refer to. Thus, when drinks enter the stomach, the vital energy flows forth, rising to the spleen, which distributes the energy upward to the lungs, connecting with the water pathways and descending to the bladder, allowing the water essence to be distributed widely, aligning with the seasons and the five organs, balancing yin and yang for constancy. If food and drink are excessive, the stomach and intestines become harmed, and thus the stomach energy cannot transform properly, nor can the spleen energy be distributed, leading to stagnation in the liver and kidneys’ regions, settling in the legs and feet, compounded by excessive sexual activity, resulting in excessive yin and deficient yang, eventually leading to chronic ailments.[86p]
Yang Dashou said: The illness of athlete's foot has historically been treated with purgatives, as it results from stagnation. However, one must not overdo it; excessive purging can harm the spleen and stomach, preventing qi from ascending and causing it to descend instead, leading to athlete's foot. On the other hand, if one does not purge sufficiently, the stagnant qi cannot disperse. Therefore, I have established formulas such as Qianghuo Daoti Decoction and Kaijie Daoyin Pill, which should be used based on careful consideration of the condition's nature.

The "External Records" states: First, avoid anger. Anger causes irritation, and irritation leads to the onset of athlete's foot. Second, refrain from speaking loudly. Loud speech damages the lungs, and when the lungs are harmed, it also triggers conditions. Additionally, one should not expose the feet; do not expose them to wind or water. Washing the feet with cold water is ill-advised, especially keeping the legs warm. Even in the summer, one should wear cotton trousers, and in winter, it is vital to keep the legs warm to induce a slight sweat, which is highly beneficial. Follow these guidelines for proper care.[87p]
Athlete's foot gradually weakens and damages the body; one should cut the nails of hands and feet on the days of Yin and Chou, cutting only a little into the flesh to dispel wind and dampness. In summer, the pores open, so it is unwise to sleep exposed to the wind. Waking can cause discomfort, so keep evil energies from lingering. Regular movement of the joints keeps them unblocked. This is essential for health and a method to ward off wind and evil.

For usual strength, after each meal, walk three to five hundred steps. If you feel fatigued, stop; the bad energy from the feet will disperse immediately, even if swelling occurs, the energy cannot rise.

Firstly, regarding diet, avoid excessive alcohol and rich foods, as overindulgence damages the spleen and stomach, leading to swelling in the legs and causing foot ailments. Secondly, desires should not be indulged; excessive cravings will cause symptoms. After eating, it is advisable to walk slowly for two to three hundred steps, not sweating excessively; if you feel tired, stop to prevent congestion. The classics say: "The unhurried person walks." They also state that those suffering from dampness and obstruction should avoid warm, over-satisfying foods and wet conditions.

Arm and Foot Pain

Arm pain has six pathways; investigate which path the pain resides in to treat the energy and blood using appropriate medicinal methods. If the pain is exterior, do not hastily administer treatment; it requires careful differentiation. For foot pain, treat new illnesses with methods for gout. Chronic foot problems do not arise from athlete's foot, but rather should be treated using methods for rheumatism. Each condition has its own diagnosis. Gout often arises from blood deficiency, allowing cold and dampness to invade.[88p]
Danxi's Heart Method (Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng)

Gout

Gout requires the use of medicines that dispel dampness, raising the humidity and accompanying the flow of Qi and blood. For gout that affects the heart, it is advisable to use the Four Substances Decoction, adding fried Huangbai; also, use the Yongquan acupoint, applying aconite powder mixed with saliva, and then using moxibustion to draw out the heat downwards.

If there is muscle movement in the big toe extending to the thigh near the waist, this is due to overindulgence and exposure to wind and cold, so it is proper to use the Four Substances Decoction combined with wine, qinpi (orange peel), safflower, dried atractylodes, nanking (south star), and ginger, decocted for consumption. Gout may involve damp heat or food accumulation, with the flow being windy dampness or cold dampness.

To combat dampness, focus on ingredients like Xianjue (immortal atractylodes), Baizhu (white atractylodes), Fangji (stephania), and Chuanxiong (chuanxiong), or use the Six Substances Aconite Decoction or the Pain Relief Decoction with Angelica. For severe Qi stagnation, utilize the Zhouche Pill or Exclude Dampness Pill. If there is retention of fluid, employ Dongyuan's Open and Guide Pill. For resolving exterior signs, use Ma Huang's Left Meridian Decoction and other medicines, choosing according to the meridians.

If there is also phlegm, Qi cold dampness together, increase the dosage of Wujisan (Five Accumulations Powder) with papaya. For dual resolution, use the Dahuang Left Meridian Decoction or Dongyuan's Qianghuo Guide to Disperse Powder. If regulating the blood is necessary, utilize the Eight Flavor Pill, or the Four Substances with Qianghuo and Tianma, or the Four Substances with Huangbai and Nanking, or the Jianbu Pill.

For dispelling wind and nourishing blood, using the Du Huojisheng Soup is the most effective.[89p]

Heel Pain

Phlegm and blood heat are present. For blood heat, it is advisable to use Siwu decoction with Rhizoma Coptidis and Anemarrhena.

Numbness in Hands and Feet

Numbness in the hands and feet is related to qi deficiency; when it involves the body, it indicates damp phlegm or stagnant blood. Numbness in all ten fingers suggests that there is damp phlegm and stagnant blood in the stomach.

Limb Joint Pain

For limb joint pain, Qiang Huo should be used to dispel wind and dampness. For obese individuals with limb joint pain, it is often due to wind-dampness and phlegm flow disrupting the meridians, indicating that Nanxing and Banxia should be used. For thin individuals with limb joint pain, this signifies blood deficiency, and Siwu decoction should be combined with Fangfeng and Qiang Huo. If a thin person exhibits impatience along with limb joint pain and fever, it indicates blood heat, and Siwu decoction should include Huangqin and wine-fried Rhizoma Coptidis. If there is swelling and pain in the joints with a slippery pulse, drying dampness is necessary, recommending Cangzhu, Nanxing, along with qi-moving herbs such as Mukang, Zhihua, and Binglang; if it is below, add Hanfangji. If there is swelling and pain in the joints with a thin and rapid pulse, this signifies stagnant blood, suggesting the use of Tao Ren, Honghua, Danggui, Chuanxiong, and a light dose of Da Huang. If there is fatigue and weakness accompanied by limb joint pain, this indicates qi deficiency, possibly with phlegm flow, and it is best to use Ren, Shu, Xing, and Ban.[90p]
Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment
(Ming Dynasty, Dai Sigong)

Hand Pain

Hand pain manifests as swelling and discomfort, affecting the palm, fingers, and arms. For treatment, use Wujin Decoction or Juanbi Decoction.

Arm Pain

Arm pain can result from wind, cold, or dampness attacking the area, or from fluids accumulating, or due to lifting heavy objects. This may lead to swelling in some cases and not in others. Excluding cases of fluid accumulation, other types of pain should be treated with Wujisuan or Wuyao Shunqi Decoction, or Juanbi Decoction. Blood deficiency can also cause arm pain, as inadequate blood nourishes the muscles; for this, use a combination of Juanbi Decoction and Four Substance Decoction. Nursing mothers who rest their arms on their children might experience arm pain due to wind and cold; they should also refer to this treatment. If pain arises from wind and dampness while sitting or lying down, or if the arm is exposed to cold while sleeping, Wujin Decoction, Juanbi Decoction, and Wuyao Shunqi Decoction are recommended. If dampness is confirmed, for Juanbi Decoction, add three qian of cangzhu and four fen of fangji; or use Wubing Decoction. If pain resulted from a previous heavy lifting injury, apply Hu Po San, Jie Rong San, or Heqi Decoction, and add half a qian of fresh turmeric to benefit the arm.[91p]
Athlete's Foot

Wind, cold, heat, and dampness, commonly encountered by the feet, lead to athlete's foot. Various pathogenic factors, whether they have been present for a long time or recently, and regardless of which meridian they belong to, can be treated with a herbal decoction to eliminate dampness, adding half a tael each of papaya, betel nut, and white atractylodes. Alternatively, one can use a powder of hydrangea and angelica, adding half a tael each of red peony and aroid. It is also advisable to take papaya pills regularly.

When athlete's foot flares up and causes unbearable pain in both feet, use the Five Accumulations Powder, adding three to five whole scorpions, and decoct in wine. During a flare-up, one will also experience body aches and fever; therefore, do not recklessly use cold medicine, as athlete's foot may resemble mild cold illnesses. If one suddenly feels weakness in the foot, numbness in the lower abdomen, cramps in the entire body, nausea or vomiting after eating, or redness and swelling in both shins, treat it as athlete's foot.

For dry symptoms, either of the previous two herbal formulations may have half a tael of stir-fried and crushed radish seeds added. For wet symptoms, add ten or more strips of green tangerine peel to the previous two medications. Remember, athlete's foot must not be treated with cold treatments; nor should cold medicines be used indiscriminately, as warmth is needed to disperse the condition.

With athlete's foot, one may observe a puncture approximately half an inch deep; every half day, pain may be distinctly abnormal. This indicates that athlete's foot has formed a discharge. Treat it by applying the essence of white wood that has been calcined over fire to draw out excess moisture, dripping it into the sore.[92p]
For persistent heat due to athlete's foot, use Baidu San with one qian of papaya, or mix equal parts Baidu San and Wujisan, known as Jiaojia San, adding one qian of papaya. If the condition results from prolonged wetness, leading to swelling or sores on both feet, use Wuling San or Heqi Yin, adding half a qian each of papaya and radish seeds, along with one qian of rhubarb.

If there's difficulty urinating due to athlete's foot, apply one patch of fresh Wuling San and one patch of Chuxie Tang, adding two qian of papaya, divided into two doses. If there’s no urine or stool passage, use Wuling San and Fuyuan Tongqi San.

For shortness of breath associated with athlete's foot, which pertains to the abdomen, it’s advisable to use Suzi Jiangqi Tang or Chenxiang Jiangqi Tang, supplemented with Yangzheng Dan or Simotan Yin.

If athlete's foot presses on the lungs causing coughing, use Xiao Qing Long Tang, adding one qian of betel nut with each dose, remade daily.

For loss of appetite due to athlete's foot, use Shengliao Pingwei San adding one qian of papaya. In cases of vomiting and nausea, use Eight Flavors Pingwei San with one qian of papaya.

For chronic athlete's foot with thin, withered legs that may feel cold or hot, or are painful or itchy, and may affect one foot more than the other, or appear weak and limp like a condition of wind, use Xiao Xuming Tang with papaya. Alternatively, one can use Duhuo Jisheng Tang, Fuzhong Bawwei Tang, swallow Huoluodan, or use the Tiger Bone pills.

If the condition is associated with blood deficiency, employ Xiongzhi Xiangsu, combining with papaya, Qianghuo, Chi Shao, Chuanxiong, and Zhizi.

For leg cramps, use Longjiao San.[93p]
Foot Pain

For foot pain, it is advisable to use two qian of Da Sheng San, mixed with half or one qian of wood melon powder, and adjust with bean soup wine. Also, use Chuan Jiao, fragrant Bai Zhi, and Cǎo Wū to brew a decoction for washing.

Crane Knee Wind

When the shins are thin and swollen, it is commonly called Crane Knee Wind, treated with Di Xian Dan. For Crane Knee Wind, add two sections of pine and cedar to Wu Ji San.

Principles of Medical Studies 【Ming Dynasty, Lou Ying】

Dominion of the Limbs

Yang governs the limbs. The classics say: "The limbs are the root of all Yang." They also state that Yang receives Qi from the limbs. When Yang is sufficient, the limbs swell. The classic states: "Accumulated Yang swelling in the limbs is this." When Yang is deficient, the limbs feel full. The classic states: "Winter Qi disease in the limbs is this."

The spleen governs the limbs. The classic states: "All limbs receive qi from the stomach but cannot reach the channels; this must be due to the spleen for them to receive it."

Inability to Lift or Use

When the spleen is full, the limbs are unable to lift. The classic states: "When the spleen pulse is excessive, the disease manifests externally, causing one to be unable to lift the limbs." When the spleen is deficient, the limbs are unusable. The classic states: "When the spleen's flesh form is insufficient, then the limbs are unusable." Furthermore, when the limbs lack energy, this is due to the spleen's essence not circulating.

In movement and qi, if the limbs are unable to lift, it all pertains to dampness. The classic states: "When earth is excessive, it is said to be dense and mounded. The manifestations of this are abdominal fullness and inability to lift the limbs."

Evil Residue in the Joints[94p]
When the five organs have pathogens, they linger in the joints. The texts state: if the lungs or the heart have pathogens, their energy resides in the elbows; if the liver has pathogens, its energy is in the thighs; if the spleen has pathogens, its energy stays in the hips; and if the kidneys have pathogens, their energy is in the knees.

Regarding leg swelling:

When there is swelling in the legs, accompanied by urinary obstruction, a feeling of fullness and discomfort in the chest, and digestive issues, it is advisable to use mild diuretics. Leg swelling often relates to excess lung Qi. The texts say that when someone has lung disease, there will be sweating, along with issues in the lower back, thighs, knees, and feet. Hence, the method of expulsion used by practitioners to treat leg swelling is based on this principle. Additionally, in the "Thousand Gold Prescriptions," those with excessive sweating should also adopt methods to drain the lungs.

There are 124 types of wind and 80 types of Qi, but when it comes to leg swelling, one must ensure medication is consistently used, while other treatments may vary according to the condition. Those who have wind Qi should expel it through proper channels in late spring, early summer, and late autumn to avoid severe complications. The term "expelling" refers to herbs like Ephedra, Qian Niu Zi, and loquat seeds; bitter cold diuretics are not necessarily required.

East Yuan's discussion on southern leg swelling indicates that it's caused by external invasion of dampness and should be treated with cold remedies, whereas northern leg swelling, stemming from internal injuries caused by alcoholic beverages, should be treated for damp-heat. This is something that previous authors have not fully expounded upon. In my view, it isn't necessary to differentiate between north and south for cold and heat. Any external invasion of cold and dampness should be regarded as cold-damp, regardless of geography. Similarly, any internal injury from alcoholic beverages is related to damp-heat, regardless of the region. Treatment should rely on pulse diagnosis and inquiry about the patient's condition.[95p]
The texts from "Wai Tai" and "Zong Lu" state that the southern regions, characterized by their low, damp, misty, and dewy environments, lead to the people's skin being thin and weak, resulting in the inability of the Yang energy to be firmly expressed. Consequently, when they tread on the ground, the dampness envelops their emptiness and illness arises from below. This is due to a deficiency of blood and weak Qi, as they suffer from the evil influence of the dampness, which interacts with the blood at the skin level. When the evil is strong and the righteous Qi is insufficient, blood and Qi become stagnant; stagnation causes blockage, and weakness leads to further deterioration, thus giving rise to what later generations termed "barley disease" (or beriberi).

The "Needling Classics" states: since ancient times, there has been a method to eliminate these conditions, predominantly treating such ailments with moxibustion to drive out the dampness. In addition, consuming fermented beverages helps to regulate the channels and disperse the evil influences. Recipes were primarily constructed with more warming herbs than cold ones, using ingredients like ephedra, processed aconite, ginger, and prepared aconitum. The "Inner Canon" asserts that excess dampness from the exterior should be expelled with bitter herbs. Ephedra, being bitter and warm, serves this purpose. Processed aconite is pungent and hot, aiding in mobility but lacking the ability to retain, thus facilitating the flow through the meridians. Ginger and prepared aconitum are pungent, sweet, and intensely warming, supportive of Yang energy while expelling the Yin, effectively dispelling the bad Qi of dampness.

Furthermore, one should examine the three Yin and three Yang points in the feet to ascertain which meridians are involved, focusing on the medicinal treatments accordingly. It is essential to consider which of the six energies is relevant, and treat accordingly with supportive and guiding herbs. Master Sun said: "The intent of the physician is key." Adjustments should be made according to circumstances, as there are no fixed prescriptions. Truly wise words indeed.[96p]
Arm Pain

According to Dong Yuan, arm pain has six pathways of meridians. By utilizing the corresponding medicinal herbs that promote the flow of qi and blood in those meridians, the following applies: When both arms are extended straight, hanging down vertically against the body, with the thumbs positioned forward and the little fingers back, if pain is felt in the front part of the arm, it pertains to the Yangming meridian, treated with Sheng Ma, Bai Zhi, and Gan Ge. If the pain is in the back part, it pertains to the Taiyang meridian, treated with Gao Ben and Qiang Huo. If the pain is on the outer side, it pertains to the Shaoyang meridian, treated with Chai Hu. If the pain is on the inner side, it pertains to the Jueyin meridian, treated with Chai Hu and Qing Pi. If the pain is in the inner front, it refers to the Taiyin meridian, treated with Sheng Ma, Bai Zhi, and scallions. If the pain is in the inner back, it pertains to the Shaoyin meridian, treated with Xi Xin and Du Huo. Acupuncture methods should also be applied, depending on the respective meridian affected.[97p]
Introduction to Medicine
[Ming Dynasty - Li Zhan]

General Discussion on Beriberi

The term "beriberi" refers to the phenomenon when the four environmental factors of wind, cold, heat, and dampness affect the feet, penetrating deeply through the meridians into the internal organs. The onset is gradual, unlike the four environmental factors confronting a person where the symptoms can be sudden and superficial. The external symptoms resemble those of a cold, with the possibility of transformation through the six meridians, such as a headache and fever resembling the Taiyang syndrome, progressing to the Jueyin syndrome of agitation and contraction, potentially leading to concurrent diseases.

Initially, there may be weakness in the feet and knees, with persistent stiffness and cramps, accompanied by redness and swelling as distinguishing features. In cases of Taiyang syndrome where pain radiates from the outer ankle along the meridians to the outer side of the little toe, one should follow the prevalent environmental factors for dispersal, using a formula such as Ma Huang Decoction, adding Feng Feng, Qiang Huo, Xi Xin, Ge Gen, Bai Zhu, and Fu Ling, or Bai Du San combined with Ping Su San.

For Yangming syndrome presenting with pain from the outer thigh and knee descending to the inner side of the middle toe, the treatment involves addressing the predominance of environmental factors, using Da Chai Hu Decoction with added Qiang Huo, Xi Xin, and Xing Ren, or Sheng Ma Ge Gen Decoction combined with Ping Su San.

For Shaoyang syndrome showing pain in the joints of the toes, one should harmonize using Xiao Chai Hu Decoction, omitting Feng Feng, Ge Gen, Xi Xin, Bai Zhu, Fu Ling, Mai Men Dong, Gan Jiang, and include Xiao Cao.

For cases where three Yang syndromes manifest together in cramps and constipation, adjustments can be made to the previous formulas, named Zuo Jing Decoction. Alternatively, for those specifically affecting the foot Taiyin meridian, if pain or swelling is observed on the inner side of the foot's big toe or inner knee, one should use Guo Gui Fu Decoction with added Fang Ji, Bai Zhu, and Fu Ling.[98p]
When symptoms of the Shao Yin channel appear, there is pain beneath the little toe extending to the arch of the foot, with external pain in the popliteal fossa and the inner thigh, accompanied by chest congestion and inability to eat, a dark face, and difficult urination. If the lower abdomen is numb, treatment is difficult; use the Eight Flavor Pill to save. When symptoms of the Jue Yin channel appear, there is pain in the abdomen with the large toe linked to the inner edge and the navel, with cramps in the feet and dry vomiting; use the Nourishing Essence Pill. If all three Yin channels show cramping and weakness, with heat rising to the chest, sides, shoulders, and back, and descending to the feet and knees, with heat in the soles, use the Foot Exchange Pill. The essence is that excessive wind enters the liver, causing tendons to be oppressed; the pulse is floating with no sweat; use the Sustained Life Decoction with added Du Huo. For wind-damp swelling and pain, use the Wind Expelling Decoction or Betel Nut Powder. For painful, stiff tendons, use the Frankincense Pain-Soothing Powder. If damp is abundant in the Spleen, causing heaviness in the flesh, resulting in sudden falls or swelling, employ the Damp-Removing Decoction. For excessive phlegm, use this decoction to swallow the white pill from Qingzhou.[99p]
