Feng Ju (Wind Abscess)

When there is itchiness in the feet and knees, scratching causes yellow fluid to emerge, which is called Feng Ju. It should be treated with the Feng Ju formula.

Tuo Ju (Detached Abscess)

The "Gui Yi" states: When swelling appears on both toes, if it does not reduce after five days, it disperses. If it festers for four days, it can be punctured. If there is black pus, it is severe; if it hasn’t surpassed the period, it can be treated. When a sore grows on the toes, if it is severe, it festers and detaches, hence it is called Tuo Ju. Some say only the big toe suffers from Tuo Ju; other toes with similar issues are called Dun Ju, which is easier to treat. Only Tuo Ju is difficult to treat. When it first appears as a red, swollen, painful toxin, use Wu Shen San and apply crushed Zihua Che, Jin Xian Diao Hu Lu, Jin Ji She, and Jin Nao Xiang; also apply juice. Additionally, use Wan Bing Jie Du Wan, ground with vinegar and applied warm. For lingering pain, eliminate dampness and attack the toxin, further moxibusting with isolated garlic until there is no pain, and using the Twelve Meridians Disinfecting Powder combined with guiding herbs.[149p]
If the swelling is severe and urgent treatment has not been obtained, one should treat it as a snake bite or a reaction to miasma, and effectiveness is expected. If the pain has not yet fully developed, and it is either absent or severe, one should use garlic moxibustion and detoxify with methods like the Xian Du Wan, adjusting according to the situation.

If it appears dark and not fully formed, it should be cut away immediately, and one should take restorative tonics to hopefully save the patient. However, if the blackness extends upward, it cannot be treated.

If the pain is severe and it appears red, one should apply detoxifying treatment, combined with moxibustion, using the Ren Shen Bai Du San mixed with Jie Geng, adding Chi Niu Xi, Yin Hua, Bai Zhi, and Da Huang to alleviate the pain; follow up with the Shi Xuan San combined with Tian Hua Fen, Jin Yin Hua, and Chi Niu Xi.

If it's not fully developed but is turning purple and there is no pain, one should apply garlic moxibustion fifty times; if pain is still unknown, follow up with moxibustion and take the Huolu Ming drink, then use the Tuo Li San to dissolve it for recovery.

If it is not fully developed but severely painful and swollen with a red color, one should apply garlic moxibustion until the pain stops, using a modified version of the Jing Jie Bai Du San with Chi Niu Xi, Yin Hua, Bai Zhi, and Da Huang, and then follow with the Huolu Ming drink.

Foot Qi Ulcer

The kidney governs the feet. When the kidney is deficient and affected by wind and dampness, attacking the feet and knees, this condition is called "Foot Qi." Due to the stagnation of qi and blood, and the excess of damp toxic qi in the skin surface, it cannot circulate properly, causing ulcers to form on the feet. If the wind and toxins do not disperse, the ulcers gradually increase with yellow fluid, swelling and pain ensue, and the body develops a high fever, making it difficult to heal for a long time.[150p]
Jia Ju [Nail Disease]

The three Yin meridians of the foot all originate at the toes. When the Qi and blood stagnate and do not flow, they can accumulate between the nails, leading to nail disease. This is due to the flow of the meridians and is not solely a problem of the muscles. It may arise from trimming the nails and injuring the underlying flesh, from nails growing into the flesh, or from improper footwear causing stagnation of Qi and blood, resulting in ulceration. If it persists, it can rot the fingers and extend up to the shins and knees, leading to sores and blisters. Since the disease occurs at the extremities, it is unnecessary to treat the internal organs; one should simply apply ointments to cleanse and remove foulness and fit the footwear properly for recovery. The toes are at the lowest part of the body, making it easy for Qi and blood to stagnate and difficult for medicinal effects to reach; weak individuals may develop sores from minor injuries that do not heal over time. In cases of severe injury, only through substantially tonifying the Qi and blood can recovery be expected. This notion of treating only the extremities is not universally applicable.

Foot Tofu Development

The text from "Gui Yi" states: Yang sores appear on the ankles and soles; if twenty days pass without improvement, it can be fatal. It may be punctured after ten days. If the sore is red and has white pus with not much blood, it is itchy and if black and red, it is fatal. The "tufu" refers to the top of the foot, where toxins can accumulate leading to swelling and pain; it is also called foot rashes and is connected to the liver channel of the foot Jueyin and the stomach channel of Yangming. It usually results from damp heat penetrating a weakness, and it is advisable to take a restorative drink adding papaya, cinnamon, and cow knee, along with moxibustion on garlic. This can be followed by a tonifying decoction or warming the middle. Thick pus can be treated, but if the pus is clear and purplish, it is fatal.[151p]
Heel Carbuncle

If someone asks about a carbuncle on the heel, what should be done? It is called "rabbit bite" because its shape resembles that of a rabbit's bite. It belongs to the Taiyang channel of the foot, with the point named Shenmai, located beneath the heel bone. This area is where the two extremes of yin and yang originate, resulting from accumulated heat in the organs. The toxicity is profound, and the use of toxic medicines externally is most to be avoided. Instead, one should perform moxibustion using garlic, and take the "Reviving Life Decoction" with added ox knee and cinnamon, or select from the "Victory Gold Pill," "Black Gold Powder," or "Purple Gold Pill." If there is purple-black discoloration, numbness, confusion, or irregular pulses, it is not treatable. If it festers over time, it might hinder eating and drinking. Additionally, if the two excretions are unregulated, or if there has been excessive physical exertion or emotional agitation, it can lead to death.

For women experiencing swelling and pain in the heel and toes, along with heat in the soles of the feet, this is due to childbirth and menstruation, lacking appropriate care, leading to deficiency in the three yin of the foot and causing false heat. If there is swelling and pain or pus formation, use the Six Flavor Pill as the main treatment, supplemented with the Eight Treasures Decoction; if there is stomach deficiency and reluctance to eat, supplement with the Six Gentlemen Decoction; for cold and heat with inner heat, supplement with the Xiaoyao Powder; if afternoon heat increases, with unclear head and eyes, supplement with the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. If phlegm is excessive, causing thirst or sores in the mouth and tongue, also use the previous two medicines to nourish the source of digestion. Generally, symptoms of fever, afternoon heat, internal heat, spontaneous sweating, and night sweating indicate false heat due to yin deficiency. Therefore, Danxi states that fire arises from the nine springs, representing the extreme of yin deficiency. Men who excessively indulge in alcohol and lust are often afflicted by this condition.[152p]
Liu Li Ju (Glazed Ulcer)

Someone asked about the ulcer beside the heel, how it manifests. It is called Liu Li Ju, belonging to the Taiyang channel of the foot. Its color is yellow and swollen like glaze, often caused by walking on rough paths, injuring the muscles, bones, and vessels internally. When cold and heat arise together, and the vital energy is insufficient, symptoms such as vomiting and dizziness occur, making it difficult to treat. In emergencies, take Five Spice Decoction, Lifesaving Drink, Sheng Jindan (Victory Gold Pill), or Wujin San (Black Gold Powder) as needed. For the robust, one pill of Jindan, or administer Bazhen San (Eight Formation Powder).

Foot Sole Boil

The "Ghost's Inheritance" states: If the soles of both feet produce pain that reaches the bone, it is untreatable. If the soles have minor skin breaks without deep damage, and the pus is not abundant, it can be treated. When the soles are swollen and painful due to toxicity, it is also known as Yongquan Ju (Gushing Spring Ulcer), commonly called "disease penetrating the board", and also referred to as "penetrating the cavernous heavenly snake". This is caused by the deficiency and damage of the Shaoyin kidney channel, and it is recommended to use garlic for moxibustion. For the robust, take Lifesaving Drink and administer Liuwei Dihuang Wan (Six Flavor Rehmannia Pill). If there are signs of exterior and interior conditions, measure for sweating and sweating out. For those who are deficient, use Shenqiusan (Decoction of All-around Great Nourishment) and large doses of Bamei Dihuang Wan (Eight Flavor Rehmannia Pill) without concern for morning or night. If there are symptoms of ulceration, nausea, confusion, and weak pulse presenting as a replacement, the prognosis is fatal.[153p]
Fleshy Callus

A fleshy callus grows between the toes, resembling a hard corn, attached to the flesh, causing hidden pain akin to a thorn, formed due to tight footwear rubbing against it.

Unnamed Tumor and Poison

Swelling on the back of the hand or foot, with red streaks resembling shrimp, is referred to as shrimp disease. Fry fragrant oil with salt and soak in hot soup, then wash with the hot infusion to eliminate. It is also necessary to take medications for sores. Near the folds of the knee, there are painful swellings that appear like elongated fish, known as "Upper Water Fish." Use a thorn needle to pierce and draw out bad blood, employing the dried ash of the mulberry tree, ingredients from the Lei Ting vine, and leaves of mountain camphor, pounded into a paste, fried, and bound on. Additionally, combine Lei Ting vine, red cow knee, mountain santalum, and dried ash to make a salty paste for binding. Another prescription includes the root bark of the Lei Ting vine, dried ash pounded and fried for binding, along with the application of Qisheng ointment, while taking the Jiu Jin Liu Ma powder internally.

Swelling and unbearable pain in the back of the foot or toes can be alleviated by elevating the foot; the pain will lessen somewhat. If the foot hangs down, the pain becomes intolerable, referred to as "Inverse Pull Swelling." Initially, use the two-sided turtle decoction, brewed with wine, followed by the two-sided turtle powder. If ineffective, grind the snake yam and consume it with wine for significant relief.[154p]
On Gangrene

Gangrene is an external decay coupled with internal corruption. It arises from the long-term consumption of rich foods, which overheat the internal organs, as well as the use of mineral supplements that deplete kidney vitality. Excessive sexual exertion can also exhaust the Qi and damage essence. Additionally, the use of potent drugs held under the tongue to transform into liquid, which then reaches the lower abdomen, or directed into the navel to cause internal heat, can induce this condition.

Some seek to enhance virility through ointments applied to the groin or by stimulating the male organs, hoping to maintain vigor. This often results in the over-accumulation of Yang essence and rampant sexual fire, leading to heat and dryness within the organs, or poisoning that seeps into the bones, culminating in ulcers and severe sores.

Truly, it reflects the foolish actions of the clever, unheeded by those who fail to protect themselves from hidden misfortunes. The wise often delude themselves into believing good fortune has come, neglecting the degradation of their health, until they realize that their present ailments have a cause, but the remedy eludes them.

This affliction often manifests in the hands and feet, which are the extensions of the five vital organs. Initially, the sores appear as small as a grain of millet, accompanied by blisters resembling cooked jujubes, with dark energy spreading throughout. The pain is intense, like flames spilling forth, while the condition deteriorates to a point where bones weaken and sinews rot. The foul odor is unbearable, and the essence of life becomes elusive.

Thus, it is said that the heart fails due to blood loss, the liver fails due to the death of sinews, the spleen fails due to the decay of flesh, the lungs fail due to the death of skin, and the kidneys fail due to the demise of bones. In these five failures, even the most potent elixirs cannot save a life.[155p]
For those who suffer from this illness, life and death should not be taken lightly. Master Sun said: When the illness is in the flesh, it should be cut; when it is in the finger, it should be sliced. This is indeed the nature of the disease. The treatment should be applied early, taking advantage of the time before it has spread. Use more than ten strands of hair to wrap tightly around the base of the affected finger for ten more turns, gradually tightening it, ensuring that the poisonous gas does not attack the healthy flesh. At the same time, use toad bile pastry, placing it on top of the original grain, and apply moxibustion until the flesh withers and the sore dies off.

The next day, if the finger turns completely black, then use a sharp knife to carefully cut along the seam of the affected joint, gently removing the finger. If the bleeding does not stop, use a gold knife like a holy remedy to stem it, and for any remaining swelling, apply a marvelous poultice. The following day, if there is still black vapor remaining, use only ground toad bile tablets mixed into a powder, cover with ointment, and the black vapor will recede. If pus develops at the site, use the regular method with jade red ointment and other medicines to protect the newly grown flesh and ensure the bone is intact, which is a favorable omen.

Internally, take medications to nourish kidney essence, support vital energy and blood, strengthen the spleen, and calm the spirit. If there are no internal changes and no external complications, there’s a 30-40% chance of recovery. However, if after cutting the black color continues to spread, pain and swelling worsen, and there’s no pus but dry mouth and a hard tongue, leading to a sluggish spirit and tastelessness in food, it will ultimately result in death.

In treating this, one should not rely solely on one’s own judgment but must consult illustrious experts and heed the patient’s wishes regarding the surgery. Furthermore, because this condition can have varying prognoses, it is unwise to act hastily. There are cases that appear similar but are not the same, true conditions that present differently, and detailed annotations are provided later for reference.[156p]
If a sore appears without thirst, with a moist mouth and a harmonious tongue, and the temperament is normal, without sudden violent reactions, following proper etiquette will be auspicious.

In the initial stages, if it resembles a pockmark, is hot and painful, with swelling in a finger, and has constriction at the root, this is auspicious.

Once it has developed, if the head begins to decay, the flesh is neither purple nor black, there is pain but occasionally pus emerges and swelling subsides, this is auspicious.

Upon rupture, if there is first pus and then decay, the flesh appears red and vibrant, the poison does not disperse, and the breath is not foul, this is auspicious.

If thirst precedes the sore, there is an excessive desire for cold, lethargy with a dry tongue, frequent urination, and impotence, this is unfavorable.

In the early stages, if it resembles a grain of millet, the flesh appears purple but does not swell, there is sharp pain, and dark energy spreads, this is unfavorable.

Once developed, if the sore appears withered, the flesh is black and the skin is charred, with pain like being cut by a knife, and the poison spreads favorably, this is unfavorable.

Once it has ruptured, if the flesh is withered and the tendons rotten, with blood and water that are foul and dirty, pain resonates deeply, this is unfavorable.

Treatment methods:[157p]
Gangrene often occurs on the toes rather than the fingers. When it first appears as a yellow blister, it should be cauterized. If it arises like a grain, with a space inside to hold millet, and the skin is purplish-red without causing burning or swelling, it should still be cauterized. After cauterization, if the wound absorbs heat and forms blisters filled with pus, external medicine should be applied while internally supporting the healing process. When the poison has developed, and the wound is slightly depressed, but the purplish color has not affected the surface of the foot, it should be evaluated for possible surgical removal. After removal, if blood and fluids flow profusely with ongoing pain, one must tonify the qi and blood, and strengthen the spleen and stomach. If recovery is slow, with decreased appetite, body fatigue, dry mouth, and frequent thirst, one should nourish the body fluids and strengthen kidney essence. Following the breakout, if qi and blood are injured, with weak spleen and stomach, spontaneous sweating, feeling hot and nauseous, restless sleep, fever in the afternoon, and severe pain, one must significantly enhance qi and blood. For those indulging in rich and greasy foods, or with repressed desires leading to toxins and stagnant blood over time, one must avoid surgical methods.

Chronic eruptions are caused by improper seasonal elements, manifesting without internal toxins. This condition often appears on the palms and soles, or in the areas of the waist, legs, and buttocks where movement occurs, causing diffuse swelling without a distinct head, aversion to cold, fever, heaviness in the limbs, and intense thirst. At the onset, one should take a universal remedy to induce sweating and relieve the exterior; if the swelling does not subside, it is likely to form pus, and one should take a detoxifying remedy combined with the wax alum pills. Subsequent treatments should follow the established protocols for managing boils, sores, and ulcers.[158p]
Pomegranate Blister

Pomegranate blister occurs when the Shaoyang fire interacts with external dampness, resulting in a condition that manifests on the inner elbow approximately one inch from the joint. It starts as a small yellow blister, which quickly enlarges, becoming red and firm, swollen like a covered bowl. When the skin ruptures, it exudes, resembling clumped pomegranate seeds and causing cold chills, akin to a severe illness. At the onset, perform moxibustion nine times, and take toad venom pills for sweating to release the hidden poison. Apply moxibustion to the top, stick a toad venom cake on it, and cover with ointment; for swollen areas, apply golden yellow powder. Internally, take chrysanthemum clearing decoction and amber wax alumen pills. If there is severe agitation and fever, use Heart-Protecting Powder and Golden Liquid Earth Pill. After nine days, if the affected area produces thick yellow pus and pain slightly decreases, with symptoms improving inside and out, and if there is slight improvement in appetite, it can be seen as safe; conversely, if not, it is a bad sign. After rupture, if vital energy is weak and mixed symptoms persist, treat according to the methods for managing abscesses.

Ankle Blister

Ankle blister develops from the downward flow and stagnation of damp heat in the three Yin channels of the foot. It initially presents as swelling and pain at the inner ankle, with the pain penetrating to the bone, making movements difficult, and in severe cases, extending to the outer ankle. If the swelling has a head, it indicates a Yang-type easy to break; if no head is present, it is a Yin-type, difficult to rupture. In both cases, at the onset, chills and fever must alternate, and it is advisable to use a modified Jingfang Baidu Powder with added Niuxi Powder; if pus forms and swelling is painful for a long time, acupuncture is recommended; for decay without closure and large openings, double the use of Yuhong Ointment; for those with weakened bodies, provide nourishment. If this condition is not treated, it may lead to a chronic disability.[159p]
On Gout

Gout occurs when the nail grows into the flesh, or from injuries to the good flesh while trimming nails, or due to tight shoes. The condition manifests as a fleshy growth wrapping around the nail, with unusual swelling and pain, making it difficult to walk. Initially, it is advisable to apply a special medicated paste to the affected area, which will dissolve and heal spontaneously. If the growth becomes hardened over time, a specific powder should be used to break it down, followed by applying pearl powder, ensuring complete recovery.

On Heavenly Snake Poison

Heavenly snake poison, also known as snake head sore, arises from a surge of heart fire. The symptom involves the fingertip swelling like a snake head, with red swelling and intense pain reaching to the heart, and in severe cases, alternating chills and fever occur with the swelling extending upwards. Small moxibustion should be applied to the top of the swelling, and a powder made of realgar should be dusted on it. Internally, toad venom pills can be taken to promote sweating and detoxification. In mild cases, the swelling gradually diminishes; in more severe cases, it may burst and produce pus, and in extreme cases, can lead to decay. After it has burst, if swelling persists, a toad venom stick should be inserted into the opening, covered with a medicated ointment for effectiveness. For decayed areas, a specific ointment should be applied. If the condition shows weakness and does not heal, supplementary tonics should be taken concurrently.[160p]
He Gu Ding

He Gu Ding, commonly known as Tiger Mouth Hundred Wrinkles, is a condition often characterized by swollen lumps and red streaks, hence the name "Ding." This affects the hand Yangming stomach channel, where dampness and toxins invade, causing itching or burning pain. At the onset, the affected area should be punctured, then covered with toad venom cake and a golden salve. After three days, if swelling accumulates and pus is formed, change the dressing. For soft, swollen, and painful areas where pus has developed, puncturing will lead to healing. If there is significant swelling and fever, both internal and external treatments are necessary.

Lian Chuang

Lian Chuang is formed by the convergence of wind, heat, and damp toxins, distinguishing between new and old cases, as well as internal and external types. For new cases, applying three fragrant ointment or incense paper will lead to self-healing. For slightly older, purplish-black cases, the detoxifying purple gold ointment can gradually alleviate the symptoms. In cases of longstanding, stubborn ulcers with blackened, sunken flesh and foul odor, treatment using centipede plasters is required to dispel wind toxins and dissolve necrotic tissue before healing can occur. For external ulcers, take Si Sheng Wan, and for internal ulcers, take Shen Qi Wan, which is effective.[161p]
Blood Wind Sores

Blood wind sores arise from the interaction of wind heat, damp heat, and blood heat. When they occur, they cause intense itching, breaking open and leaking fatty fluid, gradually spreading. In severe cases, orally take Xiao Feng San with Niu Xi and Huang Bo; externally apply antidote powder (Xiong Huang San) or Ruyi Jin Huang San as dressings. If the sores are long-standing, purple, blackened, and hardened, causing stagnant qi and blood, use needles to remove the black blood and then use a magical lamp for steaming to dispel toxins. Afterwards, apply the aforementioned medicine for effectiveness.

Itching of Women's Feet

Itching of women's feet originates from the Three Yang wind dampness descending, becoming stagnant and not dispersing. Thus, it first causes itching and later results in damp sores. Additionally, itching and dampness may occur at the curved areas of the soles; a mix of powdered alum can be applied.

Cracked Hands and Feet

Cracked hands and feet indicate dryness, due to insufficient nourishment from qi and blood. When heat in the muscles is suddenly attacked by wind and cold, it hinders the blood vessels, leading the skin to become increasingly dry and withered, resulting in cracks. Daily exposure to wind and the compounding effects of wind heat cause pain. Use Yu Ji San to wash and rub the skin, and apply a moisturizing ointment. In severe cases, it is also beneficial to take Dang Gui Yin Zi.[162p]
Crabgrass Bumps

Crabgrass bumps are caused by harm to the spleen from excessive thinking, leading to the stagnation of spleen qi. This condition often affects those with deficient qi and blood; it mainly manifests in the limbs, which are associated with the spleen's earth element. Initially, there is bone pain, which gradually develops into swelling that is firm and not hot or red. The back of the hand and the inner aspect of the wrist swell in multiple areas, preventing movement. Over time, it resembles the consistency of tofu and leaks a fluid that connects various orifices, flowing continuously day and night, alongside persistent swelling and pain. Patients appear pale and thin, with diminished appetite. Prolonged cases result in alternating chills and fever and internal symptoms manifesting. For treatment, both Qi-nourishing and Shen-boosting medicinal formulas, such as the Qi Nourishing Decoction and the Modified Xiao Yao San, are recommended for harmonizing qi and blood while supporting the spleen and stomach. Of those afflicted, about 12 to 23 out of 100 can recover. However, many die due to insufficient response to treatment, leading to the complete depletion of qi and blood.

Stinking Pond Snails

Stinking pond snails are a result of the damp heat from the Yangming stomach channel attacking and penetrating the body. This ailment typically arises on the toes, initially presenting as white spots that become ulcerated, progressing from itchiness to pain, accompanied by the discharge of foul-smelling fluid, resembling snail shells. In severe cases, the whole foot may swell, with accompanying chills and fever. The first step in treatment is to wash with a licorice decoction and apply toad venom cakes three pieces over three days. Subsequently, use pearl powder mixed with pig spinal marrow for topical application and cover with a medicated ointment. Apply the True Monarch Miracle Paste to reduce swelling. One should refrain from walking.[163p]
Niu Cheng (Foot Edema)

Niu Cheng (Foot Edema) occurs when one travels rapidly, causing heat and moisture in the feet. This leads to stagnation of qi and depletion of blood, resulting in the formation of hard and stubborn skin. The body fails to nourish the area, gradually causing swelling and pain, with swollen areas becoming high and protruding, making movement difficult. If allowed to persist, they may rupture, leading to pus discharge. Daily cleansing with warm water and applying powdered ox horn, along with addressing internal pus, is recommended. For stubborn skin that does not break, use a large, sharp needle to pierce the area to release pus and provide relief. If the hardened skin ruptures, it should be cut away. If flesh does not grow back, use jade-red ointment to promote its growth. If flesh is present but no new skin has formed, apply pearl powder to help generate skin and achieve healing.

Insect Borers (Cockroach Borer)

Insect borers often occur in the joints of fingers, appearing without redness or heat, and swelling resembling a cicada's abdomen. This condition is caused by the accumulation of phlegm and qi stagnation in the Hand Shaoyin channel. Initially, it is painless, but over time it becomes painful. Prolonged pain leads to decay, while the swelling persists. Applying toad venom cakes can help create thin pus. This condition may affect those who are physically weak and requires internal nourishing medicines to prevent it from developing into a chronic ailment.

Field Snail Blisters

Field snail blisters typically manifest on hands and feet, feeling as if they are burning with fire, followed by the development of purple, white, and yellow blisters. This is caused by wind and dampness attacking the Spleen channel, leading to gradual swelling, pain, and restlessness. Puncturing the blisters with a needle helps to release toxic fluid, after which a protective ointment should be applied. If blisters reappear, internal detoxification and Spleen-discharging decoctions may lead to healing.[164p]
Goose Palm Wind

Goose Palm Wind arises from the yangming stomach channel, characterized by hot, dry blood, and is caused by exposure to cold, leading to dry and withered skin. It may also occur when residual toxins from old sores remain. Initially, there are purple spots with white dots; if it persists, the skin becomes dry and thick, continuously cracking. Smoking and washing it with Erfan Decoction will lead to a cure.

Supplementary Evidence

Nuan Abscess occurs on the shoulder and extends to swelling around the shoulder area, characterized by hardness. Dui Abscess appears at the site of the radial artery, with swelling and pain, alternating between cold and heat, affecting the shoulder and causing difficulty in movement. Fu Yin Abscess develops three inches above the inner ankle, starting as small blisters, eventually becoming red and swollen, leading to bleeding and bone-deep pain, making walking impossible. Yao Bone Abscess occurs in the inner thigh, with no swelling or redness, but excruciating pain deep within the marrow; it is best initially treated with the Thunder Fire Needle, accompanied by internal administration of Wansheng Pill, mixed with wine for effectiveness. Yin Abscess arises three inches below the right inner thigh, causing pain radiating to the groin and lower abdomen. Yuan Abscess appears three inches below the left inner thigh, with diffuse swelling affecting the groin, and pain reaching the thigh.

For the above conditions with initial external symptoms, it is advisable to release the exterior; for internal symptoms, one should promote internal flow. After rupture, it is necessary to nourish the area; if it persists, one should focus on contraction. This is the established treatment method; it must not be confused, and one should avoid reckless medication, as it may lead to dire consequences.[165p]
Four Limb Gate

Medical Prescriptions Examination (Ming, Wu Kun)

Discussion on Foot Illness

The foot illness resembles typhoid, thus hard to diagnose; it can lead to death, thus difficult to treat. One disease, two difficulties; this cannot simply be discussed regarding foot illness. I examine seven prescriptions; fellow practitioners, please teach me as well!

Foot illness exhibits aversion to cold or strong heat, and Foria can be the main remedy. The essence of foot illness lies in the damp heat accumulating in the feet, causing painful sensations. When dampness and heat contend, if dampness prevails, it induces cold aversion; if heat prevails, it induces strong heat. This serves as the evidence. There are also those with accompanying headaches, resembling typhoid, yet their illness begins from foot illness, which is different.

One should not restrict based on foot swelling; there are also cases of pain without swelling called 'dry foot illness'. Some are characterized by slow progression that does not comply, termed 'gentle wind'. Others with painful numbness are called 'damp obstruction', and those with cramping or spasms are termed 'wind toxin'. This should be understood and differentiated by physicians, and each has its own treatment methods.

Generally speaking, foot illness is a condition of obstruction, favoring openness and disliking blockage. Hence, Master Sun stated: “Those suffering from foot illness die due to excess qi; not a single person has perished from taking medicine that leads to deficiency.” Therefore, those with foot illness should not receive substantial tonics nor excessive purgatives. The prescriptions consist of Mutong, Foria, and Areca nut, which are harmonizing agents that can relieve blockage. Rhino horn, Huangbai, Sheng Dihuang, and licorice tips are cooling agents that can dispel heat. Cangzhu and Baizhu are drying agents that can eliminate dampness.[166p]
Chuanxiong can disperse the qi within the blood, while rhinoceros horn can promote the blood within the qi. If pain occurs first and then swelling, it indicates that qi has injured the blood; therefore, use more Chuanxiong. If swelling occurs first and then pain, it indicates that blood has injured the qi; hence, use more rhinoceros horn. If the stools are firm, add peach kernel; if the urine is scanty, add cowbane; if there is internal heat, add scutellaria and coptis; if there is seasonal heat, add gypsum; if there is phlegm, add bamboo juice. It all depends on adapting the method; do not be too rigid initially. In cases where foot-related ailments affect the heart, causing persistent wheezing or vomiting, they are all fatal, as water clashes with fire.

In cases of foot-related pain and swelling, with cold and hot sensations intertwined, if the pulse is deep and fine, the prescription should be Guo Bi Decoction. The essence of the pain lies in the obstruction of qi, while the swelling results from stagnation of blood; this is the reason for the confinement of foot illnesses. The interplay of cold and heat signifies the conflict between pathogenic forces and righteous qi. A deep pulse indicates an interior condition, while a fine pulse indicates a yin condition. The name Guo Bi implies surpassing and emerging from the lowest state; "bi" suggests humility. This formula aims to release and elevate the most obstructed qi, hence the name. Gypsum is cold and heavy, with cold able to overcome heat and heaviness able to descend. Aconite is spicy and hot, with spiciness aiding in expelling obstructions and heat promoting qi. When combined with ephedra, the stagnation of cold and heat can be expelled through sweat. Utilizing white atractylodes and licorice, which have a warm and balanced flavor, can help harmonize the Qi and facilitate elevation beyond obstruction. However, licorice should be used sparingly, as its slow nature could delay swift action towards the lowest areas.

In cases of cold-damp foot ailments, characterized by pain and numbness, if the pulse at both ankles is deep and fine, the prescription should be Six Medicines Aconite Decoction, treating this as a painful obstruction syndrome.[167p]
The "Inner Canon" states: When cold dominates, it results in painful obstruction; when dampness dominates, it leads to blockage. Presently, if there is pain and numbness, it is due to both cold and dampness. The pulse at the two inches (measure of the body) pertains to the two feet; a pulse that is deep indicates an interior condition, and a slow pulse indicates cold.

For treatment, use the heartwood of cinnamon and aconite to warm the cold, while prepared leech and white atractylodes address the dampness. Licorice and poria are beneficial for the spleen, helping to support the deficient earth energy and control the excess dampness. It is essential to take cooling medicines to ensure the properties of cinnamon and aconite act downward and do not spread horizontally.

In cases of foot qi (pathological condition) transforming into internal issues, it leads to an inability to have smooth bowel movements. If foot qi affects the liver, there may be a lump in the left flank; if it affects the spleen, it causes a feeling of fullness; if it affects the heart, it may result in death at night, as the night energy supports the yin evils.

Due to extreme cold, if one is unaware of their condition, the yin invades and the yang cannot be released. Thus, cedar wood decoction is recommended, as cedar is dense and aromatic—dense enough to reach downward and aromatic enough to disperse stagnation. The flavor of citrus leaves is bitter and rich, surpassing that of green peel; areca nut is solid and heavy, comparable to iron stone. A rich taste promotes downward movement, and dense material causes descent, allowing the pathogenic qi to descend significantly.

Children's urine is salty and cold; the salty nature can lead pathogenic qi to exit with turbid yin, while the cold can balance excessive heat and prevent it from rising. The text states: "What is distant in the Way must be greatly controlled." Therefore, the quantity is five sheng.

For those suffering from cold damp foot qi, with pain and numbness, they should take decoctions internally and wash externally with a pepper soup.[168p]
Pepper can treat the cold and dampness causing obstruction, while ginger and scallions, being warm and pungent, can help promote the flow of energy in the skin. It is also said that all cases of "foot disease" are caused by obstruction and washing will yield no benefit. For swollen and painful foot conditions accompanied by damp heat and yellowing, the main treatment is a formula called "Tianwen Pain Decoction." This is because the obstruction within the feet causes pain and swelling, and the damp heat cannot be released, leading to yellowing. The ingredients in this formula, such as Qianghuo, Fangfeng, Shengma, Gegen, and Cangzhu, are all warm and dispersing agents that can relieve the obstructed foot condition. Additionally, Ku Shen, Huangqin, Yinchin, and Zhimu are bitter and cold substances that can remove the internal damp heat. Finally, Zexie, Zhuling, and Baizhu are mild diuretics effective in promoting the drainage of dampness in the lower body.[169p]
Angelica, ginseng, and licorice are used to nourish the blood after depletion and to replenish energy following excessive loss. For those with weak spleen-qi and downward-acting stomach-qi, resulting in edema in the feet and ankles, the Decoction for Raising Yang and Harmonizing Qi is the remedy. Although the spleen possesses the qualities of stability, it has the ability to promote strength; when spleen-qi is harmonious, it can lift the clear up and lower the turbid, preventing edema. When spleen-qi is deficient, the earth cannot control water, causing the fluids from food in the stomach to descend and result in leg swelling. In this formula, pinellia and licorice are used to strengthen the spleen; ginseng and astragalus are for replenishing energy; fermented malt and cardamom help digest and transform food; ephedra and bupleurum lift the stomach qi; angelica directs other herbs back to the spleen; and dried tangerine peel facilitates the movement of qi in the middle burner. The use of phellodendron is to draw out its richness, guiding ephedra and bupleurum downwards to the legs, while simultaneously lifting the sinking yang.[170p]
Medical Practices of the Physician's Realm [Qing Dynasty, Yu Chang]

On the Treatment of Beriberi with the Enhanced Eight Flavor Pill

The ancient formula, the Eight Flavor Pill of the Cui family, incorporates two yang herbs—Aconite and Cinnamon—alongside six yin herbs including Rehmannia. The "Jin Kui" text suggests its use for treating beriberi, which ascends and affects the lower abdomen, indicating a thought that is rather subtle. It implies that when earth energy increases towards heaven, one must use the aggressive properties of Ginger and Aconite to overcome it.

When the earth energy arrives in the lower abdomen, it dwells on the boundary of extreme yin, which predicates that there is no reason for excessive agitation; thus, only yang herbs are added to the yin herbs for treatment, and there is no need for a complete focus on yang.

In cases where kidney water overflows, causing issues like urinary difficulties in women—referred to as "transforming the womb"—the formula’s name is changed to Kidney Energy Pill, although the ingredients remain the same. This is because it captures the kidney energy, allowing the kidney water to return to its source, leading to normalized urination, hence there is no need to overly emphasize yang.

In consideration of this, when treating conditions characterized by yang deficiency and yin excess, it is essential to utilize purely yang without incorporating yin. There is no further doubt on this approach.[171p]
Later generations, when dealing with foot odor entering the abdomen, find the lower abdomen lacking sensation, and experience a sudden onset of shortness of breath, vomiting, and sweating. They fail to recognize that the earthly energy has intensified and affects the heavenly energy. Using this formula inappropriately, they claim this symptom is most urgent, citing the kidney overpowering the heart, with water overcoming fire, leading to death in an instant. Using the original formula with double the amounts of aconite and cinnamon can only be seen as fifty steps laughing at a hundred steps; it does not address the critical illness, as the kidney overpowering the heart and water overcoming fire is the most immediate concern. They do not understand that the organs mutually hinder each other, which poses a significant danger, and they cannot discern the urgency of the situation.

Subsequently, Zhu proposed treating foot odor by transforming the Eight Flavor Pill into the Eight Flavor Decoction, using aconite, dried ginger, peony, poria, licorice, cinnamon heart, ginseng, and white atractylodes. The reasoning is quite refined, and by further adapting the peony, licorice, and ginseng in clinical practice, it enhances its efficacy. However, unwise individuals again insert their interpretations into this decoction, removing the cinnamon heart and adding dried rehmannia, switching yin for yang—what a drastic deviation! Yet the formula texts are all mixed together, and who recognizes them as the offenders against Zhu’s proposal?[172p]
Inability to Lift the Limbs

When a stroke causes the limbs to be unable to lift, it can be either deficiency or excess. If there is deficiency in the Yangming, the tendons lose their nourishment, and the bones cannot be bound, leading to difficulty in movement. If there is excess in the Yangming, the flesh becomes dense, and with the invasion of wind, the upright Qi cannot circulate. For deficiency, use Six Gentlemen Decoction; for excess, combine Three Transformations Decoction with Purging the Qi Decoction. When treating stroke-induced limb inabilities, if one cannot distinguish between deficiency and excess and recklessly tries to tonify or drain, the practitioner is at fault. The inability to lift the limbs all pertains to the spleen and earth element. If there is excessive consumption of rich foods, leading to internal heat and congestion, it indicates stagnation in the spleen, and it should be drained to relieve this blockage. If there is little food intake and the body is thin, along with lethargy and a tendency to sleep, it indicates deficiency and weakness of the spleen, and it should be tonified to strengthen its function. If one indiscriminately tonifies the excess and drains the deficiency, could it not harm the patient?

Weakness of the Feet and Knees

Additionally, one may experience weakness in the feet and knees, with coolness in the lower buttocks, damp and foul-smelling sweat, and a slippery, unstable essence. The pulse is deep, rapid, and strong, indicating internal fire stagnation forcing yin outward, with excessive yang resisting yin. In such cases, bitter and cold medicines should be used to purge. This reflects the subtle signs of water and fire imbalance, and the elegance of pulse and symptom treatment principles should be applied accordingly.[173p]
Crane Knee Wind

Crane knee wind refers to the stiffness caused by wind, cold, and dampness affecting the knee. If the bones of the knee grow larger over time and the surrounding muscles become thin and withered, and one cannot yet treat the knee itself, one must first nourish the blood and qi, allowing the muscles to gradually thrive before treating the knee. This approach is similar to treating cases where one side of the body is withered. Once there is atrophy, one must first nourish the parts that are not yet withered, so that the withered parts may regain circulation and vitality. If one does not understand the principle of drawing qi to nourish blood, and blood to aid qi, but simply uses herbs like Ephedra and Ledebouriella to dispel wind, there are few who are not completely withered and perishing. Thus, in treating crane knee wind by hastily attacking the stiffness, one must also consider the atrophy of the foot, which becomes unusable. Consequently, when discussing the treatment approach, isn't it evident?

The ancient method for treating children with crane knee wind involves using the Six Flavors Rehmannia Pill augmented with deer antler and cattle knee, totaling eight ingredients, without addressing the wind; this is the most commendable intention. For children's cases are not necessarily due to wind, cold, or dampness, but often result from innate deficiencies, where the kidney energy is weak and cold accumulates in the lower back and knees, causing obstruction. Therefore, the Six Flavors Pill replenishes the water in the kidneys; deer antler supplements the fire in the kidneys; and cattle knee directs it to the joints to strengthen the tendons and muscles. This is an excellent method of treating the root rather than the symptoms, using this example to generalize the principle.[174p]
On Gout

The concept of gout did not exist in ancient times; it was first named during the Jin Dynasty by Su Jing. However, its symptoms of swelling, pain, and numbness are what the classics refer to as "bi" (obstruction); its looseness and inability to retract correspond to "wei" (atrophy) in the classics; and when severe enough to cause an upward rush, it corresponds to "jue ni" (counterflow) in the classics.

Later generations distinguished it as one of the four patterns of fever, categorizing it as gout if a person exhibits headaches, fever, body pain, and constipation, accompanied by weak and powerless legs and knees. This explanation is too muddled; I disagree with it. Gout is fundamentally a disease caused by dampness and blockage, not an exterior pathogenic invasion. There are cases where multiple symptoms may occur together, but if one misidentifies weakness of the legs due to external pathogens as gout, it leads to confusion and misunderstanding.

Now I will omit the unnecessary details and summarize the key points, ensuring no aspect is overlooked for clarity.

Initially, the symptoms of gout are very mild, with diet and movement remaining normal; it may suddenly appear without any other illness or develop gradually following another illness. When the disease manifests, it can affect the area from the knees to the feet in various ways: numbness, cold pain, weakness, cramps, swelling or no swelling, gradual atrophy, or fluctuating between fever and chills. It may feel as if water is cold or fire is hot; there may be a change in appetite, it may be possible or impossible to eat, or one may feel a sensation of something like a finger pressing down from the calf, causing a rush of qi to ascend to the heart. All of these represent the true illness of gout.[175p]
There are symptoms such as fever and headache, alternating chills and fever, abdominal pain, vomiting upon seeing food, aversion to the smell of food, reluctance to see light, confusion in speech, and mental disorientation; all of these are accompanying symptoms of beriberi. Generally, these symptoms can be either mild or severe: in mild cases, they gradually appear, worsening over two or three months; in severe cases, they arise quickly, sometimes within one or two days. If treated as mild when it is severe, there is a risk that the internal energy could rise to the heart, potentially leading to death.

The causes of beriberi are twofold: one from external sources and one from internal factors. The external causes involve the influence of cold, dampness, rain, and humidity, or sitting or lying on damp ground, which leads to the invasion of damp pathogens into the skin, flesh, and tendons. When dampness affects vulnerability, the illness begins in the lower body, resulting in leg and foot problems. The internal causes stem from excessive consumption of rich, sweet foods, alcohol, and unrestrained intake of foods like dairy products that create damp heat, which causes heat to obstruct the lower regions of the body, leading to swelling and pain in the legs, or even affecting the hands and joints.

In ancient times, it was said that in the southern regions where the climate is humid, illnesses are often caused by external factors, whereas in the north, where there is a penchant for alcoholic beverages, illnesses are commonly due to internal factors. This is indeed one perspective. However, the north also has cold dampness, and the south certainly cannot be devoid of wine-related dampness. Thus, it need not be strictly categorized by geographical regions. Whether the cause is internal or external, any invasion of harmful qi resulting in illness that begins in the feet and gradually leads to other symptoms is referred to as beriberi. It is essential to investigate the cause and to treat it; if done correctly, there will be no errors.[176p]
On Governance

The disease of athlete's foot is indeed caused by the three energies, yet there are also distinctions between deficiency and excess. Furthermore, athlete's foot is fundamentally a condition of stagnation. The ancients cautioned against the use of tonics; however, it is only when the fundamentals are insufficient and the energy of Yangming is impaired that the evil energies are allowed to invade, and there are also cases of deficiency involved. In summary, for all treatments of this condition, it is essential to apply remedies based on the symptoms; thus, management will be thorough. If the cause lies externally, focus primarily on dispersion; if the cause lies internally, emphasize unblocking and benefiting. External causes are often associated with cold and dampness, so warming treatments are advisable; internal causes frequently involve dampness and heat, hence cooling treatments should be employed. If the original energy is fundamentally deficient or if prolonged illness has led to deficiency, it is essential to nourish the foundations and one must not be bound by the notion of avoiding tonics.[177p]
When athlete's foot first appears, it is primarily due to dampness and stagnation. If there are no other concurrent symptoms, and the body feels heavy, then one should focus on treating the dampness, primarily through diuresis.

For general dampness in the feet and knees, or when there is soreness and heaviness in the waist and legs, one should use a dampness-dissipating decoction, regardless of whether the condition is recent or longstanding, or whether it is dry or damp. If there is soreness and heaviness in the feet and knees, accompanied by unclear stomach qi, or symptoms like belching, acid reflux, or fullness, then Ping Wei San (a formula for regulating the stomach) is recommended. For swelling inthe feet accompanied by diarrhea, one should use Wu Ling San or Wei Ling Tang.

When cold and dampness invade from the outside and lead to athlete's foot, this accounts for about sixty to seventy percent of cases. Symptoms typically include pain, cramping, aversion to cold, and a thin, wiry pulse. The treatment should focus on warming the meridians and dispelling dampness. Therefore, ancient remedies primarily used warming herbs and fewer cooling ones, often employing materials like Ma Huang, Chuan Wu, Gui, Fu, and Gan Jiang.

The "Inner Canon" states: "Dampness that prevails within should be treated with bitter and warming herbs." This is why herbs like Wu and Fu, along with Ma Huang, are able to move without obstruction, thus facilitating the circulation of the meridians.[178p]
Cinnamon and dried ginger are hot and spicy, which is why they can aid yang and dispel yin. Once dampness is cleared, no illness remains uncured.

If one is affected by cold dampness from rain or through the seasonal changes, resulting in painful and swollen feet, it is advisable to use Jieming powder like a miracle. If cold dampness invades the body, with yang deficiency and excess yin, weak stomach qi, obstructed menstrual flow, stubborn water retention and persistent pain, use Duhuo decoction. If cold pathogens invade the abdomen, causing breathlessness and pain, or if there is quick, intense discomfort, use Wu zhu yu pills or Wu zhu yu and papaya soup. If cold dampness affects the meridians, causing disharmony in the blood vessels, with soreness and weakness in the waist and legs, or with cramps and pain, along with a weak and sluggish pulse, use liquor-soaked Niuxi pills. If cold dampness causes swelling, with stagnant qi that does not circulate, or accompanied by cold or pain, use Lixiao powder for immediate effect.[179p]
If there is a combination of cold, dampness, and wind, remedies such as Wujisan and Xiao Xueming Decoction are suitable, as detailed later.

  1. Damp heat internally steaming, leading to beriberi, is often due to irregular eating and drinking. The symptoms will include irritability, fever, and excessive thirst, with a slippery and rapid pulse; urination may be excessive or difficult. The treatment should primarily focus on draining dampness and clearing heat. If damp heat stagnates, resulting in swelling and pain in the feet and legs, adjust the Fangji Decoction for treatment; alternatives include Cangzhu Huangbo Pill, Ermiaosan, or the modified Ermiaowan, which are equally effective.

  2. If damp heat obstructs upward, causing chest and abdominal distress, intense thirst, restlessness, headache, and dry mouth, use the Huoren Xijiao Powder.

  3. If damp heat flows into the meridians, causing joint pain, heavy sensation in shoulders and back, and generalized pain and swelling in hands and feet, use the Danggui Nian Tong Wan.

  4. If one has a cold with summer dampness, presenting joint pain, fever, thirst, and reddish urination along with qi deficiency and shortness of breath, use the Qing Shu Yi Qi Decoction.

  5. If liver and kidney yin deficiency leads to blood heat, causing pain in the feet and knees, difficulty in movement, and poor urination, use the Xuduan Wan.[180p]
    If there is a blockage and reverse qi due to edema, the symptoms will include shortness of breath, fullness, and urgent breathing, affecting the heart and abdomen, potentially leading to critical danger. The treatment should primarily focus on moving stagnation and descending qi.

For edema that rises to the heart and abdomen, causing shortness of breath and inability to sleep or lie down, Shi Su San or Bing Lang Tang can be used, or modified versions of Bing Lang Tang, with severe cases requiring Si Mo Yin. If the edema causes shortness of breath, abdominal fullness, and swelling of the legs, Sang Bai Pi San or Mu Tong San should be employed. If there is a rise of qi below the navel, leading to agitation and discomfort in the heart, Mu Xiang San or Bing Lang San is recommended. If there is a feeling of oppression in the chest, with nausea, reverse vomiting, excessive phlegm, and inability to eat, Ban Xia San or Zi Su Tang should be taken. In cases of puffiness, oppression in the heart and abdomen, difficult urination, Da Fu Pi San is appropriate.

In instances where wind-dampness combines with evil to cause edema, the symptoms will necessarily include external pathogens, manifesting as alternating chills and fever, shortness of breath, cough, erratic flow, or pain in the muscles and bones. The treatment should mainly focus on dispersing wind, eliminating dampness, and facilitating the circulation of the meridians.[181p]
If one experiences seasonal winds causing dampness and rheumatism, or resides in a humid place, resulting in weak legs and feet, muscle and joint pain, or alternating chills and fever, use Baidu San. If the chills and fever resemble malaria, with redness and pain, add medicated Baidu San. If the foot condition is due to wind, cold, and dampness invading the meridians, causing unbearable soreness in the bones and marrow, or all-over pain accompanied by chills and nausea, use Wuju San, adding three whole scorpions soaked in wine for preparation. If the foot condition is caused by lingering wind and dampness, with exterior cold blocking, and if there is unrelieved surface evil or symptoms like coughing and wheezing with chills and fever, use Xiao Qing Long Tang. If there is lingering wind and dampness, causing limb and joint pain, and mental distress, use Da Fu Zi San.

The "Thousand Gold" states: if the pulse for the foot condition is large and weak, it is advisable to take two doses of Xiao Xu Ming Tang for prompt recovery.

The "Living Person" states: for foot conditions related to cold, prepare Xiao Xu Ming Tang and take it with fresh ginger juice for the quickest effect.[182p]
If the symptoms of foot qi and rheumatism are severe and accompanied by fever and cough, along with pain in the limbs, use the Xiang Su San. If foot qi and rheumatism present with flowing pain, aversion to cold, fever, and no sweating, use the Ma Huang Zuo Jing Decoction.

For those with foot qi presenting with deficiency signs, the pulses of the spleen, stomach, liver, and kidneys all correspond to the feet. Since external pathogens can easily enter through weaknesses, liver deficiency leads to muscle disorders, kidney deficiency causes bone problems, spleen deficiency results in muscle issues, and stomach deficiency relates to ligament disorders. This may arise from excessive labor, excessive dampness from alcohol, or post-illness imbalances. Those with internal deficiencies and external foot qi symptoms are generally dealing with deficiency conditions. The focus should be on nourishment and supplementation while also considering the four seasonal influences for treatment. If liver and kidney yin are deficient, and one is affected by the four seasonal changes, leading to paralysis, hemiplegia, weakness in the legs and knees, and full-body pain, administer Shen Ying Yang Zhen Dan, or the San Yin Si Jin Wan, or Hu Gu Jiu, or Ba Wei Di Huang Wan.[183p]
If there is great deficiency in the spleen and stomach, with cold yin below, and yang qi not circulating, leading to beriberi, administer Du Huo Decoction or Fuzi Eight Herb Decoction. If there is insufficient essence and blood, with yin deficiency below, and qi not returning to essence, causing beriberi to rise and surge towards the heart, use Rehmannia Decoction. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and stomach, combined with external wind-dampness causing beriberi, use Wind-Inviting Du Huo Decoction or Chasing Poison Decoction. If there is deficiency and cold in the spleen and kidneys accompanied by cough, reversed qi, and vomiting, additionally use Hou Po Decoction.

For beriberi with excess evil, characterized by obstruction, swelling and pain that may lead to blockage or distention, the treatment should primarily aim to expel and resolve. If there is excess wind-dampness causing swollen and painful beriberi, with constipation and abdominal fullness, use Qiang Huo Dao Zhi Decoction or Zhi Shi Da Huang Decoction. If there is an influx of the four qi, with yangming wind-heat, swelling and pain in the waist and feet, constipation, and abdominal pain, administer Da Huang Zuo Jing Decoction. If there is indigestion related to food intake, along with a sensation of fullness beneath the heart and swollen legs and feet, use Kai Jie Dao Yin Pill.

For severe swelling and pain in beriberi, one can use poultices to disperse it, or use pepper and mugwort bags for warmth, or decoct fragrant dispersing herbs for washing. For example, Bai Cao Decoction, along with Fang Feng, Jing Jie, Ling Xian, Ai Ye, Cang Zhu, She Chuang Zi, Dang Gui, and Wu Yao can all be used. Alternatively, single use of Zi Su or Jin Yin Hua, decocted for washing, is also excellent.[184p]
Taboo

It is said in "The Living Man" and other texts that any tonic herbs taken for athlete's foot, and those used for soaking and washing, are prohibited by doctors. This is but a partial view. There are indeed certain tonics that should be avoided, particularly those that might cause stagnation of evil energies. Similarly, certain washing methods should be avoided if they involve water that exacerbates dampness or heat. If the lower body is deficient and cold, whether due to an illness or excessive depletion, and the athlete's foot does not improve, how can one still prohibit tonics? Furthermore, if cold, damp, or hot evils are obstructing and causing swelling or pain, one should use aromatic and dispersive herbs in stews or washes to quickly expel the evils. How can washing be prohibited in such cases? However, if damp heat is rising and disturbing the heart and abdomen, one should not wash abruptly, as this might further elevate dampness. It is essential to first lower the energy; once the toxins are resolved in the feet, washing can be performed without detriment. Toning is for replenishing weakness, while washing is for expelling stagnation. Thus, why should there be any prohibition?

On Ancient Practices

Yang Dashou stated: Athlete's foot is a condition of stagnation; therefore, one should use dispersing agents to prevent energy from becoming stagnant. Remedies like Qianghuo Daodi Decoction and similar ones are effective. Additionally, herbs such as Cangshu, Baizhu, Fangji, and Nanzheng are used to remove dampness; Qianghuo, Duhuo, Mugua, and Binglang help facilitate energy and relieve joint blockages; while guiding herbs like Mutong and Niuxi direct the treatment, and Danggui and Shengdi Huang harmonize the blood. These are essential medicines. Likewise, methods from Dongyuan for pain are also quite effective; I analyze the deficiency or excess of weakness and heat and distinguish treatments accordingly. This represents a flexible approach to healing.[185p]
Crane Knee Wind

In cases where the knees swell and ache while the legs are thin and small, it is called Crane Knee Wind, named for its resemblance to the shape of a crane's knee. Sometimes, it manifests simply as swelling in both knees, with thin and withered legs that cannot bend or stretch, commonly referred to as Drumstick Wind. Ultimately, it results from the afflictions of wind, cold, and dampness. However, swelling and pain must be due to an obstruction, while thinning and withering are usually caused by blood deficiency.

For treating this condition, the primary focus must be on nourishing qi and nourishing blood. If there is wind, one must also dispel it; if there is cold and dampness, these must be eliminated as well. If the condition develops into heat due to obstruction, it is essential to nourish yin and clear heat, and recovery will inevitably follow. If it arises after dysentery, it is also known as Post-Dysentery Wind, as the loss of yin during diarrhea requires strengthening of the kidneys.

For cases with dominance of cold, it is advisable to use formulations like Sanqi Drink, Wujisci Powder, or Da Fang Feng Decoction; for those with dominance of dampness, Wuling Powder or Lijiang Decoction are appropriate; and for heat dominance, Baoyin Decoction or Da Qin Jiao Decoction should be used. If insufficient yang energy leads to failure in the limbs, it is necessary to use Yang Gui Pill, Liyi Decoction, and Eight Ingredients of Rehmannia Pill or similar remedies.[186p]
Secret Prescription of the Stone Chamber
[Qing Dynasty, Chen Shiduo]

Pain in Hands and Feet

If someone experiences pain in their hands and feet, people may attribute it to heat in the spleen channel, not realizing that it is not the spleen but rather the stagnation of liver wood. By dispersing this stagnation, the pain in the hands and feet will go away. Use a prescription of Xiaoyao San (Free and Easy Wanderer Powder) with three qian of gardenia fruit, two qian each of pinellia and white mustard seed, decoct in water and take it. After two doses, the pain will be as if it has vanished. It is said that when the liver wood causes trouble, the spleen does not dare to confront its sharpness, and the qi disperses into the limbs, becoming constrained and unyielding, which is why pain arises. Now, once the liver qi is balanced, the spleen qi will naturally relax. When the spleen relaxes, is there a pain remaining in the hands and feet that cannot be eliminated?

For those with pain in their hands and feet, have one person hold the body while two others gently press down on each leg, one on the left foot and one on the right, lightly tapping them a thousand times. They will feel a slight relief in both feet. Then, use the hand to hold the area between the knee and ankle, gently stretch it seven times, and finally, loosen the grip and knead the feet a thousand times before stopping. Do the same for both hands. Within a day, the pain in the hands and feet can be alleviated.[187p]
For pain in the legs and below the waist, use two liters of yellow wine, half a pound of astragalus, five ounces of Coix seed, one ounce of Eucommia bark, five qian of poria and saposhnikovia, three qian of plantago seeds, and one qian of cinnamon. Boil with a bowl of water until it reduces to two bowls of juice. Add this to the wine, and consuming it will lead to recovery. The aforementioned pains are due to wind entering the limbs, head, between the shoulder blades, and below the waist. The use of yellow wine is essential, as it reaches all pathways, directing the medicinal properties straight to the afflicted areas. The pain in the waist and feet clearly belongs to kidney deficiency and weakened qi, which cannot facilitate movement; coupled with dampness, this results in suffering. The essence lies in not supplementing the kidney but solely boosting qi. Sufficient qi generates blood, and when blood is formed, the pathogens retreat. Additionally, Coix seed, poria, and plantago aid in removing dampness, and with the dampness gone, the blood becomes more vibrant. Moreover, adding Eucommia for strengthening the kidneys, and cinnamon for warming the kidneys, along with saposhnikovia for dispelling wind, creates a synergistic effect. They support and complement each other, which is a natural principle.

For soreness in both legs, this indicates that dampness has penetrated the bones, while there may be no external dampness. The remedy consists of two ounces of Coix seed, one ounce of fox nut, three qian of poria, one qian each of cinnamon and rhizoma of ligusticum, and two qian of achyranthes. Boil with water and take as a decoction.[188p]
The essence of this method lies in the fact that Job's tears can penetrate the bones and eliminate moisture, while adding water chestnut strengthens the spleen to dispel dampness, preventing moisture from accumulating further. Moreover, Achyranthes and Rhizoma Dioscoreae are particularly beneficial for the lower limbs, and with the addition of cinnamon to guide the herbs directly into the bones, how could the dampness remain and how could the pain persist? However, ailments in the feet are the lower aspects of the human body, and any illness is hard to eradicate. Furthermore, when dampness is lodged in the bones, it resembles low-lying land that has long become a pool; simply carting away the water won't suffice. It requires considerable effort before it can be fully drained, thus necessitating prolonged and repeated application, which is precisely the intent here.

Foot pain is prevalent and difficult to treat because the feet represent the lower aspect of the body, and when dampness invades, it accumulates stubbornly. Therefore, one must elevate the vital energy for the dampness to disperse. Nowadays, people often use Pingwei Powder to treat dampness, which is indeed a well-trodden approach, yet it ultimately cannot resolve the dampness completely. I propose a new formula that can thoroughly address the invasion of dampness in the feet.[189p]
This formula prescribes three qian each of ginseng and white atractylodes, one liang of astragalus, and one qian each of fangfeng, chaihu, and cinnamon. It includes five qian each of coix seed, white peony, and water chestnut, five fen of dried tangerine peel, and two qian of pinellia, all to be decocted in water and taken as a remedy. This formula is a divine medicine for expelling dampness. Using fangfeng among astragalus enhances energy and eliminates dampness, while chaihu helps to soothe the qi, making the energy rise even more. When the energy rises, the moisture also enters the spleen. The formula also contains white atractylodes, water chestnut, and coix seed, which are all excellent in removing water and dampness. Could there be any that fails to work?

A person experiences swelling and pain in their thigh, hardened like stone, suffering immensely, wanting to tie their foot with a rope and suspend it from a beam; only then does the pain stop. When placed down, the pain returns as if hacked. With a loud sound, the swelling moves from the thigh up to the upper arm, swelling to the size of a dou (a measure), making sitting impossible. Hanging a cloth bag brings relief; this is also related to supernatural causes.

The formula calls for one liang of raw licorice and three liang of white peony, to be decocted in water. The raw licorice specifically purges toxic gas, while white peony calms the liver to stop pain. When the pain ceases, the swelling can subside; when the toxins are expelled, the supernatural effects can be prevented.[190p]
Numbness in the Hands

Numbness in the hands is caused by a deficiency of vital energy and the invasion of wind and dampness. It is essential to use medicinal substances that enter the hand channels and eliminate wind and dampness for effective treatment. The formula includes five qian each of white atractylodes and astragalus, two qian of ginseng, five fen each of dried tangerine peel, leitchi root, and cinnamon twig, and one qian of licorice, to be boiled in water for consumption. In this formula, astragalus, ginseng, and white atractylodes replenish qi and eliminate dampness, while leitchi root expels wind; however, it is crucial to include cinnamon twig for it to effectively enter the hand channels. Once the meridians are cleared, healing will be achieved.

Redness in the Soles of the Feet

When the soles of the feet are red like fire and cannot touch the ground, and it is not due to phlegm toxins, persisting throughout the year without recovery, this condition arises from the use of hot medicines, leading to congestion of heat in the soles without dispersal, causing prolonged suffering. The proper method is to use internal medications to resolve it. If treated externally, it will likely result in sores on the soles. The formula includes three liang of prepared rehmannia, five qian each of cornelian cherry, poria, and sweet chrysanthemum, three qian each of schisandra, alisma, plantain seed, peony bark, and achyranthes, one liang each of ophiopogon, and two qian of cowbane, boiled in water for consumption. Ten doses will reduce symptoms, and twenty doses will lead to complete recovery. Sexual activities should be avoided for three months; otherwise, a relapse may occur, which could be fatal.[191p]
Loss of Hands and Feet

There is evidence that when a person loses their hands and feet, they do not necessarily die. This occurs during a time of typhoid, when excessive thirst leads to drinking cold water to temporarily quench the thirst. Little do they know that the water stagnates in the abdomen and cannot be promptly dispersed, resulting in illness in the limbs, causing qi and blood to be obstructed. Over time, the hands and feet may rot, leading to the loss of fingers and toes. Sometimes, after losing toes, the soles can also rot, and eventually, the entire soles may fall off.

If someone with typhoid experiences extreme thirst and drinks too much cold water, should they recover but find their fingers and toes emerging from the water, they should urgently use my remedy to address the loss of fingers and soles. The formula consists of three taels of coix seeds, two taels of poria, one qian of cinnamon, one tael of white atractylodes, and five qian of plantago seeds, boiled in water and taken as a decoction. This should be done for ten consecutive doses. It will promote urination and prevent the emergence of fingers and toes. There will be no future complications, and additional doses are unnecessary.[192p]

Nail Loss

Some people have their fingernails completely drop off, with no pain or itchiness. This is due to a deficiency in the fire of the kidney channel. After engaging in sexual activity and washing their hands with cold water, this condition arises. The treatment is to use Six Flavor Decoction with the addition of Chai Hu, Bai Shao, and Gu Sui Bu to achieve recovery.

Bleeding Between the Fingers

Some individuals experience continuous bleeding between their fingers, with tiny insects similar to mayflies emerging and quickly able to fly away. This condition is caused by damp heat generating insects. However, why can these insects fly? This is because it is not only damp heat involved but also accompanied by wind pathogenic factors. All insects that are affected by wind can have wings and fly. How can they not fly when the wind energy affects the human body? The prescription consists of Bai Zhu, Fu Ling, Dong Gui, Bai Shao, and Sheng Gan Cao each at 9 grams, Ren Shen, Chai Hu, Chuan Xiong, and Jing Jie each at 3 grams, and Shu Di, Huang Qi, and Yi Ren each at 25 grams, to be boiled and consumed as a decoction. The brilliance of this formula lies in that it does not focus on killing the insects but instead nourishes Qi and blood, while also helping to eliminate dampness and wind. When the Qi and blood in the human body are harmonious, insects naturally do not arise. By nourishing the harmony of Qi and blood, there will be no place for insects to hide. Furthermore, by dispelling water and wind, where can the insects live? This is what makes this formula both simple and remarkable. After taking four doses, the bleeding ceases and the insects do not emerge. After taking another four doses, the fingers will return to their original condition.[193p]
Sudden Elevation in the Palm

Within the palm, a sudden elevation of an inch occurs, without pain or itch. This is due to the fire of the Yangming channel not dispersing and accumulating in the hand. Typically, it should cause pain or itch, but now there is none. Not only is the fire congested in the pores, but also water is blocked in the skin. The method should employ external medicine to dissipate it. The fire of Yangming being intense must lead to thirst, prompting continual drinking. However, the absence of thirst suggests that the fire in the stomach has completely dispersed, turning into poison in the palm. This indicates that the individual's Yangming fire was initially strong, and pressing the hand against a bed or mat forcefully impeded the circulation of qi and blood in the palm. Over time, the elevation occurs without pain or itch, essentially becoming dead flesh.

Using a decoction of Aconite, soak the hand until it cools, and continue this for ten days. Eventually, there will certainly be pain, and further soaking will lead to itch, after which the elevated area will flatten. Aconite is extremely warming, entering through all meridians; even external application will penetrate internally. If Aconite is used in a soup for drinking, it will warm the entire body and stimulate the stomach fire, preventing the flesh of the palm from dissipating while internally causing a rise in heat. This is why I treat it externally to achieve healing. Additionally, in the Aconite decoction, adding a little light powder can draw it into the bone marrow for even more remarkable effects.[194p]
Flesh Lump on the Calf

When a person develops a large flesh lump above the calf, resembling a tumor yet not exactly a tumor, and upon pressing it causes excruciating pain, it is due to dampness from the spleen channel condensing into this lump, compounded by internal heat that isn't dispelled. Hence, it should not be pressed; pressing it intensifies the pain to the point of despair. The appropriate treatment is to vigorously tonify the spleen's energy and disperse the dampness. However, as it expresses externally in an odd form, eliminating it internally at once may not be easy. Therefore, a method of simultaneous internal and external attack should be employed for natural resolution.

For the internal remedy, use one liang each of white atractylodes, job's tears, and fox nut; five qian of water plantain; five fen of cinnamon; three qian each of plantago seed, ginseng, rhizoma dioscoreae, white alum, and white mustard seed; two qian each of pinellia, dried tangerine peel, and achyranthes; and decoct in water for two doses.

For the external medicine, roast one liang of earthworm feces; one qian of mercury; five fen each of borneol and musk; one fen of borax; roast five qian of berberis; and three qian of catechu, grinding them into a fine powder until the mercury is undetectable.

Prepare a paste from this herbal powder, mixing it with vinegar, and apply it to the afflicted area. In just one day, it will be entirely resolved, exhibiting remarkable effectiveness! For any lump, treat internally and externally with this method, and the results will inevitably follow.[195p]
If someone develops two fingers beneath their foot, causing unbearable pain, it is due to the accumulation of damp-heat, specifically offending the spirits. Take one part borax, one tael of scallion, three parts ice fragments, and one qian of ginseng, and grind them into a powder. Lightly prick the area to draw blood, applying the powder to the spot where the fingers appear. Water will quickly flow forth; apply it to the area in a star-like pattern where the blood flows, mixing as needed until the blood has drained. If it flows for three days, it'll stop, and the pain will lessen. Next, use five qian of white atractylodes, three qian each of raw licorice, ginseng, cattle knee, spatholobus, and white mustard seed, one tael of job's tears, and one qian of pinellia. Decoct in water for four doses, which can lead to full recovery and the disappearance of the fingers as they dissolve into water. For external treatment, apply a plaster combined with skin-regenerating powder for healing.

Formula: Xiao Jian Zhong Tang [Zhong Jing, same below]
For treating the exhaustion causing aches and pains in the limbs, with feelings of heat in hands and feet:
Three taels of cinnamon twig (peeled), three taels of licorice (roasted), three taels of fresh ginger, six taels of peony root, twelve red dates, and one sheng of honey syrup.
Combine these six ingredients, with seven sheng of water, boil down to three sheng, strain, add the honey syrup, and continue dissolving over a low flame. Warmly consume one sheng, three times a day.

Cui’s Eight Flavor Pill
For treating foot disease that ascends and causes numbness in the lower abdomen:

Yue Pi Decoction treats wind bi and weak legs.

Foot Qi Formula treats the initial onset of foot qi, from the feet up to swelling and pain in the knee and shin bones.
