Siwu Fuzitang

This formula is used to treat wind and dampness attacking the body, resulting in painful bones and joints, stiffness of the limbs, inability to bend or stretch, increased pain upon approach, spontaneous sweating and shortness of breath, difficulty in urination, aversion to wind and reluctance to remove clothing, and occasional swelling of the head, face, hands, and feet.

  • Zhishi (2 liang)
  • Mahuang (2 liang)
  • Gandi Huang (2 liang)
  • Shaoyao (2 liang)
  • Guixin (1 liang)
  • Beizi (7 pieces)
  • Dazao (10 pieces)

Preparation: Use 16 ingredients, chew them, add 12 liters of water, boil until you have 3.5 liters. Divide into four doses, taking three doses during the day and one at night.

Fangfeng Tang: For treating foot Qi disorders, as well as toxic qi rising, causing nausea and accumulation of gases in the chest, suitable for regular consumption.

Ingredients:

  • Fangfeng (1 liang)
  • Mahuang (1 liang)
  • Xiangfu (1 liang)
  • Renshen (1 liang)
  • Shaoyao (1 liang)
  • Danggui (1 liang)
  • Fuling (1 liang)
  • Banxia (1 liang)
  • Gancao (1 liang)
  • Jupi (1 liang)
  • Bieqiao (2 liang)
  • Shengjiang (2 liang)
  • Guixin (2 liang)
  • Xingren (halved, 2 pieces)
  • Chixiaodou (1 sheng)
  • Beizi (5 pieces)
  • Wumei (5 pieces)
  • Dazao (20 pieces)
  • Wuyu (5 he)
  • Xijiao (0.5 liang)
  • Lingyangjiao (0.5 liang)
  • Xiebai (14 pieces)

Preparation: Use 22 ingredients, chew them, add 10 liters of water, boil until you have 3 liters, divide into three doses to be taken in one day. One recipe uses 12 liters of water, consumed with porridge. Another recipe uses 2 liang of Banxia, used as needed.[209p]
Fangfeng Decoction treats symptoms of a weak body with wind, mild spasms, fever, joints that do not move freely, confusion, and erratic speech that occurs without awareness. In southern regions, it is often applied, being effective, gentle, and not reliant on forced methods. It surpasses decoctions like Xiangming, Yuebi, and Fengyin. It is commonly used by the Luo family in Guangzhou and by scholars in southern provinces. It is also highly effective for weakness of the legs.

Ingredients:

  • Gypsum (half tael)
  • Fangfeng
  • Mahuang
  • Duhuo
  • Fresh ginger
  • Qinjiao
  • Banxia (each one tael)
  • Musk (six zhū)
  • Dongguai
  • Yuanzhi
  • Licorice
  • Fangji
  • Ginseng
  • Huangqin
  • Shengma
  • Shaoyao (each one tael)

Combine these sixteen ingredients, grind them, and use water (13 liters) to boil and reduce to four liters. The dose is one liter per serving. At first, cover warmly to induce a slight sweat, and it should lead to two or three bowel movements. Between doses, space them as if walking for ten miles.

In one method, add one tael of Baizhu. If there is heat, add two taels of Dahuang. For those with a prior cold heartache, double the dose of Dongguai and add three taels of Guixin, and do not use Dahuang.[210p]
Glycyrrhiza Decoction: For treating weakness in the legs, generalized swelling, gastric reflux with vomiting of food, chest tightness and discomfort, persistent cold and heat with diarrhea, difficulty urinating; taking this decoction will result in recovery. It is also effective when combined with Nü Qu San to promote urination, reduce swelling, and with Da San Mo Gao, effective results have been observed.

Ingredients:

  • 2 sheng of Wu Zhu Yu
  • 1 liang each of Glycyrrhiza and Ginseng
  • 1 sheng of Ban Xia
  • 3 liang each of Gui Xin and Shu Jiao
  • 8 he of wheat
  • 20 Da Zao
  • 8 liang of fresh ginger

The above nine ingredients should be ground, boiled in 13 sheng of water, and after cooking the wheat to obtain 10 sheng, remove the wheat, add the herbs, and boil to yield 3 sheng, divided into six doses.

Hengshan Glycyrrhiza Decoction: If cold and heat recur multiple times a day, this formula can be taken.

Ingredients:

  • 3 liang of Hengshan
  • 1.5 liang of Glycyrrhiza

These two ingredients should be ground, boiled with 4 sheng of water to yield 1.5 sheng, divided into three doses, taken five li apart.

Dan Shen and Niu Xi Decoction: For treating weakness and numbness in the legs, with slight swelling all over the body.

Ingredients:

  • 4 liang each of Dan Shen, Niu Xi, Sang Bai Pi, Xing Ren, Sheng Ma, Fu Ling, and Zhu Ling
  • 2 liang each of Xi Jiao, Huang Qin, Ju Pi, Fang Ji, Bai Qian, Ze Xie, Gui Xin, and Qin Jiao
  • 2 liang each of fresh ginger and Li Gen Bai Pi
  • 2 sheng of Da Ma Ren

These eighteen ingredients should be crushed, coarsely sifted, mixed with 1.5 sheng of water, and boiled with a spoonful of the decoction until 7 he is obtained. Filter through a fine cloth, take all at once, twice daily. Avoid using pills or powders in hot summer weather. This decoction should be used regularly throughout the year and has proven effective.[211p]
Xiao Xu Ming Tang (from "Huo Ren Shu")
For treating weak legs due to foot edema, unable to turn sides.

  1. Prepare 5 qian of fresh Aconite, peeled and trimmed.
  2. 1.5 liang of Fang Feng
  3. Bai Shao, Bai Zhu, Ren Shen, Chuan Xiong, and Ma Huang (remove joints), soaked in water three times and then dried.
  4. 1 liang each of Fang Ji, Huang Qin, Gui Zhi, and Gan Cao.

Grind the above until they are the size of mung beans. Each dose consists of 5 qian, mixed with 1.5 cups of water, decoct until reduced to 1 cup, discard the residue, take 80% of the clear liquid, add ginger juice, and boil for one or two more rounds. Drink warm, three times during the day and twice at night.

Shen Gong Wan Zi He
For treating the downward flow of wind, waist pain, heaviness of the legs, bloating and pain below the navel, and urine that is red like gold.

  1. 3 liang of Da Huang
  2. 0.5 liang of Ren Shen
  3. 5 liang of Ma Zi Ren, ground separately
  4. 2 liang of He Zi peel, roasted.

Grind the above into a fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of catalpa seeds. Each dose consists of 20 pills, taken with warm water, three times a day, adjusted according to effect.[212p]
Wurou Pill treats elderly individuals with deficiency and beriberi, dryness of body fluids, constipation, and regulates the Sanjiao.

Ingredients:

  • 4 taels of Dahuang (rhubarb)

Crush these ingredients into a fine powder, refine with honey to make pills the size of a phoenix seed, ingest twenty pills with warm water to ensure smoothness.

Binglang Powder treats swelling of the feet.

Ingredients:

Boil these ingredients together several times, then mix 2 qian (10 grams) of Binglang powder and take after meals.

Chi Fuling Pills treats excessive spleen dampness, swelling of the limbs, abdominal distension, shortness of breath, inability to circulate qi, and red and painful urination.

Grind these into a powder, form into jujube-sized pills. Take thirty pills, wash down with a decoction of Sangbai Pi (white mulberry bark), before meals. According to one version, use 1 tael of Chi Fuling.[213p]
Damp-Removing Pill: Treats various damp-related swellings, heavy pain in the waist and knees, and floating edema in the feet and shins.

Ingredients:

  • Frankincense, ground - 1 liang
  • Myrrh, ground - 1 liang
  • Qian Niu Tou powder - 0.5 liang
  • Stir-fried Da Ji - 3 liang
  • Areca nut - 2 liang

  • Red peony - 2 liang
  • Ze Xie - 2 liang
  • Ting Li - 2 liang
  • Gan Sui - 2 liang
  • Aged tangerine peel, white part removed - 4 liang

Combine these into a fine powder, form into pills the size of a Chinese parasol seed. Take 50 to 80 pills each time with warm water before meals. If there are changes in clothing, stop taking after. Avoid alcohol for two days before and after taking the medicine, and maintain a dry face for two to three days. After meals, consuming warm, light porridge is especially beneficial for the stomach.

Wu Ai Pill: Treats spleen disorders causing excessive flow, with swelling in the limbs.

Ingredients:

  • Mu Xiang - 0.5 liang

  • Jing San Ling, toasted - 1 liang

  • Da Fu Pi - 2 liang

Grind these six ingredients into a fine powder, and crush malt into a fine powder. Form pills the size of a Chinese parasol seed. Take 20 pills each time with ginger soup, at any time.

Modified Bai Tong Decoction: Treats cold sensations, drinking cold, self-laxative stools, undigested grains, cold pain in the abdomen, and coldness in the feet and shins.

Ingredients:

  • Stir-fried Fu Zi, skin and navel removed - 1 liang
  • Dry ginger, stir-fried - 1 liang
  • Gui Pi (Cinnamon) - skin removed
  • Zhi Gan Cao - half a liang
  • Ban Xia, soaked in soup - half a liang
  • Grass cardamom powder wrapped in moist cloth - half a liang
  • Ren Shen - half a liang
  • Bai Zhu - half a liang

Combine these eight ingredients, chew, and take 5 qian each time with 2.5 bowls of water, 5 slices of ginger, and 5 green onions, simmer until reduced to a third. Strain, take on an empty stomach when old food is completely digested, warm.[214p]
Jìjì Detoxifying Decoction treats heat in the upper body, causing redness, swelling, and pain in the head, chest oppression, inability to lie comfortably, and coldness below the waist, particularly severe in the knees and feet, with slightly constipated stools. Ingredients include:

  • Dàhuáng (Rhizoma Rhei) prepared with wine
  • Jùgēng (Platycodon)
  • Huánglián (Coptis), stir-fried with wine
  • Gāncaǐ (Licorice), roasted

  • Dāngguī (Angelica sinensis)
  • Liánqiáo (Forsythia), one qian each

The above, ground into a single dose, boiled with two cups of water until reduced to one cup, strained, and taken warm after meals. Avoid exposure to damp conditions, strong spices, and raw or cold food.

Yú (Insect Qi) Pill treats gout in the knees and lower back. Dr. Hú Chǔwàng had a condition where his hands and feet were swollen and painful, resembling peaches and plums, and was fully cured after taking this.

Ingredients include:

  • Yú (Insect Qi), a whole specimen
  • Bái fùzǐ (Latex of Raphanus)
  • Āwēi (Ferula), ground
  • Guìxīn (Cinnamon inner bark)
  • Bái zhǐ (Angelica dahurica), each one liǎng (50 grams)
  • Rǔxiāng (Frankincense) three fen
  • Dāngguī (Angelica sinensis)
  • Lòulú (Reeds)
  • Sháoyào (Peony)
  • Wēilíngxiān (Corydalis)
  • Dìgǔpí (Rehmannia root)
  • Chuān niúxī (Achyranthes)
  • Qiānghuó (Notopterygium)
  • Ānxíxiāng (Benzoin)
  • Táorén (Peach kernel), each one liǎng

The above sixteen ingredients, including the nine main components Yú, Táorén, Bái fùzǐ, Āwēi, Guìxīn, Bái zhǐ, Ānxíxiāng, Rǔxiāng, and Mòyào (Myrrh), are mixed with two shēng (approximately 400 ml) of the child’s urine and wine, stir-fried until hot, then allowed to cool. The residue is combined into a powder, formed into hollow pills the size of a marble, and taken with warm wine, without restriction on timing.[215p]
Comprehensive Compendium of Books from Ancient and Modern Times, Volume 193

Four Limbs Section

Prescription

Chaihu Shengma Decoction by Dongyuan, for treating both men and women with fever in the limbs, hot muscles, and heated bones. The exterior feels as if it is scorched by fire, and can be felt with the hand as if burned. The four limbs are associated with the Spleen and Earth. When heat is trapped in the ground, this illness often arises from blood deficiency. Additionally, there may be stomach deficiency and excessive consumption of cold foods, which obstructs Yang energy within the Spleen and Earth. This medicine addresses the condition.

Ingredients:

  • Fangfeng (Siler) 2.5 taels
  • Shengma (Rhizoma Cimicifugae) 5 taels
  • Gegen (Pueraria) 5 taels
  • Duhuo (Angelica) 5 taels
  • Qianghuo (Notopterygium) 5 taels
  • Baishao (White Peony) 5 taels
  • Renshen (Ginseng) 5 taels
  • Zhi gan cao (Honey-fried Licorice) 3 taels
  • Chaihu (Bupleurum) 3 taels
  • Sheng gan cao (Raw Licorice) 2 taels

Use the above ingredients, work them into a powder, take 5 taels with 2 large cups of water, boil until reduced to 1 cup, strain, and take warm. Avoid cold substances.[216p]
Fire Stagnation Decoction treats the vexation and heat of the five hearts. This is due to fire stagnating in the earth; the limbs represent the spleen's earth. Heart fire sinks into the spleen's earth, becoming stagnant and unable to extend. The classics say: "When fire is stagnant, it must be released."

For the ingredients:

  • 1 tael each of Sheng Ma, Ge Gen, Chai Hu, and Bai Shao Yao;
  • 5 qian each of Fang Feng and Gan Cao.

Crush the above, and for each dose, use 5 qian with 2 large bowls of water, adding 3 inches of onion white. Boil until reduced to 1 bowl, strain, warm slightly, and take at any time.

Removing Dampness and Supplementing Qi Decoction treats leg numbness, heaviness without strength, excessive sweating, joyfulness, salivation, a heavy body like a mountain, and a voice that doesn't come out, with a pulse that is large and soft.

For the ingredients:

  • 6 qian of Sheng Ma;
  • 4 qian of Cang Zhu;
  • 3 qian each of Chai Hu and Huang Qi (fried in yellow vine liquor);
  • 2 qian each of Jizhi Ben, Sheng Gan Cao, and Dang Gui;
  • 1.5 qian each of Wu Wei Zi and Chen Pi.

Grind these to the size of large mung beans. For each dose, take 5 qian with 2 bowls of water, boil until reduced to 1 bowl, strain, and take on an empty stomach. Wait a little while, then follow with breakfast.[217p]
Ginseng Beneficial Qi Decoction
For treating numbness in the fingers, fatigue in the limbs, laziness, and excessive sleeping, which are caused by heat injuring the original Qi.

  • Huang Qi (Astragalus) 8 qian

Crush the ingredients above and divide into four doses. For each dose, use 2 sheng of water, decoct to 1 sheng, strain, slightly warm, and take before meals.

Crush the ingredients above and divide into four doses. For each dose, use 2 da sheng of water, decoct to 1 sheng, strain, and take hot before meals.

Middle Supplementing Decoction
For treating pale complexion, excessive sweating, red eyes, heaviness in the limbs, reduced appetite, regular abdominal pains, coughing, and short pulse in both hands. The right hand pulse is thin and choppy, and the guan pulse is weak.

  • Sheng Ma (Cimicifuga) 2 fen
  • Chai Hu (Bupleurum) 2 fen
  • Dang Gui Shen (Angelica) 2 fen
  • Shen Qu (Medicated Leaven) 3 fen, roasted
  • Ze Xie (Alisma) 4 fen
  • Hong Hua (Safflower) a little
  • Da Mai Qu (Barley Ferment) 5 fen
  • Cang Zhu (Atractylodes) 5 fen
  • Huang Qi (Astragalus) 2 qian 5 fen
  • Zhi Gan Cao (Honey-fried Licorice) 8 fen
  • Wu Wei Zi (Schisandra) 20 pieces

Crush the ingredients above and divide into two doses. For each dose, use 2 sheng of water, decoct to 1 sheng, strain, and take before meals.[218p]
Sheng Yang Yi Wei Decoction: Treats spleen and stomach deficiency, lethargy and a tendency to sleep, with limbs that do not retract.

Ingredients:

  • Astragalus (Huangqi) 2 taels
  • Pinellia (Banzhu) - if symptoms of phlegm are present, use
  • Ginseng (Renshen) and licorice (Gancao), both 1 tael
  • Angelica (Duhuo), wind protection (Fángfēng), white peony (Báisháo), and Qianghuo, each 5 qian
  • Tangerine peel (Jùzǐ) 4 qian

Additive Cangfu Powder: (from "Introduction to Medicine") Treats damp-heat in foot and ankle swellings.

Ingredients:

Grind these into a paste, add 3 slices of ginger, and decoct to take warm.

Fangji Drink

For treating athlete’s foot, it is essential to expel the dampness.

Ingredients:

  • Baizhu (white atractylodes)
  • Mouton (pu'er tea)
  • Fangji (stephania)
  • Bingtang (betel nut)
  • Chuanxiong (ligusticum wallichii)

  • Xijiao (rhinoceros horn)

  • Huanglian (coptis) roasted in wine
  • Shengdi (raw rehmannia) roasted in wine

Mix the above ingredients equally, chew and decoct with water for consumption. For hard stools, add Tao Ren (peach kernels), and for cloudy urination, add Duzhong (eucommia) and Niu Xi. If there is heat, add Huangqin (scutellaria) and Huanglian (coptis), and if there is major heat, add Shigao (gypsum) timely; if there is phlegm, add Zhuli (bamboo sap) and ginger juice. If there is persistent swelling, it is particularly due to damp heat, so use the following formula.

Ying Tong Pill: Treats unbearable foot pain, this medication is a precautionary remedy.

Recipe for ulcer treatment:

  • Frankincense
  • Myrrh
  • Mercury
  • Angelica: each half a tael
  • Sichuan lovage root
  • Fritillaria bulb
  • Yellow lead: each two and a half qian
  • True hemp oil: five taels

Grind the ingredients (excluding yellow lead and mercury); first, use fragrant oil to fry the other ingredients until black, then remove the residue and add yellow lead and mercury, cook again until black. Stir together with a willow branch into a paste, then apply with oil paper.

Another Recipe:

  • Raw dragon bone
  • Blood resin
  • Red clay
  • Yellow wax: each one tael
  • Hair (about the thickness of a finger)
  • White fragrant gum
  • Fragrant oil: quantity at discretion

First, fry the hair in fragrant oil until bubbling, remove the hair, then add yellow wax and white fragrant gum, mixing thoroughly. Place into a water bowl, wait to cool, then transfer into magnetic ware. For each ulcer, tear off a thin slice and place it on the sore, covering with bamboo leaves. After three days, replace the slice, continuing to take blood-activating medicine.[221p]
Experience with Prevention and Treatment

Treatment for pain in the legs after dysentery, appearing like a cut or bite from a tiger, with swollen knees, making walking difficult, known as Crane Knee Wind.

  • Rehmannia glutinosa, ginseng, each 3 grams;
  • Atractylodes macrocephala, Astragalus, Angelica sinensis, Chuanxiong, white peony root, Eucommia, and Rhizoma Alisma, each 4.5 grams;
  • Saposhnikovia, Stephania, Qianghuo, Cowherb, and licorice, each 2.5 grams;
  • Aconite, soaked in children’s urine for three days, processed, 4.5 grams; in winter, 6 grams.
  • Crush together, make into a plaster, with three slices of ginger and two dates, decoct in water and take.

Five Beast Three Preservation Pills

To treat depletion of blood and qi, insufficiency of liver and kidney, with weak and soft legs.

  • Deer antler, Qi Lin horn, tiger femur, cowherb, and golden hair dog spine, each in equal parts, these are the five beasts;
  • One piece of aconite, skin removed, center dug out, filled with realgar;
  • One piece of papaya, skin removed, center dug out, inside which the aconite is placed and covered with aconite powder, this is the three preservations.
  • Place the three preservations in a clay jar, steam in heavy water until very soft, take out and mix with the five beasts, rolling into pills the size of chestnuts, to be taken with papaya wine.

Pine Resin Decoction

For treatment of foot qi encroachment into the abdomen, with bloating, urgency, restlessness, and swelling pain.

  • Toasted pine resin, mulberry bark, and perilla leaves, each 30 grams;
  • Betel nut 10 grams, licorice 25 grams;
  • For every 10 grams, add twenty strands of lampwick, three slices of fresh ginger, and 15 ml of children’s urine; decoct and take.[222p]
    Red Flower Canglong Pill: Treats swelling in the feet and shins, suitable for women as well. Ingredients: Cangzhu, Huangbai, Honghua, Niuxi, Shengdi Huang, Nanshing, Longdancao, Chuanxiong, all in equal parts. Grind to powder, form into pills with wine.

Betel Nut Canglong Pill: Treats damp-heat and food accumulation, phlegm, and fluid retention. Ingredients: Huangbai, Binglang, Cangzhu, Fangji, Nanshing, Chuanxiong, Baizhi, Xijiao, all in equal parts. Grind to powder, form into pills with wine. If blood is deficient, add Niuxi and Guiban; for obese patients, add phlegm-removing medicine.

Qianghuo Daizhi Decoction: Treats the initial onset of beriberi, severe body pain, and swollen painful joints, with obstructed urination. First use this medicine to relieve, then follow with a Danggui Pain Relief Decoction to eliminate the evil. Treats wind-qi stagnation leading to foot edema; often feels slightly swollen, may cause pain when manifested.

Continuation of Bone Elixir
This is for treating weakness in the legs, fatigue and lack of strength, as well as for children who cannot walk. Use the following ingredients:

Mulberry Branch Decoction
This treats weakness in the knees and legs caused by wind.
Use 3 sheng (about 720 ml) of mulberry branches, fresh Fuzhi (Aconite) — 5 liang,
and 1 sheng each of eggplant root and black beans. Combine these four ingredients, add 3 dou (about 6 liters) of water, and boil down to 1 dou (about 2 liters). Strain out the dregs and boil down to 5 sheng (about 1.2 liters), then add the following powdered herbs:

  • Shihu (Dendrobium) with the roots removed,
  • Tianxiong (Aconite) that is pounded and peeled,
  • Tianma,
  • Niuxi,
  • Chuanqiang,
  • Gui Xin (Cinnamon bark) — each 2 liang.

Grind these into powder and mix into the previous decoction. In a silver pot, simmer over low heat, constantly stirring with a willow wood spatula until it reaches a syrupy consistency. Store in a ceramic box. Every day, on an empty stomach, mix with hot wine and take with a teaspoon, and it is especially effective if taken again before the evening meal.[225p]
Cangzhu Powder treats wind and dampness, and regular consumption strengthens muscles and bones, enhancing walking. Use one pound of Cangzhu, soak it in millet waste water, scrape off the sinews and skins with a bamboo knife, and then soak half a pound in the urine of a young boy; soak another half pound in good wine without ash. Soak according to the seasons: five days in spring, three days in summer, seven days in autumn, and ten days in winter. After soaking, take the Cangzhu out and dig a pit on clean ground, use charcoal fire to heat the pit until red, then pour the soaked Cangzhu wine and urine into the pit. Place the Cangzhu inside, cover it with a clay vessel, seal it with mud, and let it rest overnight. Afterward, take out the Cangzhu, grind it into a fine powder, and take two qian with warm salt water or wine.

Frankincense and Myrrh Pill treats long-term and recent issues like wind and dampness affecting the feet and knees, causing swelling or pain, with muscles cramping and unable to bend or stretch, preventing the foot from touching the ground, and any form of unbearable pain. Grind frankincense separately, grind myrrh separately, prepare one ounce of bone fragments without hair, one ounce of cardamom, one ounce of five spices without soil, one ounce of white zhuzi, one ounce of sweet melon seeds, soak ox knee in wine, stir-fry angelica in wine, one ounce of papaya, and one ounce of earthworm cleaned of soil, and one ounce of lucerne, lightly stir-fried. Grind all into a fine powder, boil with wine to form a paste for pills the size of a zelkova seed. Take twenty pills each time, swallow with papaya soup or warm wine, and there are no restrictions on when to take them.[226p]

Fangfeng Decoction: Treats foot qi obstruction and weakness, with remarkable efficacy.
Ingredients:

  • One tael each of Fangfeng (Saposhnikovia), Fangji (Stephania), Shu Jiao (Zanthoxylum), Xixin (Asarum), Gui Xin (Cinnamon heart), Ma Huang (Ephedra), Shigao (Gypsum), Duhuo (Angelica), Huangqin (Scutellaria), Yin Yu (Artemisia), Gegen (Pueraria), Chuanxiong (Ligusticum), Shaoyao (Paeonia), and Licorice.
  • Two taels each of fresh ginger and Fuling (Poria).
  • Two pieces of Wu Tou (Aconitum).

Prepare by chewing the above and boiling with one dou (approx. 10 liters) of bamboo juice until reduced to four sheng (approx. 1 liter), dividing into six doses to be taken over a day and a night. During this period, one may regularly consume adzuki bean tea.

If someone experiences weakness in the feet, they should first take four doses of the commonly used bamboo juice soup, and if they don't notice any change, then use this formula to feel stronger. It is also said: if the pulse is deep, thin, and quick, indicating internal wind, this decoction is recommended. If one lacks bamboo juice and adzuki beans, take three qian (approx. 10 grams) with a large cup of water, three slices of fresh ginger, and boil down to seven parts, strain, and take warm at any time.[227p]

Steaming Method: Treats weakness of kidney energy, and the spleen, kidney, and liver meridians affected by wind, cold, and dampness, which accumulate in the legs and knees, causing stagnation of the meridians and resulting in leg numbness and pain. This medicine nourishes the body and unblocks the meridians.
Ingredients:

  • One handful each of small pepper and salt
  • Three large handfuls of scallions, chopped
  • Five liters of wheat bran
  • One cup of wine

Combine above ingredients with vinegar to appropriate moisture, stirring daily. Fry in a silver vessel until very hot. Spread beneath a bed, placing the affected legs under the steam. Cover with thin clothing and blanket, allowing for uniform sweating for about half an hour. Remove the fried bran, lie down on bedding, and rest for one to two hours. Second Prescription: Du Huo Decoction
Four liang of Du Huo, three liang of cooked Rehmannia, five liang of fresh ginger, two liang each of Kudzu root, Cinnamon heart, Honey-fried Licorice, Peony root, and Ephedra. Crush these ingredients, using eight sheng of water and two sheng of clear rice wine, boil together to yield two and a half sheng. Divide into four doses, taking three doses during the day and one at night. Third Prescription: Combined Supplement with Hou Po Decoction
Treats various coughs and the counterflow of qi leading to vomiting. Two liang each of Magnolia Bark, Cyperus, Cinnamon heart, cooked Rehmannia, Peony root, Angelica, and Ginseng; three liang each of Astragalus and Honey-fried Licorice; seven liang of Wu Zhu Yu; one jin of fresh ginger. Lixiao San - Treatment for Athlete's Foot Attacking the Heart.

Large areca nuts, seven pieces; two taels of fresh ginger; one tael each of tangerine peel, Wu Zhu Yu (lugol), Zi Su (perilla), and papaya. Chop all into small pieces, then boil with two liters of water until reduced to one liter and two cups, taking in divided doses.

Cortex Cistanche and Achyranthes Bidentata Pill - Treatment for Athlete’s Foot.

Clean and dry meat cistanche; dry and chop Achyranthes bidentata; clean and dry Tian Ma (gastrodia); grind all mentioned into small pieces. Using three liters of wine, seal in a bottle, and take out after spring for five days, summer for three, autumn for seven, and winter for ten days; dry it to a powder. Select and wash Goji berries, honey-fried Astragalus, tiger bone soaked in wine and roasted. Prepare each of these in equal parts, two taels. Grind everything finely and mix well; using the previously soaked medicinal wine, make a dough to form pills the size of a phoenix seed. Dry these and take three to fifty pills before meals, washed down with warm wine or clear broth.

Frankincense and Papaya Pill - Specifically Treats Long-term Recent Athlete’s Foot.

Grind frankincense separately; grind blood resin separately, in equal parts. Mix thoroughly with one papaya, using a bamboo knife to remove the skin and core, take the top cover off, mix in the powdered medicine until full, put the top cover back on, wrap it in dough about half a finger thick, and cook in a clay pot until thoroughly soft. Pound it in a stone mortar until it becomes a paste, making pills the size of a phoenix seed. Start with thirty-nine pills, gradually increasing to forty, taken on an empty stomach with warm wine or papaya soup. Avoid moving air, cold, damp, and oily foods.[243p]
Gān Biē Sàn - Treatment for athlete's foot.
Remove the shells from two wood locust fruits, one male and one female. Take one liang of linked sweet dates. Grind these into fine powder. Take two pig kidneys, split them open, mix one qian of the powdered medicine inside, wrap in paper, and steam over fire until cooked. Allow to cool. At the beginning of the fifth watch, chew finely and wash down with rice soup. If the left foot is afflicted, use the left kidney; if the right foot, use the right kidney. Only one qian of the powdered medicine is needed.

Dú Huó Jiǔ - Treatment for weak knees and feet, accompanied by dizziness and fullness in the head.
Use three liang each of Duhuo, Dendrobium, white peony, and white Atractylodes. Use two liang each of Oxtongue, Salvia, and Cibotium (with skin and navel removed). Two liang of Spurling and Coix seeds, and one and a half liang each of Siler, Cassia, Ginseng, and prepared Angelica. Four liang of fried Rehmannia, finely shaved. Place the mixture in a silk bag and store it in a clean ceramic jar. Soak in three dou of clear wine, seal tightly. In spring and summer, leave for five days; in autumn and winter, seven days. Decant and drink according to need, five to six doses each day, ensuring the potency of the wine does not diminish. If cold, add one liang of Sichuan pepper, removing eyes and closing the mouth, and stir to induce sweating. For severe weakness and pain in the feet, make a powder, taking three qian each time, mixed with wine to consume.[244p]

Chenxiang Pills are used to treat wind toxin foot sores, which attack the internal organs, spreading into the limbs, causing weakness and swelling.

For the recipe: take one sheng of small black soybeans, two liang of aconite (washed of its skin and navel, cut), soak it in Wu zhu yu decoction and roast; eight liang each of Qingjuzi peel soaked and roasted. Four liang of fresh ginger, chopped finely.

Combine the above five ingredients in a cloth bag and place it in a large pot with ten dou of water; boil until the water is reduced and nearly dry, then take out the soybeans, dry them in the sun, and grind them into a powder. The other four ingredients are not needed at this stage.

Next, add the following ingredients: two liang each of white aconite (roasted), ba jian (cut and roasted), meat of cynomorium (cut and roasted), and agarwood. Also include one liang each of niu xi (shredded and soaked in wine, then roasted), du huo (prepped), hai tong pi (roasted), qing huo (prepared), shan yu, ze xie, xiong gen, and sheng di huang (cut and roasted).

Except for the first four ingredients, grind the remaining ingredients into a fine powder, mix well, and then knead with honey into pills the size of sycamore seeds. Take twenty pills at a time, with warm wine on an empty stomach, and repeat in the evening.[246p]
Chuanxiong Dafu Pi Powder treats athlete's foot, with symptoms of swelling, heaviness, and pain in the legs and feet due to dampness obstructing the meridians. Zizi Wine - for treating beri-beri.

Great Ingredient Mysterious Left Scripture Decoction

This remedy treats wind, cold, heat, and dampness, flowing into the three Yang channels of the feet. It addresses symptoms such as stiffness, pain in hands and feet, difficulty in movement, aversion to cold and fever, spontaneous sweating, aversion to wind, or absence of sweat with a dislike for cold. It also aids in alleviating dizziness, heaviness in the lower back, joint pain, sudden collapse, constipation or diarrhea, or abdominal pain with vomiting. Additionally, it addresses an aversion to foul food odors, stubborn pain in hips and legs, sluggishness, heat disturbance leading to palpitations, irritability with ascending qi, cold and painful sensations below the navel, and breathlessness with coarse breathing.

Ingredients:
Ephedra (Mahuang) without nodes, Kudzu Root (Gancao), Asarum (Xixin), Magnolia Bark (Houpian), Poria (Fuling), Stephania (Fangji), Prepared Fructus Aurantii (Zhike), Cinnamon (Guixin), Qianghuo, Siler (Fangfeng), Bupleurum (Chaihu), Huangqin (Scutellaria), Pinellia (Banxia), Prepared Ginger (Ganjiao), Ophiopogon (Maimendong), and Honey-Fried Licorice (Gancao), all in equal parts.

For preparation: Each dose is five qian, boiled with one and a half cups of water, five slices of fresh ginger, and one date, until reduced to one cup. Strain and take on an empty stomach.

If there is spontaneous sweating, add oyster shell and Atractylodes, and remove ephedra; for swelling and fullness, add Alisma and Akebia; if there is high heat without sweating, reduce cinnamon and add tangerine peel, before-mentioned bugs, and Siberian ginseng; for abdominal pain and diarrhea, remove Huangqin and add peony and prepared Aconite; for constipation, add rhubarb and bamboo juice; for breathlessness and fullness, add apricot kernel, white mulberry bark, and perilla, all in equal parts.

For any of these ailments, prepare detailed verification and adjust the formula accordingly; there will be no cases that do not improve.[257p]
Jiawei Baidu San treats foot qi from the three yang channels, with symptoms such as flowing edema in the ankles, heat and redness, alternating chills and fevers like malaria, spontaneous sweating and aversion to wind, or no sweating and aversion to cold. For each dose, take five qian (a traditional unit of weight), with one and a half bowls of water, five slices of ginger, and five leaves of mint, simmering until reduced to one bowl. Strain and take hot. If there is skin itching or rashes, add Chen Tui (silkworm shell).[258p]

Four Steamed Papaya Pills
For treating the deficiency of qi in the liver, kidneys, and spleen, affected by wind, cold, heat, and dampness, which have entered the meridians. Symptoms may include longstanding or recent conditions that haven’t healed despite treatment. Upon encountering the six external pathogens and changes in emotions, the heart and spirit become unsettled, resulting in agitation, swelling, or stubborn stiffness, with aversion to cold and intolerance of heat, nausea, and spontaneous sweating.
Ingredients: Four papayas, along with the following combined:

  • ½ tael of Welingxian and Tingli
  • ½ tael of Huangqi and Xuduan
  • ½ tael of Wuye and Huang Songjie
  • ½ tael of Cangzhu and Juhua
    Cut the tops off the papaya, remove the seeds, and fill them with the medicinal mixture. Seal the tops back on and steam with wine until cooked. Repeat the process of steaming three times and drying in the sun to extract the medicine. Grind to a fine powder, make a paste with the papaya, combine and knead until well mixed, then shape into pills the size of a large walnut. Take fifty pills warm on an empty stomach, swallowed with salt water. Huang Songjie refers to the wood of Poria.

Ji Ming San
Treats pain from athlete's foot, suitable for both men and women. If one is affected by wind and dampness leading to pain and swelling in the feet, this should be taken.
Chen Pi, Mu Guo, each one liang; Wu Zhu Yu, Zi Su Ye, each three qian; Jie Geng, Sheng Jiang (with peel), each half liang; seven pieces of Bing Lang.
This should be chewed before being decocted once. Use three large bowls of water, simmer until down to one and a half bowls, strain, then add two bowls of water for a second decoction. Combine the two decoctions; set by the bedside. The next morning at five, divide into three to five doses, taken cold. In winter, it can be taken slightly warm. After taking the medicine, apply a dry item to bind it down. If not all is consumed, leave some for gradual consumption the next day. Taking the medicine until dawn, one should expect dark stool and watery excrement, indicating the expulsion of cold, damp, and toxic energies from the kidney. By breakfast, pain should subside and swelling should diminish. It is advisable to delay eating to allow the medicine to take effect. This medicine is not a purgative and has no contraindications.[272p]

Shengjun Pill [from "San Yin Fang"]
This treats athlete’s foot, cramps, and pain, causing difficulty in walking and addressing all foot weakness diseases.

  • 4 taels of papaya
  • Angelica soaked in wine
  • Gastrodia soaked in wine
  • Achyranthes soaked in wine
  • Roasted sour jujube seed
  • Cooked Rehmannia soaked in wine, steamed, and pounded
  • 2 taels each of Ledebouriella and whole scorpion (toxic parts removed)
  • 1 piece of Aconite, processed and peeled
  • 5 qian each of frankincense, myrrh, Qianghuo, wood fragrant, and licorice
  • 2 qian of musk

Grind these into a powder. Use 2 jin of fresh Rehmannia, wash and pound until muddy, mix with 4 sheng of good wine, and cook into a paste. Combine with the powder and pound until firm. Each 1 tael makes 10 pills. When taking one pill, chew finely and wash down with wine before sleeping. Alternatively, the pills can be made the size of a jujube, and 50 pills can be taken down with wine. After half a month, walking will feel as light as flying; hence, it is named Shengjun. In winter, do not use Rehmannia; instead, make pills with honey.

Zhuo Hu Dan [from "Yixue Rumeng"]
This treats athlete’s foot with swelling and intolerable pain.

  • 0.5 taels of Momordica and earthworm

Grind these into a powder, and mix with glutinous rice paste to form pills the size of fox nuts. Each pill should be taken on an empty stomach with warm wine. If the foot is red and swollen and doesn't dissipate, take another pill. When black sweat emerges from the sole, the root of the problem is removed.[277p]
卷柏散
This formula is particularly effective for treating long-term cases of beriberi that are difficult to cure. Use eastern-facing卷柏. First, boil it in salt water for half a day, then boil it in sweet, cold water for another half day, and dry it. Grind to a fine powder: black morning glory root, sweet-scented wormwood, areca nut — each should be ground separately, without mixing. Take one qian (approx. 3-4 grams) of each, except for the areca nut, which should be two qian. In the early hours of the morning, discreetly boil it, and take it with scallion white broth. By the time of Chen and Si (between 7-11 AM), expel the toxins similar to fish being removed from gelatin. Those who are weak should reduce the dosage by half. Continue consuming light porridge and take the decoction, adding a clearing heat and dampness-reducing soup to it.

枳壳散
This formula treats beriberi that breaks out in spring and summer, or symptoms of heart and abdominal congestion, leg and knee pain, difficult bowel movements, and red, scanty urine.
Ingredients: three fen (approx. 10 grams) of fried bitter orange peel, purple perilla stems and leaves, and red poria; one liang (approx. 30 grams) each of areca nut and rhubarb (lightly fried); one liang each of red peony root, akebia stem, five-leaf ginseng bark, antler horn shavings, angelica, yellow gentian, and honey-fried licorice — each a half liang.
Grind everything finely, take four qian with one middle-sized cup of water, add half a fen of fresh ginger, and decoct until reduced to six parts. Remove the dregs and consume warm before meals.[278p]

Cui Yu Gao, for treating ulcerations.[283p]
One liang of asphalt, two qian each of yellow wax and copper green, one qian each of myrrh and frankincense (with oil removed). First, finely grind the copper green into a powder, mix it with fragrant oil. Then, melt the yellow wax and asphalt over a fire, add the copper green oil, and stir well. Gradually mix in the myrrh and other two ingredients, then use a bowl of river water to pour the medicine into it, pulling and mixing it evenly with your hands. Wrap it in oil paper according to the size of the wound, forming pieces. Chew them and shape into cakes, applying them to the wound, sealing with paper, and changing every three days.

Frankincense powder by Guo’s formula, also known as white resin incense powder, is used to treat various chronic sores and ulcerations that have not healed over time, particularly below the scars and stubborn sores formed on the inner and outer ankles. For this, take half a liang of alum, white resin incense, and red stone resin, and three qian each of yellow lead, frankincense, and myrrh, along with two qian of light powder. Grind these into a fine powder and add a little musk. If the sore is wet, apply when dry; if it is dry, use fragrant oil for application.

For treating ulcers, combine four qian each of mouse dung, bitter gentian, peach twigs, fir tree thorns, willow twigs, pine twigs, flour paste, egg shells, soap pods, sparrow dung, peony, cottonseed, sesame, mulberry twigs, snake skin, bottom coal from pots, and the hairs of prepared Angelica. Mix these into a fine powder, crush candle wax regardless of the amount, and combine all ingredients in a mortar. Dig a pit in the ground, place the mortar inside, and surround it with fire to melt. Afterward, take it out and grind it until uniform, apply it to the wound, and it will heal naturally. Avoid all substances that are hot or produce gas.[284p]

Ulcer Ointment Recipe

Take equal parts of yellow lead, light powder, white atractylodes, camphor, and ash from a failed boat. Grind them into a fine powder, then mix with tung oil to form a paste. Place it in an oil paper bag. First, wash the area with warm scallion soup and dry it with a cloth. Apply the medicine to the ulcer, secure it in place, and after using one side, turn it and repeat the washing and application process. An alternative recipe omits the light powder; using the ash instead is also effective.

Another Recipe: When Zhan Wuzi was thirty years old, he suffered from ulcers and found this remedy effective several times.
Combine equal parts of white atractylodes, white herb (bai lian), and yellow berberine, grinding each separately. Form a very fine powder, add a small amount of light powder, and mix thoroughly. Combine with melted honey to form a paste, shape into cakes, and apply to the ulcer, filling deep ones completely. Wrap with a cloth; the area will gradually dry over the course of a week. If there are cracks, simply apply powder until healed.

Blood-Injecting Foot Recipe

The cow dung mushroom, also known as the lime mushroom, grows on the ground. If there are stone clumps, break them apart. Use the ash from the fat oak mushroom and mulberry mushroom. For men, use male fetal hair; for women, use female. One version suggests males use female and females use male.

Take five qian (a unit of weight) of each of the three mushrooms, dried. Burn three qian of fetal hair to ash and finely grind all ingredients together. When wet, apply the dry powder; when dry, mix and apply with refined sesame oil.[286p]
Wintergreen leaves and pig bile, mixed with frost from a hundred herbs.

First, chew the wintergreen leaves thoroughly. Clean the wound with scallion and pepper broth, then apply the bile powder followed by the chewed leaves on top. Repeat this three or four times.

Miraculous Gardenia Powder treats long-standing internal and external sores. Use a small amount of powder, any amount of gardenia, burn it to obtain its essence, and grind it into a fine powder. Also grind equal parts of frankincense.

Mix the powders and store them in a ceramic container. Before use, clean the wound with scallion white and pepper broth, rest briefly, then wash it again with warm starch water until the unpleasant fluid is gone. Boil plain water, wait until it is warm, then wash the wound again. Ensure there are no pus, blood streaks, and that all water is removed. Use a cloth to dry the area before applying the medicine. For dry wounds, use fragrant oil; for wet ones, use a dry mixture. Protect the wound with soft silk if it is full. Do not use on hard wounds without pus. If swollen and soft with pus, follow the previous method to wash and apply; healing should occur in two or three applications. This method uses one medicine and two washes.

Each of astragalus and ox knee: half a tael; of qianghuo, duhuo, white peony root, chuanxiong, fangfeng, and wood fragrance: two and a half qian each; and one tael of white tribulus, with thorns removed.

Grind into fine powder, mix with honey to form pills about the size of a walnut. Each dose consists of thirty pills taken with saline water on an empty stomach, followed by applying the medicine.

Moisturizing ointment [from "Treasure Mirror"] treats the cracking and painful skin of hands and feet. Use four liang of natural asphalt, eight qian of yellow wax, and two qian of frankincense. Combine these three ingredients in an iron vessel using both gentle and strong heat. Add the asphalt to the pot, and as it begins to melt, gradually add yellow wax and frankincense, followed by one or two tablespoons of pure sesame oil. Wait until the asphalt is completely melted, stir gently, and place a large basin of clean water nearby. Using a stirring spoon, take one or two drops of the mixture and drip it into the water to test. If it hardens, add more oil; if it is just right, filter it through fresh cotton until it appears white. The oil should be added gradually, ensuring it does not become too soft. It can be stored in ceramic containers or wrapped in oiled paper. Use as needed, and first heat the area with a hot compress before applying the ointment to ensure it adheres well.

Secret Paper Plaster Recipe

For treating internal and external sores that have not healed for many years.

Ingredients:

  • Old pine bark (1 part)
  • Pine resin
  • Camphor
  • Calamine (fried)
  • Realgar (1 part)
  • Yellow lead
  • Water dragon bone
  • Light powder
  • Szechuan lovage
  • Sea crab shell

Grind the above ingredients into a fine powder. Melt the pine resin, mix in a small amount of clear oil, and incorporate the powdered medicine evenly. Use oiled paper according to the size of the sore, creating a bag to hold the medicine. Clean the sore with water until dry, then affix the plaster and secure it with silk. Change every three days. Alternatively, you can simply decoct white atractylodes, Szechuan lovage, and sea crab shell for washing.

For cases that have not healed for many years, it is often due to deficiency in kidney essence leading to downward afflictions. There may also be spleen sores; in this case, one can take the aforementioned bitter root pills to replenish kidney essence, and use detoxifying and wound-healing powders before applying the secret paper plaster.

Sizhi Gate

Fang

隔纸膏 - Treats sores and damp toxic ulcers. Calcine gypsum, grind to a powder with equal parts of powdered alumen, and mix with tung oil to form a paste. Apply it using partition paper. Additionally, take Jingfang Baidu San, and if several doses do not show effectiveness, one should take ginseng and astragalus soup.

Liushendan - Treats ulcers in men, women, and children, curing all sores on the body. Fry three taels and six qian of flower pollen until yellow, two fen of borneol, four qian of white lead powder, and one tael of yellow lead prepared with water and dried. Grind to a powder and apply a small amount to the affected area. Cover it with wintergreen leaves and change twice a day.

Biyang Fang - Treats itchy conditions of the feet caused by dampness. Six fen of mercury, one tael each of realgar and fried flower pollen, and two taels of evodia and berberine. Grind these together, and apply with candle oil.

Fangfeng Tang - Treats individuals affected by wind toxicity, which lingers in the blood and does not dissipate, fighting against the nutritive and defensive Qi, leading to wind sores, body heat, dizziness, swelling, and pain. Ingredients are: fangfeng, chih-shih, qianghuo, and sliced and toasted angelica; white atractylodes, mutong; fuzi, with skin and navel removed; ephedra with roots and joints taken away. Boil and skim off the foam. Roast, fry, and prepare licorice. Use equal amounts of these (one tael for each). Grind them into pieces the size of mung beans. Each dose is five qian mixed with one and a half bowls of water, boil until reduced to eight parts, filter out the residue, and take one dose after meals and before lying down. If sweating is desired, take two doses on an empty stomach, followed by hot ginger soup and thin porridge, then cover to induce sweating, while being cautious of wind external.[293p]
Haitongpi Wine: Treats heat poison and wind that cause sores, swelling, and pain that disrupts comfort. Ingredients: three taels of raw Rehmannia, one tael each of Haitongpi, Wujiapi, Duchong, Fangfeng, fried Scorpion, roasted Coix seeds, and Niu Xi flavored with wine, all one tael. After grinding, store in a silk bag. Soak in 15 liters of good wine in a sealed ceramic bottle. In the fall and summer, steep for three days; in winter and spring, steep for seven days. Warm and take three to five jugs before meals, without a specific time, allowing the aroma of the wine to continue.

Xijiao San: Treats athlete's foot, wind poison causing sores and swelling, and restlessness due to heat. Ingredients: rhino horn shavings, Tianma, Qianghuo, Fangfeng, Huangqi, Baijili, Huangqin, fried Zhihe, and Baixianpi, each seven and a half qian; one tael of Betel nut; two black snakes, soaked in wine; half a tael of roasted licorice. After grinding, take eight qian with one and a half middle cups of water and five slices of ginger. Boil until two large cups remain, strain, and take warm, without a specific time.

Another Formula: Treats upward wind poison causing athlete's foot, sores, swelling, and pain. Ingredients: two taels of Baijili, Liulu, Baiyan, Huai white skin, Wujiapi, and licorice, each seven and a half qian. After grinding, use five taels with one dou of water. Boil down to six sheng, strain, adjust temperature, and wash in a windless area.[294p]
Huan Shao Dan treats deficiencies in the three Yin meridians of the feet and conditions such as "crane knee." It also nourishes the spleen and kidneys and is a good remedy for improving appetite and digestion.

Soaked in wine, remove shells from the following:

  • meat from Cistanche,
  • wash with sweet licorice water and remove bones,
  • add Chinese yam,
  • fry with fragrant herbs,
  • clean the heart from Morinda root,
  • include goji berries,
  • ox knee,
  • stone calamus,
  • eucommia bark,
  • mash cooked Rehmannia,
  • Schisandra berries,
  • white Poria,
  • mulberry seeds,
  • and flesh of cornelian cherries, all in equal parts.

Grind these into a powder, and mix with red dates and honey to form pills the size of a walnut. Take seventy pills with warm wine, three times a day; white soup is also acceptable.

Erfan Decoction (from "Orthodox Text of Surgery")
Treats goose palm wind, skin dryness and thickness, fissures causing pain. This decoction should be used for fumigation and washing. If mild, it's not suitable; the heavier the condition, the more effective it will be.

  • White alum: 4 taels
  • Soap alum: 4 taels
  • Child tea: 5 qian
  • Cedar leaves: half a jin

Use 10 cups of water, add the four ingredients, boil until bubbling, and keep for use. First, apply tung oil to the affected area, then dip a piece of paper in tung oil, ignite it, and use the smoke to fumigate the area. Afterwards, pour the boiling decoction into a clean bucket, cover it with cloth to keep the steam from escaping. Once it's slightly warm, pour into a basin and soak for a long time; one treatment can cure. Avoid consuming soup or water for seven days, and it won’t occur again.[296p]
Treatment for Hand Sores

To treat sores on the hands that are swollen, painful, and producing pus, and have been broken open to leak fluid:

  • Burn pig dung to ash
  • Areca nut (5 qian)
  • Brain powder (0.5 fen)
  • Sichuan pepper and dragon bone (3 fen each)

Grind these into a fine powder. Mix the dry ingredients and apply with sesame oil. If there is pus, add 1 qian of gypsum powder.

Dragon Bone Ointment

For treating ulcerated sores:

Burned five-colored dragon bone, frankincense, myrrh, and myrrh resin (each 2 qian), half a qian of sea turtle shell, and five pieces of soap burned to a residue.

Grind these together, use double layers of cotton paper with needle-pierced holes, mix with clean oil, and apply the medicine inside. Bind it over the sore and replace every other day, applying to both sides.

Purslane Ointment

For treating thirty-six types of wind sores, chronic ulcers, ulcerated sores, damp eczema, and alopecia areata. It can also seal abscesses.

Take purslane, cook down to extract one pot of juice, add three taels of yellow wax, and simmer slowly until it becomes an ointment to apply.

Kiln Soil Ointment

For treating ulcerated sores:

Use iron-rich kiln soil or soil from the center of a stove that has been used for years, yellow lead, gypsum powder, yellow huangluo, frankincense, myrrh, and red resin (all in equal parts).

Grind these into a fine powder, mix with clean oil to form an ointment, and cover with parchment paper. Secure with silk, avoiding scratching even if it itches, and allow the ulcer to scab over. If not healed, apply again. First wash with clean tea before applying the ointment.[297p]

Two taels of tung oil, three qian each of herbal frost, yellow lead, and frankincense, along with five qian of hair powder; boil these together into an ointment and apply to oiled paper for dressing. Qiyai Ointment for Treating Ulcers.
Five qian each of Qiyai and Sichuan pepper, one tael of water powder, three qian of yellow lead, and one qian of light powder; grind into a fine powder, mix with cooked sesame oil to form an ointment, and apply between layers of paper for efficacy.

Wax Alum Paper for Treating Ulcers.
Prepare wool paper in twelve layers, cut into squares based on the size of the ulcer, and secure with paper twists. Use two taels of sesame oil and forty-nine grains of Sichuan pepper; slow-cook until it turns dark and remove the dregs. Then add forty-nine inches of locust branches and simmer until blackened, also removing the dregs. Incorporate one tael of yellow wax, one qian of burnt alum, and two qian of light powder, allowing them to melt into the previous oil mixture, ensuring it does not burn to a yellow color before removing. When applying, wash the sore with decoction of locust branches and Sichuan pepper, then place the prepared paper on top, securing it tightly with additional oiled paper. Change the inner layer of paper periodically; once the paper is removed completely, the sore will be fully healed, showing remarkable effectiveness. This is particularly beneficial for those with qi deficiency and excessive pus.[298p]
Yellow Wax Ointment: Treats ulcer sores.

Take one tael of fragrant oil and heat it with the size of a plum in placenta hair until fully melted. Add one tael each of white resin, yellow wax, and mix well. Then add one tael each of raw dragon bone, red stone resin, and blood gall powder. Stir and allow to cool, then store in a porcelain container.

When using, pinch off a thin piece to apply to the sore, and bind it with bamboo leaves or silk cloth. After three days, replace the plaster and wash with a decoction of blood-activating herbs. It is also effective for external sores.

Ash Ointment: Treats all types of unnamed toxic swellings, evil sores, and ulcer sores that have turned purple and black after many years.

Take one and a half sheng of ash from the sugar furnace and one sheng of slaked lime, and stir-fry until red. Store this in a bamboo sieve and slowly pour in three bowls of boiling water and one bowl of natural juice. In a copper pot, simmer over low heat until it becomes a thin paste.

First, add two qian of powdered father bean, then two qian of toad secretions, five fen of powdered clove, and one qian of stir-fried lime, mixing well and continuing to simmer until it reaches a dry, dough-like consistency. Remove and let it cool, storing in a ceramic jar, ensuring no air leaks in.

For use, take a small amount with a hairpin and crush it on your fingernail. Breathe onto it to mix it into a paste, then use a needle to pierce the affected area and apply the medicine.[299p]

Wugong Jian
Used for long-standing chronic sores that are black, rotten, and painful, where other medicines have no effect.

Lamp Lighting Method
Treats long-standing purple-black blood wind sores that itch constantly with fluid. First, use green onion soup to wash the affected area, then use a lamp flame to fumigate it, with three twists each time.
Ingredients: 2 qian of Xionghuang, 2 qian of cinnabar, 2 qian of dragon's blood, 2 qian of myrrh, and 4 fen of musk.
Grind these into a fine powder, using 3 fen each time, wrapped in cotton paper as a twist, about a foot long, soaked in genuine sesame oil. Fumigate at a distance of about half an inch from the sore, gradually moving from the outside inward, slowly surrounding the area. With the flame upwards, the medicinal vapor enters, dispersing the sores' toxins without harming internal organs. Start with three twists and gradually increase to four or five as the sores diminish.

Treats similar conditions as above.

Shengji Yuhong Gao - A divine medicine for removing rotten flesh and generating new tissue, with astringing effects.
5 qian of Bai Zhi, 1 liang 2 qian of Licorice, 2 qian of Zi Cao, and 2 liang each of Bai La and Gui Shen, 4 qian of Xue Jie, and 1 jin of sesame oil. First, steep the four herbs (Dang Gui, Licorice, Zi Cao, Bai Zhi) in oil for three days; then gently simmer with a large ladle until the medicine slightly darkens, strain the oil through fine silk, return it to the ladle, bring to a boil, add all the Xue Jie to dissolve completely, followed by Bai La to melt over low heat. Pre-soak four tea cups in water, divide the paste into four portions, pour into each cup, wait for a moment, then grind ultra-fine powder, adding 1 qian to each cup and mix well; collect after it has settled for a while. Do not add or reduce anything, or it will be ineffective.[308p]

Female and male thunderfire treats gangrene and all initial stages of boils that are not painful; it is advisable to use moxibustion.

Two qian of Qiai herb, two fen each of clove, female yellow, and male yellow, one fen of musk. Grind these four ingredients very finely, roll them into a mixture with mugwort, and form pea-sized pills. Place them on the affected area for moxibustion, disregarding pain or itchiness, using internal heat as a measure. If the poison has already dispersed, treat the area up to where the redness ends, using moxibustion there; if it hurts, it should turn to itching, and if it itches, it should turn to pain, as this is ideal. After moxibustion, apply a wheat paste on top and take toad venom pills and detoxifying life-restoring decoction, along with treating the condition; it is excellent to see discharge of pus.

Golden liquid and earth elixir treat gangrene and boils. Even if one consumes rich foods and alcohol, or takes restorative herbs, excessive exertion can lead to accumulated toxins in the organs. Over time, gastric juices may dry up and kidney water deplete, preventing control over heart fire, resulting in diabetes, dryness, excessive thirst, inability to eat well, weight loss, blocked orifices, anxiety, and forgetfulness. Once this condition arises, it may lead to sores that are difficult to treat; it is wise to take this as a preventive measure, which may help alleviate severe conditions to lighter ones, or from deeper to shallower issues. Additionally, it also detoxifies poisons from metals and stones.[314p]
To prepare the medicine, take one tael each of yellow ochre, Poria, Coptis chinensis, and fresh rehmannia steamed in wine, then pound into a paste. Pound the flesh of black plum and five-flavored fruit, each one tael. Additionally, take three qian each of stone calamus, Polygala, powdered realgar, vermilion, and nitre, as well as one qian each of bull bile and borneol. Use twenty sheets of gold leaf as a coating.

Grind all substances into a fine powder and mix according to the prescribed amounts. Place everything in a mortar and grind for a thousand turns. On auspicious days such as the Dragon Boat Festival, Qixi, the Summer and Winter Solstice, in a clean room, first mix the pastes of black plum and rehmannia thoroughly, then gradually add a little refined honey while continuing to pound until the mixture reaches the right consistency of softness and firmness.

Take two taels of each medicine, divide into ten pills, and coat with gold leaf. For each dose, dissolve one pill in a large cup of human milk and children's urine, and take it before and after meals according to the condition of the illness. This medicine is particularly effective at resolving the toxic effects of rich foods, suppressing evil spirits, alleviating fever, and has remarkable efficacy.

It also treats restlessness and agitation, calms the spirit, prevents pestilence, and alleviates various evils, including delusions and loss of will. During the period of preparation and while taking the medicine, one should avoid contact with women, monks, nuns, and any mourning attire, as well as dogs and chickens.

Store this medicine sealed in wax to preserve its efficacy; the longer it is kept, the more effective it becomes.[315p]
Bao'an Wanling Dan treats carbuncles, sores, and poison; it is effective for oral and facial issues, wind and dampness, phlegm and fluid retention, bone-related Yin sores, crepitant wind syndrome, left-sided paralysis, right-sided paralysis, crooked mouth and eyes, hemiplegia, stagnation of qi and blood, widespread pain, difficulty walking, unilateral hernias, headache, tetanus, clenched jaws, and colds from wind and cold—nothing is beyond its efficacy.

Grind the above into a fine powder and make pills the size of a marble. For each ingredient, one tael is divided into four pills; one tael makes six pills; and one tael makes nine pills. Prepare according to the desired effect and intensity of illness.

For use, take six qian of realgar, grind it finely and use it as a coating; store in a magnetic jar. When needed, boil nine segments of scallions in water to make a tea, dissolve one pill, and drink it all, then cover up to induce sweating as the effect. If sweating is delayed, use the scallion tea to encourage it.

When sweating begins, gradually remove clothing; the sweat will naturally diminish. If symptoms are not severe, they will gradually dissipate; if they are severe, swelling may be immediate. After taking, avoid wind and consume light porridge. Avoid cold foods and sexual activity. Do not take if pregnant.[316p]

Chansu Pills are used to treat carbuncles and abscesses, brain sores and breast abscesses, as well as abscesses on the buttocks and thighs, and all manner of severe ailments and harmful sores that are either painless or numb, or accompanied by severe vomiting or delirium. When taking this medicine, those who do not generate painful sensations will begin to feel pain; those who are in pain will find it alleviated; those who are delirious will regain their senses; those who are vomiting will have relief; unripe abscesses will resolve, while mature ones will rupture. It truly possesses the power of resurrection, making it the invaluable elixir among severe ailments.

The recipe includes 2 qian of chansu, dissolved in wine; 5 fen of light powder; 1 qian each of dry alum, calcined cold water stone, copper green, frankincense, myrrh, and vitriol; 2 qian of realgar; 21 pieces of snail; and 2 qian of cinnabar. All of these should be ground into a fine powder, measured accurately, and on the day of the Dragon Boat Festival at noon, in a clean room, first grind the snail into a paste, then combine it with chansu and grind into a thick adhesive; add all the other medicines and pound them together thoroughly. Form pills about the size of mung beans. The dosage is three pills at a time, taken with a five-inch section of the green onion, which the patient should chew until it disintegrates, then spit in the palm of the left hand for men and the right hand for women, enclosing the medicine inside. Take it down with a cup of hot wine without ash, and the patient should walk about five or six li until sweating occurs for effect. If the condition is severe, take an additional dose. During the preparation, women and animals such as chickens and dogs should not be present.[318p]

Four Limb Gate

Single Prescription

Liu Dayin from Shicun treats ulcerated sores with a medicated plaster: Use four taels of sesame oil, heat in a copper pot, and add three stalks of green onion, boiling until they turn black; then add one tael of ground Sichuan pepper, boil until black, and strain away; add one tael of copper green powder and ten branches of locust wood, each one foot long, and stir together, burn one segment off until it is fully utilized; then add one tael of alum and five qian of yellow wax, simmer for a long time until it becomes a paste. Each time, place a spoonful of the paste wrapped in oil paper and pierce it with a silver needle to create many small holes. Clean the wound with strong tea before applying the paste, changing it repeatedly, and a stinging sensation is a good sign. Usually, one or two applications yield quick results, and for long-standing cases, no more than five to seven applications are needed. The longer the paste is stored, the more effective it becomes.

Liu Chuanzhou's formula for treating ulcerated sores: Use one tael of fragrance oil, heating it in an iron ladle, and add five qian of yellow wax to dissolve; then add three qian of copper green powder, grinding it very finely, and slowly mixing it into the iron ladle for more than fifty times; separate the powdered copper money into another bowl, pour the mixture into the bowl, and let it cool and set. Clean the sore and place a piece of felt, sized to the sore, on top of it, applying the medicine and securing it in place, changing it once a day. Be sure to wash the sore clean before each change.

For muscle cramps in the feet: Soak old cotton in vinegar, steam it hot, wrap it around, and change it once it cools. Do not stop until healed.

For all cases of swelling and pain in the soles of the feet, or those caused by prolonged walking or standing, mix dirt from earthworms with water and apply thickly; it will heal overnight.[320p]
Cold and Damp Beriberi: Use ancient bricks, heat them red, then extinguish with water from aged, odorous rice, and while hot, wrap three pieces in cloth and hold between the knees, covering with a cotton blanket. Repeat three to five times for a cure.

Wind and Damp Foot Pain: Grind needle sand and Chuanwu roots into powder, mix and heat, then apply with a cloth.

Red and Swollen Feet, Hot like Fire: Known as "Red Traveling Wind," relieve by applying rust water.

Foot Pain from Beriberi: Use an unnamed powder mixed with cowhide glue to apply, changing frequently.

Weakness from Wind: Two jin of Konggong Sleeves, five liang of Dendrobium, and two dou of wine, soak and consume.

Cold and Windy Beriberi: Three jin of calcined alum stone, three dou of wine, soak for three days, and drink slightly.

Water from Foot Spaces: Mix good yellow lead with powdered flower stone.

All Types of Beriberi: Steam three sheng of salt until hot, wrap in cloth and step on it to warm the soles. Additionally, steaming with white locust bark is particularly effective; use this nightly.

Painful Beriberi: Each night, scrub the legs and knees with salt up to the toenails, soak for a short time, and wash with hot soup. There was a person who suffered from this illness and had success using this method.[321p]
Wind toxins causing foot disease and weakness: Use three taels of sulfur powder and five sheng of cow's milk, boil it, then steep it in water until it reaches three sheng. Take three he each time. Another method: Take three sheng of cow's milk and boil it down to one and a half sheng, mixing in one tael of sulfur powder to take. Cover well to induce sweating and avoid wind. If sweat doesn’t occur, take again. After resting and adjusting for a few days, take again. This is very effective for northern people. It can also be boiled or made into pills.

For wind and damp foot disease: Use one tael of raw stone extract, one tael of raw Chuan Wutou, and two taels of an unnamed herb, ground into powder. Mix with the juice of white scallion to form pills the size of a jujube. Take one qian each time with lightly brewed tea and raw scallion, once a day.

For foot disease reaching the heart: Use three taels of white alum and five sheng of water, boil and soak for washing.

For foot disease caused by wind, damp, and deficiency with light strength and much pain: Take a spoonful of burnt alum powder, toss it into boiling water, and wash the painful area.

In the southern regions, where the land is low and damp, many people suffer from foot sores, that for years may harbor worms like leeches, resulting from wind toxin attacks.

Use cow, sheep, or pig stomachs, remove the waste without washing, and grind into a paste. Depending on the size of the sore, add half a tael of calcined dry alum, mix uniformly, and apply on cloth and stick it on the sore. After a moment, if it itches deeply, gradually remove the cloth, heat it over the fire, and the worms will come out like countless threads of a horse's tail, either blue, white, red, or black. Wash them out with water, do this every three days for a few times, and the worms will be exhausted and the sores will heal.[322p]
When an ingrown toenail causes a sore, the nail grows into the flesh, making it impossible to wear boots. Apply burnt alum ash to it, which erodes the bad flesh and encourages the growth of healthy flesh. Carefully trim away the nail edges, and after ten days, it will heal. This remedy is remarkably effective.

For corns: Mix equal parts of dried alum, yellow orpiment, and vitriol into a powder, apply it, and bathe in hot water two to three times a day to heal it.

In cases of nail diseases that become rotten, it may be due to nail cutting injuring the skin or the nail growing into the flesh, leading to sores and swelling. This may cause yellow fluid to soak in, resulting in the fingers becoming rotten and eventually spreading up the foot, with blisters forming around the edges, as if burned by fire, causing constant pain and being unhealable by doctors. Take five liang of green vitriol, burn it until all the liquid is gone, and grind it into a powder that is yellow in color. Store it to use, washing with salt water, and apply the powder. Wrap it gently in a soft cloth, and the very same day, it will stop the fluid and dry the sore. Do this once a day, washing with salt water, ensuring any pus is cleaned out. For areas where scabs have formed, do not disturb them unless there is urgent pain, in which case apply a little butter to soothe. After three days, you will notice the scab lifting. Continue washing and applying treatment as before, and within ten days the scabs will gradually come off. If soft areas develop more white pus blisters, break them and apply the treatment, and they will naturally heal. A certain Zhang Shilang suffered from this ailment for sixty days without relief from various doctors, but found this method effective as if it were a miracle.[323p]
For a sore with pus at the edge of the toenail, where red flesh protrudes and is often lifted: Take two taels of Astragalus and one tael of (herb) and soak in vinegar overnight. Combine with five measures of pig fat and simmer on low heat to obtain three measures. Strain out the residue and apply to the sore, three times a day, and the flesh will naturally dissolve.

For inflamed and painful ingrown toenails: Burn motherwort to preserve its essence, and grind it to mix.

After foot swelling from illness: Simply eat less to nourish stomach qi, and externally use dog spine decoction for washing.

For painful swelling due to toxic heat: Soak in wine with bitter salty herb.

For foot qi swelling and pain: Use six taels of white peony root and one tael of licorice, ground to powder, and take with white broth.

For those suffering from foot qi, eat a full breakfast, have a light lunch, and do not eat dinner. If hungry, one may have fermented gruel. If you feel unease and want to vomit, take one tael of galanga, boil with three liters of water until down to one liter, and drink it all at once to aid digestion. If that is unavailable, use one tael of fresh ginger and decoct with clear wine. Although not as effective as galanga, it will also yield good results.

For damp and rotten toes: Pound and apply Perilla leaves.[324p]
Knee wind pain: Use chrysanthemum and dried mugwort leaves as knee protectors; with time, they will resolve on their own.

Cold and damp beriberi, leg and knee pain, weakness when walking: Soak fenugreek seeds in wine overnight, dry, crush old paper and fry until fragrant, four taels each to make powder. Cut the top of a papaya and remove the pulp, fill it with the medicine until full, seal it, steam and mash into balls the size of a walnut. Take seventy balls with warm wine on an empty stomach.

For all abscesses and sores on the back: Use ten pounds of iron broom and copper pine needles, boil in water to drink.

For beriberi with swollen legs and bone pain: Grind the root of the wild vine and mix with wine vinegar in equal portions, steam the mixture together and apply to the swelling, which should reduce in one or two days. It also treats numbness.

For weak feet: Burn red smartweed to ash, soak in juice, then steam with mulberry leaves for immediate relief.

For unhealing cuts and flesh wounds: Use the juice of ghost needle grass seedlings and mouse sticky root, mix with lard and apply.

For weakness from dampness in the feet: Cut shanglu root into small bean-sized pieces, boil until cooked, then boil with mung beans to eat as rice daily until healed, which is the most effective method.

For beriberi pain: Take seven castor seeds, remove the shell, crush and mix with musk pills, apply to the soles of the feet, and the pain will cease immediately.[325p]

The soles of the feet are swollen and raised, with black sores that are hard as nails. There are small holes forming in the tibia, with marrow oozing out, and the body shivers from cold, only yearning for alcohol. This indicates issues with the liver and kidney meridians, where cold and heat are intermingled. Use powdered Aconitum or Wu Tou to apply externally, and take a drink made of chives for internal treatment, and it will be effective.

For sores caused by cutting nails that do not heal after several years: grind equal portions of Aconitum and Coptis into a powder, wash it and apply it to heal.

For knee wind causing pain: prepare a powder of Aconitum, Asarum, and Siler, mix it into shoes and knee protection, which can eliminate wind and dampness, promoting agile steps.

For feet swelling after a long journey: grind equal portions of Aconitum, Asarum, and Siler into a powder and mix it into the soles of the shoes. For straw sandals, slightly moisten with water and apply; using this, one can walk a thousand miles, which is quite remarkable.

For painful foot conditions, or lumps in the groin: make a powder from fresh Aconitum, rhubarb, and Momordica, boil in ginger juice, and combine with tea for application. Another prescription is to use only Aconitum powdered, mixed with ginger juice or wine lees to apply.

For damp stagnation causing foot swelling, which is lighter in the morning and heavier in the evening: take one tael of fresh Aconitum, grind it with one tael of ginger, and let it sit overnight; also take one tael of Atractylodes and grind it with one tael of green onion white, letting it sit overnight. Both should be dried, ground into powder, made into pills the size of walnuts, with each dose being fifty pills taken with wine.[326p]

  • For foot conditions that lead to abdominal discomfort and shortness of breath: take 2 qian of Weilingxian with wine. If pain decreases, reduce the dosage accordingly.[327p]
