Four Limbs Door

Acupuncture and Moxibustion

The Suwen says: In cases of liver heat disease, there is heated contention resulting in delirium and agitation, fullness and pain in the sides, restlessness in the hands and feet, unable to lie down peacefully. When severe, it leads to extreme sweating. Reversed qi can result in death. Needling the foot’s Jueyin and Shaoyang points is recommended.

In cases of kidney heat disease, there is initial pain in the lower back, acidity in the legs, thirst with frequent drinking, and fever. Heated contention leads to neck pain and stiffness, cold and sourness in the legs, with warmth below the feet and reluctance to speak. Reversed qi can lead to subtle neck pain. When severe, it causes extreme sweating. Needling the foot’s Shaoyin and Taiyang points is recommended.

In cases of fever disease, there is initial pain in the chest and sides, restlessness in the hands and feet; needling the foot’s Shaoyang and supplementing the foot's Taiyin are advised. For severe cases, fifty-nine needles are used.

For fever-related arm pain, needling the hand’s Yangming and Taiyin points helps to stop the sweating.

If the fever begins in the legs and shins, needling the foot’s Yangming point will help to stop the sweating.

The Lingshu Classic states: In January, February, and March, the human energy is in the left side, hence do not needle the Yang point of the left foot. In April, May, and June, the energy is in the right side, hence do not needle the Yang point of the right foot. In July, August, and September, the energy is again in the right side, hence do not needle the Yin point of the right foot. In October, November, and December, the energy is in the left side, hence do not needle the Yin point of the left foot.[364p]
The hand Taiyin is also called Lieque, starting at the wrist and connecting with the Taiyin channel, extending directly into the palm and dispersing into the space between the thumb and index finger. When there is excess, it manifests as sharp pain and heat in the palm; when there is deficiency, it results in frequent urination. The point is located half an inch below the wrist, connecting to the Yangming channel.

The hand Shaoyang is called Waiguan, located two inches above the wrist on the outer arm, leading to the chest and connecting with the heart. In cases of excess, it causes elbow stiffness; in deficiency, it results in inability to close. This point is likewise a connecting point.

The foot Yangming is known as Fenglong, found eight inches above the ankle, diverging from the Taiyin; its path follows the outer side of the shinbone, connecting the head, converging with the energy of various channels, and also linking to the throat. If the qi is reversed, it can cause throat obstruction and sudden loss of voice; with excess, it leads to mania, while deficiency results in inability to gather strength in the feet, causing atrophy of the shins. This point signifies a connection as well.

If there is pathogenic influence in the liver, there will be pain in the sides and central area, with cold symptoms, bad blood stagnating inside, leading to spasms, and occasional swelling of the feet. Treat by stimulating the Xingjian point to draw down the sides, tonifying Sanli point to warm the stomach, relieving the bad blood by accessing the blood vessels, and using the ear's lateral veins to alleviate the spasms.

If there are injuries with significant bleeding or if one suffers from wind-cold, leading to a sensation of falling, with laxity of the limbs, it is termed body lethargy. The treatment is to stimulate the area three inches below the navel. This area is the intersection of the Yangming and Taiyin channels, also seen as the Guanyuan point, three inches below the navel.

For severe convulsions, dizziness, or inability to keep the body upright, the Tianzhu point should be used.[365p]
When a disease begins in the arms, first treat the Hand Yangming and Taiyin to induce sweating. When a disease begins in the head, first treat the Neck Taiyang to induce sweating. When a disease begins in the legs, first treat the Foot Yangming to induce sweating.

For heat diseases with a greenish face and headache, accompanied by restlessness in the hands and feet, stimulate the muscles between them with the fourth needle at the Four Reversals. When muscles are stiff and the eyes are watery, focus on the liver but do not disturb the metal, which corresponds to the lungs.

If the legs cannot be lifted, lie on the side and treat the area at the Pivot Joint. Use a round, smooth needle; do not stab with a large needle. For bleeding hemorrhoids, treat at the Ququan point.

The points Yunmen, Yugu, Weizhong, and Suikong, these eight points are used to drain heat from the limbs.

The left foot corresponds to the beginning of spring, on the days of Wuyin and Jichou. The left hand corresponds to the beginning of summer, on the days of Wuchen and Jisi. The right hand corresponds to the beginning of autumn, on the days of Wushen and Jiwuwei. The right foot corresponds to the beginning of winter, on the days of Wuxu and Jihai. The waist and below should be treated at the winter solstice, on the day of Renzi. The major prohibitions occur on the days of Taiyi and all Wuxi. Of these nine rules, one must be careful to observe the eight points in their proper places, attending to the directions left, right, above, and below. If there are abscesses or swellings on the body, to treat them, do not use the days directly indicated, as this is called an auspicious day forbidden by heaven.

The "Synopsis of the Golden Chamber" states: For a disease characterized by inability to retreat, where the person can only move forward, needle the abdomen two fen deep; this is due to an injury in the Taiyang channel.

The "Classic of Changes" states: In cold and heat, there is lethargy and aching in the limbs, with heaviness and pain in the extremities, and difficulty in speech; this is ruled by the Great Yang.[366p]
In the chest, there is a swelling sensation, so intense that one may cross their hands and feel dizzy, with violent convulsions, shortness of breath, and pain in the channels and the Tianfu point; this is called "Da Yu."

For cold and heat symptoms such as coughing and spitting, there is heat in the palms; if deficient, one experiences cold shivers in the shoulders and arms, and insufficient breath; when cold and convulsions occur, hands tremble and froth comes from the mouth; if excessive, there is heat and pain in the shoulders and back, sweating and swelling in the limbs, a feeling of warmth shaking throughout the body, alternation of cold and heat; hunger leads to restlessness, while fullness brings comfort, facial color changes, the mouth cannot be opened, and aversion to wind manifests with tears; the point Lieque governs this.

Heart pain feels like being suspended; there are hidden cold symptoms with urgent pain in the lower abdomen, blood stasis causing fecal pus and blood, pain in the feet and ankles, inability to speak due to tongue rolling, excessive laughter, and atrophy of the feet leading to the inability to wear shoes, with urine appearing in blue, red, white, or black.[367p]
Green corresponds to the well, red to honor, yellow to transmission, white to scripture, and black to convergence.

For cold and heat, sourness and pain, limbs unable to raise, swelling under the armpits, horse knife abscess, throat obstruction, hip and knee issues, and shaky neck bones, Yangfu is in charge of these.

For cold and heat with sighing, heavy head and cold feet, lack of appetite, cramping legs, Jinggu is in charge of these.

For cold and heat occurring afterward, convulsions, heaviness and pain in the feet, trembling and inability to stand for long, swelling in the feet, pain in the ankle joints, pain in the lower abdomen leading to throat, difficulty in bowel movements, and Chengjin is in charge of these.

For acute coldness in the knees and feet, back pain radiating to the abdomen, heat in the groin, sudden severe pain, cold and hot sensations, heaviness in the knees, Huyang is in charge of these.

For fullness in the chest and sides, reverse Qi in the diaphragm, shallow breathing, wheezing, inability to raise arms, and Buluang is in charge of these.

For fullness in the chest and horse knife pain, inability to raise the arms, and Yuanyan is in charge of these.[368p]
Feeling startled, sad, and unhappy, with heat beneath the shins and feet, the face is excessively hot and thirsty, a condition that is governed by the interstitial spaces. Dizziness, coldness, and a feeling of fainting, along with pain in the arms, lead to agitation, flushed face, and weeping, which are controlled by the axilla. Pain in the lower back and spine, difficulty in bending or straightening, inability to breathe lying back, heaviness in the feet, inability to raise the buttocks, red urination, numbness from the waist down to the feet, leading to an inability to sit up, is governed by the bladder region. Persistent lower back pain with an inability to bend or straighten, numbness from the waist down to the feet, coldness in the lower back, is associated with the second lumbar region. Begin by addressing the missing pelvic area, followed by the tailbone and the eight crests. Inability to lift due to back pain, pain behind the heel and ankle, weakness in the feet, is managed by the back middle point. Qi stagnation leading to urinary issues and urgency, with pain in the groin area, is addressed at the intersection. A feeling of fullness in the chest that resembles distension, and actual blockage leading to swollen armpits, as well as weakness leading to involuntary urination, with anxious feet and painful muscles, causing inability to urinate or defecate, along with back pain radiating to the abdomen and difficulty bending or straightening, is governed by the perineum. In febrile diseases, initial symptoms in the arms with spasms, gathering of sweat on the lips and mouth, open nostrils and lowered eyes, with sweating profusely like pearls, hardness below the breasts two inches, fullness and palpitation in the sides, are managed by the channel at the wrist.[369p]
Shivering with cold, unable to extend the hands, coughing with phlegm, a feeling of nausea in the chest, unable to sweat from the temples, feeling irritated and full-bodied. Due to the cough and bleeding, the hour of the wrist governs this. The left side punctures the right, and the right side punctures the left.

Shivering with cold, the little finger does not respond to heat and cold, no sweating, headaches, sore throat, curled tongue, heat between the little fingers, heat in the mouth, troubled heart and chest pain, pain in the inside of the arms and sides, deafness, coughing, and shivering. Dry mouth, severe headaches that cannot be ignored, the lesser seal governs this.

Shivering with cold, alternating between cold and heat, pain in the shoulders and arms, unable to regard the head, feeling irritated and hot all over, aversion to cold, red and painful eyes, tearing and membrane growing in the corners of the eyes, acute pain, sneezing, deafness, heavy arm pain, elbow cramps, scabs and lesions, sensation of pulling in the chest towards the shoulder, weeping out in shock, stiff neck, cold body and head that cannot be regarded, the rear stream governs this.

Shivering with cold, hot swollen neck, if strong, elbow cramps and head pain are severe, if weak, warts will develop, and smaller scabs and lesions arise. The main regulating point is the upright position.

Wheezing, continuous bleeding due to heat illness, troubled heart with sadness, abdominal bloating and reversed breath, heated internal air, legs and shins so cold one cannot lay down, fullness in the chest, hot explosive discharge, breathing upwards, cold beneath the feet, chest heaviness leading to nausea, no desire for food or drink, the hidden white governs this.

Heat pain and troubled heart, cold feet and clearness, excessive sweating, first take the quinoa grain, then the great stream and the artery between the big toe. All should be nourished first.

If the hands and feet are cold to the joints, with wheezing, it leads to death.[370p]
When the hands and feet are clear but hot and there is no sweating, the limbs cramp, and there is a headache that feels like being pierced by a needle. Movement exacerbates the agitation, with throat discomfort, a dry and rolled-up tongue, and an inability to reach the inner arm with the head. There is deafness and ringing in the ears, all governed by the lower orifices.

When the outer knee is painful, there is a fever with no sweating, redness and pain in the outer corners of the eyes, dizziness, pain in the jaws, cold reversals leading to tears, ringing and deafness in the ears, excessive sweating, itchy eyes, and chest pain that prevents turning sides—this is governed by the foot rivers.

When vision is unclear, chilly tremors occur, there is a film over the eyes, the pupils are not visible, there is pain in the waist and flanks, and the feet ache and cramp—this is governed by the hill abyss.

When there is heaviness in the head, nosebleeds, and convulsions, with no sweating, restlessness, heat beneath the feet, a disinclination to approach clothing, neck pain, and a film over the eyes, while nasal and urination difficulties occur—these are governed by the extreme yin.[371p]
Pain in the lower back and spine, heaviness and soreness in the legs, trembling and unable to stand for long, a sensation of cracking in the legs, acute pain in the heels, colicky pain in the lower abdomen, throat pain, difficulty with bowel movements, and bloating—this is governed by the point Chengshan.

If there is numbness and heaviness in the hands and feet persisting for a long time, with heat and pain in the shins, this is governed by the point Neiting.

For convulsive shocks, with a sensation of tightening in the legs and cracking in the joints, the point Shugu is indicated.

If there is stiff neck and back, dizziness, and the legs feeling constricted while the joints feel cracked, this is governed by the point Kunlun.

For the persistent pain of wind-dampness, if the feet feel like walking on ice and then suddenly entering hot water, with limbs feeling heavy and a throbbing headache, nausea, and boredom alternating, dizziness accompanied by sweating, prolonged cases leading to vision disturbance, emotional fluctuations, shortness of breath, and a lack of joy could result in death within three years.

If the feet are too painful to be raised, one should lie to the side to access the point in the joint area. Use a round needle; a large needle is not appropriate. For knee pain, use the needle at the point Dubi with a round needle. When the needle is inserted, it should be intermittently applied.

For numbness in the feet, needle the Fengfu point.[372p]
From the waist down to the feet, there is lack of sensation, making it impossible to sit or stand; the lumbar region governs this. If there is heat in the feet, causing pain that prevents prolonged sitting, or if there is dampness obstructing movement, the point San Yin Jiao governs this. Fu Liu, Feng Long, Da Du, are responsible for wind and swollen limbs. For Beriberi, first apply moxibustion at Feng Shi, then at Fu Tu, next at Du Bi, then at both knees' eyes, followed by San Li, then Shang Lian, then Xia Lian, and finally at Jue Gu.

In total, there are eight moxibustion points: the first is Feng Shi point. The patient should stand upright, arms hanging down, fingers spread over both hips, and moxibustion should be applied directly on the center of the thigh muscle with the fingertip. Apply moxibustion with a hundred strong doses; for a lighter condition, do not reduce below a hundred, while for a heavier condition, it may go up to five or six hundred at one point. Do not apply all at once; give three intervals between applications for best results.

The second point is Fu Tu. The patient should sit cross-legged, placing their palm horizontally over the knees, with fingers pointing parallel to the bent knee. Moxibustion should be applied to the middle part of the side flesh at this location, with a hundred doses recommended, but fifty doses may also be sufficient. The third point is Du Bi.[384p]
At the upper edge of the patella, on the outer side where the bone is flat, pressing with the hand and feeling relief indicates the spot; another source says it is below the patella, near the three outer bony protrusions where the foot moves, pressing here yields relief. Burning with moxa may require fifty to a hundred applications.

The fourth point is Knee Eye (Xiyan). It is located in the depressions on either side below the patella, situated in the middle.

The fifth point is Three Miles (Sanli). It is found five inches below the knee joint, on the outer side of the tibia; one source states it is three inches below the knee joint, depending on the size of the patient’s hand for measurement. Burn with moxa a hundred times.

The sixth point is Upper Margin (Shanglian). It is located one inch below Three Miles, also on the outer side of the tibia. Burn with moxa a hundred times.

The seventh point is Lower Margin (Xialian). It is located one inch below Upper Margin; another source mentions it is on the outer side of the tibia. Burn with moxa a hundred times.

The eighth point is Absolute Bone (Juegu). It is situated one inch above the outer ankle, while another source says it is four inches.

For all these points, burning with moxa does not need to be completed in one round; it can be done daily. Ideally, complete the required number of applications within three days.[385p]
When there is a sickness in one foot, apply moxibustion to that foot; if both feet are afflicted, moxibustion should be done on both. Weakness in the feet often affects both legs. Additionally, if one feels discomfort in the foot, moxibustion should be applied at three cun and at the point of the bone. For afflictions in both feet, moxibustion should be performed at four locations. The number of treatments depends on the severity of the illness; even for light ailments, do not reduce the amount below one hundred applications. If the condition does not improve, continue moxibustion in order, as more is better. Some say moxibustion at the point of the bone is particularly important. If a person has weak feet and does not treat it promptly, there may be swelling in the lower abdomen or difficulty in breathing, thus requiring the application of moxibustion to various important points and joints on the abdomen and back, along with taking Baifeng Powder; often they experience healing. If the illness is felt in the abdomen and the patient is unable to bear the pain, then instead of extensive treatment, focus moxibustion on the chest, heart, abdomen, and points on both feet, where they may also achieve good recovery. The method for measuring a person's moxibustion is to cover the hand, stretching four fingers; measure up to the middle joint, where the width becomes one unit. There are two kinds of measurements; one where three fingers count as one unit, but for weak feet, use four fingers as one unit.[386p]
The existing methods retain the old practices, including points such as Liangqiu, Dubi, Sanli, Shanglian, Xialian, Jiexi, Taichong, Yanglingquan, Juegu, Kunlun, Yinlingquan, San Yin Jiao. Originally, it included "Foot Taiyin and Foot Taiyang," which are extraneous, so they are omitted. Points like Gongsun, Fulium, Rangu, Yongquan, Chengshan, Shugu, etc., total eighteen points. The old methods often involved moxibustion at Baihui, Fengfu, and the five zang and six fu points. Recently, those who practice moxibustion have noted that it commonly raises the Qi upward, which is why they no longer follow those methods. If the Qi does not stop, it can still be used. The key is that if a disease has already manifested and there are fears of no recovery, all must be treated with moxibustion. There are eight points on each foot, excluding the peculiarities of the toes, which Cao's school refers to as the "Eight Chongs," effectively stimulating downward Qi. At the tips of the ten toes, called "Qi Tips," apply moxibustion three times daily, which is a significant method. The Eight Chongs can be treated with moxibustion seven times a day, and the upward flow of Qi will then cease.[387p]
If the patient does not deeply understand their condition, one must be very careful not to perform moxibustion on them. Be cautious, be cautious. When moxibustion is done on the eight points of the pulse, the moxa must be made small.

According to the "Treasure Mirror of Health," for cold in the knee, the Qi Sea point is located one and a half inches below the navel, arising from the Ren vessel. The Three Mile point is located three inches below the knee, between the two tendons on the outer side of the knee; this point is where the foot yangming channel converges. It can be treated with three cones of moxa, and a needle inserted to a depth of half an inch.

The Three Yin Intersection point is located three inches above the inner ankle bone, in the middle of the depression below the bone; it is where the foot taiyin, shaoyin, and jueyin channels converge, and can be treated with three cones of moxa, and a needle inserted to a depth of three-tenths of an inch.

The Marrow Connection point is at the base of the outer ankle bone, under the auxiliary bone, and at the back knee. It is a point related to the marrow. The ancient healer Jie Gu said: If the head feels hot like fire, and the feet cold like ice, one can moxibust the Yang Auxiliary point. He also said that if the knee feels sour and cold, one can treat the Marrow Connection point.[388p]
Yangfu and Erxue are located four inches above the external malleolus, in front of the auxiliary bone and at the end of the absolute bone, about three fen away from the previous point and seven fen from Qiuxu. This is where the Foot Shaoyang meridian runs. Moxibustion can be applied with three seven-grain sticks, and the needle should be inserted to a depth of five fen.

According to the "Medical Guidelines," for red and swollen heels or frostbite, at the front of the toes and the back of the heel at the boundary of red and white flesh, below the bone, insert the needle three fen deep and give a gentle puncture to induce bleeding, applying moxibustion with two seven-grain sticks.

For swelling and pain from foot edema, select Sanli and Juegu points at two and a half inches each; puncture Qiuxu to one inch and reduce; puncture Xingjian to five fen and retain for eight breaths, then reduce; puncture Jiexi to five fen and retain for ten breaths, then reduce; puncture Shangqiu to five fen and reduce for ten breaths.

For treating foot edema, select points from the meridians accordingly. Puncture Xian Gu to three fen and reduce; puncture Qian Gu to five fen and reduce, moxibustion; puncture Zhong Feng to reduce and moxibustion; for Xia Xi, first reduce and then reinforce with moxibustion; for Yangfu and Juegu, each at two and a half inches reduce and moxibustion; puncture Tong Gu to one fen and reduce with moxibustion.[389p]
Bian Que treats athlete's foot by taking kidney energy near the navel, each four inches apart. The points are Jianjing, Sanli, Qihai, and Jiaolong.

For cold and damp athlete's foot causing redness, swelling, and sores, use Zhongfeng for five parts to reduce it; Yangfu and Juegu, each two and a half inches, also reduce it with moxibustion.

Another method: use Xingjian, Sanli, Zhaohai, Kunlun, Juegu, Jinggu, Weizhong, and Sanyinjiao.

If both feet are numb and the knees are weak, use Fengshi, located on the outer side of the leg, with the middle finger pointing to the corresponding acupoints. Needle five parts, tonify more and reduce less, leaving the needle in for five breaths—first reduce, then tonify.

Additionally, for inability to walk, use Qiuxu, Xingjian, Kunlun, Taichong, Yangfu, Sanyinjiao, Fuliu, and Sanli. This one point greatly treats inability to walk.

For needling and moxibustion of various pains, first clarify the meridians, then differentiate between superficial and deep. The meridians refer to the twelve meridians of the hands and feet.

For arm pain: use Jianyu, Shousanli, and Waiguan.[390p]
Pain in the arms and numbness often points to the shoulder point (Jianyu), shoulder well (Jianjing), and the 曲池 (Quchi). Another method involves selecting Jianyu, Quchi, the radial side of the hand, and Hegu. If these do not yield results, then try Jianjing and Lieque.

For pain in the arm that radiates to the wrist, use Yemin, and follow the skin towards Yangchi, where you will need to apply treatment; then, from Zhongzhu along the skin to the wrist bones, apply treatment there as well.

For internal pain along the arm’s radial side, select Jingqu at one point, avoiding moxibustion; for Lingdao at one point, insert the needle, angling forward three points; for Shaohai at five points.

For wrist pain, focus on Yangxi and Quchi.[391p]

If there is pain in the knee and tightness in the muscles, treat the points Fengchi, Sanjian, Sanyinjiao, and Sanli. When seated and experiencing knee pain, treat the area where the hip bone connects. If standing alleviates heat in the knee joint, treat the joint there. If knee pain radiates to the big toe, treat the back of the knee; after loosening the knee, find the point in the flexed foot known as Weizhong. If seated with the knee pain feeling obstructed, treat the joint by pressing behind the knee; stand and apply pressure while moving, feeling the response in the muscles. If the knee pain prevents bending or stretching, treat the inner part of the back at the Dazhu point.[396p]
If the heel feels broken, treat it at the Yangming Zhongyu point, which is the Sānlǐ point.

For pain in the knee as if separated, treat it at the Jǔyáng and Shàoyáng points, according to Wang Bing’s annotation of the "Suwen" Bone Hollow Theory. This refers to the Rángǔ point.

If there is excessive movement of the limbs and an inability to stand for long, treat it at the Shàoyáng Wei point, originally stated as "miscellaneous,” but amended in the "Suwen" Bone Hollow Theory. According to the "Jia Yi Jing," this point is located five cun above the outer ankle, which is the Guāngmíng point.

If both elbows are contracted, use the Qūchí point at nine fen, first draining then tonifying, tonifying four breaths and draining nine breaths. For the Shìzé point, use it like a bow for needling, five fen, first tonifying then draining.

For tendons contracting and bone pain, tonify the Húnmén point.[397p]
Zhang Zhongwen's divine acupuncture method treats acute contractions of the foot tendons, where bending and stretching aren’t possible: burn moxa on both sides of the curved points (in autumn), around the left and right feet. Each point receives three burns, specifically at the internal and external curved intersection points. For each foot, two fires are used simultaneously, and the moxa is burned down to the flesh. Initially, pain is felt, but then two people blow until the fire goes out. Moxa is applied at noon, and once the moxa takes effect, the organs may automatically shift or rotate with a sound like thunder, leading to an immediate recovery. This method is remarkably effective and cannot be quantified.

For the knee's tendons that cannot relax, take a point one and a half inches above the knee bend.

If the knee’s tendons are cramped and cannot open, take the two sharp external points of the knees and apply moxa 27 times, targeting the Weiyang point.

The "Jingyue Complete Book" states: When foot illness is first perceived, one should apply moxa 20-30 times at the affected area, or use a thunder fire needle to guide the dampness out, complemented by drinking fermented liquor to open the channels and disperse evil. This is the essential method.

If blockage has already formed and the evil is strong, there will be significant swelling, pain, and heat, and medicaments alone will struggle to disperse it. In such cases, it is advisable to use a lancet to remove the stasis blood to alleviate the heat and swelling, followed by medication.[398p]
Guidelines for Practice

The "Remarkable Efficacy of Good Remedies" says: To treat a sudden cramping in the foot, stretch the foot and tightly pull it forward; the pain will then cease. The "Secret Essentials for Preserving Life" states that for numbness in the hands and feet, place the left foot on the right knee, use the right hand to pull the left foot, and support the heel with the left hand, pulling towards the right while simultaneously turning the head. Do the same for the opposite side. In addition, engage in practices that promote the circulation of energy, utilizing the tidal flow of energy. For symptoms of both qi and blood deficiency, begin at the origin point and gradually stimulate the affected area. Rotate and twist to restore proper alignment. You can practice this while sitting, standing, or lying down. Occasionally, use your nails to pinch the numb areas—this will stimulate blood flow. For wind diseases affecting hands and feet, focus on the navel and use a breathing technique, perhaps focusing on the back, and then disperse energy throughout the limbs to alleviate pain in the joints, imagining a burning sensation. For pain in the fingers, concentrate on the afflicted area, using circular motions, and further break it down to disperse the energy. For numbness in the hands and feet, focus on rotating the navel and the Qihai point, and at night, turn over to let the water nourish Kunlun. Sweating all over and healing the limbs requires diligent practice. It is beneficial to rub both feet against each other, especially at the three yin points. For weakness in the hands and feet, first focus on the navel, then move from the Yongquan point up to the navel and back down, while crossing the energy from the left hand to the right and vice versa, performing this six times each. For burning sensations in the affected areas, push and disperse the energy while imagining washing them with water.[399p]
Hand disease like anthrax: for the bones and joints both inside and outside the hands, imagine a fire burning them, then wash with water, and again circulate and disperse the blood vessels of the limbs. For foot sores, at the affected area, visualize and rotate multiple times, then push and disperse it, applying fire to heal it. For hand wind (a type of ailment), from the heart of the left hand, imagine fire rising and rotating to the shoulder, crossing over the heart, and reaching the heart of the right hand; do the same from the heart of the left hand. For foot qi (a condition), at the Yongquan point on the soles, where dampness enters, daily rotate and alternate the bare feet, using one hand to grip a finger and the other to rub it. When the feet feel warm after doing this many times, slightly move and curl the toes to ease it. Alternatively, someone else can rub it, but self-rubbing is preferable.[400p]
Strengthen the legs, free from weakness and pain. Accompanying this is the method of unblocking the meridians: start from the North Pole to determine the axis, spin three times. The universe encompasses everything; descend below the navel, splitting into two paths, spiraling down before the legs, connecting uninterruptedly. Move in pairs around the base of the legs, winding back towards the original sea, rising to the mingmen to converge. Rotate right, then left, spinning three times, dividing two shoulders from below the spine, passing beyond the elbows to the outer point, reaching the palms, following the inner path over the shoulder well, through the neck to the niwan, circulating down through the bright hall, gradually resting the eyes, downward to the chest cavity, gathering at the heart center. From the left, descend, spinning three times, as before splitting below the navel, circulating throughout the body, flowing and employing, during the hours of the rabbit and rooster, stopping at either nine or twenty-one degrees. Be careful not to cling; whether it is or isn't, this is called refining one's form and harmonizing one's energy.[401p]
Compilation of Ancient and Modern Books - Complete Record of the Medical Section, Volume 198

Four Limbs Section

Medical Case

The "Records of the Three Kingdoms" states in the biography of Hua Tuo: A person, during the Qinglong period, saw the Governor of Shanyang, Liu Jingzong of Guangling. Jingzong mentioned that throughout the Zhongping era, he had met Hua Tuo several times, and that Hua Tuo's diagnosis of illnesses and his pulse examinations were as accurate as a divine revelation.

Liu Xun of Langye was a governor of Henei, who had a daughter nearly twenty years old. She had a sore on her left knee that was itchy but not painful. The sore would heal for several days only to reappear, this cycle continued for seven or eight years. They called in Tuo to examine her, and he said: "This is easy to treat. You should acquire a yellow dog with rice husk, and two good horses. Tie the dog by the neck with a rope and let it run alongside the horses. The horses will tire quickly."

After running about thirty miles, the dog could not continue. They then had a person drag it for about fifty miles. Tuo then gave the girl medicine to drink, and she immediately fell asleep, unaware of her surroundings.

Then he took a big knife and cut the dog's belly near its hind legs, placing the cut part against the sore. He instructed them to hold it in place for two to three inches. In a moment, something resembling a snake emerged from the sore. Tuo swiftly drove an iron spike through the snake's head while it was still within the skin; it writhed for a long time before finally stopping. He then pulled it out; it was about three feet long, entirely a snake, with only eyes but no other features, and had backward scales.

He applied an ointment to the wound, and within seven days, it healed.[402p]
The "Bingbu Shouji" states: Prime Minister Wu Yuanheng, while in Xichuan, suffered from a severe leg ulcer that caused unbearable itching and pain, with numerous physicians' treatments proving ineffective. Upon arriving in the capital, a clerk presented a remedy, which led to his recovery. The remedy involved crushing common purslane and applying it, only needing two or three applications.

The "Hui Chen Lu" mentions: The Yangmei of Kuaiji is the best in the world. Tong Guan suffered from athlete's foot, and some said that the kernels of Yangmei could cure it. The county magistrate, Wang Yi, gifted him fifty shi (a unit of measure), and Guan used it to achieve recovery. The kernels were prepared by mixing them with persimmon varnish, and when exposed, they cracked open naturally.

The "Rumen Shiqin" states: An elderly man, Ma Sou, aged fifty-nine, was punished with a cane for failing to pay autumn taxes, which shock led to a long-standing condition of wind-induced spasms lasting three years. His illness manifested in violent tremors of hands and feet, rendering him unable to hold objects, requiring others to feed him, with his mouth and eyes appearing dazed, and unable to control his movements, resembling a puppet on strings, drawing crowds whenever he appeared in public. At night, he experienced fever, shedding all clothing and blankets, his body sick and itchy, alternating between internal heat and external chill. He longed for death yet lacked the strength to end his life. Seeking medical help led to financial ruin, worsening his condition. His son, a former minor official in the town, carried news of his parents' illness. The doctor stated: This illness is very easy to treat. During the summer heat, with a single bout of treatment, you only need to undergo it again to be cured. Now, as autumn brings chill, it should be done three times.[403p]
If there is no improvement, further needling of the Yu point will surely bring healing. First, use the Tongsheng powder to induce sweating, then take the Yongji medicine, which will cause the expulsion of one to two liters of phlegm. By evening, another five to seven passages will be released, and the illness will be somewhat relieved. Wait five days before administering another expulsion, leading to the discharge of three to four liters of phlegm, resembling clumped chicken fat and appearing hot like soup. The elderly man, trembling and unable to probe himself, had his wife assist him; his throat and neck were swollen, and he felt dazed as if intoxicated. After about one or two hours, he gradually awakened and expelled a few more passages, immediately feeling lighter and less tremulous, with the heat also subsiding. He was able to walk again, use his hands for grooming, and handle utensils. Before the third expulsion was reached, the illness vanished as if washed away, leaving him feeling extremely cold. The physician said: He should be supplemented with food, and in time, he will recover. The reason is that after a severe illness, the defensive qi has not yet returned, thus it is advisable to use medicines that disperse wind and guide qi; one must not use warming medications, for that could lead to other ailments.

An elderly man from Huangru, with both hands trembling, appeared as if he were sawing; he couldn’t cover himself with a blanket in winter. While treating a patient in Wuyang, I passed through Huangru and did not apply medication but needled the middle point behind the thumbs on both hands. The physician remarked: From the elbows upward, there are no ailments, solely the trembling in the hands, which is what the leftist refers to as wind-induced minor illness. Alternatively, needling the Houbie point, which corresponds to the hand's Taiyang point, and bending the little finger to where the lines converge is also a significant point.[404p]
A young boy from the Li family suffered from spasms in his hands and feet, signifying the influence of a spirit. The spirit said: "This is caused by excessive heart fire; do not restrain his hands. He should go through the spasms." This was due to the nurse's improper cradling. They then cleaned the ground, sprinkled it with water, and re-sprinkled it until it was thoroughly wet, placing the child face down on the ground for a long time. The child turned and rolled, getting completely muddy, and they washed him with water. After a while, he was cured.

Another patient, a tax official, experienced pain from wind, cold, and dampness, feeling heavy and swollen in the waist and legs, suffering greatly at night. His feet were unbearably cold, and for five to six months, he still wore cotton socks. The skin on his knees and feet was minimally exposed; when cold wind touched it, it penetrated his meridians, worsening his condition, with pain fluctuating and shifting unpredictably. In the area of greatest pain, there would be spasms and swelling, but the flesh color remained unchanged, with the skin feeling like it had bugs crawling beneath it. Whenever exposed to wind and cold, his illness would surely worsen. His appetite decreased, and his body became weak and thin, requiring assistance to walk or stand. He had taken various warming herbs and moxibustion, but to no avail for three years.

One day, I examined his pulse; both hands were heavy, slippery, and strong. I first administered one dose each of Water Conduit Pill and Meridian Passage Powder. That night, he had over thirty bowel movements, and his pain was reduced by half. Gradually, he took Red Poria Decoction, Chuanxiong Decoction, and Fangfeng Decoction, which are prescribed in the "Xuanming Lun" for treating bi syndrome. He took these three remedies three times a day, boiled at seven to eight qian, and soon began to sweat lightly. Following that, through a process of steam treatment using a delicate stove, he was cured.[405p]
In Yinggao, Han Jiqing suffered from damp sores from his thighs to his feet, with the larger ones resembling coins and the smaller ones like beans. They itched, causing him to scratch them open; when water touched them, they became soaked and resembled insects crawling on socks. Even after healing, they would recur, leaving pits as scars, and for over ten years, he could not recover. A certain physician remarked, saying: "These are damp sores. They arise from moisture, hence they are often found on the lower parts of the body. With boats and carts, one travels over ten miles, and it's as if they have been swept away."

Zhang Zhongwen, the liquor supervisor from Guyang Town, visited a temple and noticed that the workman had built a lookout platform about four feet high. While climbing down, he twisted one foot, causing swelling around the outer ankle, with a heat and pain like fire. One doctor intended to use a needle (gold not being suitable) to prick the swollen area to release blood. But another physician urgently stopped him, saying: "The pain from the twist is already severe; to inflict a needle prick would cause double the pain. How can one endure that?" Hence, he administered Shenyou pills, around eighty or ninety, and instructed him to abstain from hot foods.

At midnight, the swollen area became itchy, the pain subsided, and he could walk normally again. The physician said: "My method has healed all ten cases, I do not deceive future generations."[406p]
Zhongming's wife, whenever winter comes, experiences a burning pain in her hands. A physician said: "The limbs are the foundation of all Yang energy. In summer, they disperse and there's no pain, but when autumn and winter arrive, they contract and thus cause pain." He treated her with the Sanhua Shen'you pill and she was cured.

In Yancheng, there lived a man named Liang Jia, who was over sixty. One morning, he woke up and began to comb his hair, only to find that the fingers of his left hand were numb. Soon, half of his arm became numb, then the other arm, and shortly after, the upper half of his head. By the time he finished combing, he felt numbness from his side down to his feet. He hadn’t had a proper bowel movement for two or three days. He consulted other doctors, who all said it was due to wind; whether through medicine or acupuncture, none provided relief, so he sought treatment from the physician.

The physician examined him and said: "The three pulse points in your left arm are faint, being three times smaller than those of your right. This is not merely due to wind; there is also a combination of dryness caused by heat." He prescribed methods of expelling along with purging and sweating, and the numbness immediately subsided. Later, he used warm and moistening medications to treat the dryness, but the little and ring fingers remained numb. The physician said: "The root of the illness is gone; this is just residual heat." Only then was it appropriate to perform acupuncture at the Xigu point, which is the space of the bones.

On a sunny and mild day, he went to perform the acupuncture, using the technique from the "Ling Shu" involving the chicken foot method—he inserted the needle while the patient was lying upward, applying it three times, then withdrew it and inserted it while lying downward. The numbness throughout the fingers was relieved, and the hand felt as hot as fire. The numbness completely disappeared. In the past, Liu Hejian wrote the "Yuan Bing Shi," often associating numbness with dryness, truly a connoisseur of understanding ailments.[407p]
In the summer of Yang, a woman from the Hu family had cracked hands and feet, and her eyes were dim. The physician said: "This is caused by wind affecting the liver." He also said: "The sounds of resonance and disturbances are both manifestations of wind. Wind belongs to wood, and when wood is congested, it must be released." He meant that it needs to be expelled. First, he ordered an emetic, and then prescribed a modified Gui Pi Decoction with Angelica to drain it, which had immediate effect.

A maidservant of the physician had frostbite on her feet. The physician instructed her to take Zhuo Che Pill and Jun Chuan Powder, leading to a significant purge, and she recovered. Some questioned this. The physician replied: "When the heart fire is reduced, the cold below dissipates; what is there to doubt?"[408p]
Mr. Ma's brother was bitten by a dog while in the village. He was carried home, and his leg swelled up like a jar, as hard as iron or stone. Poison entered, causing him to vomit and preventing food from staying down, along with a heavy headache. He went to consult a healer. The young maid said, "The pain follows the reduction in benefits; use betel nut pills to expel it." There were two excretions, but it did not improve. Just then, the healer returned from Wuyang and said to Ma, "With such swelling, can the three yin and three yang of the foot be unblocked?" Ma replied, "Neither can be unblocked." The healer asked, "Then why not use a strong purge?" He ordered that night to take one hundred and fifty pills of Zhuoche, along with three or four qian of Tongjing San. By midnight, there were fourteen excretions, and the swelling immediately subsided, leaving a walnut-patterned skin, even thinner than the uninjured leg. The healer cautioned, "Be careful not to apply a plaster, as it must allow the poisoned fluids to flow out; the purulent blood and water should continue to move." Another day, fearing the poison had not yet fully dissipated, he took over a hundred more pills of Zhuoche, along with three or four qian of Junchuan San, resulting in six excretions. The patient said, "Fourteen excretions are easy to manage, but six are unexpectedly difficult; why is this?" The healer replied, "When the illness is severe, it overcomes the medicine; when the illness is milder, it cannot withstand the medicine." On the sixth day, the purulent water was completely gone. The healer stated, "While the purulent water flows, do not fear the wind; after it is gone, fear the wind." He then used a wind-canceling cake, taking it three times a day. After another two days, he finally applied a wound-healing powder, and it formed a scab. Alas! The use of medicine varies and makes a significant difference. If he had not seen the healer, the advice on reduction of benefits would not have been accurate. This shows that even recognizing the need for a doctor is difficult, let alone actually using one.[409p]
Mr. Ma's wife fell ill, her pain was unbearable. A penny's worth of a medicinal wine was mixed to relieve her symptoms, and in the middle of the night, she vomited; after vomiting, her pain lessened. I lamented, saying: "I once saw Chen Wu suffering from a similar condition; the doctor thought it was caused by small insects, or perhaps she had touched something toxic on the grass, and her affliction lingered for several months, only recovering when the pus was entirely expelled. Looking back on it now, it is laughable."

Then there was a gentleman who suffered from severe pain in his waist and hips, making it difficult for him to walk or ride. Some treated it as a case of athlete's foot due to cold and damp, while others thought it was a deficiency. Herbs like black, aconite, myrrh, and others that invigorate blood and strengthen bones were all employed. After more than sixty days, his eyes were red and he was overheated; both his urination and defecation were not normal, and his waist and hip pain remained unchanged. A physician examined both his hands; the pulses were all deep and slow. The deep pulse indicated a problem within, so it was appropriate to drain it. He took a dose of Zhuoche Pills and Junquan Powder, eliminating over twenty blockages. By morning, after consuming a few bowls of scallion porridge, he was helped onto a horse and was already able to appear refreshed.[410p]
Li Shibolang from Tangxi had been suffering from a back ailment for several years, unable to fully extend his large feet and walking in a hunched, limping manner. Medications had proven ineffective and only seemed to worsen his condition. One autumn evening, after crossing water, his illness flared up again. The doctor prescribed him a medicinal pill weighing four pounds. His father, Li Zhong'an, then requested medicine from Mr. Dai. Mr. Dai asked, "What medication has he been taking recently?" Zhong'an replied, "The four-pound pill." Mr. Dai then asked, "Are your eyes feeling dim and red?" The father was startled and responded, "His eyes are severely swollen." Mr. Dai said, "You must come quickly; if you do not, he will lose his sight." When they finally arrived, he walked with a cane, unable to see because of the swelling in his eyes. Mr. Dai first instructed them to induce vomiting, after which he expelled a large quantity of pills, and suddenly his vision cleared. He discarded the cane. After further purging, he was able to read official documents within a month. He was then prescribed Angelica pills and was able to walk home with ease.[411p]
The "Ten Books of the Eastern Garden" states: In the winter of the Gui Mao year, during heavy snowfall, Dong Jianjun from Ling Shou County went to Zhen Ding for some affairs and suddenly felt a strong wind blowing. Upon examination, he found all six pulse positions to be taut, and pressing revealed a strong and forceful pulse. The symptoms included sudden spasms of the hands, constipation, and a red, hot face, indicating an onset of wind-cold attacking the body. The four limbs correlate with the spleen; if wind and cold evil affect it, then there will be spasms and pain, showing that wind is the superficial ailment while cold exists on the exterior. The "Inner Canon" states that cold causes muscle contractions, which directly relates to this situation. The patient, who regularly drank alcohol, had damp heat accumulating in his intestines and stomach, leading to constipation and a red, hot face. Internally, the hands and feet are afflicted by Yangming (the Yangming meridian), while externally, the Taiyin spleen meridian is suffering from the wind-cold evil. Therefore, I used cinnamon and licorice to expel the cold evil and ease the spasms. Also, using the bitter and cold properties of bitter coptis to purge heat and moisten dryness, I urgently rescued the kidney water. I applied angelica and kudzu to uplift Yang energy and mobilize the meridians of the hands and feet without obstruction. Additionally, I used cinnamon, which is spicy and warm, to guide into the hand Yangming meridian. To replenish the spleen's energy and prevent the invasion of wind-cold, I added peony and licorice specifically to nourish the spleen’s Qi, thus suppressing the wood evil and benefiting the lung's metal. I included ginseng to boost the innate Qi as an auxiliary treatment, along with angelica to relieve internal urgency while harmonizing the blood and moistening dryness. The chief formula is the Blood Activating and Meridian Opening Decoction.[412p]
In the spring of the Year of the Snake, when Lian Pingzhang was thirty-eight years old, he suffered from a condition marked by body and limbs swelling slightly with redness. His feet and shins were red and swollen, causing unbearable pain. He did not dare lean on a walking stick; when he touched his skin, the pain intensified. He would rise only to lie back down, struggling day and night, unable to describe his suffering, and sought my treatment.

Due to the high, cold northern lands, he had consumed much alcohol over time, damaging his spleen and hindering its ability to process food and drink, resulting in this condition. I prescribed him a decoction of Angelica to relieve pain, and his pain was reduced by half. After a second dose, the swelling and pain completely disappeared, leaving only slight redness and swelling in the tips of his right-hand fingers. I used a three-edged needle to prick the tips of his fingers, and much vile blood was released, fully eliminating the redness and swelling.

A few days later, after eating moist food, he experienced pain in his limbs again, so I treated him with a decoction of bitter orange and rhubarb. The ailment, foot edema, is caused by excessive water and dampness. The face gathers this dampness, obstructing the blood's circulation and resulting in aching limbs and joints. The Inner Canon states: wind can overcome dampness. Qianghuo, being aromatic and warm, penetrates the joints to expel dampness, hence it is used primarily. When blood stagnates and cannot flow, pain ensues, and Angelica's warming qualities disperse the obstruction and alleviate pain. The bitter and cold nature of bitter orange treats distention and aids in digestion, thus it serves as an adjunct. Rhubarb, being bitter and cold, guides out the damp heat from the face and treats all accumulated blood clots, acting decisively, which is why it is included as an envoy in this formulation.[413p]
The "Danxi Heart Method" states: If the soles of the feet feel sharp pain like being pricked with a needle, or if there is swelling in the ankles, and the wrists also feel painful and swollen, accompanied by urgent diarrhea, this indicates a deficiency of blood, and that the lower body has been affected by dampness, thereby causing illness; the remedy is the Jianbu Pill.

There was a villager who was hunched and had cramping legs, rendering him unable to work. I examined his pulse and found both hands to be heavy and tight, so I administered the Renyuan Renal Decoction. He experienced vomiting and diarrhea for over a month, alternating between the two. After three applications of this, he finally recovered.

Sir Cheng, in his life, always felt heat in his feet below the ankles, and could not add cotton to them in winter. He once remarked, "I am robust and not afraid of the cold." I replied, "This is due to deficiency in the three yin meridians of your feet; it would be best to stop excessive activities and nurture your yin and blood, which might help you avoid problems." He only smiled and did not respond. He was merely seventeen years old when he succumbed to atrophy and died six months later.[414p]
The "Hygienic Treasure" states: Zhang Danian from Zhen Ding Prefecture, at the age of twenty-nine, had a strong fondness for alcohol. During the fifth month of the year Xinyi (the 13th year of the Yuan dynasty), he suffered from swelling and pain in his finger joints, making flexion and extension difficult; his knees were similarly affected. He felt a fullness in his chest, a heaviness throughout his body, a lack of desire to eat, and when he did eat, he felt the urge to vomit. His complexion was pale yellow, and his energy was diminished. In June, he came seeking treatment from me. Upon examining his pulse, it was found to be deep and slow; a slow pulse indicates spleen issue. The "Nanjing" states that the body is heavy with joint pain. The spleen governs the arms and legs; due to his long history of drinking, combined with the current excessive dampness, the moisture flowed to his limbs, causing the swelling and pain. The "Inner Canon" states that all dampness causing swelling and pain is related to the spleen soil. Zhong Jing mentions: “When dampness flows into the joints, the limbs become painful”—this refers to that situation. He should be treated with the major Qianghuo Decoction. The "Inner Canon" further states: "When dampness lingers internally, treat with bitter warmth, disperse it with bitterness and drain it with lightness." It also says: "Wind can overcome dampness." Qianghuo and Duhuo are spicy and warm, penetrating the joints to overcome dampness, thus they are the monarch herbs. Shengma is bitter and neutral; Weilingxian, Fangfeng, and Cangzhu are bitter, spicy, and warm, making them dispersing ministers. If blood is stagnant and not flowing, add Danggui, which is spicy and warm to disperse it. Licorice is sweet and warm, benefiting qi and warming the center; Zexie is salty and neutral, Fuling is sweet and neutral, guiding dampness and benefiting urination, thus draining it with lightness. This harmonizes the flavors, allowing for dispersion of dampness both upwards and downwards.[415p]
Zhongshu Nianhe was forty years old, sturdy in build. In the spring of the year of Bingchen, he journeyed to the eastern part of Yangzhou. Suddenly, he experienced a surge of symptoms in his feet, with swelling throughout his body, causing pain so severe that he could not approach them. The pain in his legs was especially intense, making it impossible for him to wear shoes. He rode on horseback with his feet barely resting in the stirrups, using a bamboo container to manage the situation, and urgently came to seek help.

I recalled that the "Neijing" states: "Dampness begins within and manifests as swelling outside." Furthermore, it says: "All pains are due to excess." If the blood is excessive, it should be drained. I used a three-edged needle to pierce the swollen area several times, and blood gushed out, rising more than two feet, gradually flowing out like a thread, totaling about half a liter, with a purple-black color. Shortly after, the swelling subsided and the pain decreased. I prescribed a dose of Danggui Nian Tong decoction, weighing about one and a half liang, for him to take. That night, he was able to sleep, and after taking it again the next day, he was cured. "Bencao" mentions that certain treatments can dispel obstruction and promote flow. The "Neijing" states that internal dampness should be treated with bitter and warming remedies.[416p]
Qianghuo is bitter and pungent, penetrating the joints to dispel dampness. Fangfeng and licorice warm and scatter the dampness flowing in the meridians, thus they are used as the main herbs. Water has a moistening property; Shengma and Gegen are bitter and pungent, with a thin flavor that leads the yang within the yin upward, allowing it to emerge through bitterness. Baizhu is bitter, sweet, and warm, harmonizing the stomach and overpowering dampness. Cangzhu is light and buoyant, with a strong energy that can eliminate dampness from the skin and pores, thus it is used as an assistant. When the blood is stagnant and not flowing, it causes pain; Danggui is warm and pungent, dispersing it to ensure that blood and qi return to their proper places. Renshen and licorice are sweet and warm, tonifying the spleen and stomach, nurturing the righteous qi so that bitter medications do not harm the stomach. Zhòngjīng says that when dampness and heat combine, the limbs and joints experience pain. Ku Shen, Huangqin, Zhim mu, and Yinchén are bitter and cold, serving to drain excess. All are prepared and stir-fried for use. If treatment does not facilitate urination, it is not effective. Zhū líng is sweet, warm, and neutral, while Zexie is salty and neutral, mild enough to promote diuresis and also capable of guiding out retained fluids, thus they are used as aids. The properties of the herbs harmonize to disperse dampness, allowing the stagnant qi to circulate freely.[417p]
The Deputy Marshal of Southern Expeditions, Da Te Mu Er, was sixty-eight years old. In the autumn of the Wuxu year, I accompanied him on a campaign southward. Passing ten miles beyond Yangzhou, it was mid-winter, and I fell ill. My digestion was poor, my abdomen was cold and painful, my lower legs felt icy, and I could not feel any pain or itch when I scratched myself. I attempted to warm myself by burning stones, but it did not help. I examined my pulse, which was deep, thin, and weak. Considering my condition, I realized that at such an advanced age and with a weak constitution, entering enemy territory, facing the urgent demands of warfare, along with the cold of night and day, disrupted eating habits and excessive consumption of dairy products had weakened my vitality. Walking on damp ground had allowed cold and dampness to invade my body, leading to my discomfort. The “Inner Canon” states: When afflicted by cold, one may experience mild symptoms such as a cough, or more severe manifestations like diarrhea and pain. This results from a combination of cold and dampness causing illness. Therefore, the proper course of action is to quickly dispel the cold and dampness, and strongly invigorate the Yang energy; moxibustion is necessary to remedy the illness. First, I applied moxa sticks to the Qi Hai point, doing it a hundred times to bolster the Yang energy in the lower abdomen.[418p]
For the treatment of coldness in the knee and its reversal, and to guide the yang energy downward, moxibustion is applied to the three miles and two points, each with three seven-sticks. Additionally, moxibustion is used on the three yin junctions to dispel the cold and dampness affecting the feet. Therefore, the prescription states that cold invasion should be treated with warming, pungent herbs, while exterior dampness should be addressed with bitter and hot herbs, which are released by bitterness.

For this, Aconite is the chief herb, being greatly warming and pungent, aiding yang and dispelling yin, warming the meridians and scattering cold. Dried Ginger and Cinnamon are also highly warming and pungent, dispelling cold dampness; White Atractylodes and Pinellia are bitter, pungent, warm, and dry dampness from the spleen, thus they serve as deputies. Ginseng, Cardamom, and roasted Licorice are sweet and pungent, greatly warming, nourishing the middle and benefiting qi; Fresh Ginger is pungent and warm, dispelling the clear dampness; Green Onions are pungent and warm, facilitating the upward flow of yang energy, thus they serve as assistants.

Additionally, it is said: to nourish and treat descending issues should be done urgently; when urgent, the flavor of the remedy is rich, hence a substantial dose should be taken. After several doses, the diarrhea stops and the pain diminishes, the knee gradually warms, and dietary adjustments are made, stabilizing by over ten days. After several doses of the previous remedy, a good recovery was achieved.[419p]

The "Essentials of Medicine" states: There was a person with a serious illness, unable to touch the ground for ten years, and even the best doctors had exhausted their skills without being able to cure him. His relatives placed him by the roadside to seek help. Later, a mountain man named Deng Si Ji learned of it and recorded the method, stating: Harvest the herb, dry it in the shade for over a month, pound and sieve it, then mix two qian with warm clear wine, taking it on an empty stomach. If the person’s natural constitution is strong against the medicine, the dosage can be increased to six qian. If the purging effect becomes too strong, reduce the dosage, and stop taking it once the illness is cured. Its nature is very gentle; it does not interact negatively with other medicines, but it should be avoided with tea and wheat soup; instead, licorice and gardenia can be used as substitutes for drinks.[422p]
