Honglu Zhai Shaoxi developed sores that eventually led to fever throughout his body, with symptoms including phlegm production, dry mouth, dry throat, night sweats, irritability, red urine, and hot feet, worsening by evening and causing weight loss. This indicated a deficiency of kidney yin with excess fire. I used Liu Wei Di Huang Wan, and within a month, all symptoms resolved. After three months, his vital energy was restored.

Another man had swelling in his left leg with normal flesh color, experiencing chills, fever, nausea, and reduced appetite. This indicated insufficient spleen energy affected by external pathogens. I prescribed Liu Jun Zi Decoction with addition of Huoxiang, Jiegeng, and Chuanxiong, which alleviated the chills and fever, followed by Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction to relieve the swelling and pain.

Chen Hu Lu Maocheng, due to excessive drinking and indulging in sexual activities, developed a fever and leg pain resembling sores. I gave him a formula to promote sweating, but both legs became swollen and dark, with a mist-like heat, on the verge of convulsions, and his pulse was notably strong and rapid, especially in the lower extremities. I suggested this was due to deficiency in the three yin channels of the legs, compounded by dampness from alcohol, leading to a loss of vital energy and exacerbation of pathogens. I prescribed Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction with added Shan Yao, Shan Zhu Yu, and Fu Zi, which promptly improved his pulse and symptoms. I then removed Fu Zi and after two more doses he was fully cured.[454p]
Collection of Medical Cases from Ancient and Modern Texts: Volume 199

Four Limbs Section

Medical Cases

Xue Ji's Medical Case: The venerable Xue Xunzhai, aged sixty-one, suffered from wind sores on both legs, with pus oozing and a fever accompanied by phlegm for four years; this was due to kidney wind. He was treated with Liuwei Wan (Six-Flavor Pill) and Sisheng San (Four Fresh Powder) and recovered. After a year, the ailment recurred, spreading throughout his body, worsening in the afternoons, accompanied by phlegm thirst and night sweats, with sores on his lips and tongue and red, dim eyes—indicative of a deficiency of kidney yin and excess fire. He was treated with a modified version of the Eight Flavor Pill and was cured. Three years later, he experienced dripping during urination, and painful sensations in the genitals—this indicated impotence with drained essence. The essence failed to emit, leading to internal decay. He was treated with the previous pill and with Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang (Restore the Middle and Augment the Qi) plus wheat husk and five-flavored herb, leading to recovery.

Governor Zhang Tianze's Case: He had swelling and pain in the left knee, fullness and discomfort in the chest, poor appetite and frequent nausea, with phlegm blocking his head, and increasing fatigue in the afternoons—this indicated a deficiency in the spleen and lungs. He was treated with a scallion poultice and Liu Jun Zi Tang (Six Gentlemen Decoction) augmented with fried ginger, which quickly alleviated the symptoms, although appetite remained low. He was given Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang with Chinese privet fruit, resulting in a clear and refreshed head. Subsequently, he was given over ten doses of Da Fang Feng Tang (Major Siler Decoction) and more than thirty doses of Bu Zhong Yi Qi, after which the swelling subsided.[455p]
Liu Guowei from the Dongfu suffered from muscle and bone pain, with his right knee swollen. After using phlegm-resolving and detoxifying medicinals, the swelling and pain worsened, coupled with reduced appetite and fatigue. Adding medicines to dispel wind and detoxify led to chills, fever, and nausea, along with loose stools. After administering Erchen Decoction to dispel dampness, the swelling became red and internal pain felt like being pierced. Upon examining his pulse, it was slippery, rapid, and weak; this indicated the presence of pus, and the vital energy was deficient, unable to resolve. I prescribed four doses of Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction, along with one dose of Da Fang Feng Decoction, leading to resolution, and after over a hundred doses, he was cured.

One Confucian scholar experienced leg muscle tension with swollen and painful knees for more than a month, which was caused by deficiency of yin and damp-heat. I used Liu Wei Di Huang Wan as the main treatment, supplemented with Ba Zhen Decoction, adding Niu Xi and Du Zhong, alternating with Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction, and after more than three months, it resolved.

One man had leg pain and knee swelling; the pulse was floating, and palpating revealed a tightness, indicating liver and kidney deficiency, caused by "crane knee wind." I prescribed two doses of Da Fang Feng Decoction, which resolved the condition. He was confused about the toxicity of Fuzi and thus took medicine meant for ulcers, gradually wasting away and presenting with deficiency symptoms, leading him to seek treatment again. I remarked: fatigue and weight loss indicated that the spleen and stomach were weak and unable to nourish; inability to control urination indicated a deficiency of the bladder; dry heat and empty distension suggested weak stomach qi could not digest; confusion and forgetfulness meant spiritual loss and incoherence. Severe symptoms gathered, and I declined further treatment, after which he ultimately passed away. This condition often afflicts those with deficiency, thus I recommended modified Xiaoxu Ming and Da Fang Feng Decoctions. Using detoxifying medicines would surely be detrimental.[456p]
A woman experienced swollen and painful knees, which worsened with cold. For over a month, various medicines had no effect, and her pulse was taut and tight, indicating that cold evil was deeply lodged within. I prescribed a large dosage of Fangfeng Decoction combined with Huolong Ointment to alleviate her condition.

A man had a swollen left knee that had not ruptured for three months. I believed that in those with weak constitutions, wind evil attacks the joints, causing qi stagnation, resulting in an enlarged knee and a thinner leg, a condition known as "Crane Knee Wind." I then administered more than thirty doses of Fangfeng Decoction, and the swelling subsided.

Zhang Shangshe suffered from Crane Knee Wind, with pus flowing for three months after lying on a pillow for half a year. He said that he initially took Fangfeng Decoction without Aconite; as the swelling was about to rupture, he took the Ten Xuan Powder. Now he used the Complete Tonifying Decoction without cinnamon and also received no response. Upon examining his pulse, which was very weak, I prescribed the Complete Tonifying Decoction, increasing the Aconite to ten grams. After more than thirty doses, there was slight improvement; I then reduced the Aconite to five grams and continued for over thirty doses, leading to further recovery; eventually, I removed the Aconite altogether and after another thirty doses, he was cured.

The principle of a formula must suit individual cases. In those with weak qi, if evil enters the bones and joints, obstructing the pathways, one cannot rely on the pungent and warm properties of Aconite and cinnamon to dispel the cold evil from the joints and facilitate the flow of qi and blood through the pathways; it will not lead to healing. Moreover, the "Compendium of Materia Medica" states that Aconite is a holy medicine for treating cold and dampness. Cinnamon opens the blood vessels, eliminates stagnant blood, strengthens the joints, treats wind and dampness, and promotes the efficacy of various medicines.[457p]
The Ten Complete and Great Tonic Soup is used to treat the aforementioned conditions, and not only should cinnamon not be removed, but aconite should also be added. Without these two ingredients, how can the effects of ginseng and astragalus be realized, or the qualities of angelica and chuanxiong support blood and energy, helping to unblock the meridians and reinforce the severe deficiency to achieve effective results? Furthermore, since the aforementioned condition occurs between the bones and joints, a critical area, treating it hastily without promoting blood and energy circulation can lead to stagnation and form pus, causing a leak that exhausts the vital essence, disrupting the natural process of regeneration. Additionally, one may experience conditions caused by exposure to the cold in autumn and summer that lead to internal heat, thus developing abscesses in the bones. If wind attacks the joints, causing deep pain in the bones, especially aggravated by the cold, applying heat may provide slight relief, but it is essential to use a large dose of wind-dispelling soup, and also to crush and spread garlic on the affected area, covering it with mugwort and burning it. Even if the garlic deteriorates, the breaking of the skin is not a concern. If the condition does not improve after a long time and if yin is generated causing yang to rupture and leak fluids, it can result in localized atrophy or leakage conditions; in such cases, one should take internal sealing powder and apply aconite moxibustion. If the pulse is strong and thirst is present, it should not be treated, for it indicates a deficiency of genuine vital energy and an excess of pathogenic energy.[458p]
At Juyong Pass, Wang Huishige experienced swelling in one arm, which was not painful or red, yet the pulse was weak and he had little appetite, occasionally vomiting. He was treated with Liu Junzi Decoction, supplemented with Agastache and wine-fried Peony root, which stopped the vomiting and allowed him to eat. He then took Ba Zhen Decoction for over twenty doses, resulting in the formation of pus that was drained; he was later cured with Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction.

The following year, after suffering a chill from a fever, his arm remained slightly swollen and painful, attributed to residual toxins from the fever. However, there were no surface symptoms, just general weakness. Initially, I used Shi Xuan San for four doses to support the vital energy with Ginseng, Astragalus, Angelica, and Chuanxiong, while Fangfeng, Platycodon, Bai zhi, and Houpu were used to disperse the swelling; cinnamon was used to invigorate the channels and break up the blood stasis, leading to a reduction in swelling after three to four treatments. He subsequently took Ba Zhen Decoction, and the pus was resolved, leading to recovery.

By winter, his arm began to hurt again after taking wind-dispelling medicine, resulting in severe muscle cramps. I believed that this was due to a deficiency of blood that could not nourish the muscles, and the weakness in the muscles could not support the bones. Therefore, I prescribed an enhanced Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction for a hundred doses, leading to his recovery.[459p]
Wang Wenyuan suffered from swelling and pain in his arm. After taking cold and cooling medicine, he experienced a loss of appetite and ineffective bowel movements. I prescribed two doses of the Lizhong pill, and further treated him with Six-Gentlemen Decoction, adding sandalwood and patchouli, which led to an improvement and eventual recovery after the pus discharged. Generally, for severe pain due to abscesses, if the person has a robust constitution with excess internal heat, then bitter and cold medications are advisable; if the constitution is weaker, then one should use the Middle-Boosting and Energy-Increasing Decoction, adding herbs like Scutellaria and Coptis. For those who are overweight and experiencing painful abscesses, it is best to use herbs like Vitex, Saposhnikovia, and Notopterygium, as they are known to dispel wind and overcome dampness.

A woman in her twenties, after meals, would often experience sour regurgitation and bloating, accompanied by swollen heels when she was angry. She did not respond to medications like the Yueju pill. This was due to a deficiency in the spleen and downward movement of dampness. I prescribed Six-Gentlemen Decoction along with fennel, sandalwood, patchouli, and fried ginger over several doses, which led to slight recovery. I then continued with several doses of Six-Gentlemen Decoction, resulting in her complete recovery.[460p]
Chen, the envoy, was over fifty years old. In winter, he suffered from an abscess in his leg, with a rapid pulse, restlessness, coldness, and constipation; the swelling and pain were severe. This was due to internal heat. The treatment involved cool herbs and an increased dose of Huangqin to bring down the condition; subsequently, he was cured with Siwu Decoction plus Huangqin.

Zhang Fu, a man from Beijing, was over thirty years old. He was generally timid and weak, unable to eat cold food. He had a toxic condition in his arm with a weak pulse. I treated him with purgative medicine, leading to an outbreak. However, he had reduced appetite or experienced bloating and sourness, gradually becoming emaciated. Ginseng and Poria didn't help, but the pulse on the right wrist was weak; this indicated a decline in the fire of the Mingmen, which couldn’t generate earth. Therefore, I used Bawei Pill to tonify the earth, and gradually his appetite improved and he recovered. He also experienced pain in both knees, leading to pain in all joints—women suffering from blood wind and men from soft wind. This is known as wind-damp bi, also called joint pain. It should be treated with Fuzi Bawuzhong Decoction with modifications.

A woman had an abscess in her arm, with a purple and depressed wound and clear pus that wouldn’t close. She thought the poison hadn’t been completely expelled and wanted to take medication to expel the poison. I explained that for the condition of sores, if the swelling was hard and the pus thick, it was real; if the swelling was soft and the pus thin, it was deficient. I used a Fuzi cake for moxibustion along with administering a hundred doses of the Shiquan Dabu Decoction, after which she began to recover.[461p]
Cao Jiangdu, the chief official, suffered from an abscess on the left foot next to the little toe. The pain was unbearable, and he urgently underwent over thirty treatments of garlic moxibustion, which allowed him to walk. Eager for a speedy recovery, he applied a cooling medicine, which led to blood coagulation and necrosis in the flesh, causing the toxic effects to intensify. After another hundred moxibustion treatments and taking a revitalizing potion, he expelled purple blood, indicating that the poison was beginning to resolve. However, the sole of his foot became severely ulcerated, with much rotten sinew and flesh. Just as he was about to recover, I had to return north for work, and he inadvertently used flesh-repairing medicine, which only aggravated the poison and depleted his vital energy, making the wound difficult to heal. Upon my return, I used a treatment to restore him, pleased with his robust constitution, and after staying in the guest house for over three months, he finally healed.

My cousin Zhifu had an abscess on the little finger of his right hand. Initially, he attempted to drain it with a needle, applying a cooling medicine, which caused his palm and finger to swell three to four times their normal size, and his pulse was greatly forceful. This indicated that true energy was being depleted, while evil energy prevailed. I first administered a life-saving pill and two doses of a revitalizing potion, which slightly alleviated his condition. While I was away, he further punctured to drain blood, causing the swelling to extend to his forearm and wrist like a large gourd, with his fingers swelling multiple times, unable to rupture—this indicated a further depletion of true energy and an increase in evil energy. Upon my return, I used a large dose of ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and poria, along with frequent moxibustion across his hand, gradually reducing the swelling. Later, he experienced insufficient bowel movements and often felt weak, indicating his vital energy was sinking. I supplemented him with a tonic soup, adding herbs like psoralea, nutmeg, evodia, and schisandra, and replaced tea with a revitalizing powder. His bowel movements gradually improved, and the back of his hand began to resolve; he subsequently took over fifty doses of strong tonics until he recovered.[462p]
A neighbor, Su Zi, encountered a condition in which his left hand showed signs of a boil, feeling numb and itchy, experiencing chills and fever, nausea, and the left side of his body was entirely numb, with an irregular pulse. I said: Generally, sores should not be painless; they should not be overly painful. If there is agitation, it should not be treated. Now, presented with numbness and especially itching, this is particularly bad. I administered two doses of a life-threatening pill, which showed no effect. I then used a detoxifying agent, and the itching began to subside, but then it developed into swelling and pain. I remarked: Although the situation seems dire, the presence of pain is a good sign. However, the toxic qi must be released; I want to use acupuncture. Just then, it was the time of the full moon, and his family only mentioned the spirit in his buttocks, refusing to comply, resulting in further swelling. I insisted on acupuncture, and all symptoms immediately receded; then I used the detoxifying agent, and the sore healed completely.

A man had a carbuncle on the outer side of his leg, which was swelling and causing severe pain. I prescribed a decoction of astragalus wine twice, which alleviated it somewhat. I then used a dispersing powder several times, which caused it to rupture and heal.[463p]
A woman suffered from a leg abscess for a long time without improvement. The sore's edge was purple and sunken, with clear and thin pus, which I diagnosed as weakness. She did not believe me and took a toxic remedy, which worsened her condition, leading to further requests for treatment. I recommended moxibustion with aconite poultice and over a hundred doses of a nourishing tonic, after which she recovered. In cases where pus is thin and does not heal or is sunken, it indicates severe deficiency of qi and blood, which requires substantial tonification; otherwise, it leads to complications or failure. If she suffers from other ailments afterward, treatment becomes even more difficult.

Another woman experienced pain in both legs and could not stretch them. Her pulse was tense and tight, and pressing on it felt brittle. I first administered two doses of Wujisan, which slightly relieved her pain; a third dose completely stopped it, and after taking Shenyin Yangzhen Decoction, she could bend and stretch again.

A woman suffered from foot qi, with occasional leg swelling and muscle cramps, accompanied by abdominal pain. Various medications were ineffective, and her condition gradually worsened. Various texts state that the Eight Flavor Pill treats foot Shaoyin qi disorders, which cause abdominal pain and shortness of breath leading to a crisis. I administered a dose, which provided rapid relief, and she recovered after further doses. People with weak and cold kidney channels often have this condition, where the kidney overacts on the heart, leading to water overcoming fire, and it can be fatal if not quickly addressed.

A man had leg pain combined with muscle cramps and bone pain, with a tense pulse. I prescribed two doses of Dāfángfēng Decoction, which reduced the cramps; after another two doses, the swelling diminished. However, one area still hurt, and the pulse was no longer tense, indicating that the cold evil had departed, but there was still stagnant, turbid material that was likely forming pus, hence the persistent pain. I used a few doses of a detoxifying remedy; the swelling appeared, the pulse became slippery and rapid, indicating that pus had formed. Acupuncture was applied, and after taking the nourishing tonic for over a month, he felt secure.[464p]
A man initially experienced pain in his legs, which later spread to all four limbs, fluctuating and worsening at night. He took a remedy to eliminate dampness and dispel toxins, but it had no effect. His pulse was slippery and thin, indicating that damp phlegm and turbid blood were the issues. He was treated with Erchen Decoction, adding Cangzhu, Qianghuo, Taoren, Honghua, Niuxi, and Cao Wu, and he recovered. For all cases of damp phlegm and damp heat, or stagnant blood accumulating in the joints, without the use of acrid and warm remedies to open the pores, promote circulation, and harmonize Qi and blood, how can one expect to recover?

Another man had leg pain, which was associated with excess phlegm that sometimes produced a gurgling sound. His pulse was slippery and rapid. He was treated with Erchen Decoction, adding Shengma, Erzhur, Zexie, Qianghuo, and Nanshen, and he found relief.

A man experienced pain in his shins and ankles, treated successfully with a modified remedy for dispelling toxins.

A woman suffered from pain in both legs, with a pulse that was thin and rapid, indicating blood deficiency combined with damp heat. Initially, she was treated with several herbs including Cangzhu, Huanglian, Zhi Mu, Longdancao, Fuling, Fangfeng, Fuling, and Qianghuo, leading to gradual improvement in her swollen and painful condition. She was later given Siwu Decoction with added Erzhur, Huanglian, Niuxi, and Mugua, and was completely healed after about a month.

Another man had swollen and painful joints, with a pulse that was slow and rapid, indicating damp heat. He received a modified version of Jingfang Baidu San with two doses of Ma Huang, which reduced the pain by half. He was then given four doses of Binglang Baidu San, which also alleviated the swelling. Lastly, he received several doses of Siwu Decoction with Erzhur, Niuxi, and Mugua, leading to full recovery.[465p]
A woman experienced swelling and pain in her legs, along with chills and fever, and her pulse was floating and rapid. This indicated damp-heat from the three Yang channels affecting the exterior. She was treated with a modified version of the Bai Du San, but there was no response, indicating the presence of stagnant blood that the medicine could not reach. Therefore, they used acupuncture to remove the stagnant blood at the affected site and continued with the previous medicine for two more doses, resulting in improvement. They then used Dang Gui Nian Tong Tang for four doses, which led to recovery. Yang Dashou said: "Leg Qi is caused by blockage. The treatment should facilitate the flow to prevent stagnation." Once stagnation occurs and worsens, the stagnant blood should be removed to eliminate its force. The classics say: "If accumulation occurs, there will be swelling and heat. After acupuncture, treat with medicine."

A woman suffered from pain in both legs, which would cramp upon exposure to cold. Her pulse was wiry and tense, indicating a symptom of cold evil. She was treated with Wujisuan facing Si Wu Tang for several doses, which relieved the pain. Afterward, she took Si Wu Tang with added papaya, achyranthes, and zhi ke for over a month, leading to recovery.

A man had swollen legs with cramps, making it difficult for him to move. He was treated with Jiao Jia San for two doses and recovered.

A woman had leg pain that prevented her from bending or stretching, and it worsened with wind and cold; no medicines worked, and she suffered greatly. Initially, she took one pill of Huo Luo Dan and immediately improved, and continued the treatment until she recovered. The following year, the pain recurred, but taking one pill again alleviated most of the pain, and she then took Du Huo Ji Sheng Tang for four doses and recovered.

A man who had a history of leg Qi also suffered from an abcess in the bone, causing pain. After taking Huo Luo Dan for nine doses, both conditions resolved.

A woman had swelling and pain in her limbs and joints, particularly severe in her shins and feet. She occasionally experienced spontaneous sweating or headaches, which were caused by damp-heat in the Tai Yang channel. She was treated with Ma Huang Zuo Jing Tang for two doses and recovered.[466p]
A woman suffered from hemorrhoids and leg pain that felt like numbness, caused by deficiency of yin blood that could not nourish the muscles. It was advisable to prioritize nourishing the blood, and she was treated with a modified version of the Four-Ingredient Pill and recovered.

An elderly man experienced pain in the tendons and bones, with weakness in both legs that made him unable to walk. He was treated with a specific formula for strengthening the legs and recovered.

A woman suffered from muscle spasms and numbness, with weakness in both legs that impaired her ability to walk. She was treated with the San Yin Sheng Jun Pill and recovered.

A woman experienced leg pain coupled with cramps in her feet and shins; taking dispersing medicines made her condition worse. Her pulse was tight, indicating weakness in the kidneys and liver, with internal invasion of wind and dampness. She was treated with the Du Huo Ji Sheng Decoction which alleviated her pain, and further treated with the Shen Ying Yang Zhen Dan which prevented recurrence of spasms.

A man who habitually had leg pain exacerbated by dietary indiscretions experienced increased pain, fatigue, and weak pulse. He was treated with the Six Gentlemen Decoction augmented with hawthorn, shen qu, and other herbs, leading to recovery.

A man who ate very little experienced discomfort in the chest and abdomen, sometimes felt sour after eating, and had pain in both legs. He took two doses of the Daoyin Pill which produced immediate relief. Afterwards, he was treated with the Six Gentlemen Decoction reinforced with shen qu, cang zhu, and malt in over twenty doses, resulting in no further problems.

Wang Shiheng from Jintai, over forty years old, suffered from toxic pain in his arm and severe vomiting. After taking detoxifying medicines that worsened his symptoms, I prescribed Liang Ge San in two doses which immediately alleviated his condition, followed by the Four Substance Decoction enhanced with qin and lian in four doses to resolve it. This condition was indicative of swelling and sores caused by heat and toxins attacking the heart, leading to vomiting.[467p]
A man named Shao, who worked as a door attendant, had a painful lump on his hand. After half a year, it ruptured to form a small hole, about the size of a grain, and it did not heal for over a year. Clear pus would ooze out daily, sometimes three or four drops, his face was red, his pulse was rapid, and his mouth was dry. At night he would have fever, while during the day he felt cold. His mobility remained normal, indicating that both his qi and blood were deficient, yet he refused treatment. After more than a month, he had an encounter elsewhere. That person said: "The child has the power of no medicine." I replied: "It is the excess heat that brings joy." Eventually, he indeed passed away.

Another man had a boil on his leg, with pus already formed. I used a needle to drain about two bowls of pus and administered a decoction to support the inner organs. He developed a high fever; then I gave him two doses of Shengyu decoction, which brought it to a stop. The next day, he had chills and no appetite, with a pulse as fine as a thread. After giving him one tael of ginseng, three slices of cooked fuzi, simmered with ginger and jujube, he recovered. However, he had a slight loss of appetite and insomnia, so I gave him an internal restorative decoction with astragalus, which helped him stabilize.

In Shanxi, Song Yan, over thirty years old, suffered from a boil on his arm that ruptured but was painless, with thin pus and a weak pulse. Danxi noted that a deep and painless boil indicates that the stomach qi is severely deficient and cannot feel pain. Dongyuan noted that thin and clear pus, along with an unhealed sore, indicates that both qi and blood are deficient. Strong restorative medicine should be used for treatment. He did not listen and took antiseptic medicines, which severely depleted his qi and blood, leading to his failure to recover. Danxi remarked: "Once swelling and pain are seen, with a weak pulse, it is necessary to give nourishment; if qi and blood are not depleted, a good resolution can be preserved. Furthermore, both internal and external ulcers being deficient, treatment should primarily focus on replenishing and healing."[468p]
A woman suffered from a lump on her arm that did not heal for a long time, experiencing alternating chills and fever, with vexation in her five hearts, decreased appetite, and obstruction of her menstrual flow. After taking Xiaoyao Powder for over a month, there was no effect; then she took Eight Treasures Decoction with added Danpi and Xiangfu, and after more than a month, her menstrual flow was restored. Later, with the addition of Huangqi and Bailian, she was cured after more than two months.

A person had a tuberculosis-like lump on the arm extending to the neck, resembling scrofula. This was treated as rheumatism by using modified Xiaoxuming Decoction and Duhuo Jisheng Decoction, along with strong tonification herbs such as ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and poria to expedite recovery. It was noted that although there was no pulse evidence, it was recognized and treated as rheumatism, indicating there must have been observable symptoms at that time. Ultimately, the use of tonics led to recovery, showing it was fundamentally a case of deficiency.

A three-year-old boy had a painful toxic condition in his arm. He took detoxification pills and applied Shen Gong Powder, which led to resolution. There was also a similar case of arm toxicity that caused closed sores and restlessness; he took Wufu Huadu Dan with effect. When pus formed, it was urgent to lance it, using a paper twist dipped in sesame oil to moisten the wound, then apply a medicated plaster. If the child was calm, there was no need for medication, and it was advisable to wait for the pus to be discharged before applying the plaster.

A person with a sore on the arm had a rapid pulse. After drinking one dose of Sophora Flower wine, the heat subsided; subsequently, more than ten doses of honeysuckle, astragalus, and licorice were administered, leading to recovery. The efficacy of Sophora Flower in treating damp-heat conditions is particularly swift, but it should not be overdosed in cases of gastric cold.[469p]
Yin, from a poor family, suffered in both body and spirit. Since childhood, he had been ill, and in early winter, he developed sores along the Hand Yangming Large Intestine channel. By the fourth day, the pus was thick, and his arm was swollen and painful. The pulses on both sides of the Hand Yangming were taut; when pressed, they were strong and full yet slow. This was caused by changes due to the 'Eight Winds.' The pulse indicated that the evil Qi was on the surface; his appetite remained normal, and his bowel movements were unchanged. His abdomen felt balanced, his mouth could taste, indicating the problem was not internal. He did not fear wind or cold, only felt heat and restlessness; the pulse was not floating, suggesting the problem was not superficial. Both exterior and interior balanced, the evil was in the tendons and meridians. Hence, it was said that stagnation in the blood vessels causes boils. The boils appeared above halfway on the body, thus the wind influenced him from above, leading to changes due to the Eight Winds. The sores were confined to the meridians, so it was necessary to dispel cold and harmonize the blood and Qi in the meridians to remove any stagnation for healing. The appropriate remedy was Bai Zhi Sheng Ma Decoction. In this formula, the focus is on the entire body, thus Yangming pertains to the body as a whole. If discussing each channel, Yangming also has formulas for exterior and interior conditions. Sun Yang has its own treatments for both aspects, and the other channels can be similarly inferred.

One person had swollen and painful arms; after taking a tonic, the condition worsened daily. I concluded that the swelling was due to dampness and the pain to heat. This indicated humid heat infiltrating the meridians. I used Ren Shen Bai Du San, adding Wei Ling Xian, Jiu Huang Qin, and Nan Xing over several doses to gradually improve; I then supplemented Si Wu Tang with Cang Zhu, Huang Bo, and Jie Geng in over twenty doses to alleviate the condition. The initial tonic worsened the symptoms, thus a damp-heat treatment was implemented.[470p]
A man initially suffered from sores on his limbs, which later spread all over his body, resembling but not quite resembling scabies. At times, pus would ooze profusely, particularly from his legs. He experienced severe fatigue, itching, and a feeling of heat; he did not recover for over a year. I diagnosed him with deficient kidney fire and treated him with a modified version of the Eight Flavor Pill, which led to his recovery.

The "Effective Remedies" states: Dong Shouyue recommended treating athlete's foot by taking several rice snails, crushing them, and applying the mixture to the inner thighs; one would then feel a cool sensation descending to the feet, relieving the condition. The property of snails is to separate and clarify the dampness, thus healing the wet heat of athlete's foot.

In Piling, there was a man named Ma who sold wine and had long been troubled by wind in his kidneys. One of his feet had swollen like a gourd, and from his waist down, he was uniformly swollen. The pain was unbearable; he could only lie down and had to be assisted by two people to move. Someone suggested using a needle or knife to relieve it. I prescribed Gan Bie Powder for him. By the early hours of the morning, after chewing it with rice and drinking water, he produced several liters of pus that resembled crystal, and immediately the pain ceased and the swelling reduced. A month later, he still needed crutches to walk. I then applied Chi Wu Powder to his knee, which ultimately cured him. Ten years later, when I passed through Piling, he brought his son to express his gratitude, saying that the foot ailment had not recurred and the wind in his kidneys had disappeared; he could now walk briskly without suffering.[471p]
At the Jiezhu Temple in Shaoxing, a monk, who had been ill for several years and could not walk due to his condition, recovered after taking a medicinal pill. This method was also passed down by the elder Heng.

A person with a body full of excess fat began to suffer from leg edema. His head, face, and limbs exhibited slight swelling, all of which were red. In the year of Dingyou, in Lin'an, during a time of extreme heat, I saw Wu Kuanfu using fire to heat a cloth bag to warm his feet. He explained that the properties of the pepper are hot and can dispel cold and dampness. This made a lot of sense; after using it for over a month, I gradually saw improvement.

In the year of Gengzi, in Chun'an, Kuanfu passed by again. I asked about his ailment, and he said: "I've been cured for quite some time, thanks to the power of the pepper bag. Not only was it effective for me, but I passed it on to several relatives, and they are all well now. It truly is a miraculous formula."

In the year of Renyin, I returned to Lin'an, and while staying at an inn, I unexpectedly met Captain Wang Cheng, who was also using fire to heat a cloth bag. I asked him, "Is it not pepper?" He replied: "I also added a third of broken areca nut and a third of dried mugwort." He added, "Indeed, it is remarkable."

Generally speaking, ailments of the feet and knees reside in the lower yin region, which is particularly prone to cold and dampness. In the winter of Gengchen, I glimpsed the teacher's face at the ancestral garden of Ding Wengong. I secretly observed his body, which was heavy and found it difficult to walk, his complexion was dull, his speech slow, leading me to believe he was suffering from a condition due to excessive worry. In the autumn of Xinsi, during a consultation, I carefully examined him. Yet, with the tendons and pulses being strained and painful, causing sleeplessness, it was largely due to wind aggravated by dampness, fueled by his vulnerability. This led me to conclude that he could still receive treatment for some time to come. Why is this? Wind is related to liver ailments, being the energy of heaven; dampness pertains to spleen issues, being the energy of earth. The quickness of heavenly energy causes sudden outbreaks, while the slowness of earthly energy can restrain such outbreaks. Yet, if the energies are different, the ailments will differ, and if the energies converge, the ailments will correlate; this must be clearly discerned. When ailments differ, in relation to heavenly energy, wind is the leader of all diseases. Its onset is subtle and follows a process of mutual restraint, inevitably beginning with the five organs before becoming intense; if it comes on strongly, it strikes directly without following the usual path. Only those with a weakened constitution will find the onset unpredictable. In relation to earthly energy, dampness is an issue of the lower body; if it develops subtly, the ankles become swollen, but once the cause is overcome, it dissipates quickly; if it comes on severely, it affects the skin and muscles, gradually advancing upwards, yet this too concerns those with yang deficiency, starting to rise abnormally. The two are rooted in distinct aspects of heaven and earth, with differing ailments and therefore requiring different treatments. When ailments converge, the energy of heaven enters the tendons, and the energy of earth also enters the tendons.[485p]
When the weather is favorable, the tendons and meridians become taut and strong; when the earth's energy is dominant, the tendons and meridians become slack and weak. Although their sources are different, their flow is the same, intermingling and becoming difficult to manage. The wind in the teacher's room, although initially imperceptible, is subtly felt. As for humidity, it is both brewed internally with rich wine and flavors and externally attacked by hot mist and pestilence; thus, the feet suffer daily, and despite the relaxation of the entire body’s tendons and meridians, there is still discomfort. Ultimately, nothing compares to the ceaseless tugging pain in the feet, with sores and swellings that become unmanageable. The winds of spring, the humidity and heat of summer, and the dryness of autumn—these seasonal influences are all ailments affecting the teacher's body. And the afflictions of his body reside uniquely in one corner, which is indeed a bitter hardship.[486p]
If the internal wind, dampness, heat, and dryness are not eliminated, how can one expect to escape from foot ailments? What is commendable is only the cold water in winter, which somewhat reduces the situation. However, doctors do not understand this principle and often prescribe strong medicinal wines to drive out the dampness, unaware that this is merely a method for treating cold dampness, which should only be used when the illness increases in winter. How can one counteract wind-damp and heat-damp with such counterproductive methods without worsening the condition?
