The symptoms of spleen wind include excessive sweating, aversion to wind, lethargy in the body, unwillingness to move the limbs, a pale yellow complexion, lack of appetite, and diagnosis often shows yellow in the nose.

Note: The spleen governs the muscles and limbs, leading to lethargy and unwillingness to move, which indicates spleen qi illness. The foot Taiyin channel belongs to the spleen and connects to the stomach, traversing the diaphragm and linking the throat to the base of the tongue. The meridian section states: sickness produced by the spleen is characterized by inability to digest food. Located at the center, thus, diagnosis shows in the nose.

Discussion on Reversal

If there is reversal in the great yang, the head swells and feels heavy, and the feet cannot walk, resulting in fainting.

Note: Great yang corresponds to the sun. The foot Taiyang channel begins at the inner canthus of the eye, crosses the forehead to the crown, connects to the brain, and travels down the neck along the spine to the waist, passing through the buttocks and entering the popliteal fossa, moving along the inner knee and exiting behind the outer ankle. Therefore, if the reversal is above, it leads to head swelling and head pain; if it is below, it results in an inability to walk, and if there is clouding of the spirit and qi, it causes fainting. The sun governs all yang energies, and this illness affects the channels and then transforms into an issue of qi.

Reversal in the lesser yang results in sudden deafness, facial swelling and heat, pain in the side, and the inability to move the legs.[15p]

　　 【注　足少阳之脉，起于目锐眦，从耳后入耳中，下颊车，循胸骨，过季胁，出膝外廉，循足跗，故逆则暴聋颊肿，胁痛，足胻不可以运行。】　　厥阴之厥，则少腹肿痛，腹胀，泾溲不利，好卧屈膝，阴缩肿，胻内热。　　 【注　足厥阴之脉，内抵少腹，挟胃属肝络胆。肝主筋，膝者筋之会，经脉厥逆，不能濡养筋骨，故好卧而屈膝。】　　三阴俱逆，不得前后，使人手足寒，三日死。　　 【注　三阴俱逆，是阴与阳别矣。不得前后者，阴关于下也。诸阳之气，皆生于阴，三阴俱逆则生气绝灭，是以手足寒而三日死。此厥在气分，故主三日死，谓三阴之气厥绝也。若厥在经脉，则为厥状病，不能至于死矣。】[16p]

The channel of the foot Shaoyang originates from the outer canthus of the eye, enters the ear from behind, descends through the jaw, follows the sternum, passes through the hypochondrium, exits at the outer side of the knee, and travels along the foot's dorsum. Therefore, if the flow is reversed, it leads to sudden deafness, swelling of the cheeks, pain in the hypochondrium, and an inability to move the foot joints.

The condition of the foot Jueyin manifests as swelling and pain in the lower abdomen, abdominal distension, ineffective urination, a preference for lying with knees bent, swelling of the genitals, and internal heat in the joints.

The channel of the foot Jueyin penetrates into the lower abdomen, connecting to the liver and gallbladder via the stomach. The liver governs the tendons and the knee is the convergence of the tendons. If the channels are reversed, they cannot nourish the tendons and bones, hence the preference for lying down with knees bent.

When all three Yin channels are reversed, it prevents movement back and forth, resulting in cold hands and feet, leading to death within three days.

The reversal of all three Yin channels signifies a distinction between Yin and Yang. The inability to move back and forth indicates that Yin concerns the lower part. All Yang energy arises from Yin; thus, if the three Yin channels are reversed, the vital energy is completely extinguished, causing coldness in the limbs and resulting in death within three days. This condition affects the Qi level, hence it is said to lead to death in three days, indicating the cessation of Three Yin Qi. If the reversal occurs in the channels, it results in a condition characterized by Jue, but does not lead to death.[16p]

　　　　　大奇论

　　肾壅，脚下至少腹满，胫有大小，髀胻大跛，易偏枯。　　【注　壅者，谓脏气满而外壅于经络也。肾脉起于足下，循内踝，上腨内，属肾络膀胱，故自脚下至少腹满。肾主骨而寒水主气，故足胫有大小，髀胻大而跛，变易为偏枯，此论脏气壅于经脉而为此病，与邪在三焦之不得小便，虚邪偏客于形身，而发为偏枯之因证不同也。】[17p]

Great Treatise on Aberrations

When the kidneys are obstructed, there is fullness below the abdomen, with variations in the size of the shins; the thighs become large and one may limp, easily leading to atrophy. [Note: "Obstruction" refers to the condition where the vital energy is full but externally obstructs the meridians. The kidney's pulse starts at the feet, circulates around the inner ankle, and is associated with the kidneys and bladder, hence the fullness below the abdomen. The kidneys govern the bones, and cold water governs the qi, which results in variations in size of the shins; the thighs become large and one may limp, easily leading to atrophy. This discussion pertains to the obstruction of vital energy in the meridians and the resulting condition, which differs from the situation where evil influences in the Sanjiao prevent urination, or from the presence of external evils impacting the physical body, which lead to atrophy for different reasons.][17p]

　　　　　脉解篇

　　病偏虚为跛者，正月阳气冻解地气而出也。所谓偏虚者，冬寒颇有不足者，故偏虚为跛也。　　 【注　此言太阳之气，生于冬令水中，寒水之气有所不足，以致太阳之气亦虚，而为偏枯跛足也。】　　少阳所谓色色不能，久立久坐，起则目(目巟)(目巟)无所见者，万物阴阳不定，未有主也。秋气始至，微霜始下，而方杀万物，阴阳内夺，故目(目巟)(目巟)无所见也。　　 【注　色色不能，犹言种种不能自如也。此言少阳主七八月为首，七月之交，阴气上升，阳气下降，万物阴阳不定，而未有所主，是以色色不能而亦未有定也。秋气始至，则阳气始下，而未盛于内，阴气正出而阴气内虚，则阴阳之气夺于内矣。阴阳内夺，故目(目巟)(目巟)无所见也。】[18p]

Pulse Diagnosis Chapter

When a disease manifests as a limp due to deficiency, it results from the yang energy of the first month breaking through the frozen earth energy. The term "deficiency" refers to a significant lack during the cold of winter, which leads to the limp. [Note: This indicates that the yang energy arises from the cold water of winter, and when the cold water energy is insufficient, the yang energy is also deficient, resulting in a withered and limp foot.]

In the case of the lesser yang, when there are various difficulties, prolonged standing or sitting leads to a state where the eyes cannot see anything. The interplay of yin and yang becomes unstable, lacking a definitive control. As autumn begins to arrive with the first light frost, it begins to kill off all things. The internal struggle between yin and yang takes place, hence the inability of the eyes to see anything. [Note: "Various difficulties" refers to many things not being in harmony. This indicates that the lesser yang governs the periods of July and August, where, at the turn of July, the yin energy rises and the yang energy descends, causing instability between yin and yang elements, resulting in various difficulties and lack of clarity. As autumn arrives, the yang energy begins to descend, still weak internally, while the yin energy emerges, thus leading to an internal conflict between yin and yang, which causes the eyes to be unable to see anything.][18p]

　　　　　调经论

　　形有余则腹胀，泾溲不利，不足则四肢不用。　　 【注　脾主四肢，故虚则不用。】
　　　　　气交变大论

　　岁土太过，雨湿流行，肾水受邪，民病腹痛清厥，意不乐，体重烦冤，甚则肌肉痿，足痿不收，行善瘈，脚下痛，饮发中满，食减，四肢不举。　　 【注　诸甲之岁，土运太过，土胜则制水，故肾脏病而脚下痛。】　　岁金太过，燥气流行，肝木受邪，甚则喘咳逆气，肩背痛，尻阴股膝髀腨胻足皆病。　　 【注　肃杀太甚，则金气自虚而火气来复也。喘咳逆气，肺病也。肺俞在肩背，故肩背痛。尻阴股膝髀胻皆病者，金气虚而下及于所生之水脏也。】　　岁水不及，湿乃大行，民病腹满身重，濡泄，寒疡流水，腰股痛发，腘腨股膝不便，烦冤，足痿，清厥，足下痛，甚则胕肿。[19p]

Discussion on Menstrual Regulation

When the body has excess, it causes abdominal distension, ineffective urination and defecation; when it is deficient, the limbs are weak and unusable. [Note: The spleen governs the limbs, hence if it is deficient, they cannot function.]

Discussion on Variations of Qi

In a year dominated by earth, excessive moisture leads to ailments; the kidneys are affected by pathogenic factors, resulting in abdominal pain, cold extremities, lack of joy, a heavy and burdensome body, and in severe cases, muscle atrophy and weakness in the feet. People experience pain in their feet, fullness from drinking, decreased appetite, and heavy limbs. [Note: In years with excessive earth, the earth dominates and constrains water, hence kidney issues and foot pain arise.]

In a year dominated by metal, excessive dryness causes ailments; the liver is affected by pathogenic factors, leading to severe symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, reversed qi, shoulder and back pain, as well as ailments affecting the buttocks, groin, knees, and feet. [Note: Excessive drying leads to the weakening of metal qi, allowing fire qi to rise. Wheezing and coughing indicate lung disease. Pain in the shoulders and back is due to lung issues located there, while ailments in the lower parts are due to weakened metal qi affecting the water organs.]

In a year with insufficient water, excessive dampness prevails; people experience abdominal fullness, a heavy body, diarrhea, and cold sores with discharges, as well as pain in the lower back and thighs, and difficulty in mobility. They suffer from restlessness, weakness in the feet, cold extremities, foot pain, and in severe cases, swelling in the legs.[19p]

　　 【注　六癸之岁，水运不及，土乃胜之，故湿气大行。湿土太过，伤及肾阴，故为此诸病。】　　岁火不及，寒乃大行，民病两臂内痛，暴挛痿痹，足不任身。　　 【注　岁火不及，六癸岁也。足不任身，寒湿之证。】　　土不及，四维有埃云润泽之化，则春有鸣条鼓坼之政；四维发振拉飘腾之变，则秋有肃杀霖霪之复。其眚四维，其脏脾，其病内舍心腹，外在肌肉四肢。　　 【注　埃云润泽，土之德化也。鸣条鼓坼，木之政令也。此气之和平无胜复也。振拉飘腾，木淫而胜土也。肃杀霖霪，秋金之复也。土王四时，故曰四维，曰不时。心者，胃脘之分；腹者，脾土之郛郭也。】
　　　　　五常政大论[20p]

In the year of the six Gui, the water currents did not prevail, leading to dominance of the earth, hence the proliferation of humidity. Excessive damp soil harms the kidney yin, resulting in various illnesses.

When the fire of the year is insufficient, cold prevails, causing the people to suffer from internal pain in the arms, sudden cramps, and paralysis, leading to weakness in the legs.

When the earth is insufficient and the four directions are permeated with fine rain, in spring there are policies to announce the sound of bamboo drums; when the four directions vibrate and sway, in autumn there is a return to dried-up conditions. Illnesses are found in the four directions, within the spleen, and manifest as internal afflictions of the abdomen, while externally affecting the muscles and limbs.

The fine rain reflects the virtue of the earth's transformation. The sounds of bamboo announce regulations of wood. This balance of energies creates harmony with no dominating recovery. The vibration and swaying of wood overwhelms the earth. The harsh conditions of autumn represent the return of the metal element. The earth rules the four seasons, hence the reference to the four directions and the absence of timeliness. The heart is the division of the stomach, while the abdomen represents the bounds of the spleen.[20p]

　　土太过曰敦阜。敦阜之纪，是谓广化。其经足太阴阳明，其脏脾肾，其病腹满，四肢不举。　　 【注　土气盛而化气布于四方，故为广化。其经合于足太阴脾、足阳明胃，其脏合于脾肾。其腹满四肢不举，水湿之为病也。】
　　　　　六元正纪大论

　　阳明所至，为鼽尻阴股膝髀腨胻足病。　　 【注　此夏病之常也。】

　　　　　至真要大论

　　少阴在泉，客胜则腰痛，尻、股、膝、髀、腨、胻、足病，瞀热以酸，胕肿不能久立，溲便变。　　 【注　四之客气，乃太阳寒水。故为腰尻股胻足病，皆太阳之经证，同气相感也。次之气，乃厥阴风木。瞀热以酸，胕肿不能久立，乃脾土之证，盖木淫而土病也。终之客气乃少阴君火，主气乃太阳寒水。溲便变者，水火相交，火淫于下也。】　　太阳在泉，寒复内余，则腰尻痛，屈伸不利，股胫足膝中痛。　　 【注　寒复内余者，太阳寒水之客气，入于内而复内有余也。[21p]

When the earth is overly abundant, it is called "dun fu" (rich and fortified). The significance of "dun fu" relates to broad transformation. It corresponds to the channels of the foot Taiyin (Spleen) and foot Yangming (Stomach), and its organs are the Spleen and Kidneys. Symptoms include abdominal fullness and inability to lift the limbs.

  • Note: The abundance of earth energy spreads transformation throughout the four directions, which is why it is called broad transformation. It corresponds with the channels of the foot Taiyin and foot Yangming, and the organs of Spleen and Kidneys. Abdominal fullness and inability to lift the limbs are due to water and dampness causing illness.

Wherever Yangming reaches, there are ailments in the nose, buttocks, thighs, knees, and feet.

  • Note: This reflects the common ailments of summer.

In the Shaoyin (Lesser Yin) position, if guest qi prevails, it leads to腰 pain, ailments in the buttocks, thighs, knees, and feet, accompanied by dizziness due to heat with sourness, and swelling that prevents standing for long. Urination and defecation become abnormal.

  • Note: The guest qi of the four corresponds to the cold water of Taiyang (Greater Yang), which is why it affects the waist, buttocks, and thighs; all are related to the Yang channel's manifestations and mutual interactions of similar energies respectively. The subsequent qi corresponds to Jueyin (Absolute Yin) involving wind and wood. The dizziness with heat and sourness, along with swelling preventing prolonged standing, is a manifestation of the Spleen and earth, demonstrating that the excess of wood leads to the illness of earth. The final guest qi pertains to Shaoyin's fire, while the main qi relates to Taiyang's cold water. Changes in urination and defecation occur due to the intersection of water and fire, with fire dominating downward.

In the Taiyang position, if cold returns internally, it leads to pain in the waist and buttocks, with difficulty in bending and extending, along with discomfort in the thighs, shins, knees, and feet.

  • Note: The cold returning internally reflects the guest qi of Taiyang's cold water, which enters within, leading to an excess condition inside.[21p]

腰尻股胫足痛者，太阳之经证也。屈伸不利者，太阳之主筋也。】　　岁阳明在泉，燥淫所胜，民病足外反热。　　 【注　阳明在泉，子午岁也。足外反热，乃足少阳病。】　　少阴司天，客胜则鼽嚏，颈项强，肩背瞀热，头痛，少气发热，耳聋目瞑，甚则胕肿。　　 【注　少阴司天，初气乃太阳寒水，甚则胕肿，乃太阳寒水之气胜也。】　　少阳司天，主胜则胸满，咳仰息，甚而有血，手热。　　 【注　少阳司天，初气三气，乃君相二火。有血，手热者，火发于外也。君相之脉，皆循于手，故为手热。】[22p]

Pain in the waist, hips, thighs, and legs is a symptom of the Taiyang channel. If the flexibility is impeded, it is the primary sinew of the Taiyang.

When the year reaches the Yangming, dryness and excess prevail, causing the people to suffer from external heat in the feet.

(Note: Yangming pertains to the hour of Zi and Wu. The external heat in the feet is associated with Shaoyang ailments.)

The Shaoyin governs the heavens; when there is excess, symptoms include sneezing, a stiff neck, heat in the shoulders and back, headaches, slight breathing difficulties with fever, hearing loss, blurred vision, and in severe cases, swelling in the abdomen.

(Note: The Shaoyin governs the heavens, and the initial energy corresponds to the cold water of Taiyang; severe swelling indicates the triumph of this cold water energy.)

The Shaoyang also governs the heavens; with excess, symptoms include fullness in the chest, coughing with difficulty breathing, and in severe cases, blood, along with hot hands.

(Note: The Shaoyang governs the three energies of the initial phase, linked to the two fires of monarch and minister. Blood and hot hands indicate fire manifesting externally. The pulses of monarch and minister circulate in the hands, hence the warmth.)[22p]

　　　　　示从容论

　　雷公曰：于此有人，四肢懈惰，喘咳血泄，而愚诊之，以为伤肺，切脉浮大而紧，愚不敢治。粗工下砭石病愈多出血，血止身轻，此何物也？帝曰：予所能治，知亦众多，与此病失矣。譬以鸿飞，亦冲于天。夫圣人之治病，循法守度，援物比类。化之冥冥，循上及下，何必守经。今夫脉浮大虚者，是脾气之外绝，去胃外归阳明也。夫二火不胜三水，是以脉乱而无常也。四肢懈惰，此脾精之不行也。喘咳者，是水气并阳明也。血泄者，脉急血无所行也。若夫以为伤肺者，由失以狂也。不引比类，是知不明也。　　【注　此明肾之精水，贯乎地中，上通于天也。于此有人者，言即于此肾脏，而有人病四肢懈惰诸证也。此何物者，言如此之病，当以何物比类也。[23p]

A Discourse on Composure

The Thunder Lord said: There are people who are lethargic in their limbs, have coughs with blood, and experience leakage. Foolishly diagnosing them, they believe it is a lung injury, feeling the pulse as floating, large, and tight, but they do not dare to treat. Coarse practitioners, when using stone needles, often lead to greater blood loss; when the blood stops, the body feels light. What is this? The Emperor said: What I can treat is numerous, yet this illness is lost to me. An analogy can be made to the swan flying, soaring into the sky. The sage in treating illness follows laws and keeps to measures, using connections and comparisons. In transformation, there is the dark and the bright, following both above and below—must one necessarily adhere to the classics?

Now, a floating, large, and weak pulse indicates an absolute deficiency of spleen qi, departing from the stomach and returning to the Yangming. The two fires cannot overcome the three waters, thus the pulse is chaotic and irregular. Lethargy in the limbs signifies a deficiency in the movement of spleen essence. Coughing with breathlessness indicates that water qi combines with Yangming. Blood leakage reflects that the pulse is rapid and the blood has nowhere to circulate. If one thinks it is a lung injury, it stems from an errant understanding. Not drawing analogies and comparisons indicates a lack of clarity.

[Note: This refers to the essence-water of the kidneys, which penetrates the earth and connects to the heavens. The phrase “there are people here” refers to these kidneys, where the individual suffers symptoms like lethargy in the limbs. The question of “what is this” asks how such an illness should be compared.][23p]

圣人治病，循阴阳之法度，引物比类，譬以鸿飞，亦冲于天，犹人之肾精中贯于脾胃，而上合于肺也。故圣人察造化之冥冥，循水天之上下，又何必仅守其经乎？脾气外绝者，不行于肌腠也。去胃外归阳明者，去中胃而外归阳明之经也。二火者，君火相水也。三水者，太阴所至为湿生，终为注雨，是地之水湿也。太阳之上，寒水主之，通天之寒水也。肾为水脏，天一之癸水也。夫三水太盛，则火不能胜之，是以脉乱无常。盖心主血，心主包络主脉，水并于脉中，而君相之阳不能胜，故脉乱而血妄行也。四肢懈惰者，脾土之精气，不行于肌腠也。喘咳者，下焦之水气，并于阳明之经也。血泄者，水气并于脉中，则脉急而无所循行，故血妄行而下泄也。若夫以为伤肺者，由失其比类之义而以狂论也。不援物比类，是以知之不明也。言肾精之上交于肺者，必由中土而上，今反乘于脉中，故君相之火伤。】[24p]

The sage treats illness by following the principles of yin and yang, drawing comparisons from nature and illustrating with metaphors, such as a swan flying, which ascends to the sky, similar to how the essence of the kidneys connects to the spleen and stomach, aligning with the lungs above. Therefore, the sage observes the profound workings of creation, following the flow between water and heaven; why should one solely adhere to the classics? The outward deficiency of spleen qi does not circulate through the muscles and skin. The path returning from the stomach to the Yangming meridian involves departing from the middle stomach to reach the external Yangming channel. The two fires refer to the governing fire interacting with the water. The three waters denote the moisture engendered by the Taiyin, ultimately manifesting as rainfall, which represents the moisture of the earth. Above the sun, the cold water dominates, representing the celestial cold water. The kidneys are the water organ, embodying the essence of heavenly water. When the three waters become too abundant, fire cannot overcome them, resulting in chaotic pulses and irregularities. The heart governs the blood and envelops the pulse, and when water converges within the pulse, the governing yang cannot prevail, causing disorder in the pulse and erratic blood flow. If the limbs are sluggish, it points to the essence of the spleen and earth not circulating through the muscles and skin. Those with coughs and wheezing have the water vapor of the lower jiao converging on the Yangming channel. For blood leakage, the water vapor mingles within the pulse, thus the pulse becomes rapid and lacks direction, leading to erratic blood flow and discharge. If one assumes there is injury to the lungs based on misguided reasoning, it indicates a failure to grasp the principles of comparison. Without drawing comparisons, one cannot attain clear understanding. The connection of kidney essence to the lungs must ascend from the central earth; if it instead travels through the pulse, then the governing fire is harmed.[24p]

　　　　　阴阳类论

　　二阴一阳，病出于肾，阴气客游于心脘下，空窍堤闭塞不通，四肢别离。　　 【注　此言水从中土而上交于肺，复随天气而运行于上下四旁。二阴谓少阴所主之两肾，一阳乃肾脏所生之少阳。空窍谓汗空，乃肺主之毛窍，如水不随气运行于肤表，则空窍闭塞不通矣。堤，所以防水者也，水不渗入于土中之理路，则堤闭塞不通，而四肢不能受气于中土矣。此缘肾脏病而津液少不能渗灌于脾肺，其虚气反从少阳而客游于心下也。】　　二阴二阳，病在肺，少阴脉沉，胜肺伤脾，外伤四肢。　　 【注　此二阴二阳相类而为病也。夫肾精之上通于肺者，从脾土而上升，若鸿渐之冲天也。二阴二阳相类，而病在肺者，肾水从阳明而直乘于肺，是以肺反病也。少阴脉沉，是心肾不交矣。水不济火，则火热炎上而胜肺，水不灌于土中，则土燥而脾气损伤，外伤四肢，盖土受水津之湿，而后能灌溉于四旁。】[25p]

Yin-Yang Classification

Two Yins and one Yang cause illness in the kidneys, where Yin energy wanders under the heart, resulting in blocked and obstructed empty orifices, leading to the separation of the limbs.

Notes: This refers to water rising from the central earth to interact with the lungs, which then moves according to the weather in all directions. The two Yins refer to the two kidneys governed by the Lesser Yin, while the one Yang is the Lesser Yang generated by the kidney organs. The empty orifices denote the "sweat cavities," overseen by the lungs; if water does not follow Qi to circulate on the surface of the skin, then the empty orifices become obstructed. The "dam" is what prevents water; if water does not penetrate into the soil's pathways, then the dam becomes blocked, causing the limbs to be unable to receive energy from the central earth. This is due to kidney disease and insufficient body fluids failing to nourish the spleen and lungs, leading to a deficiency of Qi that wanders under the heart following the Lesser Yang.

In the case of two Yins and two Yangs, illness affects the lungs; the pulse of the Lesser Yin is deep, overcoming lung weakness and affecting the limbs externally.

Notes: Here, the classifications of two Yins and two Yangs signify illness. The essence from the kidneys ascends to the lungs from the spleen, akin to a swan soaring into the sky. When the two Yins and two Yangs are similar but the illness affects the lungs, it signifies that kidney water directly ascends through the Yangming, thus causing the lung to become ill. The deep pulse of the Lesser Yin indicates that the heart and kidneys are not communicating. If water does not support fire, fire becomes hot and rises, overpowering the lungs; if water does not nourish the soil, the soil becomes dry, injuring the spleen's Qi, and external harm to the limbs occurs because the earth must receive water and moisture to irrigate in all directions.[25p]

　　　　　解精微论

　　夫人厥则阳气并于上，阴气并于下。阳并于上则火独光也，阴并于下则足寒，足寒则胀也。夫一水不胜五火，故目眦盲。
　　　　灵枢经

　　　　　邪气脏腑病形篇

　　肾脉急甚为骨癫疾，微急为沉厥，奔豚，足不收，不得前后。　　 【注　肾为阴脏而主骨，阴寒太甚，故为骨癫疾。肾为生气之原，正气虚寒则为沉厥；虚气反逆，故为奔豚；阴寒在下，故足不收。肾开窍于二阴，气虚不化，故不得前后也。】
　　　　　本神篇

　　脾忧愁而不解则伤意，意伤则悗乱，四肢不举，毛瘁色夭，死于春。　　 【注　忧愁，肺之情也。如脾因忧愁不解，则伤脾脏之意。意伤则悗乱而四肢不举，盖意乃心之所生，而脾主四肢也。】　　脾藏荣，荣舍意，脾气虚则四肢不用，五脏不安。　　 【注　脾主四肢，虚则四肢不用。土灌四脏，是以五脏不安。】[26p]

Treatise on Subtle Principles

Man's essence manifests as the yang energy above and the yin energy below. When yang gathers above, fire alone shines; when yin gathers below, it brings coldness, leading to stagnation. Thus, one water cannot withstand five fires, resulting in blindness.

On Pathological Conditions of the Organs Caused by Evil Qi

A rapid pulse in the kidney indicates bone epilepsy; a slightly rapid pulse suggests sinking lethargy, "running pig" (a sensation of panic or agitation), and inability to lift the legs, preventing movement forward or backward.

On the Spirit

If the spleen is troubled by worries and cannot resolve them, it harms the mind; when the mind is harmed, it leads to confusion, causing the limbs to be weak, the complexion to be poor, and leading to death in spring.

The spleen stores the essence, and essence harbors the mind; if spleen qi is deficient, the limbs become unresponsive, resulting in instability in the five organs.[26p]

　　　　　经脉篇

　　胃足阳明之脉，是主血所生病者，狂疟温淫，汗出，鼽衄，口喎，唇胗，颈肿，喉庳，大腹水肿，膝膑肿痛，循膺、乳、气街、股、伏兔、骭外廉、足跗上皆痛，中指不用。　　 【注　平脉篇曰：水入于经，而血乃成。胃为水谷之海，主生此荣血，故是主血所生病者，为狂为温疟。汗出者。胃气热而蒸发水液之汗也。鼽衄者，经气热也。口喎、唇胗、颈肿、喉痹、腹肿、膝痛、膺股骭跗皆痛者，阳明经脉之为病也。】　　脾足太阴之脉，是主脾所生病者，不能卧，强立，股膝内肿厥，足大指不用。　　 【注　不能卧，强立，股膝内肿，足大指不用，经病之在外也。】　　膀胱足太阳之脉，是动则病髀不可以屈，腘如结，踹如裂，是为踹厥；是主筋所生病者，项背腰尻腘踹脚皆痛，小指不用。　　 【注　太阳之气，生于膀胱水中，而为诸阳主气。[27p]

Channel and Vessel Chapter

The Stomach Foot Yangming channel governs diseases arising from blood, such as mania, intermittent fever, sweating, nasal bleeding, mouth crookedness, swollen lips, swollen neck, throat obstruction, abdominal edema, knee pain, and pain along the breast, ribs, groin, popliteal fossa, outer calf, and the top of the foot. The middle finger may be unusable.

Note: The "Pingmai" chapter states: Water enters the channels, and then blood is formed. The stomach is the sea of food and grain, which occupies the role of generating this nourishing blood. Thus, it governs blood-related illnesses, including mania and intermittent fevers. When sweating occurs, it is due to the heat of stomach qi evaporating the fluids into sweat. Nasal bleeding is due to hot channel qi. Signs like crooked mouth, swollen lips, swollen neck, throat obstruction, abdominal swelling, knee pain, and pain in the channels of the breast, groin, popliteal fossa, and top of the foot indicate diseases of the Yangming channel.

The Spleen Foot Taiyin channel governs diseases arising from the spleen, leading to inability to lie down, forcing oneself to stand, internal swelling of the thigh and knee, and inability to use the big toe.

Note: Inability to lie down, forcing oneself to stand, swelling of the thigh and knee, and inability to use the big toe suggest an external illness related to the spleen.

The Bladder Foot Taiyang channel leads to a condition where movement causes pain in the hip, hindering bending, a tight feeling in the knee, or a tearing sensation; these represent contracted pain. It governs diseases arising from tendons, resulting in pain in the neck, back, waist, buttocks, knees, and feet, and the little toe may be unusable.

Note: The qi of Taiyang originates from the water of the bladder, and it governs all Yang qi.[27p]

阳气者，柔则养筋，故主筋所生之病，腰背腘踹诸证，皆经脉所循之部分而为病也。】　　心主手厥阴心包络之脉，是主脉所生病者，烦心心痛，掌中热。　　 【注　心主血而包络代君行令，故主脉，是主脉之包络所生病者，烦心心痛，掌中热，皆经脉所循之部分而为病也。】　　三焦手少阳之脉，是主气所生病者，汗出，目锐眦痛，烦肿，耳后肩臑肘臂外皆痛，小指次指不用。　　 【注　少阳乃一阳初生之气，故主气所生病者，汗出，阳加于阴则汗出也。目锐眦痛，颊肿，耳后肩臑肘臂小指次指，皆经脉所循之部分而为病也。】　　胆足少阳之脉，是主骨所生病者，胸胁肋髀膝外至胫绝骨外踝前及诸节皆痛，小指次指不用。　　 【注　少阳属肾，故主骨所生病者，为髀膝胫踝皆痛，乃足少阳经脉所循之部分而为病也。少阳主骨，故诸节皆痛也。】
　　　　　经筋篇

　　足太阳之筋，其病小指支跟肿痛。
　　 【注　此经筋之为病也。】[28p]

Yang energy is soft and nurtures the tendons, hence it is responsible for diseases arising in the tendons, including ailments related to the lower back, waist, and knees, all of which are associated with the pathways of the meridians. The heart governs the hand's jueyin (pericardium) meridian, which is the source of diseases related to the arteries, manifesting as heart distress, heart pain, and heat in the palms.

The heart governs blood and commands the pericardium, thus it is responsible for diseases originating from the pericardium meridian, resulting in heart distress, heart pain, and heat in the palms—all linked to the pathways of the meridians. The Sanjiao (Triple Burner) corresponds to the hand's shaoyang (lesser yang) meridian, which is linked to diseases arising from qi, presenting as sweating, sharp eye pain, swelling, and pain in the back of the ears, shoulders, and elbows, and leading to dysfunction in the little and ring fingers.

The shaoyang is characterized as an early manifestation of yang energy, which leads to diseases related to qi; thus, the sweating occurs when yang is intensified in the presence of yin. Symptoms such as sharp eye pain, cheek swelling, pain in the back of the ears, shoulders, elbows, and dysfunction in the little and ring fingers all correlate to the pathways of the meridians. The gallbladder corresponds to the foot's shaoyang meridian, attributing to diseases arising from the bones, resulting in pain in the chest, ribs, hips, knees, and various joints, particularly affecting the little and ring fingers.

The shaoyang pertains to the kidneys and thus governs diseases of the bones, leading to pain in the hips, knees, and ankles, which are manifestations in the foot's shaoyang meridian. Since shaoyang governs the bones, this results in widespread joint pain.

The chapter on Meridian Tendons mentions that the foot's taiyang (greater yang) tendon manifests disease as swelling and pain in the little toe and heel.[28p]

　　足少阳之筋，病小指次指支转筋，引膝外转筋，膝不可屈伸，腘筋急，前引髀，后引尻，伤左角则右足不用，命曰维筋相交。　　 【注　维筋者，阳维之筋也。阳气从左而右维筋，左右之交维也。左络于右，故伤左角者，病从左而右也。右足不用者，从上而下也。】　　足阳明之筋，其病足中指支胫转筋，脚跳坚，伏兔转筋，髀前肿。　　【注　足阳明之筋，起于中三指，乃厉兑之外间，循髀股而上经于颈，结于口鼻耳目之间，其病支胫伏兔转筋，脚跳而坚，经筋之为病也。】　　足太阴之筋，其病足大指支内踝痛，转筋痛，膝内辅骨痛，阴股引髀而痛。　　 【注　足太阴之筋，起于大指内侧之隐白间，循膝股而上于胸腹，其内者着于脊，其病在经筋之部分而为痛】　　足少阴之筋，其病足下转筋，及所过而结者皆痛及转筋。　　 【注　其病足下转筋，及所过而结者皆痛，病在此所过所结者，主癎瘈痉强，亦经筋之为病也。[29p]

The muscles of the Lesser Yang of the foot, when ill, result in cramps in the little and next toes, with the knee unable to bend or stretch, tightness in the hamstrings, pulling forward at the hip, and backward at the buttocks. If the left angle is injured, the right foot becomes unusable; this condition is called "the intermingling of the tendons."

(Note: "The intermingling of the tendons" refers to the Yang Wei muscle. The Yang energy circulates from the left to the right tendon, thus the intermingling of left and right. The left connects to the right; therefore, injury to the left angle means the illness travels from left to right. The right foot being unusable occurs from above to below.)

The muscles of the Greater Yang of the foot are affected when there are cramps in the middle toe and the shank, the foot feels stiff while jumping, and there is tension in the Achilles tendon, with swelling in the front of the hip.

(Note: The Greater Yang muscle begins at the middle three toes, aligns with the area outside of the foot, and ascends along the hip and thigh to the neck, connecting between the mouth, nose, ears, and eyes. The illness manifests as cramps in the shank and tension in the Achilles tendon, leading to stiffness in the feet, which indicates an issue with the tendons.)

The muscles of the Greater Yin of the foot, when affected, result in pain in the big toe and inner ankle, cramps causing pain, inner knee ligament pain, and pulling pain in the inner thigh.

(Note: The Greater Yin muscle begins at the inner side of the big toe and follows the knee and thigh up to the chest and abdomen; internally, it adheres to the spine, and the illness manifests as pain in the affected areas.)

The muscles of the Lesser Yin of the foot have illnesses characterized by cramps below the foot, and pain in all areas crossed or connected by the muscles.

(Note: The illness manifests as cramps below the foot, with pain in areas crossed or bound, indicating conditions such as spasms and rigidity, which are also issues with the tendons.)[29p]

】　　足厥阴之筋，其病足大指支内踝之前痛，内辅痛，阴股痛，转筋，阴器不用。　　 【注　足厥阴之筋，起于足大指之大敦，循胫股而结于阴器，络诸筋。阴器乃宗筋之会，厥阴主筋，故连络于三阴三阳之筋也，其病乃筋之所过而结者，为痛，为转筋，为阴器不用。】　　手太阳之筋，其病小指支肘内锐骨后廉痛。　　 【注　此筋之所过而结者，为肿，为筋痿也。[30p]

The sinews of the Foot Jueyin: when affected, there is pain in the area before the inner ankle of the big toe, pain in the inner thigh, cramping, and inability to use the genitals.

Note: The sinews of the Foot Jueyin begin at the great swell of the big toe, tracing up the leg and connecting to the genitals, intertwining with various sinews. The genitals hold the convergence of the sinews; as the Jueyin governs the sinews, it connects with the sinews of the Three Yin and Three Yang. Therefore, its path leads to pain, cramping, and the dysfunction of the genitals.

The sinews of the Hand Taiyang: when affected, there is pain behind the bony ridge of the inner elbow associated with the little finger.

Note: The areas traversed by this sinew can lead to swelling and weakness of the muscles.[30p]

】　　手少阳之筋，起于小指次指之端，结于腕上，循臂结于肘，上绕臑外廉，上肩走颈，合手太阳，其病当所过者，即支转筋。　　 【注　手少阳之筋，起于小指次指之关冲穴，循腕臂肘臑而上肩颈，其病当所过之处，即支分而为转筋。】　　手太阴之筋，起于大指之上，循指上行，结于鱼后，行寸口外侧，上循臂，结肘中，上臑内廉，入腋。其病当所过者，支转筋痛。　　手少阴之筋，起于小指之内侧，结于锐骨，上结肘内廉，上入腋。其病当所过者，支转筋筋痛。　　 【注　手少阴之筋，起于手小指侧之少冲间，循肘腋，其病当筋之所过者，为转筋筋痛。】[31p]

The muscle of the Hand Shaoyang originates at the tip of the little finger and the ring finger, terminates at the wrist, travels up the arm to the elbow, loops around the outer part of the forearm, ascends to the shoulder, and runs towards the neck, connecting with the Hand Taiyang. Its ailments correspond to the areas it passes through, leading to muscle cramps.

The muscle of the Hand Taiyin starts from the top of the thumb, moves along the finger upward, connects at the back of the wrist, runs along the outer side of the wrist, ascends the arm, connects at the middle of the elbow, travels along the inner part of the forearm, and enters the armpit. Its ailments correspond to the areas it passes through, resulting in painful muscle cramps.

The muscle of the Hand Shaoyin begins at the inner side of the little finger, connects at the sharp bone, and ascends along the inner part of the elbow to the armpit. Its ailments correspond to the areas it traverses, causing painful muscle cramps.[31p]

　　　　　海论

　　髓海有余，则轻劲多力，自过其度。髓海不足，则脑转耳鸣，胫酸眩冒，目无所见，懈怠安卧。　　【注　精液补益脑髓，而下流阴股，故髓海有余，则足劲轻健而多力。度，骨度也。髓从骨空，循骨度而上通于脑，故有余则自过其度矣。髓海不足则津液竭，津液者所以濡空窍者也，是以耳为之鸣，目无所见。液脱者，骨属屈伸不利，故胫酸而懈怠安卧也。】[32p]

Discussions on the Sea of Marrow

When the Sea of Marrow is abundant, one possesses lightness, strength, and excessive potency. When the Sea of Marrow is insufficient, there are symptoms like dizziness, tinnitus, a sourness in the shins, blurred vision, and a tendency to lethargy and languor.

Note: Seminal fluid nourishes the brain marrow and, flowing downwards to the lower regions, thus when the Sea of Marrow is abundant, the vitality is invigorated and one has much strength. "Degree" refers to the bone's capacity. The marrow originates from the bone cavities and travels up through the bone's structure to connect with the brain; thus, when it is abundant, it surpasses its normal limits. When the Sea of Marrow is insufficient, the bodily fluids are depleted; these fluids also moisten the orifices, which is why one experiences tinnitus and blurred vision. When the fluids are exhausted, the bones are unable to flex and extend properly, leading to sourness in the shins and a tendency to lethargy and slothfulness.[32p]

　　　　　逆顺肥瘦篇

　　黄帝曰：脉行之逆顺奈何？岐伯曰：手之三阴，从脏走手；手之三阳，从手走头；足之三阳，从头走足；足之三阴，从足走腹。　　 【注　此言手足阴阳之脉，上下外内，逆顺而行，应地之经水也。】
　　　　　阴阳系日月篇

　　黄帝曰：余闻天为阳，地为阴，日为阳，月为阴，其合之于人奈何？岐伯曰：腰以上为天，腰以下为地，故天为阳，地为阴。故足之十二经脉，以应十二月，月生于水，故在下者为阴。手之十指，以应十日，日主火，故在上者为阳。　　 【注　积阳为天，积阴为地，天地合气，命之曰人。故身半以上，天气主之，身半以下，地气主之。日以应火，月以应水，人秉先天之水火而成此形，故在上者，为阳以应日，在下者，为阴以应月。[33p]

On Reversal and Order of Fat and Thin

The Yellow Emperor said: How do the pulses run in reverse and order? Qi Bo replied: The three Yin of the hands run from the organs to the hands; the three Yang of the hands run from the hands to the head; the three Yang of the feet run from the head to the feet; the three Yin of the feet run from the feet to the abdomen. 【Note: This refers to the pulses of the hands and feet, both Yin and Yang, moving internally and externally in reverse and order, corresponding to the channels of earth and water.】

On the Relations of Yin and Yang to the Sun and Moon

The Yellow Emperor said: I have heard that heaven is Yang, earth is Yin, the sun is Yang, and the moon is Yin; how do these correlate in humans? Qi Bo replied: Above the waist is heaven, below the waist is earth; hence heaven is Yang and earth is Yin. Therefore, the twelve channels of the feet correspond to the twelve months. The moon arises from water, thus those below are Yin. The ten fingers of the hands correspond to the ten days, with the sun as the master of fire; thus those above are Yang. 【Note: Accumulated Yang constitutes heaven, accumulated Yin constitutes earth, and the union of heaven and earth results in human life. Accordingly, the upper half of the body is governed by heavenly energy, while the lower half is governed by earthly energy. The sun corresponds to fire, the moon to water; humans possess the primal water and fire, forming this shape, hence those above are Yang corresponding to the sun, and those below are Yin corresponding to the moon.】[33p]

十日应天之十干，十二月应地之十二支，是以足之十二经脉，以应十二月，手之十指，以应十日，人秉天地水火而生，故与天地相参。】　　黄帝曰：合之于脉奈何？岐伯曰：寅者，正月之生阳也，主左足之少阳。未者六月，主右足之少阳。卯者二月，主左足之太阳。午者五月，主右足之太阳。辰者三月，主左足之阳明。巳者四月，主右足之阳明。此两阳合于前，故曰阳明。申者，七月之生阴也，主右足之少阴。丑者十二月，主左足之少阴。酉者八月，主右足之太阴。子者十一月，主左足之太阴。戌者九月，主右足之厥阴。[34p]

The ten days correspond to the ten celestial stems, while the twelve months correspond to the twelve earthly branches. Thus, there are twelve primary meridians in the feet to correspond with the twelve months, and ten fingers in the hands to correspond with the ten days. Humans are born from the interaction of heaven, earth, water, and fire, hence they are connected to heaven and earth. The Yellow Emperor asked: How shall we connect this to the meridians? Qi Bo replied: The Yin of the tiger corresponds to the birth of Yang in the first month, governing the lesser Yang of the left foot. The horse corresponds to the sixth month, governing the lesser Yang of the right foot. The rabbit corresponds to the second month, governing the greater Yang of the left foot. The horse corresponds to the fifth month, governing the greater Yang of the right foot. The dragon corresponds to the third month, governing the brightness of Yang on the left foot. The snake corresponds to the fourth month, governing the brightness of Yang on the right foot. These two Yangs combine in the front, hence it is called brightness of Yang. The monkey corresponds to the seventh month, governing the lesser Yin of the right foot. The ox corresponds to the twelfth month, governing the lesser Yin of the left foot. The rooster corresponds to the eighth month, governing the greater Yin of the right foot. The rat corresponds to the eleventh month, governing the greater Yin of the left foot. The dog corresponds to the ninth month, governing the closed Yin of the right foot.[34p]

亥者十月，主左足之厥阴。此两阴交尽，故曰厥阴。　　 【注　岁半以上为阳，而主少阳太阳，岁半以下为阴，而主少阴太阴，犹两仪之分四象也。两阳合明，故曰阳明。两阴交尽，故曰厥阴。此四象而生太少中之三阴三阳也。男生于寅，故始于正月之少阳；女生于申，故始于七月之少阴。阳从左，故左而右；阴从右，故右而左。】　　甲主左手之少阳，己主右手之少阳，乙主左手之太阳，戊主右手之太阳，丙主左手之阳明，丁主右手之阳明，此两火并合，故为阳明。[35p]

The month of Hai is October, which governs the left foot of the Jueyin. As these two Yin energies intersect completely, it is thus called Jueyin.

(Note: Ages above half a year are considered Yang, presiding over Shaoyang and Taiyang; ages below half a year are considered Yin, presiding over Shaoyin and Taiyin, resembling the division of the two principles into the four images. The two Yang energies unite and are thus called Yangming. The two Yin energies intersect completely, hence it is called Jueyin. These four images give rise to three Yin and three Yang in Tai, Shao, and Zhong. Males are born in Yin (Tiger), thus beginning with the Shaoyang of the first month; females are born in Shen (Monkey), thus beginning with the Shaoyin of the seventh month. Yang flows from the left, hence left to right; Yin flows from the right, hence right to left.)

Jia governs the left hand of Shaoyang, Ji governs the right hand of Shaoyang, Yi governs the left hand of Taiyang, Wu governs the right hand of Taiyang, Bing governs the left hand of Yangming, and Ding governs the right hand of Yangming. Since these two fires unite, this is termed Yangming.[35p]

庚主右手之少阴，癸主左手之少阴，辛主右手之太阴，壬主左手之太阴。　　 【注　太阳主日，少阳主火，故两火并合，是为阳明。阳明者，离明之象也。明两作离，故两火并合。两阳合明，是为阳明。手少阴君火主日，手太阴肺金主天，故应手之十指，此阳中有阴也。】　　故足之阳者，阴中之少阳也；足之阴者，阴中之太阴也。手之阳者，阳中之太阳也；手之阴者，阳中之少阴也。腰以上者为阳，腰以下者为阴。　　 【注　腰以上者为阳，腰以下者为阴，此阴阳之定位。手经有阴，足经有阳，乃上下之气交。】[36p]

The Geng governs the right hand's Shaoyin, while the Gui governs the left hand's Shaoyin. The Xin rules the right hand's Taiyin, and the Ren oversees the left hand's Taiyin. 

[Note: The Yangming corresponds to the sun, and the Shaoyang to fire; thus the convergence of the two fires constitutes Yangming. Yangming symbolizes clarity and brightness. The concept of two fires converging represents brightness. The combination of two Yangs creates clarity, defining Yangming. The Shaoyin of the hand corresponds to the fire governing the sun, while the Taiyin of the hand pertains to the metal of the lung governing the sky; thus, in the ten fingers, there exists Yin within Yang.]

Therefore, the Yang of the feet represents the Shaoyang within Yin; the Yin of the feet represents the Taiyin within Yin. The Yang of the hands signifies the Taiyang within Yang; the Yin of the hands denotes the Shaoyin within Yang. Above the waist is considered Yang, while below the waist is considered Yin. 

[Note: The differentiation of above the waist as Yang and below the waist as Yin represents the positioning of Yin and Yang. The hand channels possess Yin, while the foot channels embody Yang, illustrating the interplay of energies between the upper and lower parts of the body.][36p]

　　　　　本脏篇

　　肝应爪。爪厚色黄者胆厚，爪薄色红者胆薄，爪坚色青者胆急，爪濡色赤者胆缓，爪直色白无约者胆直，爪恶色黑多纹者胆结也。　　 【注　朱氏曰：爪者筋之余，故肝应爪，视爪之好恶，以知胆之厚薄缓急也。】
　　　　　五色篇

　　颧者，肩也。颧后者，臂也。臂下者，手也。目内眦上者，膺乳也。挟绳而上者，背也。循牙车以下者，股也。中央者，膝也。膝以下者，胫也。当胫以下者，足也。巨分者，股里也。巨屈者，膝膑也。此五脏六腑肢节之部也，各有部分。有部分，用阴和阳，用阳和阴。当明部分，万举万当。能别左右，是谓大道。男女异位，故曰阴阳。
　　　　　卫气失常篇

　　皮有部，皮之部输于四末。
　　【注　卫气行于皮，输于四末，为所主之部。盖卫气出于阳，从头目而下注于手足之五指，故以四末为部也。】
　　　　　动输篇[37p]

On the Organs

The liver corresponds to the nails. If the nails are thick and yellow, the gallbladder is thick; if the nails are thin and red, the gallbladder is thin; if the nails are hard and blue, the gallbladder is urgent; if the nails are moist and red, the gallbladder is relaxed; if the nails are straight and white without constraints, the gallbladder is direct; if the nails are dark and mottled, the gallbladder is congested.
[Note: Zhu states that the nails are an extension of the tendons, hence the liver corresponds to the nails. By observing the condition of the nails, one can understand the thickness, thinness, relaxation, and urgency of the gallbladder.]

On the Five Colors

The zygomatic bone corresponds to the shoulders. The area behind the zygomatic corresponds to the arms. Below the arms corresponds to the hands. The inner canthi of the eyes correspond to the breast and nipples. The area alongside and above corresponds to the back. The region beneath the zygomatic corresponds to the thighs. The center corresponds to the knees. Below the knees corresponds to the shins. Below the shins corresponds to the feet. The major articulation corresponds to the inner thighs. The major bend corresponds to the kneecap. These are the parts of the five organs and six viscera, as well as the limbs, each having its respective sections. Each section interacts with the yin and yang; the yin and yang interact with each section. Understanding the sections is crucial, as it informs countless actions. The ability to distinguish left from right is called the Great Way. Men and women occupy different positions, hence the concept of yin and yang.

On the Abnormality of Defensive Qi

The skin has areas, and the areas of the skin extend to the four extremities.
[Note: Defensive qi flows through the skin and extends to the four extremities, corresponding to the areas it governs. Defensive qi emerges from yang, flowing from the head and descending to the five fingers of the hands and feet, hence the four extremities are considered the area.]

On Movement and Transmission[37p]

　　黄帝曰：荣卫之行也，上下相贯，如环之无端。今有其卒然遇邪气，及逢大寒，手足懈惰，其脉阴阳之道，相输之会，行相失也，气何由还？岐伯曰：夫四末阴阳之会者，此气之大络也。四街者，气之径路也。故络绝则径通，四末解则气从合，相输如环。黄帝曰：善。此所谓如环无端，莫知其纪，此之谓也。
　　　　　阴阳二十五人篇

　　足少阳之下，血气盛则外踝肥，血多气少则外踝皮坚而厚，血少气多则外踝皮薄而软，血气皆少则外踝瘦无肉。　　 【注　足少阳经脉之下行者，循膝外廉下辅骨之前，抵绝骨之端，下出外踝之前，循足跗上，是以在下皮肤分肉之血气盛，则外踝肥血多则皮坚而厚，血少则皮薄而软。】　　足太阳之下，血气盛则跟肉满踵坚，气少血多则踵跟空，血气皆少则善转筋、踵下痛。　　 【注　转筋、踵下痛者，血气少而不能荣养筋骨也。】　　手阳明之下，血气盛则手鱼肉以温，气血皆少则手瘦以寒。[38p]

The Yellow Emperor said: "The functions of nourishment and defense interconnect above and below, like a ring without ends. Now, when one suddenly encounters evil qi and faces severe cold, if the hands and feet are sluggish, the pathways of yin and yang can lose their connection, and how can the qi return?" Qi Bo replied: "The meeting of yin and yang at the four extremities is the great network of qi. The four channels are the routes of qi. Hence, when the network is interrupted, the routes are clear; when the four extremities are relaxed, the qi unites and circulates like a ring." The Yellow Emperor said: "Good. This is what is meant by a ring without ends, with no one knowing its origins."

In the chapter on the twenty-five persons of yin and yang:

Below the foot of the lesser yang, when blood and qi are abundant, the outer ankle is plump; when blood is plentiful and qi is scarce, the skin of the outer ankle is tough and thick; when blood is scanty and qi is abundant, the skin of the outer ankle is thin and soft; when both blood and qi are insufficient, the outer ankle is lean with no flesh.

[Note: The lesser yang meridian descends, following the outer side of the knee and passing in front of the tibia, reaching the tip of the fibula, and descending out in front of the outer ankle, following the foot's dorsal surface. Thus, in conditions where blood and qi are abundant, the outer ankle appears plump; if blood is plentiful, the skin is tough and thick; if blood is scarce, the skin is thin and soft.]

Below the foot of the greater yang, when blood and qi are abundant, the heel is full and strong; when qi is scarce and blood is plentiful, the heel is hollow; when both blood and qi are deficient, one experiences muscle cramps and pain under the heel.

[Note: Muscle cramps and heel pain occur when blood and qi are deficient and are unable to nourish the tendons and bones.]

Below the hand of the yang brightness, when blood and qi are abundant, the hand feels warm and meaty; when both qi and blood are scarce, the hand appears thin and cold.[38p]

　　 【注　手阳明经脉之下行者，循臑臂上入两筋之间，出合谷，故血气盛则手鱼肉以温，血气皆少则手瘦以寒也。】　　手少阳之下，血气盛则手卷多肉以温，血气皆少则寒以瘦，气少血多则瘦以多脉。　　 【注　手少阳经脉之下行者，从肩臑肘臂而上出于手腕，故血气盛则手卷多肉以温。盖手少阳之血气，循手表腕，盛则皮缓肉淖，故善于卷握也。多脉者，皮肉瘦而脉络多外见也。】　　手太阳之下，血气盛则掌肉充满，血气皆少则掌瘦以寒。　　 【注　手太阳之脉下行者，循肩臑肘臂而下出于手腕，是以血气盛则掌肉充满，血气皆少则掌瘦以寒也。】[39p]

The pathways of the hand Yangming descend along the upper arm, entering between the two muscles and exiting at Hegu (LI4). Therefore, when the blood and qi are abundant, the hands are fleshy and warm; when they are deficient, the hands become thin and cold. In the hand Shaoyang, when blood and qi are abundant, the hands are fleshy and warm; when they are deficient, they become cold and thin. If qi is scarce and blood is plentiful, the hands will be thin despite having many veins visible.

Regarding the pathways of the hand Taiyang, when blood and qi are abundant, the palm is plump; when they are deficient, the palm is thin and cold. The pathway of the hand Taiyang descends along the shoulder and elbow, exiting at the wrist, which explains why, when blood and qi are abundant, the palm is full, and when they are deficient, the palm is thin and cold.[39p]

　　　　　百病始生篇

　　虚邪之中人也，始于皮肤，留而不去则传舍于络脉，留而不去传舍于经，留而不去传舍于输。在输之时，六经不通，四肢，则肢节痛，腰脊乃强。　　 【注　输者，转输血气之经脉，即脏腑之经隧也。脏腑之大络，左右上下，并经而出，布于四末，故邪留于输，则六经不通，四肢之肢节痛也。腰脊乃强者，脏腑之大络，通于督脉之长强也。】[40p]

The Beginning of All Diseases

When the external evil enters a person, it starts in the skin. If it remains and does not disperse, it settles in the channels and vessels; if it does not leave, it lodges in the meridians; if it continues to remain, it stays in the collaterals. During the time it resides in the collaterals, the six channels do not flow smoothly, leading to pain in the joints of the limbs and stiffness in the waist and spine.

(Note: "The collaterals" refers to the channels that transport blood and vital energy, specifically the pathways related to the organs. The main networks of the organs connect and exit through various channels, spreading to the extremities. Therefore, if the evil lingers in the collaterals, the six channels become obstructed, resulting in joint pain in the limbs. The stiffness in the waist and spine arises because the major networks of the organs are connected to the Governing Vessel.)[40p]

　　　　　邪客篇

　　天圆地方，人头圆足方以应之。天有四时，人有四肢；天有十日，人有手十指。辰有十二，人有足十指茎垂以应之。女子不足二节，以抱人形。
　　　　　论疾诊尺篇

　　肘所独热者，腰以上热；手所独热者，腰以下热；肘前独热者，膺前热；肘后独热者，肩背热；臂中独热者，腰腹热；肘后粗以下三四寸热者，肠中有虫；掌中热者，腹中热；掌中寒者，腹中寒；鱼上白肉有青血脉者，胃中有寒。　　 【注　手太阴之脉从指井之少商，过于输，行于经，而入于肘之尺泽。脉外之气血，从手阳明之五里，走尺以上鱼，相逆顺而行也。肘所自寸而下，尺也。手所自尺而上，寸也。肘所独热者，腰以上热，手所独热者，腰以下热，此诊尺肤以候形身之上下，故与脉候之上下反其诊也。肘前乃手厥阴之曲泽处，肘后乃手少阳之天井处。[41p]

Evil Guest Poem

The heavens are round and the earth is square; the human head is round and the feet are square to correspond. The heavens have four seasons, and humans have four limbs; the heavens have ten suns, and humans have ten fingers. The zodiac has twelve signs, and humans have ten fingers and toes hanging down to correspond. Women have only two segments to embrace the human form.

Discussion on Disease Diagnosis by Measuring

When the elbow is warm, the heat is above the waist; when the hand is warm, the heat is below the waist; when the front of the elbow is warm, the heat is in the front of the chest; when the back of the elbow is warm, the heat is in the shoulders and back; when the center of the arm is warm, the heat is in the waist and abdomen; if three to four inches below the back of the elbow is warm, there are parasites in the intestine; if the palm is warm, there is heat in the abdomen; if the palm is cold, there is cold in the abdomen; if there are blue blood vessels on the white flesh of the fish, there is cold in the stomach.

Note: The path of the hand Tai Yin meridian starts from the lesser merchant at the tip of the finger, goes past the Shu point, travels through the channel, and enters the cubit at the point of the Lesser Marsh. The external Qi and blood of the pulse come from the hand Yang Ming's five miles, moving above the cubit of the fish, flowing in reverse and order. The pulse of the elbow starts at the inch and goes down to the cubit. The hand starts at the cubit and goes up to the inch. The warm sensation in front of the elbow indicates heat above the waist; the warm sensation in the hand indicates heat below the waist. This measures the skin and assesses the shape of the body above and below, hence the diagnosis is inverted compared to the pulse evaluation. The front of the elbow is where the hand Jue Yin's curve marsh is located, and the back of the elbow is where the hand Shao Yang's celestial well is located.[41p]

盖以两手下垂，上以候上，下以候下，前以候前，后以候后也。夫所谓肘所手所者，谓手臂之背面，臂中掌中鱼上，乃手臂之正面。背面为阳，故候形身之外；正面主阴，故候腰腹肠胃之内。即尺外以候季胁，尺里以候腹中之大义相同也。】　　大便赤办，飧泄脉小者，手足寒，难已。飧泄脉小，手足温，泄易已。　　 【注　大便赤办者，谓黄赤之间别也。盖中焦泌糟粕，蒸津液，乃化而为血，独行于经隧，命曰荣气；水谷常并居于胃，成糟粕而俱下于大肠，济泌别汁而渗入于膀胱。如大便赤办，乃中焦之血与糟粕并下矣。飧泄，大肠虚而不能济泌矣。此肠胃虚泄于下，中焦之汁，不能荣于脉中，故脉小也。若手足温者，得下焦之生气，故泄易已。】[42p]

The hands hang down, one above to receive from above and one below to receive from below, on the front to receive from the front, and on the back to receive from the back. The so-called area of the elbows and hands refers to the back of the arms; the part above the palm signifies the front of the arms. The back is associated with Yang, hence it receives external shapes; the front governs Yin, thus it receives the internal organs such as the waist and abdomen. The area outside the measurement corresponds to the seasonal side, while within the measurement corresponds to the abdomen; the fundamental principles are the same.

Regarding stool that is reddish and loose, if the pulse is weak and the hands and feet are cold, it is difficult to resolve. If the pulse is weak but the hands and feet are warm, it is easy to resolve.

Note: The term 'reddish and loose stool' refers to a distinction between yellow and red. In the middle burner, the turbid residue is transformed into fluids, leading to the formation of blood, which travels through the channels and is called the nourishing Qi. Food and drink regularly coexist in the stomach, forming turbid residue, which passes down into the large intestine, aiding in the separation of essences that seep into the bladder. If the stool is reddish and loose, it indicates that blood and turbid residue from the middle burner are moving downward together. Loose stools indicate a deficiency in the large intestine, causing it to be unable to properly separate the essences. This causes a deficiency in both the intestines and stomach; the fluids from the middle burner cannot nourish the pulse, thus resulting in a weak pulse. Conversely, when the hands and feet are warm, it indicates the receipt of vital energy from the lower burner, hence the ease of resolution.[42p]

　　　　　痈疽篇

　　发于股胫，名曰股胫疽，其状不甚变，而痈脓搏骨，不急治，三十日死矣。　　 【注　发于股胫，足少阴之毒也。其状不甚变者，毒附于骨而不外发，故皮肤不甚变，为痈毒之状也。】　　发于股阴，名曰赤施，不急治，六十日死。在两股之内，不治，十日而当死。　　 【注　股阴，足三阴之部分也，以火毒而施于阴部，故名赤施。六者，水之成数。十日者，阴数之终也。】　　发于膝，名曰疵痈，其状大痈，色不变，寒热，如坚石。勿石，石之者死；须其柔，乃石之者生。[43p]

Yongju Commentary

When a sore occurs on the thigh or leg, it is called "thigh and leg sore." Its appearance does not change much, but the pus affects the bone. If not treated urgently, death will occur within thirty days.

Note: The occurrence on the thigh and leg is due to the toxicity of the lesser yin of the foot. The appearance does not change significantly because the toxin adheres to the bone and does not manifest outwardly, hence the skin does not change much, which is characteristic of this toxic sore.

When it occurs in the inner thigh, it is called "red application." If not treated urgently, death will occur within sixty days. If it is inside the two thighs, without treatment, death will occur in ten days.

Note: The inner thigh is part of the three yin of the foot; due to fire toxicity applied to the genital area, it is named "red application." The number six represents the essence of water, while ten days signifies the end of the yin cycle.

When it occurs at the knee, it is called "blemished sore," its condition large and unchanging, cold and hot, like a hard stone. Do not treat it as a stone, for doing so will lead to death; it must be handled gently to allow recovery.[43p]

　　 【注　膝者，筋之会，足少阳之分也。色不变者，色与皮肤相同而不赤也。其状如大痈而色不变者，毒在外内之间也。盖少阳主枢，故其色状如此而为寒热也。如坚石者勿砭石之，石之则死，毒气入于内也。须其柔软而石之者生，毒气出于外也。盖少阳主枢，可内而可外也。】　　发于胫，名曰兔啮，其状赤至骨，急治之，不治，害人也。　　 【注　兔乃阴类，发于胫，名曰兔啮者，发于阴胫也。其状赤至骨者。从外而内也，故曰急治之。不治害人，犹言外贼之来害人也。】　　发于内踝，名曰走缓，其状痈也，色不变，数石其输，而止其寒热，不死。[44p]

The knee is where the tendons converge and is an area of the lesser yang. If the color does not change, it means the color is the same as the skin and is not red. If it resembles a large sore but the color does not change, it indicates that the poison is situated between the exterior and interior. The lesser yang governs joints; hence its color and condition signify cold and heat. If it feels like a hard stone, do not use a stone to press on it; doing so will cause death as the poison will enter the interior. It must be soft, and when pressed, it will help the poison escape from the exterior. The lesser yang governs the joints, therefore it can operate both internally and externally.

When the hair appears on the shin, it is called "rabbit gnaw." If its condition is red down to the bone, it requires urgent treatment; if untreated, it will harm the person. "Rabbit" refers to the yin aspect. The emergence on the shin, referred to as "rabbit gnaw," indicates a condition on the yin side of the shin. The redness extending to the bone signifies an inward progression, thus urgent treatment is necessary. Untreated, it harms the person, akin to an external thief causing harm.

If it appears on the inner ankle, it is called "slow journey," resembling an abscess, with no change in color. It requires a few applications, after which the cold and heat will be stopped, and it will not be fatal.[44p]

　　 【注　夫痈疽之变，有病因于内而毒走于外者，有肿见于外而毒气走于内者，此邪留于脉而不行，故名曰走缓，其状若痈而色不赤也。足少阴之脉，起于小指之下，邪趋足心，出然谷之下，循内踝之后，以上腨内，故当数石其输，去其邪而止其寒热。盖足少阴秉先天之水火，故能为寒为热也。】　　发于足上下，名曰四淫，其状大痈，不急治之，百日死。　　【注　四淫者，邪气淫于左右之太少也。少阳主初阳之生气，而发于肾脏，太阳乃肾之府，而为诸阳主气，故当急治之，不则阳气伤而百日死矣。[45p]

The transformation of carbuncles and sores has two types: one has an internal cause with toxins spreading outward, while the other has swelling visible externally with toxic energy moving inward. When the evil remains in the pulse and does not move, it is called "slow-moving," resembling a carbuncle but without a red color. The foot's lesser yin meridian starts from beneath the little toe, with the evil moving to the sole, emerging under the arch and following behind the inner ankle, rising within. Therefore, one should alleviate the evil and stop the cold and heat by using stones. The lesser yin of the foot embodies the primordial water and fire, which allows it to manifest cold and heat.

When it arises from above and below the foot, it is called the "Four Evils." Its appearance resembles a large carbuncle; if not urgently treated, it can lead to death within a hundred days. The "Four Evils" refers to the evil energy that dwells excessively in the left and right sides. The lesser yang governs the energy of early yang, pertaining to the kidneys, where the sun is the repository of the kidneys and governs all yang energies. Hence, urgent treatment is necessary; otherwise, the yang energy will be harmed, leading to death within a hundred days.[45p]

】　　发于足旁，名曰厉痈，其状不大，初如小指发，急治之，去其黑者，不消辄益。不治，百日死。　　 【注　足阳明之脉，起于足大指次指之厉兑，故发于足旁，名曰厉痈。黑者，水之色，不急治之以去其黑，则寒淫而土败矣。】　　发于足指，名曰脱痈，其状赤黑，死不治。不赤黑，不死。不衰，急斩之，不则死矣。　　 【注　此足少阴之毒，从内而发于外，故曰脱痈，谓从阴而脱出于阳也。发于足指者，发于足大指也。夫足少阴秉先天之水火，其状赤黑者，水火之淫毒太盛，故为不治之死证。不赤黑者，其毒气少衰，故为不死。如痈肿不衰，急斩去其指，不则毒气注于诸经之络而死矣。】[46p]

When a sore appears beside the foot, it is called a "Li Ying." Its initial size is small, resembling the thickness of a little finger. It should be treated quickly; if the blackness is removed, it will not worsen. If left untreated, death may occur within a hundred days.

Note: The yangming channel of the foot originates from the point next to the big toe, hence the sore appears beside the foot and is named "Li Ying." The blackness refers to the color of water; if it is not promptly treated to remove the blackness, coldness will dominate and the earth element will fail.

When a sore arises on the toe, it is called a "Tuo Ying." Its appearance is red-black, and if left untreated, it leads to death. If it is not red-black, it will not cause death. If it is not diminishing, it must be urgently excised; otherwise, it will result in death.

Note: This "Tuo Ying," attributed to the lesser yin poison, manifests from within to the outside, hence called "Tuo Ying," referring to a departure from yin to yang. The sore on the toe refers to the big toe of the foot. The lesser yin harbors the primordial water and fire; a red-black appearance indicates that the toxicity of water and fire is excessively potent, leading to an untreatable death. If it is not red-black, the toxic qi has diminished, thus not leading to death. If the sore does not recede, urgent amputation of the toe is necessary; otherwise, the toxic qi will penetrate the various channels and result in death.[46p]

　　　　扁鹊难经

　　　　　四肢满闭

　　假令得肝脉，其外证善洁面青善怒，其内证脐左有动气，按之牢若痛，其病四肢满闭，淋溲便难，转筋。有是者肝也，无是者非也。
　　　　　四肢不收

　　假令得脾脉，其外证面黄善噫善思善味，其内证当脐有动气，按之牢若痛，其病腹胀满，食不消，体重节痛，怠惰嗜卧，四肢不收。有是者脾也，无是者非也。　　饮食劳倦，其病身热而体重嗜卧，四肢不收，其脉浮大而缓。
　　　　　足寒

　　假令得肾脉，其外证面黑善恐欠，其内证脐下有动气，按之牢若痛，其病逆气小腹急痛，泄如下重，足胫寒而逆。有是者肾也，无是者非也。　　中湿，其病身热而小腹痛，足胫寒而逆，其脉沉濡而大。[47p]

Bian Que's Difficulties in Diagnosis

Full Closure of the Limbs

If the liver pulse is obtained, its external symptom is a clean face that appears blue or angry. Internally, there is movement sensation at the left side of the navel, which feels firm and painful upon pressure. The condition presents with the limbs full and closed, urination and defecation difficult, and muscle cramps. If these symptoms are present, it indicates a liver issue; if not, it indicates otherwise.

Limbs Not in Retraction

If the spleen pulse is obtained, its external symptom is a yellow face with tendency to burp, think deeply, and enjoy food. Internally, there is movement sensation at the navel, which feels firm and painful upon pressure. The condition presents with abdominal fullness, poor digestion, heavy body, joint pain, lethargy, and a desire to lie down, with limbs not retracting. If these symptoms are present, it indicates a spleen issue; if not, it indicates otherwise. Dietary strain and fatigue may lead to body heat and a heavy sensation, with limbs not retracting, and the pulse being floating, large, and slow.

Cold Feet

If the kidney pulse is obtained, its external symptom is a dark face with tendency to be fearful. Internally, there is movement sensation below the navel, which feels firm and painful upon pressure. The condition presents with reversed qi, urgent pain in the lower abdomen, diarrhea, and cold feet and shins. If these symptoms are present, it indicates a kidney issue; if not, it indicates otherwise. Dampness in the center may lead to body heat and lower abdominal pain, cold feet and shins, with a submerged, moist, and large pulse.[47p]

　　　　金匮要略 【汉　张机】

　　　　　四肢肿重

　　皮水为病，四肢肿，水气在皮肤中，四肢聂聂动者，防己茯苓汤主之。　　脾水者，其腹大，四肢苦重，津液不生，但苦少气，小便难。　　诸肢节疼痛，身体尩羸，脚肿如脱，头眩短气，温温欲吐，桂枝芍药知母汤主之。　　味酸则伤筋，筋伤则缓，名曰泄；咸则伤骨，骨伤则痿，名曰枯。枯泄相搏，名曰断泄。荣气不通，卫不独行，荣卫俱微，三焦无所御，四属断绝，身体羸瘦，独足肿大，黄汗出，胫冷，假令发热，便为历节也。　　病人常以手指臂肿动，此人身体瞤瞤者，藜芦甘草汤主之。
　　　　　寒热

　　腹痛脉弦而紧，弦则卫气不行，即恶寒，紧则不欲食，邪正相搏，即为寒疝。寒疝绕脐痛，若发则白津出，手足厥冷，其脉沉紧者，大乌头煎主之。[48p]

Jin Kui Yao Lue (by Zhang Ji, Han Dynasty)

Swelling of the Limbs

If there is skin edema as an illness, resulting in swollen limbs and water qi residing in the skin, with the limbs feeling heavy and difficult to move, the prescription of Fangji Fuling Decoction is indicated.

For edema associated with the spleen, the abdomen will be distended, limbs will feel heavy, bodily fluids will not be produced, leading to shortness of breath, and difficulty in urination.

If all joints ache, the body becomes weak, feet swell as though they are falling off, the head feels dizzy with shortness of breath, and there is a warm sensation wanting to vomit, the prescription of Guizhi Shaoyao Zhimu Decoction is indicated.

Sour flavors can damage the tendons; when the tendons are hurt, they weaken, which is termed "leakage"; salty flavors can damage the bones; when the bones are hurt, they wither, which is termed "withered." The combination of withering and leakage is termed "interrupted leakage."

When the qi of nourishment does not flow, the defensive qi does not function, both the qi of nourishment and the defensive qi are weak, and the three burners have no control, leading to a severing of the four extremities, the body becomes emaciated, the feet alone swell substantially, yellow sweat appears, the shins are cold, and if there is fever, it indicates a form of rheumatism.

Patients often feel the swelling of their arms with their fingers; they are those who feel tremors in their body, for which the prescription of Lilu Gancao Decoction is indicated.

Cold and Heat

For abdominal pain with a stringy and tight pulse, if it is stringy, the defensive qi is not flowing and is accompanied by aversion to cold; if it is tight, there is a loss of appetite, where the evil qi and the righteous qi clash, which is termed a cold hernia.

If cold hernia pain radiates around the navel, and when it occurs white fluids come out, causing cold extremities, and the pulse is deep and tight, the prescription of Dahuang Wutu Decoction is indicated.[48p]

　　　　　酸疼

　　虚劳里急，悸衄腹中痛，梦失精，四肢酸疼，手足烦热，咽干口燥，小建中汤主之。
　　　　　不仁

　　寒疝腹中痛，逆冷，手足不仁，若身疼痛，灸刺诸药不能治，抵当乌头桂枝汤主之。
　　　　　食禁

　　时病差未健，食生菜，手足必肿。
　　春秋二时，龙带精入芹菜中，人偶食之为病，发时手背腹满，痛不可忍，名蛟龙病。治之方：　　硬糖二、三升。
　　右一味，日两度服之，吐出如蜥蜴三、五枚，差[硬糖三、五升……差　原本脱，据《金匮》果实菜谷禁忌并治第二十五补。]。
　　　　　浸淫疮

　　浸淫疮，从口流向四肢者可治，从四肢流来入口者不可治。　　浸淫疮，黄连粉主之。

　　　　　转筋

　　转筋之为病，其人臂脚直，脉上下行微弦。
　　　　中藏经 【汉　华佗】[49p]

Soreness

In cases of weakness and urgency, with palpitations and abdominal pain, nocturnal emissions, achy limbs, heat in the hands and feet, and dryness in the throat and mouth, the formula Xiao Jian Zhong Tang is indicated.

Numbness

For cold hernia causing abdominal pain and reversely cold sensations, with numbness in the hands and feet, and if there is body pain that cannot be treated by moxibustion or medication, Xuan Wu Tang is indicated.

Dietary Restrictions

In cases of lingering illness where health has not fully restored, eating raw vegetables will certainly lead to swelling in the hands and feet.

During the spring and autumn, when dragon essence enters celery, if someone inadvertently consumes it, they will suffer from pain on the back of the hands and fullness in the abdomen, which is called "dragon disease." The treatment method involves hard sugar in amounts of two to three sheng (a measurement).

For the above remedy, take it twice daily, expelling three to five lizard-like substances. (Note: the original text appears incomplete; according to "Jin Kui," there are specific dietary restrictions and treatments in the twenty-fifth section.)

Soggy Sores

Soggy sores that flow from the mouth to the limbs can be treated, but if they flow from the limbs to the mouth, they cannot be treated. For soggy sores, Huang Lian powder is indicated.

Muscle Spasms

In cases of muscle spasms, the individual’s arms and legs are stiff, and the pulses feel slightly taut upon rising and falling.

Zhong Cang Jing [Han, Hua Tuo][49p]

　　　　　论脚弱状候不同

　　人病脚气与气脚有异者，为邪毒从内而注入脚，名曰气脚也；风寒暑湿邪毒之气，从外而入于脚膝，渐传于内者，名曰脚气也。皆以邪夺共正，使人病形顿相类例。其于治疗，亦有上下先后也，故分别于耳目一揆而不察其由，无理致其瘳也。又喜怒忧思寒热毒邪之气，流入肢节，或注于脚膝，其状类诸风历节偏枯臃肿之证，但入其脚膝，谓之气脚也；若从外入足入脏者，谓之脚气也。脚气者，先治内而次治外，实者利之，虚者益之。又病脚气多者，何也？谓人之心肺二经起于手，脾肾肝三经起于足，手则清邪中之，足则浊邪中之。人身之苦者，手足耳，而足则最重者艰苦，故风寒暑湿之气，多中于足，以此脚气病多也。然而得此病者，从渐而生病，但始萌而不悟，悟者不晓，医家不为脚气，将为别疾，治疗不明，因循至大，身居厄矣。本从微起，渐成巨候，流入脏腑，伤于四肢头项腹背，未甚终不能知觉也。[50p]

On the Different Conditions of Weakness in the Feet

The distinction between foot qi and qi foot lies in the fact that foot qi is characterized by the invasion of internal evil toxins into the feet, while qi foot is caused by external influences such as wind, cold, heat, and humidity that penetrate the feet and knees and gradually affect the internal organs. Both conditions result in the body being deprived of balance, leading to similar ailments.

In treatment, there is a hierarchy; consequently, one must discern the underlying causes rather than ignoring them, as this can lead to ineffective healing. Additionally, the emotions of joy, anger, worry, and cool or hot conditions can affect the limbs, particularly the feet and knees, presenting symptoms akin to wind-related joint ailments. However, when the issue originates externally, it is termed foot qi, whereas when it comes from within, it is referred to as qi foot.

For foot qi, one should first treat the internal problems before addressing the external, through nourishing the strong and supporting the weak. The prevalence of foot qi can be attributed to the heart and lung meridians originating in the hands, while the spleen, kidney, and liver meridians emerge from the feet. The hands clear internal evils, while the feet bear the burden of external toxins, making them most affected by wind, cold, heat, and humidity.

Those who suffer from this condition often do so gradually, starting with subtle signs that go unnoticed. Those who become aware may misunderstand, while practitioners may attribute the symptoms to other ailments, leading to unclear treatment and worsening conditions. What begins as a minor issue can escalate into a severe state, affecting the internal organs and resulting in pain across various body parts without the individual even realizing it.[50p]

时因他而作，或如伤寒，或如中暑，或腹背疼痛，或肢节不仁，或语言错乱，或精神昏昧，或时喘乏，或暴盲聋，或饮食不入，或脏腑不通，或孪急不遂，或舒缓不收，或口眼牵搐，或手足颤掉，种种名状，莫有达者。故使愚俗束手受病，死无告疗，仁者见之，岂不伤哉？今始述本末，略示后学浅深消息。至于醉入房中，饱眠露下，当风取凉，对月贪欢，沐浴未干而熟睡，房室纔罢而冲轩，久立于低湿，久伫于水泾，冒雨而行，侵寒而寝，劳伤汗出，食饮悲生，犯诸所禁，因成疾矣。其于不正之气，中于上则害于头目，害于中则蛊于心腹，形于下则失于腰脚，及于旁则妨于肢节，千状万证，皆属气脚。[51p]

At times, one may suffer due to various causes, such as from cold infections or heat strokes, abdominal and back pains, numbness in limbs and joints, confusion in speech, mental fog, shortness of breath, sudden blindness or deafness, inability to eat or digest, dysfunction of internal organs, urgency that cannot be relieved, discomfort that cannot be eased, twitching of mouth and eyes, trembling of hands and feet—so many various manifestations, and none can find a cure. Thus, the ignorant and ordinary people are left helpless in sickness, dying without recourse to treatment. Would not a benevolent person feel sorrow upon witnessing this? Now I begin to outline the essentials, briefly indicating the depth and understanding for future learners.

As for becoming intoxicated and entering a room, indulgently sleeping under the dew, seeking coolness against the wind, reveling under the moon, bathing yet not drying before falling into deep slumber, soon afterward confronting the cold air, standing for a long time in dampness, lingering by waters, walking in the rain, sleeping in cold, over-exerting and sweating, dining with grief, violating prohibitions, all lead to illness. Regarding improper energies, if they affect the head, they harm the mind; if they affect the heart, they damage the abdomen; if they affect the lower body, they impair the waist and feet; if they affect the sides, they obstruct the limbs and joints—countless forms and proofs, all belong to the influence of these energies.[51p]

起于脚膝，乃谓脚气也。形候脉理，亦在详明。其脉浮而弦者起于风，濡而弱者起于湿，洪而数者起于热，迟而濇者起于寒，滑而微者起于虚，牢而坚者起于实。在于上则发于上，在于下则发于下，在于中则发于中。结则因气，散则因忧，紧则因怒，细则因悲。风者汗而愈，湿者温而愈，热则解而愈，寒则熨而愈。虚者补之，实者泻之，气则流之，忧则宽之，怒则悦之，悲则和之。能通斯方，谓之良医。脚气之病，传于心肝，十死不治。入心则恍惚妄谬，呕吐，食不入，眠不安定，左手寸口脉乍大乍小，乍有乍无者，是也。入肾则腰脚俱肿，小便不通，呻吟不绝，目额皆黑色，时上冲胸腹而喘，其左尺中脉绝者是也。切宜明审矣。
　　　　　死候

　　手足爪甲肉黑色者死。
　　骨绝腰脊痛，肾中重不可反侧，足膝后平者，五日死。　　肾绝足肿者，九日死。[52p]

The condition begins at the knees and is referred to as "foot qi." The examination of the pulse and the body's state should be thorough. A floating and taut pulse arises from wind, a moist and weak pulse from dampness, a surging and rapid pulse from heat, a slow and thick pulse from cold, a slippery and faint pulse from deficiency, and a firm and solid pulse from excess. If it is in the upper part of the body, it manifests upwards; if in the lower part, it manifests downwards; if in the middle, it manifests centrally. Stagnation is due to qi, dispersal due to worry, tightness due to anger, and thinness due to grief. Wind leads to sweating and recovery, dampness to warmth and recovery, heat to resolution and recovery, and cold to smoothing and recovery. Deficiency should be supplemented, excess should be drained, qi should flow, worry should be eased, anger should be transformed, and grief should be harmonized. A healer who understands these principles is called a good doctor. Foot qi disease is transmitted to the heart and liver, with a mortality rate near 100% if untreated. When it enters the heart, it causes confusion, delusions, vomiting, inability to eat, and restless sleep. The pulse at the left wrist may alternate between large and small, appearing and disappearing. When it enters the kidneys, both the waist and feet swell, urination becomes obstructed, moaning is incessant, and the eyes and forehead turn dark. At times, it affects the chest and abdomen, causing difficulty in breathing, and the pulse at the left wrist may be absent. This should be examined carefully.

      Death indicators:

If the fingers and toes have blackened nails and flesh, it indicates death.
If the bones cause pain in the waist and spine, and there is heaviness in the kidneys preventing turning, with the back of the knees flat, death occurs in five days.
If the kidneys are compromised and the feet swell, death occurs in nine days.[52p]

　　筋绝魂惊虚恐，手足爪甲青，呼骂不休者，八九日死。
　　　　脉诀 【晋　王叔和】

　　　　　四肢酸疼

　　滑脉关前热在胸，到关翻胃几千重。更向尺中还若是，小便赤濇脚酸疼。
　　　　　死候

　　足趺趾踵膝如斗，十日须知难保守。手足甲青叫骂多，筋绝九日定难过。
古今图书集成医部全录卷一百九十

四肢门

　　　　千金方 【唐　孙思邈】

　　　　　论风毒状

　　考诸经方，往往有脚弱之论，而古人少有此疾。自永嘉南渡，衣缨士人多有遭者。岭表江东有支法、存仰道人等，并留意经方，偏善斯术，晋朝仕望，多获全济，莫不由此二公。又宋齐之间，有释门深师师道人述法存等诸家旧方，为三十卷，其脚弱一方，近百余首。周魏之代，盖无此病，所以姚公集验，殊不殷勤，徐王撰录，未以为意。特以三方鼎峙，风教未一，霜露不均，寒暑寒暑　原缺，据《千金》卷七补。不等，是以关西河北，不识此疾。[53p]

If the tendons are severed and the soul is alarmed, causing terror in the void, with the hands and feet turning blue and the person persistently shouting and cursing, they will die in eight or nine days.

The pulse diagnosis: In the heat at the anterior joint, it feels heavy in the chest, and when it reaches the joint, it turns the stomach over multiple times. If this continues in the radial pulse, there will be scanty, red urine, and soreness in the feet.

Signs of death: If the feet, toes, heels, and knees feel like they are in a fight, one must know that preservation is difficult in ten days. If the hands and feet turn blue and there is much shouting and cursing, it is certain that if the tendons are severed, one will hardly survive nine days.

Discussion on wind poison symptoms: Reviewing various classic texts, there are often discussions about weakness in the feet, yet this ailment was rare in ancient times. Since the Yongjia period when many scholars migrated south, numerous cases have appeared. In Jiangdong, there are practitioners who focus on classic methods and excel in these treatments, achieving great success due to the teachings of these two figures. Furthermore, between the Song and Qi dynasties, there were deep masters of Buddhist teachings who recorded their methods in old texts, compiling nearly a hundred treatments for foot weakness. In the Zhou and Wei dynasties, this disease seemingly did not exist; thus, Master Yao's compilations did not receive much attention, and Xu Wang's records were not taken seriously. Hence, even when there were three methods practiced, the teachings were not uniform, and not caring for frost and dew, as well as temperature variations, led to a lack of understanding of the disease in regions such as Shanxi and Hebei.[53p]

自圣唐开辟，六合无外，南极之地，襟带是重，爪牙之寄，作镇于彼，不习水土，往者皆遭。近者，中国士大夫虽不涉江表，亦有居然而患之者。良由今代天下风气混同，物类齐等所致之耳。然此病发，初得先从脚起，因即胫肿，时人号为脚气，深师云脚弱者，即其义也。深师述支法存所用永平山敷施莲范祖耀黄素等诸脚弱方，凡八十余条，皆极精要。然学者寻览，颇觉繁重，正是方集耳。卒欲救急，莫测指南。今取其所经用灼然有效者，以备仓卒，余者不复具述。[54p]

Since the glorious Tang dynasty was established, the world has been unified, with the southernmost regions being heavily fortified. Those who do not adapt to the local environment have invariably faced troubles. Recently, even among Chinese scholars and officials who do not traverse the rivers and seas, there are those who suffer from this issue. This is largely due to the current state of affairs, where the prevailing attitudes are confused, and all things seem to be equalized. However, this affliction begins at the feet: it manifests as swelling in the legs, and is commonly referred to as “gout” by contemporaries. According to historical masters, the weak-footed are meant in this context. These masters have described various remedies for weak feet, including over eighty potent formulas, such as those using lotus leaves and yellow essence from Mount Yongping, which are all quite essential. Yet, for those studying these remedies, they often seem cumbersome, as it is essentially a compilation of prescriptions. In times of urgent need, one cannot rely on detailed guidance. Therefore, I will now select the most effective remedies that I have come across for urgent use, without elaborating further on the others.[54p]

　　　　　论何以得之于脚

　　问曰：风毒中人，随处皆得作病，何偏着于脚也？答曰：夫人有五脏，心肺二脏经络所起在手十指，肝肾与脾三脏经络所起在足十趾。夫风毒之气皆起于地，地之寒暑风湿皆作蒸气，足常履之，所以风毒之中人也，必先中脚。久而不瘥，遍及四肢腹背头项也。微时不觉，痼滞乃知。经云，次传间传是也。
　　　　　论得已便令人觉否

　　凡脚气病皆由感风毒所致，得此病多不令人即觉，会因他病一度方始发动，或奄然大闷，经两三日不起，方乃觉之。诸小庸医，皆不识此疾，谩作余病治之，莫不尽毙。故此病多不令人识也。始起甚微，食饮嬉戏，气力如故，惟卒起脚屈弱不能动，有此为异耳。黄帝云：缓风湿痹，是也。[55p]

On How It Affects the Feet

The question is asked: When people are affected by wind toxins, they can fall ill anywhere; why is it particularly focused on the feet? The answer is: Humans have five organs, with the heart and lungs connected to the hands and fingers, while the liver, kidneys, and spleen are associated with the feet and toes. The energy of wind toxins arises from the ground, and the cold, heat, wind, and humidity of the earth create vapor. Since the feet are always in contact with the ground, those afflicted by wind toxins will first be affected at their feet. If the illness does not heal over time, it may then spread to the limbs, abdomen, back, head, and neck. At first, one may not be aware of it, but over time, the chronic nature of the illness becomes evident. The classics say this is a transmission of symptoms.

On Recognizing Its Manifestation

All cases of foot ailments are caused by exposure to wind toxins. Most people do not recognize this illness immediately; it may only manifest after the onset of another sickness, or one may suddenly feel lethargic, remaining inactive for two to three days before noticing it. Many lesser-skilled doctors do not understand this condition and mistakenly treat the symptoms as other diseases, often leading to fatal outcomes. Therefore, this illness frequently goes unrecognized. It begins very subtly, and one may feel normal in terms of food intake, hydration, and play, but suddenly experiences weakness in the feet, unable to move. This is the distinct sign. The Yellow Emperor states: It is a lingering issue of wind and dampness causing obstruction.[55p]

　　　　　论风毒相貌

　　夫有脚气未觉异而头项臂膊已有所苦，有诸处皆悉未知而心腹五内已有所困。又风毒之中人也，或见食呕吐，憎闻食臭，或有腹痛下利，或大小便秘濇不通，或胸中冲悸，不欲见光明’或精神昏愤’或喜迷忘，语言错乱，或壮热头痛，或身体酷冷疼烦，或觉转筋，或脚胫肿或不肿，或(月坒)腿顽痹，或时缓纵不随，或复百节挛急，或小腹不仁，此皆脚气状貌也，亦云风毒脚气之候也。其候难知，当须细意察之，不尔必失其机要。一朝病成，难可以理，妇人亦尔。又有妇人产后，春夏取凉，多中此毒，深宜慎之。其热闷掣瘲，惊悸心烦，呕吐气上，皆其候也。又但觉脐下冷痞，愊愊然不快，兼小便淋沥，不同生平，即是脚气之候。顽弱名缓风，疼痛为湿痹。[56p]

On the Manifestations of Wind Toxins

In cases of foot ailments, one may not feel any unusual symptoms in the feet, yet discomfort can be present in the head, neck, and arms. Additionally, there may be difficulties in various parts, yet the heart and internal organs suffer from distress. There are those afflicted by wind toxins who might experience symptoms such as vomiting upon seeing food, aversion to food odors, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation. Some may feel a palpitating sensation in the chest and desire to avoid bright light, or experience a foggy mind and forgetfulness, with speech becoming disordered. Others may have fevers and headaches, or feel extreme cold and pain throughout the body, or experience muscle cramps, swelling of the legs, or stubbornness in limb movements. Sometimes, they may face spasms in the joints or numbness in the lower abdomen. All these are manifestations of foot ailments and are also referred to as symptoms of wind toxins.

The signs can be difficult to discern, requiring careful observation; otherwise, one may miss crucial indicators. Once the illness develops, treatment can be challenging, particularly for women. Furthermore, there are women who, after childbirth, often suffer due to exposure to cool conditions in spring and summer, which can lead to these toxins, so caution is advised. Symptoms include heat, discomfort, palpitations, irritability, and nausea—all indicators of this condition. Additionally, if one feels a cold sensation in the lower abdomen and experiences discomfort with urination that is different from their usual state, this is also a sign of foot ailments. Pain and weakness are associated with dampness and obstruction.[56p]

　　　　　论得之所由

　　凡四时之中，皆不得久坐久立湿冷之地，亦不得因酒醉汗出，脱衣靴袜，当风取凉，皆成脚气。若暑月久坐久立湿地者，则热湿之气，蒸人经络，病发必四肢酸疼烦闷。若寒月久坐久立湿冷地者，则冷湿之气，上入经络，病发则四体酷冷转筋。若当风取凉得之者，病发则皮肉顽痹，诸处瞤动，渐渐向头。凡常之日，忽然暴热，人皆不能忍得者，当于此时，必不得顿取于寒以快意也。卒有暴寒，复不得受之，皆生病也。世有勤功力学之士，一心注意于事，久坐行立于湿地，不能动转，冷风来击，入于经络，不觉成病。故风毒中人，或先中手足十指，因汗毛孔开，腠理疏通，风如急箭，或先中足心，或先中足趺，或先中膝已下腨胫表里者。若欲使人不成病者，初觉即灸所觉处三二十壮，因此即愈，不复发也。黄帝云：当风取凉，醉已入房，能成此疾。[57p]

On the Causes of Disease

In all four seasons, one should not sit or stand for long in damp and cold places. Also, one must not, when drunk and sweating, remove clothing, shoes, or socks to cool off in the wind, as this can lead to foot ailments. If, during the hot months, one sits or stands for too long in damp places, the heat and humidity can penetrate the meridians, causing pain and discomfort in the limbs. Conversely, if one sits or stands in damp and cold places during the cold months, the cold and dampness may enter the meridians, leading to intense coldness and cramps throughout the body. If one cools off in the wind after being overheated, the resulting illness can lead to stubborn pain and twitching in the flesh, gradually moving towards the head.

On ordinary days, when there is suddenly extreme heat that is unbearable, one must not immediately seek relief in the cold. If a severe cold follows, one cannot endure it, and such conditions will lead to illness. There are diligent scholars focused on their studies, who sit or stand for long periods in damp places, unable to move, and when a cold wind strikes, it invades the meridians, unbeknownst to them, resulting in sickness. Thus, people afflicted by wind toxins may first experience symptoms in their fingers and toes, as excessive sweating opens the pores and allows the wind to enter swiftly. Symptoms may also first appear in the soles of the feet, or in the arches, or in the lower legs, inside and out.

To prevent illness, at the first signs of discomfort, one should apply moxibustion to the affected area with three to twenty strong treatments, and thus recover, preventing recurrence. The Yellow Emperor states: cooling off in the wind, or drunkenness followed by retreat indoors can lead to such diseases.[57p]

　　　　　论冷热不同
