Definitive Theory 【Jin Chengwujia】

Sweating of Hands and Feet[77p]

　　伤寒手足汗出，何以明之？四肢者诸阳之本，而胃主四肢，手足汗出者，阳明之证也。阳经邪热，传并阳明，则手足为之汗出。阳明为津液之主，病则自汗出。其有身汗出者，有但头汗出者，有手足汗出者，悉属阳明也。何以使之然也？若一身自汗出者，谓之热越，是热外达者也。但头汗出者，是热不得越，而热气上达者也。及手足汗出者，为热聚于胃，是津液之旁达也。经曰：手足濈然汗出者，此大便必鞕也。手足漐漐汗出，大便难而讝语者，下之则愈。由此观之，手足汗出，为热聚于胃可知矣。或谓热聚于胃而手足为之汗出，其寒聚于胃而有手足汗出者乎？经曰：阳明中寒者不能食，小便不利，手足濈然汗出，此欲作痼瘕，即是中寒者也。且热聚于胃为可下之证，其寒聚于胃为不可下，又何以明之？要明于此二者，曰：大便初鞕后溏，以胃中冷，水谷不别，是以不可下也。若大便难讝语者，为阳明证具，则是可下之证，临病宜审之。[78p]

In cases of typhoid with sweating in the hands and feet, how can this be clarified? The limbs are the source of all yang energies, and the stomach governs the limbs. Sweating in the hands and feet is a sign of yangming. When the pathogenic heat of the yang meridians spreads and affects yangming, it causes sweating in the hands and feet. Yangming is the master of bodily fluids, and when ill, there will be spontaneous sweating. One may experience sweating all over the body, only on the head, or specifically in the hands and feet, all of which belong to yangming. Why does this happen? If there is sweating all over the body, it is termed “heat exceeding,” indicating that the heat is expressed outward. If there is only sweating on the head, it shows the heat cannot extend outward but rather ascends. Sweat in the hands and feet indicates that heat is concentrated in the stomach, manifesting as fluid discharge. The texts state: when the hands and feet sweat profusely, there is a likelihood of constipation. If there is dripping sweat from the hands and feet, and if the stool is hard with difficulty in speaking, purging will lead to recovery. From this, it is evident that sweating in the hands and feet is caused by heat accumulating in the stomach. Some may ask if sweating in the hands and feet can occur due to cold accumulating in the stomach. The text says: when there is cold in the middle, one cannot eat, there is difficulty in urination, and there is profuse sweating in the hands and feet; this is indicative of wanting to form a stubborn mass, and indicates cold in the middle. Furthermore, heat accumulating in the stomach is a sign that one can purge, while cold accumulating in the stomach is a sign that one cannot purge. How can this be clarified? To distinguish between these two conditions, it can be said that when constipation is followed by diarrhea, this is due to cold in the stomach, where food and fluids are not differentiated, hence it cannot be purged. However, if this is accompanied by difficulty in stool and the signs of yangming are present, it indicates that it is a purgable condition, and one should be careful in diagnosing the illness.[78p]

　　　　儒门事亲 【元　张从政】

　　　　　手指麻木

　　凡人初觉大指次指麻木不仁或不用者，三年内有中风之疾也。宜先服愈风汤、天麻丸各一料，此治未病之先也。是以圣人治未病，不治已病。[79p]

The Confucian Way of Serving Parents

Numbness of the Fingers

When an ordinary person first feels numbness or lack of sensation in the thumb and index finger, or if they are unable to use them, it is an indication that within three years there may be a stroke. It is advisable to first take a dose of Yu Feng Decoction and Tian Ma Pills, as this is a way to treat what is unwell before it becomes ill. Thus, the sages treat what is unwell before it becomes ill, rather than treating what is already ill.[79p]

　　　　　北方下注脚气论

　　《内经》云：太阳之胜，火气内郁，流散于外，足胻胕肿，饮发于中，胕肿于外。又云：脾脉搏坚而长，其色黄，当病少气，其软而散，色不泽者，当病足胕肿若水状也。脾病者，身重肉痿，足不收，行善瘈，脚下痛，此谷入多而气少，湿居下也，故湿从下受之。如上所说，皆谓脾胃湿气下流，乘其肝肾之位，于是足胫疼痛而胕肿也。夫五谷入胃，糟粕、津液、宗气分为二隧，故宗气积于胸中，出于喉咙，以贯心肺而行呼吸焉。营气者，泌其津液，注之于脉，化而为血，以营四末，内注五脏六腑，以应刻数焉。卫气者，出悍气之慓疾，而先行于四末分肉之间，行而不休者也。又宗气之道，内谷为宝，谷入于胃，乃传之于脉，流溢于中，布散于外，精专者行于经隧，常营无已，终而复始，是谓天地之纪。[80p]

The Theory of Foot Edema in the Northern Regions

The "Inner Canon" states: When the sun prevails, fire energy becomes trapped within, dispersing outward, leading to swelling of the lower legs. Fluid accumulates internally, resulting in swelling externally. It also states: The spleen pulse is firm and long, and its color is yellow; this indicates illness characterized by a deficiency of qi. If it is soft and dispersed, lacking luster in color, this indicates foot swelling resembling water.

Those with spleen disorders experience heaviness in the body, muscle atrophy, inability to retract the feet, painful walking, and pain in the feet. This happens when excessive food intake generates insufficient qi and dampness accumulates below, thus dampness is received from the lower part. As mentioned, it is said that damp qi from the spleen and stomach flows downward, affecting the liver and kidneys, leading to pain in the legs and swelling of the feet.

The five grains enter the stomach, and the waste, fluids, and ancestral qi are divided into two channels. Thus, ancestral qi accumulates in the chest, exiting through the throat, traversing the heart and lungs to facilitate breathing. The nutritive qi secretes fluids, injecting them into the pulses, transforming them into blood to nourish the extremities and internally support the five organs and six bowels, responding to timely needs.

The defensive qi expels excessive energy and circulates in the gaps between the flesh of the extremities, constantly flowing without pause. Furthermore, the pathways of ancestral qi consider internal grains as a treasure; when the grains enter the stomach, they are transmitted through the pulses, overflowing within, spreading outward. The pure and specialized flow travels through the channels, continuously circulating, beginning and ending perpetually, which is known as the rhythm of heaven and earth.[80p]

或饮食失当，胃气不能鼓舞，脾气不能运化，行于百脉，其气下流，乘其肝肾，土木水相合，下注于足，胻胕肿而作疼痛，晋　苏敬号为脚气是也。凡治此疾，每旦早饭任意饱食，午饭少食，日晚不食弥佳，恐伤脾胃营运之气，失其天度。况夜食则血气壅滞而行阴道，愈增肿痛。古之人少有此疾，自永嘉南渡，衣缨士人多有之。大唐开辟，爪牙之士，作镇于南极，其地卑湿，雾露所聚，不袭水土，往往皆遭之。[81p]

Sometimes, improper diet leads to a failure of the stomach’s energy to invigorate and the spleen’s energy to transform. The energy flows through the hundred channels, descending and affecting the liver and kidneys. The interaction of earth, wood, and water converges and descends to the feet, resulting in swelling and pain in the lower limbs, which is what is referred to as "gout" in Jin, as called by Su Jing.

For treating this ailment, one should eat heartily for breakfast, eat less for lunch, and it is best not to eat dinner at all, for fear of injuring the spleen and stomach's operational energies and losing their natural balance. Moreover, eating at night causes stagnation of blood and qi, leading to increased swelling and pain. In ancient times, this ailment was rare, but since the Southern migration during the Yongjia era, many scholars have suffered from it. Following the establishment of the Tang Dynasty, those who were tasked with governance in the southern regions, where the land is low and wet, often suffer from it due to the accumulation of mist and dew, as they are not accustomed to the water and soil conditions.[81p]

关西河北人皆不识此疾，《外台秘要》、《总录》亦说江东岭南大率有此，此盖清湿袭虚伤于下，故经云，感则害人皮肉筋骨者也。故制方立论，皆详其当时土地所宜而治之。今观北方爽垲而无卑湿之地，况腠理致密，外邪难侵，而有此疾者，何也？盖多饮乳酪醇酒水湿之属也，加以奉养过度，以滋其湿，水之润下，气不能呴之，故下注于足胻，积久而作肿满疼痛，此饮之下流之所致，岂可与南方之地同法而治哉？当察其地势高下，详其饮食居处，立为二法，一则治地之湿气，一则治饮食之下流，随其气宜，用药施治，庶几合轩岐之旨也。[82p]

People from the northern part of Guanshi do not recognize this ailment. The texts "Wai Tai Mi Yao" and "Zong Lu" also indicate that this condition is common in Jiangdong and Lingnan. This is likely due to the attack of dampness on a weakened constitution, which is why the classics state that it harms the skin, flesh, tendons, and bones. Hence, the creation of treatment plans is based on the specific conditions of the land at that time.

Now, observing the northern regions which are crisp and free of low-lying damp areas, and considering that the pores are tight and external pathogens are hard to invade, one wonders why there are individuals suffering from this ailment. It is likely due to excessive consumption of milk, rich wines, and damp foods, compounded by overindulgence in nurturing one's body that fosters dampness. As moisture accumulates and cannot be expelled, it settles in the feet and ankles, leading to prolonged swelling and pain. This issue arises from the consumption of these damp substances, which is distinctly different from how ailments are treated in the southern regions.

Thus, it is essential to consider the topography and dietary habits of the area, creating two treatment strategies: one to address the dampness of the land and the other to handle the impact of food and drink. Medications and treatments should be adjusted according to the prevailing conditions to align with the principles of Xuanqi.[82p]

　　　　东垣十书 【元　李杲】

　　　　　四肢辨内外伤

　　内伤等病，是心肺之气已绝于外，必怠惰嗜卧，四肢沉困不收，此乃热伤元气。脾主四肢，既为热所乘，无气以动，经云热伤气，又云热则骨消筋缓，此之谓也。若外伤风寒，是肾肝之气已绝于内，肾主骨为寒，肝主筋为风，自古肾肝之病同一治，以其递相维持也。故经言胆主筋，膀胱主骨是也。或中风，或伤寒，得病之日，便着床枕，非扶不起，筋骨为之疼痛，不能动摇，乃形质之伤。经云：寒伤形，寒则筋挛骨痛，此之谓也。内伤及劳役、饮食不节，病手心热，手背不热；外伤风寒则手背热，手心不热。此辨至甚皎然。
　　　　　四肢不收

　　脾胃虚则怠惰嗜卧，四肢不收，时值秋燥令行，湿热少退，体重节痛，口干舌干，饮食无味，大便不调，小便频数，不欲食，食不消，兼见肺病，洒淅恶寒，惨惨不乐，面色恶而不和，乃阳气不伸故也。当升阳益气，宜升阳益胃汤主之。[83p]

East Garden Ten Treatises
Yuan Dynasty - Li Gao

Distinction Between Internal and External Injuries to the Limbs

Internal injuries, such as illnesses, occur when the vital energy of the heart and lungs is severed from the outside, leading to laziness and a propensity to lie down, with heavy and unresponsive limbs. This is due to heat damaging the original qi. The spleen governs the limbs, and when affected by heat, there is insufficient energy to move. The classics say that heat damages qi, and when heat is present, bones can decay and tendons can loosen; this is what is referred to.

In contrast, external injuries from wind and cold indicate that the vital energy of the kidneys and liver has been severed internally. The kidneys govern the bones and are associated with cold; the liver governs the tendons and is associated with wind. Since ancient times, diseases of the kidneys and liver have been treated similarly because they support one another. Thus, the classics say that the gallbladder governs the tendons, and the bladder governs the bones.

Whether it is a stroke or an injury from cold, on the day the illness occurs, one feels the need to lie down; it is not that one cannot be supported, but that the tendons and bones are painful and unable to move, thus indicating a physical injury. The classics state: "Cold harms the form; cold causes the tendons to cramp and the bones to ache." This is what is referred to.

For internal injuries and labor, along with irregularities in diet, if one experiences heat in the palms and coolness in the backs of the hands, it indicates internal issues; whereas, if external injuries from wind and cold are present, the backs of the hands feel hot while the palms do not. This distinction is remarkably clear.

Inability to Control the Limbs

When the spleen and stomach are deficient, one feels lazy and prefers to lie down, with involuntary limbs; during the autumn dryness, when damp heat diminishes, the body feels heavy and achy, with dry mouth and tongue, lack of taste in food, irregular bowel movements, frequent urination, loss of appetite, inability to digest food, and concurrent signs of lung disease, such as chills and a sad disposition, along with an unhappy, pale complexion—this is due to the yang qi not rising. It is advisable to promote the yang and augment the qi, and the formula for this is to enhance yang and strengthen the stomach.[83p]

　　　　　脚气

　　脚气之疾，实水湿之所为也。盖湿之害人皮肉筋脉而属于下，然亦有二焉。一则自外而感，一则自内而致，其治法自应不同，故详而论之。其为病也，有证无名，脚气之称，自晋　苏敬始，关中河朔无有也。惟南方地下水寒，其清湿之气中于人，必自足始。故经曰：清湿袭虚，则病起于下。或者难曰：今兹北方，其地则风土高寒，其人则腠理致密，而复多此疾者，岂是地湿之气感之而为邪？答曰：南方之疾，自外而感者也；北方之疾，自内而致者也。何以言之？北方之人，常食潼乳，又饮酒无节，过伤而不厌，且潼乳之为物，其气味则潼乳，其形质则水也，酒醴亦然。人之水谷入胃，胃气蒸腾，其气与味，宣之于经络，化之为血气，外荣四末，内注五脏六腑，周而复始，以应刻数焉，是谓天地之纪，此皆元气充足，脾胃之气无所伤而然也。[84p]

Athlete's Foot

The disease known as athlete's foot is indeed caused by dampness. Dampness harms the skin, flesh, muscles, and tendons and relates to the lower parts of the body; however, it can arise in two ways. One is from external influences, and the other is from internal causes, hence the treatment methods should differ accordingly. Thus, it is necessary to discuss this in detail.

As for the disease, it presents symptoms without a name; the term athlete's foot originated with Su Jing during the Jin Dynasty, and it was not known in regions such as Guanzhong or Heshuo. Only in the South does the cold underground water and the clear, damp air penetrate the people, leading to the condition from the feet. The classics say: "When clear dampness invades the empty, the illness arises from the lower parts."

Some might argue: "Now in the North, the land is high and cold, and the people have close pores; why are there still many cases of this disease? Could it not be caused by the dampness of the land?" The answer is: the disease in the South arises from external causes, while the disease in the North is due to internal factors. How can this be explained? Northerners often consume too much milk and drink alcohol excessively, impairing their health without restraint. Milk, in its essence, has the nature of milk, while its form and quality resemble water; the same applies to wine and sweet drinks. As food enters the stomach, the stomach's energy rises and mingles its essence with taste, spreading through the meridians and transforming into qi and blood. This nourishment supports the extremities and feeds the five organs and six bowels, creating a cycle of response that corresponds with the rhythms of nature. This is known as the equilibrium of heaven and earth, which relies on the abundance of vital energy when the spleen and stomach are uninjured.[84p]

苟元气不充则胃气之本自弱，饮食既倍则脾胃之气有伤，既不能蒸化所食之物，其气与味亦不能宣畅旁通，其水湿之性流下而致之。其自外而入者，止于下胫肿而痛；自内而致者，乃或至于手节也。经云：足胫肿曰水，太阴所至为重胕肿，此但言其自外者也。所治之法，前人方论备矣。自内而致者，治法则未有也。杨大受云：脚气是为壅疾，治以宣通之剂，使气不能成壅也。壅既成而盛者，砭恶血而去其势。经曰：蓄则肿热。砭射之后，以药治之。　　《内经》论南方者，其地下，水土弱，雾露之所蒸也。江东岭南，大率如此。春夏之交，山林蒸郁，风湿毒气为甚，足或感之，遂成瘴毒脚气。其候则脚先屈弱，渐至痹疼，胫微肿，小腹不仁，头痛烦心，痰壅吐逆，时作寒热，便溲不通，甚者攻心而势逼，治之诚不可缓。支法存所以留意经方，偏善此术者，岂非江右岭表此疾行之多欤？　　异法方宜论云：北方者，其地高陵居，风寒冷冽。[85p]

If the vital energy is insufficient, then the foundational energy of the stomach is inherently weak. When intake of food is excessive, the energy of the spleen and stomach gets injured, unable to properly transform and digest what is consumed; the essence and flavors cannot circulate smoothly, causing the nature of dampness to flow downward. Those conditions originating externally stop at the lower limbs, causing swelling and pain; while those arising from within might even reach the joints of the hands. The classics state that swelling of the feet and lower limbs is caused by water, with heavy swelling being due to the arrival of the Taiyin; this describes only the external causes. The methods of treatment have been elaborated by previous scholars. However, for internal conditions, there has yet to be a established treatment approach. Yang Dashou states that leg qi is a type of obstruction disease, treated with disseminating and unblocking medications to prevent Qi from becoming stagnant. If obstruction has already formed strongly, then cupping and removing the stasis in the blood is necessary. The classics say: if accumulation occurs, swelling and heat result. After cupping, treat with medication.

The "Inner Canon" discusses the southern regions where the ground is weak and the water and soil are poor, influenced by mist and dew. The Jiangdong and Lingnan regions are generally like this. When transitioning from spring to summer, the mountains and forests are steamy and dense, and the air is filled with wind, dampness, and toxins; the feet may be affected, resulting in endemic leg qi. The symptoms include weakening and bending of the feet, gradually leading to pain and numbness, slight swelling of the shins, numbness of the lower abdomen, headaches, irritability, phlegm obstruction and regurgitation, intermittent chills and fevers, and difficulties in urination; in severe cases, it may attack the heart and become urgent, thus treatment cannot be delayed. Therefore, it is essential to pay attention to classical formulas; those skilled in this art, could they not be more prevalent among the Jiangyou region?

Regarding different methods, the northern regions are characterized by high elevations, exposed to cold and frigid winds.[85p]

其俗饮潼酪而肉食，凡饮潼酪，以饮多饮速者为能。经云：因而大饮则气逆，又云：食入于阴，长养于阳，今乃反行阳道，是为逆也。夫乳酪醇酒者，湿热之物，饮之属也。加以奉养太过，亦滋其湿，水性润下，气不能呴，故下注于足胫，积久而作肿痛，此饮食下流之所致也。　　通评虚实论云：谷入多而气少，湿居下也。况潼酪醇酒之湿热，甚于谷者也。至真要大论云：太阴之盛，火气内郁，流散于外，足胫胕肿，饮发于中，胕肿于下，此之谓也。故饮入于胃，游溢精气，上输于脾，脾气散精，上归于肺，通调水道，下输膀胱，水精四布，五经并行，合于四时五脏，阴阳揆度，以为常也。若饮食自倍，肠胃乃伤，则胃气不能施化，脾气不能四布，故下流乘其肝肾之位，注于足胫，加之房事不节，阴盛阳虚，遂成痼疾。[86p]

Their custom is to drink thick yogurt and eat meat. Among those who drink thick yogurt, those who consume quickly and in large amounts are considered capable. The classics say that excessive drinking leads to reversed energy, and it is stated that food enters the yin and nourishes the yang; now they are going against the yang way, which is considered a reversal. Thick yogurt and strong wine are damp and hot substances associated with drinking. Furthermore, overindulgence in nourishment increases dampness as the water quality descends, causing energy to stagnate—hence it settles in the legs and calves, leading to swelling and pain over time, which is a result of improper diet.

The "General Discussion on Ventilation and Solidification" states: When grains are abundant but energy is lacking, dampness resides below. Moreover, the dampness and heat of thick yogurt and strong wine are even worse than that of grains. The "Essential Discussions of the Ultimate Truth" asserts that when the yin is strong, fire energy becomes trapped internally, spreading outward, leading to swelling in the legs and lower limbs. This is what they refer to. Thus, when drinks enter the stomach, the vital energy flows forth, rising to the spleen, which distributes the energy upward to the lungs, connecting with the water pathways and descending to the bladder, allowing the water essence to be distributed widely, aligning with the seasons and the five organs, balancing yin and yang for constancy. If food and drink are excessive, the stomach and intestines become harmed, and thus the stomach energy cannot transform properly, nor can the spleen energy be distributed, leading to stagnation in the liver and kidneys’ regions, settling in the legs and feet, compounded by excessive sexual activity, resulting in excessive yin and deficient yang, eventually leading to chronic ailments.[86p]

　　杨大受云：脚气之疾，自古皆尚疏下，为疾壅故也，然不可太过，太过则损伤脾胃，使营运之气，不能上行，反下注为脚气。又不可不及，不及则使壅气不能消散，今立羌活导滞汤、开结导引丸等方，详虚实而用之。　　《外台》云：第一忌嗔。嗔则生烦，烦则脚气发。第二禁大语。大语则伤肺，肺伤亦发动。又不得露足，当风入水，以冷水洗脚，两脚胫尤不宜冷，虽暑月常须着绵褲，至冬寒倍令两胫温暖，得微汗大佳。依此将息。[87p]

Yang Dashou said: The illness of athlete's foot has historically been treated with purgatives, as it results from stagnation. However, one must not overdo it; excessive purging can harm the spleen and stomach, preventing qi from ascending and causing it to descend instead, leading to athlete's foot. On the other hand, if one does not purge sufficiently, the stagnant qi cannot disperse. Therefore, I have established formulas such as Qianghuo Daoti Decoction and Kaijie Daoyin Pill, which should be used based on careful consideration of the condition's nature.

The "External Records" states: First, avoid anger. Anger causes irritation, and irritation leads to the onset of athlete's foot. Second, refrain from speaking loudly. Loud speech damages the lungs, and when the lungs are harmed, it also triggers conditions. Additionally, one should not expose the feet; do not expose them to wind or water. Washing the feet with cold water is ill-advised, especially keeping the legs warm. Even in the summer, one should wear cotton trousers, and in winter, it is vital to keep the legs warm to induce a slight sweat, which is highly beneficial. Follow these guidelines for proper care.[87p]

脚气渐薄损，每至寅丑日割手足甲，割少侵肉，去风湿气。夏时腠理开，不宜当风卧睡，睡觉令人按挼，勿使邪气稽留，数劳动关节，常令通畅。此并养生之要，拒风邪之法也。寻常有力，每食后行三五百步，疲倦便止，脚中恶气，随即下散，虽浮肿，气不能上也。　　第一，凡饮食酒及潼酪，勿使过度，过则伤损脾胃，下注于足胫，胕肿遂成脚疾。第二，欲不可纵，嗜欲多则脚气发。凡饮食之后，宜缓行二三百步，不至汗出，觉困则止，如此则不能成壅也。经云：逸者行之。又云：病湿痹，忌温食饱食，湿地濡水。
　　　　　臂足痛

　　臂痛有六道经络，究其痛在何经络之间，以行本经药行其气血，血气通则愈矣。若表证疼痛，不可便下，当详细辨之。　　足痛，新病以痛风法治之。久病非脚气，以鹤膝风治之。各自有门。痛风多属血虚，然后寒湿得以侵之。[88p]

Athlete's foot gradually weakens and damages the body; one should cut the nails of hands and feet on the days of Yin and Chou, cutting only a little into the flesh to dispel wind and dampness. In summer, the pores open, so it is unwise to sleep exposed to the wind. Waking can cause discomfort, so keep evil energies from lingering. Regular movement of the joints keeps them unblocked. This is essential for health and a method to ward off wind and evil.

For usual strength, after each meal, walk three to five hundred steps. If you feel fatigued, stop; the bad energy from the feet will disperse immediately, even if swelling occurs, the energy cannot rise.

Firstly, regarding diet, avoid excessive alcohol and rich foods, as overindulgence damages the spleen and stomach, leading to swelling in the legs and causing foot ailments. Secondly, desires should not be indulged; excessive cravings will cause symptoms. After eating, it is advisable to walk slowly for two to three hundred steps, not sweating excessively; if you feel tired, stop to prevent congestion. The classics say: "The unhurried person walks." They also state that those suffering from dampness and obstruction should avoid warm, over-satisfying foods and wet conditions.

Arm and Foot Pain

Arm pain has six pathways; investigate which path the pain resides in to treat the energy and blood using appropriate medicinal methods. If the pain is exterior, do not hastily administer treatment; it requires careful differentiation. For foot pain, treat new illnesses with methods for gout. Chronic foot problems do not arise from athlete's foot, but rather should be treated using methods for rheumatism. Each condition has its own diagnosis. Gout often arises from blood deficiency, allowing cold and dampness to invade.[88p]

　　　　丹溪心法 【元　朱震亨】

　　　　　脚气

　　脚气，须用升提之药，提起其湿，随气血用药。　　有脚气冲心者，宜四物汤，加炒黄蘗；再宜涌泉穴，用附子末津唾调敷，上以艾灸，泄引热下。　　有筋动于足大指，上至大腿近腰结了，乃因奉养厚，遇风寒，宜四物汤加酒芩、红花、苍朮、南星、生姜煎服。脚气有湿热、有食积，流注有风湿、有寒湿。　　胜湿，以仙朮、白朮、防己、川芎为主，或六物附子汤，或当归拈痛汤。　　气郁甚者，舟车丸、除湿丹。有饮者，东垣开结导引丸。解表用麻黄左经汤等药，随经选用。有兼痰气寒湿者，五积散加木瓜。　　若双解以大黄左经汤，东垣羌活导滞汤。若理血以八味丸，或四物加羌活、天麻，又或四物加黄蘗、南星，或健步丸。　　若疏风养血，用独活寄生汤最效。[89p]

Danxi's Heart Method (Yuan Dynasty, Zhu Zhenheng)

Gout

Gout requires the use of medicines that dispel dampness, raising the humidity and accompanying the flow of Qi and blood. For gout that affects the heart, it is advisable to use the Four Substances Decoction, adding fried Huangbai; also, use the Yongquan acupoint, applying aconite powder mixed with saliva, and then using moxibustion to draw out the heat downwards.

If there is muscle movement in the big toe extending to the thigh near the waist, this is due to overindulgence and exposure to wind and cold, so it is proper to use the Four Substances Decoction combined with wine, qinpi (orange peel), safflower, dried atractylodes, nanking (south star), and ginger, decocted for consumption. Gout may involve damp heat or food accumulation, with the flow being windy dampness or cold dampness.

To combat dampness, focus on ingredients like Xianjue (immortal atractylodes), Baizhu (white atractylodes), Fangji (stephania), and Chuanxiong (chuanxiong), or use the Six Substances Aconite Decoction or the Pain Relief Decoction with Angelica. For severe Qi stagnation, utilize the Zhouche Pill or Exclude Dampness Pill. If there is retention of fluid, employ Dongyuan's Open and Guide Pill. For resolving exterior signs, use Ma Huang's Left Meridian Decoction and other medicines, choosing according to the meridians.

If there is also phlegm, Qi cold dampness together, increase the dosage of Wujisan (Five Accumulations Powder) with papaya. For dual resolution, use the Dahuang Left Meridian Decoction or Dongyuan's Qianghuo Guide to Disperse Powder. If regulating the blood is necessary, utilize the Eight Flavor Pill, or the Four Substances with Qianghuo and Tianma, or the Four Substances with Huangbai and Nanking, or the Jianbu Pill.

For dispelling wind and nourishing blood, using the Du Huojisheng Soup is the most effective.[89p]

　　　　　足跟痛

　　有痰、有血热。血热宜四物加黄蘗、知母。
　　　　　手足麻木

　　手足麻者，属气虚，木者有湿痰、死血。　　十指麻木，是胃中有湿痰、死血。

　　　　　肢节痛

　　肢节痛，须用羌活。去风湿，亦宜用之。　　如肥人肢节痛，多是风湿与痰饮流注经络而痛，宜南星、半夏。　　如瘦人肢节痛，是血虚，宜四物加防风、羌活。　　如瘦人性急躁而肢节痛发热，是血热，宜四物汤加黄芩、酒炒黄蘗。　　如肢节肿痛脉滑者，当用燥湿，宜苍朮、南星，兼行气药木香、枳壳、槟榔，在下者加汉防己。　　若肢节肿痛脉濇数者，此是瘀血，宜桃仁、红花、当归、川芎及大黄微利之。　　如倦怠无力而肢节痛，此是气虚，兼有痰饮流注，宜参、朮、星、半。[90p]

Heel Pain

Phlegm and blood heat are present. For blood heat, it is advisable to use Siwu decoction with Rhizoma Coptidis and Anemarrhena.

Numbness in Hands and Feet

Numbness in the hands and feet is related to qi deficiency; when it involves the body, it indicates damp phlegm or stagnant blood. Numbness in all ten fingers suggests that there is damp phlegm and stagnant blood in the stomach.

Limb Joint Pain

For limb joint pain, Qiang Huo should be used to dispel wind and dampness. For obese individuals with limb joint pain, it is often due to wind-dampness and phlegm flow disrupting the meridians, indicating that Nanxing and Banxia should be used. For thin individuals with limb joint pain, this signifies blood deficiency, and Siwu decoction should be combined with Fangfeng and Qiang Huo. If a thin person exhibits impatience along with limb joint pain and fever, it indicates blood heat, and Siwu decoction should include Huangqin and wine-fried Rhizoma Coptidis. If there is swelling and pain in the joints with a slippery pulse, drying dampness is necessary, recommending Cangzhu, Nanxing, along with qi-moving herbs such as Mukang, Zhihua, and Binglang; if it is below, add Hanfangji. If there is swelling and pain in the joints with a thin and rapid pulse, this signifies stagnant blood, suggesting the use of Tao Ren, Honghua, Danggui, Chuanxiong, and a light dose of Da Huang. If there is fatigue and weakness accompanied by limb joint pain, this indicates qi deficiency, possibly with phlegm flow, and it is best to use Ren, Shu, Xing, and Ban.[90p]

　　　　证治要诀 【明　戴思恭】

　　　　　手气

　　手气，手肿痛，或在掌指连臂膊，并五痹汤、蠲痹汤。
　　　　　臂痛

　　臂为风寒湿所搏，或饮液流入，或因提挈重物，皆致臂痛，有肿者，有不肿者。除饮证外，其余诸痛，并宜五积散及乌药顺气散，或蠲痹汤。　　外有血虚一证，血不荣于筋，或致臂痛，宜蠲痹汤、四物汤各半贴，和匀煎服。　　乳妇以臂枕儿，伤于风寒，多有臂痛，亦宜于此选用。　　若坐卧为风湿所搏，或睡后手在被外，为寒邪所袭，遂令臂痛，宜五积散及蠲痹汤、乌药顺气散。审知是湿，蠲痹汤，每服加苍朮三钱，防己四分；或用五痹汤。　　曾因拿重伤筋，以致臂痛，宜琥珀散、劫荣散、或和气饮，每服加白姜黄半钱，以姜黄能入臂故也。[91p]

Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment
(Ming Dynasty, Dai Sigong)

Hand Pain

Hand pain manifests as swelling and discomfort, affecting the palm, fingers, and arms. For treatment, use Wujin Decoction or Juanbi Decoction.

Arm Pain

Arm pain can result from wind, cold, or dampness attacking the area, or from fluids accumulating, or due to lifting heavy objects. This may lead to swelling in some cases and not in others. Excluding cases of fluid accumulation, other types of pain should be treated with Wujisuan or Wuyao Shunqi Decoction, or Juanbi Decoction. Blood deficiency can also cause arm pain, as inadequate blood nourishes the muscles; for this, use a combination of Juanbi Decoction and Four Substance Decoction. Nursing mothers who rest their arms on their children might experience arm pain due to wind and cold; they should also refer to this treatment. If pain arises from wind and dampness while sitting or lying down, or if the arm is exposed to cold while sleeping, Wujin Decoction, Juanbi Decoction, and Wuyao Shunqi Decoction are recommended. If dampness is confirmed, for Juanbi Decoction, add three qian of cangzhu and four fen of fangji; or use Wubing Decoction. If pain resulted from a previous heavy lifting injury, apply Hu Po San, Jie Rong San, or Heqi Decoction, and add half a qian of fresh turmeric to benefit the arm.[91p]

　　　　　脚气

　　风寒暑湿，足常履之，遂成脚气。诸邪气不问久近干湿，及属何经，并可用除湿汤加木瓜、槟榔、白芷各半钱，或芎芷香苏散加赤芍药、萆薢各半钱，仍吞木瓜丸，此药宜常服。脚气发动而两足痛不可忍者，五积散加全蝎三五个，入酒煎。　　脚气发动，必身痛发热，不可妄用伤寒等药，缘脚气类伤寒，若卒起脚弱，或小腹不仁，或举体转筋，或见食呕逆，或两胫赤肿，便当作脚气治。干者于前二药中，或更加萝卜子炒研碎半钱，湿者于前二药中，加青橘皮十数片。　　切记脚气不可令下寒，亦不可妄用寒药，得温则消散。　　脚气，跟注一孔，深半寸许，每下半日疼痛异常，此乃脚气注成漏，以人中白于火上煅令水出，滴入疮口。[92p]

Athlete's Foot

Wind, cold, heat, and dampness, commonly encountered by the feet, lead to athlete's foot. Various pathogenic factors, whether they have been present for a long time or recently, and regardless of which meridian they belong to, can be treated with a herbal decoction to eliminate dampness, adding half a tael each of papaya, betel nut, and white atractylodes. Alternatively, one can use a powder of hydrangea and angelica, adding half a tael each of red peony and aroid. It is also advisable to take papaya pills regularly.

When athlete's foot flares up and causes unbearable pain in both feet, use the Five Accumulations Powder, adding three to five whole scorpions, and decoct in wine. During a flare-up, one will also experience body aches and fever; therefore, do not recklessly use cold medicine, as athlete's foot may resemble mild cold illnesses. If one suddenly feels weakness in the foot, numbness in the lower abdomen, cramps in the entire body, nausea or vomiting after eating, or redness and swelling in both shins, treat it as athlete's foot.

For dry symptoms, either of the previous two herbal formulations may have half a tael of stir-fried and crushed radish seeds added. For wet symptoms, add ten or more strips of green tangerine peel to the previous two medications. Remember, athlete's foot must not be treated with cold treatments; nor should cold medicines be used indiscriminately, as warmth is needed to disperse the condition.

With athlete's foot, one may observe a puncture approximately half an inch deep; every half day, pain may be distinctly abnormal. This indicates that athlete's foot has formed a discharge. Treat it by applying the essence of white wood that has been calcined over fire to draw out excess moisture, dripping it into the sore.[92p]

脚气发热不退者，败毒散加木瓜一钱，或用败毒散、五积散各半贴和匀，名交加散，更加木瓜一钱。　　若久履湿而得，两脚或肿或疮，五苓散或和气饮，加木瓜、萝卜子各半钱，大黄一钱。　　脚气小便不通者，生料五苓散一贴，除湿汤一贴，加木瓜二钱，重分二服。若大小便俱不通，五苓散、复元通气散。　　脚气喘急者，此系入腹，宜苏子降气汤，或沉香降气汤，仍佐以养正丹或四磨饮。　　脚气迫肺，令人喘嗽，宜小青龙汤，每服加入槟榔一钱，重煎服。　　脚气畏食者，宜生料平胃散加木瓜一钱。呕逆恶心，八味平胃散加木瓜一钱。　　脚气日久，脚胫枯细，或寒或热，或痛或痒，或一脚偏患，或软弱亸曳，状如偏风者，宜小续命汤加木瓜。或独活寄生汤、附子八味汤吞活络丹、虎骨四斤丸之类。　　脚气血虚，芎芷香苏，内加木瓜、羌活、赤芍、芎、芷之类。　　脚转筋，用龙胶散。[93p]

For persistent heat due to athlete's foot, use Baidu San with one qian of papaya, or mix equal parts Baidu San and Wujisan, known as Jiaojia San, adding one qian of papaya. If the condition results from prolonged wetness, leading to swelling or sores on both feet, use Wuling San or Heqi Yin, adding half a qian each of papaya and radish seeds, along with one qian of rhubarb.

If there's difficulty urinating due to athlete's foot, apply one patch of fresh Wuling San and one patch of Chuxie Tang, adding two qian of papaya, divided into two doses. If there’s no urine or stool passage, use Wuling San and Fuyuan Tongqi San.

For shortness of breath associated with athlete's foot, which pertains to the abdomen, it’s advisable to use Suzi Jiangqi Tang or Chenxiang Jiangqi Tang, supplemented with Yangzheng Dan or Simotan Yin.

If athlete's foot presses on the lungs causing coughing, use Xiao Qing Long Tang, adding one qian of betel nut with each dose, remade daily.

For loss of appetite due to athlete's foot, use Shengliao Pingwei San adding one qian of papaya. In cases of vomiting and nausea, use Eight Flavors Pingwei San with one qian of papaya.

For chronic athlete's foot with thin, withered legs that may feel cold or hot, or are painful or itchy, and may affect one foot more than the other, or appear weak and limp like a condition of wind, use Xiao Xuming Tang with papaya. Alternatively, one can use Duhuo Jisheng Tang, Fuzhong Bawwei Tang, swallow Huoluodan, or use the Tiger Bone pills.

If the condition is associated with blood deficiency, employ Xiongzhi Xiangsu, combining with papaya, Qianghuo, Chi Shao, Chuanxiong, and Zhizi.

For leg cramps, use Longjiao San.[93p]

　　　　　脚心痛

　　脚心痛者，宜大圣散二钱，入木瓜末半钱或一钱，豆淋酒调，仍用川椒、香白芷、草乌，煎汤洗。
　　　　　鹤膝风

　　胫细而肿者，俗呼为鹤膝风，宜地仙丹。　　鹤膝风则于五积散中、加松木、杉木二节。
　　　　医学纲目 【明　楼英】

　　　　　四肢所主

　　阳主四肢。经云：四肢者，诸阳之本也。又云，阳受气于四肢，是也。阳实则肢肿。经云：结阳肿四肢是也。阳虚则肢满。经云，冬气病在四肢，是也。　　脾主四肢。经云：四肢皆禀气于胃，而不得至经，必因于脾乃得禀者是也。
　　　　　不举不用

　　脾实则四肢不举。经云：脾脉太过，为病在外，则令人四肢不举者是也。　　脾虚则四肢不用。经云：脾脏肉形不足，则四肢不用。　　又云，四肢懈惰，此脾精之不行，是也。　　运气，四肢不举，皆属湿。经云：土太过曰敦阜，敦阜之纪，其病腹满，四肢不举，是也。
　　　　　邪留肢节[94p]

Foot Pain

For foot pain, it is advisable to use two qian of Da Sheng San, mixed with half or one qian of wood melon powder, and adjust with bean soup wine. Also, use Chuan Jiao, fragrant Bai Zhi, and Cǎo Wū to brew a decoction for washing.

Crane Knee Wind

When the shins are thin and swollen, it is commonly called Crane Knee Wind, treated with Di Xian Dan. For Crane Knee Wind, add two sections of pine and cedar to Wu Ji San.

Principles of Medical Studies 【Ming Dynasty, Lou Ying】

Dominion of the Limbs

Yang governs the limbs. The classics say: "The limbs are the root of all Yang." They also state that Yang receives Qi from the limbs. When Yang is sufficient, the limbs swell. The classic states: "Accumulated Yang swelling in the limbs is this." When Yang is deficient, the limbs feel full. The classic states: "Winter Qi disease in the limbs is this."

The spleen governs the limbs. The classic states: "All limbs receive qi from the stomach but cannot reach the channels; this must be due to the spleen for them to receive it."

Inability to Lift or Use

When the spleen is full, the limbs are unable to lift. The classic states: "When the spleen pulse is excessive, the disease manifests externally, causing one to be unable to lift the limbs." When the spleen is deficient, the limbs are unusable. The classic states: "When the spleen's flesh form is insufficient, then the limbs are unusable." Furthermore, when the limbs lack energy, this is due to the spleen's essence not circulating.

In movement and qi, if the limbs are unable to lift, it all pertains to dampness. The classic states: "When earth is excessive, it is said to be dense and mounded. The manifestations of this are abdominal fullness and inability to lift the limbs."

Evil Residue in the Joints[94p]

　　五脏有邪，留在肢节。经云：肺心有邪，其气留于两肘；肝有邪，其气留于两股；脾有邪，其气留于两髀；肾有邪，其气留于两膝，是也。
　　　　　脚气

　　脚气壅肿，便溺阻隔，心下痞满，饮食不消，宜微利之。　　脚气多属肺气实。经云：肺病者，汗出，尻阴股膝髀腨胻足皆病。故戴人治脚气用涌法者，良由此也。又《千金方》多汗之者，亦泻肺之法也。　　风有一百二十四种，气有八十种，惟脚气头风上气，当须药不绝，余则随其发动，临时消息。但有风气之人，春末夏初，及秋暮得通泄，则不困剧。所谓通泄者，如麻黄、牵牛、(木郁)李仁之类，不必苦寒利药也。　　按东垣论南方脚气，外感清湿，作寒治；北方脚气，内伤酒醴，作湿热治。此实发前人之未发者。以余论之，不必以南北分寒热。凡外感寒湿者，皆为寒湿，不必南方为然。凡内伤酒醴者，皆属湿热，不必北方为然。但随脉证及询其病之由来而施治可也。[95p]

When the five organs have pathogens, they linger in the joints. The texts state: if the lungs or the heart have pathogens, their energy resides in the elbows; if the liver has pathogens, its energy is in the thighs; if the spleen has pathogens, its energy stays in the hips; and if the kidneys have pathogens, their energy is in the knees.

Regarding leg swelling:

When there is swelling in the legs, accompanied by urinary obstruction, a feeling of fullness and discomfort in the chest, and digestive issues, it is advisable to use mild diuretics. Leg swelling often relates to excess lung Qi. The texts say that when someone has lung disease, there will be sweating, along with issues in the lower back, thighs, knees, and feet. Hence, the method of expulsion used by practitioners to treat leg swelling is based on this principle. Additionally, in the "Thousand Gold Prescriptions," those with excessive sweating should also adopt methods to drain the lungs.

There are 124 types of wind and 80 types of Qi, but when it comes to leg swelling, one must ensure medication is consistently used, while other treatments may vary according to the condition. Those who have wind Qi should expel it through proper channels in late spring, early summer, and late autumn to avoid severe complications. The term "expelling" refers to herbs like Ephedra, Qian Niu Zi, and loquat seeds; bitter cold diuretics are not necessarily required.

East Yuan's discussion on southern leg swelling indicates that it's caused by external invasion of dampness and should be treated with cold remedies, whereas northern leg swelling, stemming from internal injuries caused by alcoholic beverages, should be treated for damp-heat. This is something that previous authors have not fully expounded upon. In my view, it isn't necessary to differentiate between north and south for cold and heat. Any external invasion of cold and dampness should be regarded as cold-damp, regardless of geography. Similarly, any internal injury from alcoholic beverages is related to damp-heat, regardless of the region. Treatment should rely on pulse diagnosis and inquiry about the patient's condition.[95p]

　　《外台》、《总录》所录，皆谓南方卑湿雾露所聚之地，其民腠理疏，阳气不能外固，因而履之，则清湿袭虚，病起于下，此因血虚气弱，受清湿之邪气，与血并行于肤腠，邪气盛，正气少，故血气濇，濇则痹，虚则弱，故令痹弱也，后人名曰脚气。《针经》云：有道以来，有道以去，治之多以灸焫为佳，以导引湿气外出，及饮醪醴以通经散邪，所制之方，寒药少热药多，多用麻黄、川乌、姜、附之属。《内经》云：湿淫于外，以苦发之。麻黄苦温，发之者也。川乌辛热，走而不能守，通行经络。姜、附辛甘大热，助阳退阴，亦能散清湿之邪。又察足之三阴三阳，是何经络所起，以引用药为主治。复察六气中何气当之，治以佐使之药。孙真人云：医者意也。随时增损，初无定方。真知言哉。[96p]

The texts from "Wai Tai" and "Zong Lu" state that the southern regions, characterized by their low, damp, misty, and dewy environments, lead to the people's skin being thin and weak, resulting in the inability of the Yang energy to be firmly expressed. Consequently, when they tread on the ground, the dampness envelops their emptiness and illness arises from below. This is due to a deficiency of blood and weak Qi, as they suffer from the evil influence of the dampness, which interacts with the blood at the skin level. When the evil is strong and the righteous Qi is insufficient, blood and Qi become stagnant; stagnation causes blockage, and weakness leads to further deterioration, thus giving rise to what later generations termed "barley disease" (or beriberi).

The "Needling Classics" states: since ancient times, there has been a method to eliminate these conditions, predominantly treating such ailments with moxibustion to drive out the dampness. In addition, consuming fermented beverages helps to regulate the channels and disperse the evil influences. Recipes were primarily constructed with more warming herbs than cold ones, using ingredients like ephedra, processed aconite, ginger, and prepared aconitum. The "Inner Canon" asserts that excess dampness from the exterior should be expelled with bitter herbs. Ephedra, being bitter and warm, serves this purpose. Processed aconite is pungent and hot, aiding in mobility but lacking the ability to retain, thus facilitating the flow through the meridians. Ginger and prepared aconitum are pungent, sweet, and intensely warming, supportive of Yang energy while expelling the Yin, effectively dispelling the bad Qi of dampness.

Furthermore, one should examine the three Yin and three Yang points in the feet to ascertain which meridians are involved, focusing on the medicinal treatments accordingly. It is essential to consider which of the six energies is relevant, and treat accordingly with supportive and guiding herbs. Master Sun said: "The intent of the physician is key." Adjustments should be made according to circumstances, as there are no fixed prescriptions. Truly wise words indeed.[96p]

　　　　　臂痛

　　按东垣云：臂痛有六道经络，以行本经药行其气血者。盖以两手伸直，其臂贴身垂下，大指居前，小指居后而定之，则其臂臑之前廉痛者属阳明经，以升麻、白芷、干葛行之；后廉痛者属太阳经，以槁本、羌活行之；外廉痛者属少阳，以柴胡行之；内廉痛者，属厥阴，以柴胡、青皮行之；内前廉痛者属太阴，以升麻、白芷、葱白行之；内后廉痛者属少阴，以细辛、独活行之。并用针灸法，视其何经而取之也。[97p]

Arm Pain

According to Dong Yuan, arm pain has six pathways of meridians. By utilizing the corresponding medicinal herbs that promote the flow of qi and blood in those meridians, the following applies: When both arms are extended straight, hanging down vertically against the body, with the thumbs positioned forward and the little fingers back, if pain is felt in the front part of the arm, it pertains to the Yangming meridian, treated with Sheng Ma, Bai Zhi, and Gan Ge. If the pain is in the back part, it pertains to the Taiyang meridian, treated with Gao Ben and Qiang Huo. If the pain is on the outer side, it pertains to the Shaoyang meridian, treated with Chai Hu. If the pain is on the inner side, it pertains to the Jueyin meridian, treated with Chai Hu and Qing Pi. If the pain is in the inner front, it refers to the Taiyin meridian, treated with Sheng Ma, Bai Zhi, and scallions. If the pain is in the inner back, it pertains to the Shaoyin meridian, treated with Xi Xin and Du Huo. Acupuncture methods should also be applied, depending on the respective meridian affected.[97p]

　　　　医学入门 【明　李梴】

　　　　　脚气总论

　　脚曰气者，风寒暑湿四气蒸于足，循经入脏之深，而发则以渐，非若四气中人，虽浅而骤也。外证全类伤寒，且有六经传变，一如太阳头疼身热云云，直至厥阴烦满囊缩，又有合并二病。但初起脚膝软弱，顽痹转筋，赤肿为异耳。如太阳证见，外踝循京骨至小指外侧皆痛者，随四气偏胜发散，麻黄汤加防风、羌活、细辛、葛根、白朮、茯苓、防己，或败毒散合槟苏散。阳明证见，髀膝外廉下入中指内痛者，随四气偏胜微利，大柴胡汤加羌活、细辛、杏仁，或升麻葛根汤合槟苏散。少阳证见，诸足指节痛者，宜和解小柴胡汤去参加防风、葛根、细辛、白朮、茯苓、麦门冬、干姜，小草。三阳合病，拘挛便闭者，合前三方加减而服，名左经汤。或专入足太阴经，证见脚膝内廉、足大指端内侧痛或浮肿者，古桂附汤加防己、白朮、茯苓。[98p]

Introduction to Medicine
[Ming Dynasty - Li Zhan]

General Discussion on Beriberi

The term "beriberi" refers to the phenomenon when the four environmental factors of wind, cold, heat, and dampness affect the feet, penetrating deeply through the meridians into the internal organs. The onset is gradual, unlike the four environmental factors confronting a person where the symptoms can be sudden and superficial. The external symptoms resemble those of a cold, with the possibility of transformation through the six meridians, such as a headache and fever resembling the Taiyang syndrome, progressing to the Jueyin syndrome of agitation and contraction, potentially leading to concurrent diseases.

Initially, there may be weakness in the feet and knees, with persistent stiffness and cramps, accompanied by redness and swelling as distinguishing features. In cases of Taiyang syndrome where pain radiates from the outer ankle along the meridians to the outer side of the little toe, one should follow the prevalent environmental factors for dispersal, using a formula such as Ma Huang Decoction, adding Feng Feng, Qiang Huo, Xi Xin, Ge Gen, Bai Zhu, and Fu Ling, or Bai Du San combined with Ping Su San.

For Yangming syndrome presenting with pain from the outer thigh and knee descending to the inner side of the middle toe, the treatment involves addressing the predominance of environmental factors, using Da Chai Hu Decoction with added Qiang Huo, Xi Xin, and Xing Ren, or Sheng Ma Ge Gen Decoction combined with Ping Su San.

For Shaoyang syndrome showing pain in the joints of the toes, one should harmonize using Xiao Chai Hu Decoction, omitting Feng Feng, Ge Gen, Xi Xin, Bai Zhu, Fu Ling, Mai Men Dong, Gan Jiang, and include Xiao Cao.

For cases where three Yang syndromes manifest together in cramps and constipation, adjustments can be made to the previous formulas, named Zuo Jing Decoction. Alternatively, for those specifically affecting the foot Taiyin meridian, if pain or swelling is observed on the inner side of the foot's big toe or inner knee, one should use Guo Gui Fu Decoction with added Fang Ji, Bai Zhu, and Fu Ling.[98p]

少阴经证见，足小指下连足心腘外廉股内痛，冲胸不食，面黑溺濇，小腹不仁者难治，八味丸救之。厥阴经证见，足大指连内廉脐腹胀痛，脚挛干呕者，养真丹。如足三阴挛痹缓弱，上攻胸胁肩背，下注脚膝，足心热者，换脚丸。要之风多入肝，病筋走注，脉浮无汗，小续命汤加独活。风毒肿痛，排风汤、槟榔散。筋急掣痛，乳香定痛散。湿多入脾，病肉重着，行起忽倒，或肿，除湿汤。痰多者，用此汤吞青州白丸子。[99p]

When symptoms of the Shao Yin channel appear, there is pain beneath the little toe extending to the arch of the foot, with external pain in the popliteal fossa and the inner thigh, accompanied by chest congestion and inability to eat, a dark face, and difficult urination. If the lower abdomen is numb, treatment is difficult; use the Eight Flavor Pill to save. When symptoms of the Jue Yin channel appear, there is pain in the abdomen with the large toe linked to the inner edge and the navel, with cramps in the feet and dry vomiting; use the Nourishing Essence Pill. If all three Yin channels show cramping and weakness, with heat rising to the chest, sides, shoulders, and back, and descending to the feet and knees, with heat in the soles, use the Foot Exchange Pill. The essence is that excessive wind enters the liver, causing tendons to be oppressed; the pulse is floating with no sweat; use the Sustained Life Decoction with added Du Huo. For wind-damp swelling and pain, use the Wind Expelling Decoction or Betel Nut Powder. For painful, stiff tendons, use the Frankincense Pain-Soothing Powder. If damp is abundant in the Spleen, causing heaviness in the flesh, resulting in sudden falls or swelling, employ the Damp-Removing Decoction. For excessive phlegm, use this decoction to swallow the white pill from Qingzhou.[99p]

暑多入心，病气喘闷烦躁，所患必热，败毒散加大黄。寒多入肾，病骨挛急掣痛，所患必冷，五积散、越婢加木瓜、通用千金续命汤、流气饮子、乌药顺气散。烦躁者，单竹沥饮。大便闭者，三和散、脾约丸。毒气冲心作痛者，苏子降气汤下养正丹，或吴茱萸煎汤入姜汁速救之，不然，死在旦夕。寻常春夏槟苏散加川楝子，热肿赤者败毒散加木瓜、苍朮，秋冬五积散加木瓜、槟榔、牛膝、吴萸。最忌补汤淋洗，草药摊盦。其证有因于气，因于饮食及丹石者，不可不知。
　　　　　分干湿证

　　脚气，《内经》名厥，两汉名缓风。初病不觉，因他病始发，或奄然大闷。其证寒热全类伤寒，但初起则卒然脚痛，发则旬月又作为异。湿者筋脉弛长而软或浮肿，或生臁疮之类，谓之湿脚气，宜利湿疏风。　　干即热也。干者筋脉蜷缩挛痛，枯细不肿，谓之干脚气，宜润血清燥。[100p]

Excess heat enters the heart, causing symptoms of breathlessness, irritability, and discomfort; the ailment must be heat-related, treated with Baidu San plus Dahuang. Excess cold enters the kidney, leading to acute pain and spasms in the bones; the ailment must be cold-related, treated with Wujisan, adding Mu Guo or combining with Qianjin Xueming Tang, Liuqi Yinzi, and Wuyao Shunqi San. For irritability, use Dan Zhuli drink. For constipation, use Sanhe San or Piyue Wan. If toxic Qi rushes to the heart causing pain, administer Suzi Jiangqi Tang with Yangzheng Dan, or use Wuzhuyu decoction mixed with ginger juice for quick relief; otherwise, death may occur unexpectedly. Commonly in spring and summer, use Binsu San with Chuanlianzizi; for heat-related swelling and redness, use Baidu San with Mu Guo and Cangzhu. In autumn and winter, use Wujisan with Mu Guo, Binglang, Niuxi, and Wuyuyu. It is most important to avoid nourishing soups and herbal poultices. Symptoms arising from Qi, diet, or minerals should not be overlooked.

Differentiation between dry and damp conditions:

For "Jiaqi" (foot disease), noted in the "Inner Canon" as "Jue," and called "Huanfeng" in the Han dynasties. Initially, the disease goes unnoticed, possibly triggered by another illness, leading to sudden heaviness and discomfort. Symptoms resemble cold and heat types of typhoid, but at first, there is sudden foot pain, which may transform over weeks into something different. In cases of dampness, the tendons and vessels become relaxed, elongated, and soft, possibly causing swelling or sores, referred to as "damp foot disease," which should be treated with methods to drain dampness and dispel wind. Dryness indicates heat. In dry conditions, tendons and vessels contract sharply, lacking swelling, referred to as "dry foot disease," and should be treated by nourishing blood and clearing dryness.[100p]

　　　　　辨内外因

　　内因好食乳酪醇酒，湿热下流肝肾，加之房劳，故宙贵之人，亦有脚疾。外因久坐久立湿地，或贫虫涉山溪瘴毒，夏月则感湿热之气，发则四肢多热，冬月则感湿冷之气，发则四肢多冷，加以当风取凉，汗出洗足，醉后入房，故成此疾。外感止于下胫肿痛，内伤或至手节周身，初起察其起处，隔蒜灸之，最妙。　　湿胜则肿，除湿汤加槟榔、防己。胫肿者，红花苍蘗丸，肥人加痰药。赤裂肿痛甚者，用甘遂为末，水调敷肿处，另用甘草煎汤服之立消，或败毒散加苍朮、大黄，搜风顺气丸。　　湿兼寒则痛，五积散、不换金正气散、附子六物汤、胜骏丸。　　湿兼风则走注不常，乌药顺气散、地仙丹；甚者用赤芍、草乌等分，酒糊丸服以劫之；挟瘀血者，复元通圣散合消风散。　　湿兼热则肿痛异常，加味苍蘗散、二炒苍蘗散、清燥汤。　　食积湿痰下注者，槟榔苍蘗丸。[101p]

Distinguishing Internal and External Causes

The internal cause is a fondness for rich food, dairy, and fine wine, creating damp heat that flows downward to the liver and kidneys. Coupled with excessive sexual activity, even the wealthy may suffer from foot ailments. The external cause arises from prolonged sitting or standing in moist environments, exposure to pests in mountainous streams, or the damp heat of summer affecting the limbs. In winter, the exposure to damp cold can lead to chilling effects. Additionally, cooling oneself in the wind, sweating, and entering a bedroom after drinking may contribute to these conditions. External issues result in swelling and pain in the lower legs, while internal damage may reach the joints and occasionally affect the whole body. At first, observe the source of the issue, and use garlic moxibustion at that point, which is quite effective.

When dampness is predominant, swelling occurs; use a diuretic soup with areca nut and lignum isatis. For swollen legs, utilize a red flower and root pill, and for overweight individuals, add phlegm-relieving herbs. If there is severe redness, swelling, and pain, grind euphorbia into a powder, mix with water to apply at the swollen area, and additionally take licorice decoction for immediate relief, or use a decoction for blood detoxification with rhizoma atractylodis and rhubarb, and phytotherapy for wind to smooth the qi.

When dampness is combined with cold, pain can occur; use Wu Ji San, Bu Huan Jin Zheng Qi San, Fu Zi Liu Wu Tang, or Sheng Jun Wan.

When dampness is combined with wind, there can be irregular pains; utilize Wu Yao Shun Qi San or Di Xian Dan; for more severe cases, use a mixture of red peony and chinaberry in equal parts, make into pills with wine for expulsion; if blood stasis is present, use Fu Yuan Tong Sheng San combined with Xiao Feng San.

When dampness is combined with heat, swelling and pain are severe; use modified Cang Zhu San, Er Chao Cang Zhu San, or Qing Zao Tang.

For food accumulation with damp phlegm descending, use areca nut and Cang Zhu pills.[101p]

　　软痹者，乃膏粱火乘肝肾，以致血气濇则痹厥不仁，虚则软缓无力，或麻木不举，三妙丸、搜风顺气丸。然肾主骨，虚则骨软。阳虚，附虎四斤丸，阴虚，虎潜丸、肾气丸。脚软筋痛者，大补阴丸去地黄加白芍、知母、甘草、倍牛膝。肝主筋，虚则脚膝顽麻，养真丹。肝肾脾俱虚者，五兽三匮丹。　　凡湿气在下，随气血痰药中，加防风、苍朮，升提其湿，冲心则恍惚，呕吐不食，脉乍大乍小者死，宜木香流气饮，或苏子降气汤吞养正丹。有火者，四物汤加黄蘗以降之，再用附子末津调涂涌泉穴，引势下行。入腹不仁，喘急欲死者，朮萸散。腹胀烦躁者，松节汤。入肺喘咳，小青龙汤加槟榔。入肝，头目昏眩，喘满逼促，乌药平气散。[102p]

Soft paralysis is caused by the dampness and heat affecting the liver and kidneys, leading to thick blood and qi, resulting in numbness and loss of sensation. If weakness is present, the limbs may become soft and slack, or develop numbness and inability to move. Treatments include San Miao Pills and Sou Feng Shun Qi Pills. The kidneys govern the bones; if deficient, the bones become soft. For yang deficiency, use Fu Hu Si Jin Wan; for yin deficiency, use Hu Qian Wan or Shen Qi Wan. For weakness and pain in the legs, use Da Bu Yin Wan, removing Rehmannia and adding White Peony, Anemarrhena, Licorice, and doubling the use of Eucommia. The liver governs the tendons; if deficient, the legs and knees may feel stubbornly numb. Use Yang Zhen Dan. For simultaneous deficiency of the liver, kidney, and spleen, use Wu Shou San Kui Dan.

When dampness is present in the lower body, add Fang Feng and Cang Zhu to remedies for qi, blood, and phlegm to lift the dampness. If the heart is affected, leading to disorientation and vomiting without appetite, and the pulse fluctuates between large and small, this indicates a severe condition; use Mu Xiang Liu Qi Yin or Su Zi Jiang Qi Tang with Zheng Yang Dan. If fire is present, use Si Wu Decoction with Huang Bo to reduce it, then apply powdered Fu Zi topically to the Yongquan point to guide the force downward.

For insensitivity and urgent breathlessness, use Zhu Yu San. For abdominal distension and agitation, use Song Jie Tang. If it affects the lungs leading to cough and wheezing, use Xiao Qing Long Tang with Areca. For liver involvement, causing dizziness and forcing sensation, use Wu Yao Ping Qi San.[102p]

入肾，腰脚肿胀，小便不利，目额皆黑，左尺绝者死，牛膝散加大黄救之。如少阴肾气入心，乃水克火也，急宜八味丸救之。有脚气寒热，足肿心烦，体痛垂死者，杉节汤。不食，加砂仁、青皮、木瓜，外用桃、柳、桑、槐、楮五枝煎汤洗之，消肿住痛，先吃酒三五杯。最忌热药蒸泡，恐逼邪入经络，故治脚以疏通气道为佳。　　湿热流注三阴经络，火郁成毒肿，上干三阳，寒热呕恶，身痛且重者，左经汤主之，或香苏散加木瓜、槟榔。七情再加五加皮、木香。痛加赤芍、忍冬藤。妇人加当归。　　三阴里证，胸满怔忡，遍体转筋，二便秘濇或自利者，羌活导滞汤、除湿丹、导水丸、搜风顺气丸。挟痰者，三花神佑丸。挟食积者，开结导饮丸。里虚者，独活寄生汤、换腿丸。表里兼见者，左经汤加大黄。[103p]

When the kidney is affected, causing swelling in the lower back and feet, difficulty in urination, darkening around the eyes and forehead, and the left wrist pulse is gone, one is doomed. Use Niu Xi Powder with Da Huang to save. If the kidney qi invades the heart, it is water overcoming fire; one must urgently use Ba Wei Wan to save. For symptoms of foot disease with chills and fever, swelling of the feet, heart disturbance, body pain, and imminent death, use Shen Jie Decoction. If there is no appetite, add Sha Ren, Qing Pi, and Mu Guo; externally, use an infusion of peach, willow, mulberry, locust, and catalpa branches to wash, reducing swelling and alleviating pain, preceded by consuming three to five cups of alcohol. It is especially important to avoid hot herbs and steams, for fear of forcing the pathogenic factors into the meridians; thus, treating the feet by opening the qi pathways is best.

With damp-heat invading the three yin meridians, and fire forming poisonous swellings, affecting the three yang, with chills and fever, vomiting, nausea, overall body pain, and heaviness, use Zuo Jing Decoction; alternatively, Xiang Su Powder with Mu Guo and Bing Lang. For emotional distress, add Wu Jia Pi and Mu Xiang. For pain, add Chi Shao and Ren Dong Teng. For women, add Dang Gui.

In cases of three yin interior syndromes, with fullness in the chest, palpitations, entire body cramping, and either constipation or diarrhea, use Qiang Huo Dao Zhi Decoction, Zhu Shi Dan, Dao Shui Wan, or Sou Feng Shun Qi Wan. If there is phlegm, use San Hua Shen You Wan. For food accumulation, use Kai Jie Dao Yin Wan. For interior deficiency, use Du Huo Ji Sheng Decoction or Huan Tui Wan. If both exterior and interior symptoms are present, use Zuo Jing Decoction with Da Huang.[103p]

　　　　　脚跟痛

　　脚跟痛有血热者，四物汤加知母、黄蘗、牛膝。有痰者，五积散加木瓜，或开结导饮丸。
　　　　　脚转筋

　　脚转筋，有血热者，四物汤加酒芩、红花；感湿者，除湿汤。常用松节二两，乳香一钱，慢火焙，存性为末，每一钱，木瓜煎酒调服。[104p]

Heel Pain

For heel pain caused by excessive heat in the blood, use Siwu Decoction with additions of Zhimu, Huangbai, and Niuxi. If phlegm is present, use Wujisan with added Mu gua, or take Kaijiedao Yin Wan.

Cramps in the Feet

For cramps in the feet, if due to heat in the blood, use Siwu Decoction with additional Jiuqin and Honghua; if caused by dampness, use Chushi Decoction. Commonly used are two liang of pine resin and one qian of frankincense, baked slowly over low heat until fragrant, then ground into powder. For each qian, decoct Mu gua in wine and take it as a remedy.[104p]

　　　　　手足自汗

　　伤寒，津液自胃腑旁达于外，则手足自汗。有热袭胃腑逼而出之者，必有讝语燥粪，阳明证也。大便已鞕者，大柴胡汤，或大承气汤；大便不鞕而软者，小柴胡汤。凡伤寒欲下，而小便少，手足心并腋下不滋润者，不可攻也。有寒聚胃腑，大便初鞕后溏，或水谷不分，手足濈然汗出者，不可下，少与理中汤或猪苓汤。如寒甚不食，小便不利者，此欲作痼瘕也，宜理中兼散气之药治之。
　　　　　四肢挛搐

　　四肢诸阳之本，腰背太阳之络，因发汗腠理空疏，盖复不周，将息未久，以致风邪复入筋骨之间，孪搐有妨行持，牛蒡根汤主之。如脚挛齿啮者，风热也，承气汤下之。　　拘急者，手足不能自如，屈伸不便，蜷卧恶风之状，发汗亡阳而有此证。汗多小便难者，桂枝汤加附子。吐下后，厥逆拘急者，四逆汤。心烦足挛，属血虚者，芍药甘草汤。阴阳易病，手足搐搦如风状者，古瓜竹汤。
　　　　　甲疽[105p]

Sweating of Hands and Feet

In cases of typhoid fever, when the body fluids from the stomach channel reach the exterior, sweating will occur in the hands and feet. If heat attacks the stomach channel causing fluid to be forced out, there will be accompanying symptoms such as dry feces and signs associated with the Yangming channel. If the stool is initially hard, the treatment should be Da Chaihu Decoction or Da Chengqi Decoction; if the stool is not hard but soft, Xiao Chaihu Decoction should be used. In all instances of typhoid fever where one wishes to purge, if urination is scant, and the palms, feet, and armpits are not moisturized, one must avoid purgation. If there is a cold accumulation in the stomach channel with initial hard stool followed by diarrhea, or if food and drink are not being properly digested, and sweating occurs, one should not purge but rather administer a small dose of Lizhong Decoction or Zhu Ling Decoction. If there is severe cold, a lack of appetite, and difficulty urinating, this may indicate the onset of a chronic condition, and treatment should include Lizhong Decoction along with medicine to disperse Qi.

Twitching of the Limbs

The limbs are the foundational Yang; the waist and back are the conduits of the Taiyang. Due to sweating causing the pores to become loose, if rest is insufficient, wind pathogens may re-enter the muscles and bones, leading to contraction and difficulty in movement. For this, Niubang Root Decoction is indicated. If there is twitching and grinding of the teeth, this indicates wind-heat, warranting the use of Chengqi Decoction. In cases where limbs are rigid and unable to move freely, with difficulty in bending and stretching, and the posture resembles curling up to avoid wind, this is due to excessive sweating and loss of Yang. If sweating is profuse and urination is difficult, Gui Zhi Decoction with added Fu Zi should be used. After vomiting and purging, if there is reversed cold and rigidity, Si Ni Decoction is indicated. If there is heart vexation accompanied by limb spasms due to blood deficiency, Shaoyao Gancao Decoction should be applied. For conditions where both Yin and Yang are compromised, and there are spasms in the hands and feet resembling wind symptoms, Guazhu Decoction is appropriate.[105p]

　　甲疽乃毒气攻于手足指，努肉裹上指甲，疼痛出血，疮中有虫，或因剔甲伤肌，或因甲长侵肌，遂成肿痛，俱用绿矾五两，置铁板上，以炭火封之，吹令火炽，其矾即熔，流出赤汁，直俟汁尽，去火待冷，取为末，色似黄丹收之。先以盐汤洗拭，后用绿矾为君，入乳香少许敷之。重者，用绿矾五钱，芦荟一钱半，麝香一字为未，以绢袋盛药，纳所患指于袋中，线扎定，以瘥为度。
　　　　　代指

　　代指，指头先肿，焮热掣痛，然后于爪甲边结脓，甚者爪甲俱脱，先用芒硝煎汤淋洗，然后用乌梅核中仁为末，米酢调成膏，入指渍之自愈。或用猪脂和蚯蚓捣烂敷之。
　　　　　天蛇头

　　天蛇头疮，生手指上或足，疮旁一块，开口肿痛，用鸡母杨根，好酢浸一宿即消；或以雄黄入鸡子内，以患指浸其中一宿，次早更以蜈蚣烧烟熏病指一二次，即消。如痛甚流血不止者，用雄黄、蜈蚣、全蝎为末，搽在疮上，却以少油抹帛上扎之。[106p]

Jiaju refers to a condition where toxic gas attacks the fingers and toes, causing the flesh to swell around the nails, leading to pain and bleeding, with worms in the sores. This can be due to injuring the skin when removing nails or the nails growing into the flesh, resulting in swelling and pain. For treatment, use five taels of green vitriol, place it on an iron plate, cover it with charcoal fire, and blow to make the fire hot, allowing the vitriol to melt and release red juice. Wait until the juice is gone, remove from the fire, let it cool, and grind it into powder that resembles yellow earth. First, wash with salted water, then apply the green vitriol as the main ingredient, mixed with a small amount of frankincense as a paste. For more severe cases, use five qian of green vitriol, one and a half qian of aloe, and a small amount of musk to make a powder. Place the affected finger in a silk bag containing the medicine, tie it securely, and keep it until healed.

Dai Zhi refers to an initial swelling of the fingertip, accompanied by heat and intense pain, which then results in pus forming at the edge of the nail. In severe cases, the entire nail may fall off. Begin treatment by using a solution of Glauber's salt to wash the area, then prepare a paste using the kernel of a black plum mixed with rice vinegar, soaking the finger to heal itself. Alternatively, one can use pig fat mixed with crushed earthworms for application.

Tian She Tou refers to sores that develop on the fingers or toes. If there is swelling and pain near the sore, soak the roots of a chicken mother poplar in vinegar overnight for relief. Alternatively, place realgar inside a chicken egg and soak the affected finger in it overnight. The next morning, burn a centipede and use the smoke to fumigate the injured finger one or two times to achieve healing. If there is severe pain and continuous bleeding, prepare a powder from realgar, centipede, and scorpion, applying it directly on the sore, then cover it with a cloth smeared with a bit of oil.[106p]

　　　　　鹤膝风

　　鹤膝风，乃足三阴亏损，风邪乘之，以致内热，减食肌瘦，肢体挛痛，久则膝愈大而腿愈细，有如鹤之膝。然初起宜用葱熨法，以内消之。寒热者，五积交加散加乌药、僵蚕。已溃者，独活寄生汤、大防风汤。　　阳虚热来复去者，无根虚火也，十全大补汤、大防风汤。脐腹疼痛，溺频头运吐痰者，八味丸。发热大渴，面赤脉大，血虚甚也，古归芪汤。　　阴虚形瘦发热者，肾气丸；挟湿热者，苍　丸、二炒苍蘗散。食少面黄者，六君子汤。津干中气不足者，补中益气汤加五味子。脓清肌肉不生者，八物汤。　　妇人月经不调，发热口渴，两膝肿痛者，肾气丸、苍　丸、逍遥散加牛膝、杜仲，黄蘗。[107p]

Crane Knee Wind

Crane knee wind is caused by the deficiency of the three yin in the legs, allowing wind pathogens to invade, resulting in internal heat, reduced appetite, weight loss, and painful limbs. Over time, the knees may become swollen while the legs appear thinner, resembling the knee of a crane. Initially, it is advisable to use scallion poultices for internal resolution. If there is a combination of cold and heat, one should use a formulation with Wu Yao and Jiang Can. If there is already ulceration, Du Huo Ji Sheng Decoction or Da Feng Feng Decoction should be utilized.

For those with yang deficiency where heat recurs, this is rootless虚火; use Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction or Da Feng Feng Decoction. If there is pain in the umbilical region, frequent urination, and phlegm with vomiting, apply Ba Wei Wan. If there is fever and significant thirst with a flushed face and a rapid pulse, it indicates severe blood deficiency, treat with Guo Gui Qi Decoction.

In cases of yin deficiency with emaciation and fever, administer Shen Qi Wan; if there is damp-heat present, use Cang Zhu Wan or Er Chao Cang Zhu San. For reduced appetite and a pale complexion, administer Liu Jun Zi Decoction. If there is insufficient fluid and qi in the body, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction with Wu Wei Zi added. If there is clear pus and inadequate muscle generation, apply Ba Wu Decoction.

For women with irregular menstruation, fever, thirst, and swollen painful knees, administer Shen Qi Wan, Cang Zhu Wan, and Xiao Yao San, adding Niu Xi, Du Zhong, and Huang Bai.[107p]

　　　　　臁疮

　　此疮生两臁上，初起臖肿作痛，寒热者，属外邪湿热，槟榔散、败毒散主之；毒盛发寒热者，活命饮。　　漫肿作痛，或不肿不痛，属三阴虚也，或发寒热，俱宜八物汤、十全大补汤。脾虚挟表邪者，补中益气汤加桔梗、白芷。脾虚湿热流脓，口干少食者，补中益气汤加茯苓、芍药。晡热加炒黑黄蘗、熟地。挟怒气，加山栀、川芎。有郁者，归脾汤加山栀、柴胡。若患处黑黯，肢体恶寒，饮食少思，属肝肾虚败，宜八味丸。内热口干者，肾气丸。久不愈者，大苦参丸。肾脏虚风，四生散、黄芪丸。　　外治法：因风热者，洗以葱汤，次用龙骨膏贴之。风热者，马齿膏。湿热者，窑土膏。因血气凝滞者，小驻车丸加乳香少许掺之。　　内臁疮初起，洗以盐汤，次以蜡矾纸贴之。重者桐油膏，痒甚者蕲艾膏。久不愈者，内外通用炉灰膏，点去瘀肉，后贴黄蜡膏。然内必量体服药，若误用攻伐伤胃者，亦能伤人。[108p]

Ulcer

This ulcer develops in the two areas above, initially manifesting as swelling and pain. In cases of cold and heat, it is attributed to external pathogens of damp heat, treated with Pinellia Powder or Detoxifying Powder; if the toxicity is severe with cold and heat, use Lifesaving Drink. If there is diffuse swelling and pain, or if there is no swelling or pain, this pertains to the deficiency of the three Yin; if there are occurrences of cold and heat, both Eight-Treasure Decoction and Ten-Full Great Supplement Decoction are advisable. If there is spleen deficiency combined with exterior pathogens, use the Qi-Boosting Decoction with added Platycodon and Angelica dahurica. For spleen deficiency with damp heat leading to pus, along with dry mouth and poor appetite, use the Qi-Boosting Decoction with added Poria and Peony. For evening heat, add stir-fried black Coptis and cooked Rehmannia. If anger is present, add Gardenia and Chuanxiong. If there is stagnation, use Spleen-Returning Decoction with added Gardenia and Bupleurum. If the affected area appears dark and cold with a weak appetite, this signifies liver and kidney deficiency; Eight-Ingredient Pill is appropriate. For internal heat and dry mouth, use Kidney Qi Pill. If it does not heal for a long time, use Bitter-Sweet Herb Pill. For kidney wind deficiency, use Four-Birth Powder or Astragalus Pill.

External Treatment Method:

For wind heat, wash with scallion soup and then apply dragon bone ointment. For wind heat, use Horsetail Ointment. For damp heat, use kiln soil ointment. If due to blood and qi stagnation, add a little frankincense to Xiao Zhu Che Wan.

At the initial stage of the internal ulcer, wash with salt water, then apply wax alum paper. For severe cases, use tung oil ointment; for intense itching, use Qianai Ointment. If it has not healed for a long time, utilize both internal and external use of ash ointment to eliminate necrotic tissue, followed by applying yellow wax ointment. However, internally, medication must be dosed appropriately; if mistakenly using aggressive treatments that harm the stomach, it can also cause injury.[108p]

　　　　　脚跟疮

　　脚跟，乃督脉发源，肾经过脉。内因饮食起居，亏损足三阴所致，或外被犬兔所咬而成。　　漫肿食少者，补中益气汤。晡热头昏者，逍遥散、肾气丸。咳嗽吐痰者，十全大补汤、八味丸。若不敛口，沥尽气血而死。
　　　　　脚肚疮

　　脚肚上生疮，初如粟渐大，抓搔不已，成片包脚相交，黄水流出，痒不可忍，久成痼疾难愈。先用贯众煎汤淋洗，后用百药煎为末，津唾调逐，旋涂敷，自外而入。
　　　　　褲口疮

　　褲口疮生于脚胫，或因物打扑而成。其疮口狭，皮内极阔，皮薄如竹膜，极痒痛，终日黄水流，延蔓而生，甚者数十年不愈，又易于染人。患者须忌房室则易愈。用韭菜地干地龙屎为未，入轻粉清油，或白犬血调敷。内外臁疮亦治。[109p]

Heel Ulcer

The heel is the source of the Governing Vessel and the pathway of the Kidney. Internally, it arises from eating habits and daily activities that weaken the Three Yin of the foot, or it can be caused by bites from dogs or rabbits. For symptoms of swelling and decreased appetite, use the Ba Zhen Tang. For heat in the evening and dizziness, use Xiao Yao San or Shen Qi Wan. For coughing and phlegm, use Shi Quan Da Bu Tang or Ba Wei Wan. If left untreated, it could drain energy and blood leading to death.

Calf Ulcer

An ulcer on the calf starts small like a grain and gradually enlarges; incessant scratching causes it to form patches that overlap, with yellow fluid flowing out and unbearable itching, eventually becoming a chronic illness difficult to heal. Start by washing with a decoction of Guanzhong, then apply a powder made from various herbs mixed with saliva, spreading it from the outside in.

Cuff Ulcer

Cuff ulcers occur on the shins, sometimes caused by impact from objects. The ulcer has a narrow opening but is wide beneath the skin, which is thin like bamboo film, causing extreme itching and pain, with yellow fluid streaming all day. They can persist for decades and are easily transmissible. Patients should abstain from sexual activity for easier recovery. A mixture of chives and earthworm dung can be used, combined with light powder and clear oil or blood from a white dog for application. Internal and external ulcers can also be treated.[109p]

　　　　　足发

　　湿热下注者，先用隔蒜灸及活命饮以解蕴毒，次服补中益气汤、肾气丸以补精气。三阴虚者，初起托里消毒散，或托里散加牛膝、槟榔、杜仲、或托里消毒散。溃后，大防风汤、十全大补汤、八味丸。阴虚足心热者，四物汤加知母、黄蘗。脾亏者，补中益气汤。若专治疮者死。
　　　　　嵌甲

　　嵌甲，因靴窄研损，爪甲陷入，四边臖肿，黄水流出，浸淫相染，五指湿烂，渐渐引上脚趺，泡浆四起，如汤泼火烧，日夜倍增，不能行动，以陈皮浓煎汤，浸良久，甲肉自相离开，轻手剪去肉中爪甲；外用蛇退一条烧灰，雄黄四钱为末，干掺。干者，香油调敷。与甲疽条参治。
　　　　　脚指丫疮

　　脚指丫疮，乃足指角急，为甲所入肉，便刺作疮湿烂，川枯矾三钱，黄丹五分为末，掺之。或鹅掌黄皮，烧灰掺之。[110p]

Foot Conditions

For conditions involving damp heat descending, first use garlic moxibustion and the Vitality Drink to resolve toxin accumulation, then administer the Middle-Supplementing Qi Decoction and Kidney Qi Pills to replenish essence and qi. In cases of three yin deficiency, initially apply the Detoxifying Powder to relieve toxins, or the Detoxifying Powder plus achyranthes, betel nut, eucommia, or the Detoxifying Powder itself. After ulceration, use the Great Wind-dispelling Decoction, the Ten Complete Replenishing Decoction, or the Eight Flavor Pills. If there is heat in the foot soles due to yin deficiency, use the Four Substance Decoction with added anemarrhena and phellodendron. For spleen deficiency, use the Middle-Supplementing Qi Decoction. If the treatment focuses specifically on ulcers, it can be fatal.

Ingrown Toenail

An ingrown toenail occurs when a narrow shoe causes pressure, leading to the nail embedding into the flesh, with swelling on all sides, yellow fluid discharge, and the skin becoming soft and rotten, gradually extending up the foot, leading to blisters rising like boiling water, increasing day and night, making movement impossible. Use a strong decoction of dried tangerine peel for soaking for a long time until the flesh and nail separate, then gently trim the ingrown nail part; externally apply a burnt snake skin powder mixed with four qian of realgar, and apply it dry. For those with dry nails, mix it with fragrant oil for topical application. Treat it alongside nail-related conditions.

Toe Nail Ulcer

Toe nail ulcers occur when the sharp nail pierces the flesh, causing painful ulcers to become moist and rotten. Use three qian of dried alum and five fen of yellow lead powder, ground to a fine powder, and mix it in. Alternatively, use burnt powdered hog plum.[110p]

　　　　　脚背发

　　脚背发，又名为脱疽疔，以其能溃脱也。亦有患于手背及手指者。原因膏粱房室，损伤脾肾。或先渴而后发，或先发而后渴。轻则色赤，作痛自溃，可治。先用隔蒜灸，内服活命饮或败毒散加金银花、白芷、大黄，痛止乃与托里散，或内托十宣散去桂加天花粉、金银花。挟气者，十六味流气饮。下虚者，十全大补汤、八味丸、大苦参丸。　　重者色黯不痛，先用隔蒜灸、桑枝灸，更服补药固内，则恶肉不致上侵，庶可保生。又有因修手足口咬等伤，或外涂生肌凉药，内服克伐，兼犯房室，患处不溃不痛，色黯上延，亦多致陨。重者，须用利刀，解去其筋，则筋骨出而毒得泄。又甚在指，则斩去其指，在肉，则割去其肉。外治用桐油及无名异，煎一沸，入花椒一勺，看疮大小，剪蓼叶在内同煎，浸一七后，单以此叶贴疮上，即安。[111p]

Footback Sores

Footback sores, also known as ulcerative sores, are named for their ability to rupture and discharge. They can also occur on the back of the hands and fingers. The cause is attributed to a diet of rich and heavy foods, which harms the spleen and kidneys. Symptoms may present as initial thirst before sores develop, or sores may appear first and then be followed by thirst. In mild cases, the sores appear red and painful, and can be treated. One should first use garlic moxibustion, and internally take revitalizing decoctions or detoxifying powders with added honeysuckle, angelica dahurica, and rhubarb. Once the pain subsides, one can use the Conclusion Powder, or take the internal Exuberance Powder with celestial flower powder and honeysuckle. For those with stagnant qi, the Sixteen Ingredient Flowing Qi Decoction is recommended. For those with deficiency below, the Complete Nourishment Decoction, Eight Ingredient Pill, or Large Bitter Orchid Pill may be used.

In more severe cases, the sores are dark in color and not painful. Initially apply garlic moxibustion and mulberry twig moxibustion, while taking tonic medicines to strengthen internally. This prevents the necrotic flesh from encroaching, increasing chances of survival. Additionally, injuries from biting or scratches might lead to sores which do not rupture or hurt, but extend in dark color. Such cases also pose a risk of severe complications. In critical situations, one must use a sharp knife to remove the affected tendons, allowing the poison to disperse. If the issue is located on a finger, the finger must be amputated; if on flesh, the affected flesh must be excised. For external treatment, use castor oil and unnamed herbs, boil together, then add a spoonful of Sichuan pepper. Depending on the size of the wound, slice perilla leaves and boil them together. After soaking, apply these leaves directly onto the wound to ensure comfort.[111p]

　　有踝上生一孔，约深半寸，至下半日异疼者，此湿毒注成漏也，用人中白炙出水，滴入疮口。古今图书集成医部全录卷一百九十一

　　　　　脚气

　　治之之法，用苍朮、白朮以治其湿；黄芩、黄蘗、知母以治其热；当归、芍药、生地黄以调其血；木瓜、槟榔以调其气；羌活、独活以利关节而散风湿。兼用木通、防己、牛膝引诸药下行，及消肿去湿，以为此证之大法矣。兼用针焫，导引其湿热之气外出也。东垣立当归拈痛汤冶之，其效捷于影响，学者更宜详究焉。[112p]

Leaking Ankle

There is a hole that forms above the ankle, approximately half an inch deep, accompanied by peculiar pain below for half a day; this is caused by damp heat leading to a leak. Use human-centered white (a type of remedy) to expel moisture and drip it into the wound.

Medical Insights of Past and Present 【Ming Dynasty – Gong Xin】

Beriberi

The method of treatment involves using Atractylodes and White Atractylodes to address dampness; Huangqin, Huangbo, and Zhimu for heat; Danggui, Shaoyao, and Shengdi for regulating blood; Mugua and Binglang for adjusting qi; Qiangan and Duhuo to promote joint mobility and disperse wind-damp. Also use Mutong, Fangji, and Niuxi to guide various medicines downward, and to reduce swelling and expel dampness, forming the primary treatment for this condition. Additionally, acupuncture can be applied to guide the damp-heat qi outward. Dongyuan’s formula "Danggui Nian Tong Tang" treats this condition effectively, and students should study it in detail.[112p]

　　　　　脉法

　　脚气之脉，其状有四：浮弦为风，宜汗；濡弱湿气，宜渗；迟濇因寒，宜温；洪数为热，宜下。　　微滑者虚，牢坚者实。结则因气，散则因忧，紧则因怒，细则因悲。
　　　　　臁疮

　　夫臁疮者，皆因肾脏虚寒，风邪毒气外攻三里之旁，灌于阴交之侧，风热毒气，流注两脚，生疮肿烂，疼痛臭秽，步履艰难。此疮生于臁骨为重，以其骨上肉少皮薄，故难愈。至有多年无已，疮口开阔，皮烂肉见，臭秽可畏。　　治法当先取虫，然后傅贴，仍宜内服蜡矾之类。须翘足端坐，勿多行履，庶可全愈矣。
　　　　医宗必读 【明　李中梓】[113p]

Pulse Diagnosis

The pulse of beriberi has four patterns: a floating and wiry pulse indicates wind, and sweating is appropriate; a moist and weak pulse indicates dampness, and draining is suitable; a slow and thick pulse due to cold indicates warming is needed; a surging and rapid pulse indicates heat, and purging is advisable. A slightly slippery pulse suggests deficiency, while a firm and solid pulse suggests excess. A pulse that is constricted indicates concern, scattered indicates worry, tight indicates anger, and thin indicates sorrow.

Ulcers

Ulcers arise due to kidney deficiency and cold, with wind and toxic qi attacking from outside, affecting the sides of the lower abdomen. Wind-heat and toxic qi flow to the feet, causing ulcers that ooze and rot, accompanied by pain and foul odor, making walking difficult. These ulcers located on the hip bones are severe, as there is little flesh and thin skin over the bones, making healing difficult. Some may persist for many years with wide-open sores, rotten skin exposing flesh, producing an odorous and repulsive condition. The treatment should focus first on removing worms, followed by topical application; internal medications like wax and alum are also advisable. It is essential to sit with legs elevated and to avoid excessive walking, which may facilitate complete healing.[113p]

　　　　　脚气类伤寒

　　脚气乃足受寒湿，头痛身热，肢节痛，便闭，呕逆，但脚痛或肿满，或枯细，与伤寒异耳。　　许仁则曰：此病有数种，有饮气下流以成脚气，饮气即水气之渐；亦有肾气先虚，暑月承热，以冷水洗脚，湿气不散，亦成脚气；亦有肾气既虚，诸事不节，有因居卑湿，湿气上冲，亦成脚气。此诸脚气，皆饮人脚胫大，脚趺肿，重闷，甚则上冲心腹，满闷短气。中间有干湿二脚气，湿者脚肿，干者脚不肿，渐觉枯燥，皮肤甲错，须细察之。若先觉胁肋心腹刺痛，胸背满闷，吃食之后，此状弥加，时时气短，手脚沉重，骨髓疼，多喘气，每食诸粘腻陈败臭物，即诸状转剧，此即饮气下流而成脚气，有此候者，自宜依疗饮。将成水气，细辛等八味汤、葶苈子等十五味丸疗之。若先无前状，但觉脚肿疼闷沉重，有缓弱，乍冲心腹满闷，小腹下不仁，有时急痛，宜依吴茱萸等五味汤、桑根白皮等六味丸、侧子等十味酒，细细服之。[114p]

Foot Qi Cold Type

Foot Qi occurs when the feet are affected by cold and dampness, leading to headache, body heat, joint pain, constipation, and nausea. However, the pain may be localized to the feet, which can be swollen or shriveled, distinguishing it from typhoid. Xu Renze states: There are several types of this illness. One results from drinking cold water, which causes foot Qi, derived from the gradual accumulation of water vapor; another occurs when kidney energy is initially weak, and during the hot months, if cold water is used to wash the feet, the dampness does not disperse, resulting in foot Qi. Additionally, if kidney energy is already weak, imbalances due to a damp environment can lead to upward surging dampness, contributing to foot Qi. All these conditions can cause swollen ankles, heavy discomfort, and in severe cases, may even lead to discomfort in the heart and abdomen, making breathing short. There are also dry and wet types of foot Qi; the wet type has swollen feet, while the dry type shows no swelling but gradually feels dry, with skin issues that require careful observation. If one first feels stabbing pain in the chest or sides, along with fullness and discomfort in the chest and back, worsened after eating, accompanied by shortness of breath and heaviness in the limbs, with bone marrow pain and increased difficulty in breathing, especially after consuming greasy or spoiled foods, these are symptoms of foot Qi due to downward flowing dampness. If these symptoms are present, one should follow the appropriate treatment. If there is a progression of water vapor, remedies like Xixin decoction with eight herbs and Tianmizi pills can be used. If there are no prior symptoms but there is a sensation of swollen, aching, heavy, and dull feet, sometimes accompanied by acute pain or numbness in the lower abdomen, one should adhere to prescriptions like Wuzhuyu decoction with five ingredients and Sanggenbaipei pills with six ingredients, along with Zhezi liquor containing ten ingredients, to take carefully.[114p]

　　　　伤寒六书 【明　陶华】

　　　　　手足寒热辨[115p]

In "On Cold Damage," by Tao Hua from the Ming dynasty, the section titled "Differentiating Cold and Heat in the Extremities" discusses how to discern between cold and heat conditions in the limbs.[115p]

　　或曰：人之手足，乃胃土之末。凡脾胃有热，手足必热，脾胃有寒，手足必寒，理之常也。惟伤寒乃有厥深热亦深，厥微热亦微之论，何邪？曰：胃寒则手足冷，胃热则手足热，此病之常也。若夫极则变，不可以常道拘也。盖亢则害，承乃制。火气亢极，反兼水化，故有此象耳。阴阳反复，病之逆从，未可以常理论也。凡经言厥逆、厥冷、厥寒、手足寒冷等语，皆变文耳，不可以论轻重。若言四肢则有异也，亦未可纯为寒证。若厥冷直至臂胫以上，则为真寒无疑矣，急用姜附等药温之，少缓则难疗矣。谓其寒上过乎肘，下过乎膝，非内有真寒，达于四肢而何？然更当与脉并所兼之证参之，庶乎其无误也。凡看伤寒，不可以厥逆便断为寒，必须以脉兼证参之，方知端的。如手足厥逆，兼之以腹痛腹满，泄利清白，小便亦清，口不渴，恶寒战栗，面如刀刮，皆寒证也。若腹痛后重，泄利稠粘，小便亦墙，渴而好饮，皆热证也。宜详审之。[116p]

It is said that the hands and feet are the extremities of the stomach and spleen. When there is heat in the spleen and stomach, the hands and feet will certainly be hot; when there is cold in the spleen and stomach, the hands and feet will certainly be cold—this is the common principle. However, in cases of a cold attack, there can be a deep cold and deep heat, or slight cold and slight heat. Why is this? It is said: If the stomach is cold, the hands and feet are cold; if the stomach is hot, the hands and feet are hot—this is the regular pattern of disease. However, extreme conditions can change things, so one should not be bound by ordinary reasoning. Excess leads to harm, and the response counters it. When fire energy is excessive, it can also involve water transformation, thus producing this phenomenon. Yin and yang alternate; the reversals of disease cannot be understood by regular theories. Phrases like "cold extremities," "cold limbs," or "hands and feet cold" are all expressions of variation and should not be analyzed lightly.

If we speak of the four limbs, there could be differences, and it cannot be solely attributed to a cold condition. If cold in the extremities reaches above the arms and below the knees, it is undoubtedly true cold, and one must urgently use warming medicines like ginger. If it is neglected for long, it becomes difficult to treat. This cold surpasses the elbows and knees; how could there be true cold within that extends to the limbs? However, one should also consider the pulse alongside the accompanying symptoms to avoid mistakes.

In examining cold attacks, one cannot simply conclude it is cold due to a reversal; one must correlate with pulse findings to understand the situation accurately. For instance, if the hands and feet feel reversed along with abdominal pain, fullness, diarrhea with clear discharge, and clear urination, while there is no thirst and the person feels chills and trembling with a pale face, these all indicate a cold condition. Conversely, if there is abdominal pain with heaviness, diarrhea that is thick and sticky, dark urination, and thirst with a desire to drink, these all indicate a heat condition. Careful scrutiny is required.[116p]

　　　　　自汗

　　手足乃诸阳之本，热聚于胃腑，则津液旁达于四肢也。蕴热则燥屎谵语，手足汗出者，大承气汤下之。挟水则水谷不分，手足汗出者，理中汤温之。是有承气、理中之不同也。
　　　　　拘急

　　拘急者，手足不能自如，屈伸不便，如蜷卧恶风之貌。四肢诸阳之本，因发汗亡阳，阳虚而有此证，自汗脉浮，小便数，心烦恶寒，足挛拳急，芍药甘草汤。太阳病，发汗后，遂漏不止，恶风，小便难，拘急者，桂枝加附子汤。吐利后，汗出发热，恶寒拘急，手足厥冷者，四逆汤温之也。[117p]

Self-Sweating

The hands and feet are the foundation of all yang. When heat accumulates in the stomach and intestines, the fluids spread to the four limbs. When heat is trapped, it causes dry stools and delirium; if sweating occurs in the hands and feet, one should administer Da Chengqi Decoction. If there is water retention, it indicates that the fluids are not properly separated, and again, if sweating occurs in the hands and feet, one should warm with Li Zhong Decoction. This illustrates the difference between Da Chengqi and Li Zhong.

Contraction and Rigidity

Contraction and rigidity refer to the hands and feet being unable to move freely, with difficulty in bending and stretching, resembling a curled position suffering from wind. The limbs are the foundation of all yang; sweating leads to the loss of yang, and when yang is deficient, these symptoms arise. There is self-sweating with a floating pulse, frequent urination, restlessness, aversion to cold, and the feet cramping and tightening; one should use Shao Yao Gan Cao Decoction. In cases of taiyang disease, after sweating, if there is a continuous leak, aversion to wind, and difficulty in urination alongside contraction and rigidity, one should use Gui Zhi Jia Fu Zi Decoction. After vomiting and diarrhea, if sweating leads to fever, aversion to cold, contraction and rigidity, and cold hands and feet, one should warm with Si Ni Decoction.[117p]

　　　　明医杂着 【明　王纶】

　　　　　腿中热痛

　　问：两脚自膝以下，或时内热，或骨中觉热，或有一点酸痛热者何？答曰：此血热也。但是风病，其血必热，惟其血热，故风寒之气一袭之，则外寒束内热而为痛。丹溪论痛风，谓血热得寒，污浊凝滞，所以作痛。遇夜痛甚，行于阴也；遇风雨阴寒痛甚，寒湿甚也。又风病必血燥，风木生火，故血热而燥。　　【注　临川陈先生云，医风先医血，血行风自灭。盖肝藏血而主风，又肝气为阳为火，肝血为阴为水，若肝火旺则肝血必虚。故凡风病，多因肝经风火为患，当推五脏相胜相生，以益其血。经云：肾藏精而主骨，故肾虚者则骨中热。或涌泉穴两胫两足内热，多患骨痿以致不起，属足三阴亏损之虚热耳。滋其化源，庶可保其生也。】[118p]

Ming Medicine Miscellany
Ming Dynasty - Wang Lun

Leg Heat and Pain
